DOC.HEAD: Sharp Criticism of China, Nicaragua, Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The embargo on this story, 10 a.m. EST Wednesday, has been broken.
DOC.TEXT: The annual human rights report of the State Department is particularly severe on China, Iraq and Nicaragua, according to a copies made available Tuesday. Among other abuses, the report also recounts floggings in Iran, amputations in Saudi Arabia and the forced marching of men through mine fields in Burma. The report must be submitted each year to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the House Foreign Affairs Committee. This year's covers 1989. ``The human rights climate in China deteriorated dramatically in 1989,'' the report noted, as troops fired on peaceful demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. ``At least several hundred, and possibly thousands'' were killed, and a ``drastic, country-wide crackdown'' on dissent is still in force. The report called Iraq's record ``abysmal,'' with ``freedoms of speech and press and of assembly and association ... virtually non-existent.'' ``Other important human rights problems include continuing disappearances and arbitrary detentions, lack of fair trial, widespread interference with privacy, excessive use of force against Kurdish civilians and an almost total lack of worker rights,'' the department said. In Nicaragua, which holds national elections on Sunday, the Sandinista government maintains ``an extensive and repressive internal security apparatus.'' Arbitrary killings are reliably reported both by government forces and the Contra resistance, the report said. Killings by government forces in central Nicaragua ``seem designed to cow the local population,'' it said. Both the government and Contra leadership prosecuted troops accused of murder, the report noted, and men on both sides were sentenced to prison. Among other points: _Human rights in territories occupied by Israel, where the Arab population is in the 27th month of a rebellion, are ``a source of deep concern.'' _The Soviet Union has adopted a ``more forthcoming approach'' to criticism and is improving its human rights record. Yet the liberalization of the country has seen a sharp increase in anti-Semitism not fostered by, and even embarrassing to, the government. _Widespread human rights abuses in east Germany ``were being changed at year's end,'' following the collapse of the hard-line Communist government.

DOC.HEAD: The Russians Are Broadcasting, The Russians Are Broadcasting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The anchorman doesn't look like Peter, Dan or Tom and doesn't use a TelePrompTer. He looks at the camera and says something in Russian. ``Welcome, comrades,'' says the translator's voice-over. ``Vremya,'' the Soviet evening news program, has come to U.S. public television. More than 100 Public Broadcasting Service stations from New York to Los Angeles are broadcasting ``Vremya'' in a two-week test begun Feb. 12 and coordinated by Boston's WGBH. ``Vremya'' _ it means ``time'' in Russian _ has telegenic anchors, Marina Burtseva and Kira Grigoryeva, but lacks the pinball graphics and slick, electronic packaging of U.S. network news. Grigoryeva sits in front of the logo, Burtseva before a shelf of casually toppled videotape cases. They read from their scripts. Glasnost is evident in its workmanlike Soviet's-eye view of the upheavals of Soviet society in transition, such as the ethnic riots by ``hooliganist thugs'' in Tadzhikistan and corruption in labor unions. ``It's like a broadcast you might have found in the 1960s,'' said Steven Weinstock, executive producer of ``The Eleventh Hour'' late news show on the New York City PBS station, WNET. His station broadcasts ``Vremya'' at 1:30 a.m. While technically primitive, ``Vremya'' is straightforward in presenting the news, he said. ``It lacks the entertainment values that have crept into U.S. news and it lacks the technical wizardry _ and it's refreshing.'' ``It also allows an American audience to see the most popular broadcast in the Soviet Union, to see what is driving Soviet public opinion, and get a good sense of what is going on,'' he said. It has been estimated that 150 million Soviet people watch the 9 p.m. Moscow edition of ``Vremya,'' which would make it the most popular TV broadcast in the world _ if only the Soviets had A.C. Nielsen Co. In the United States, nine of the nation's top 10 public TV stations are airing ``Vremya,'' said WGBH news director Alan Foster. The broadcasters are seeking underwriters for the show, which Foster estimates would cost $1 million a year. Other big-market stations participating include Los Angeles, New York City, San Francisco, Seattle, Denver, Chicago, Minneapolis, St. Louis, New Orleans, Dallas and Washington. ``There's not a lot in the Deep South and not much of the Southwest _ although Lubbock, Texas, and Las Cruces, N.M., are running it,'' Foster said. ``But otherwise the heartland of America has really taken to it, as has the big city.'' ``We're very excited about it,'' said Stella Giammasi, spokeswoman for WNET. She said WNET got the show on short notice and could schedule it for only 1:30 a.m. If the experiment succeeds, WNET could put ``Vremya'' in prime time. Boston viewers see the show at 4:30 p.m., and Chicago viewers watch it at 10:30 p.m. It even penetrated commercial TV when the Philadelphia PBS station opted not to use it and WTGI, an ``international format'' UHF station, grabbed it instead. WGBH, which solicits viewer mail at the end of the half-hour broadcast, by Friday had more than 100 letters from enthusiastic viewers, Foster said, ``and there's not a single one ... that says this is Communist propaganda.'' Turning ``Vremya'' into U.S. TV fare makes for a fast day at International Video Broadcasts, the Virginia-based company that captures the early ``Vremya'' from a Soviet satellite each day at 4:30 a.m. EST. The signal is altered to U.S. broadcast standards and two IVB translators _ Soviet emigres trained at top-rated Soviet language institutes _ translate the videotape. ``We have from 7:30 a.m. to 1:15 p.m. to get it all translated, edited and dubbed,'' said Dick Kuiper, who is in charge of the production. He recalled one day last week when they finished with just a minute to spare. Television has been Mikhail Gorbachev's ally in perestroika, the restructuring of Soviet society, Kuiper said. ``I think he specifically chose that medium as a powerful tool to get his message to society, past all the editors and middle managers,'' he said. The ``Vremya'' experiment already is a qualified success, Foster said. ``I think it will be a success even if it proves that the show may be a good product without a market,'' he added. So far, he said, there's been no word from the underwriters _ corporations and foundations that ultimately would bear most of the program's cost _ but WGBH is moving to extend the ``Vremya'' test for two more weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Lure Youth Vote With Sex, Not Marx
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Ajax Delgado snaps his fingers and plops his sneaker-clad feet on the table. The laces are electric green. ``Music!'' he exclaims. ``The campaign needed young music!'' On the wall hangs a glossy poster showing two pairs of naked thighs pressed together, jeans and a rose crumpled on the floor. ``It's beautiful the first time when you do it with love,'' reads the coy slogan. Personally, Delgado doesn't like the poster. ``The guy's legs are too skinny,'' he says, dismissing it with another snap of his fingers. Who is this fast-talking fellow in the black T-shirt and the tight jeans eating whipped cream cheese with his fingers? A hip advertising executive? A rising record producer? Not quite. Delgado, 28, is secretary-general of the Sandinista Youth, part of the leftist party that has ruled Nicaragua for more than a decade. He is one of the keys to President Daniel Ortega's effort to beat the United National Opposition, led by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Clearly, things have changed since the days when the Sandinista Youth motto was a dreary Marxist ``Study, Defend, Produce.'' The motto is now ``Plug into the Future,'' and the sell is pure sex. The youth vote will be a critical factor in Sunday's general election. A third of the 1.7 million registered voters are between the ages of 16 and 25. Delgado is a mastermind of the campaign aimed at selling the Sandinistas as the fun party, the party of the future, the hip place to be. It's a tall job in a country left shabby and tattered by war, a U.S. embargo and a devastating economic crisis. But Delgado is convinced the Sandinistas have the youth vote wrapped up. Membership in the Sandinista Youth, open to people between the ages of 15 and 30, has doubled to 50,000 in the past two months, he says. Delgado laughs off the idea that the Sandinistas have shamelessly adopted one of the crasser advertising concepts of their capitalist nemesis: sex sells. ``It's a Sandinista invention,'' he jokes. The poster with the naked legs and the double-entendre message for first-time voters is just one of a series of posters featuring amorous couples in the youth-oriented campaign. The group has also sponsored beauty contests _ ``The feminists were critical,'' Delgado admits _ kissing contests, dances, parties and even a Valentine's Day rally at which a member of the nine-man Sandinista directorate got married in the ``Forest of Love.'' Sandinista campaign headquarters bustles with young workers in brightly colored T-shirts bearing pictures of President Ortega and other candidates. Young people wear Sandinista headbands, Sandinista tank tops and Sandinista baseball caps. They light up with Sandinista lighters, tote their books in Sandinista backpacks and tap their toes to Sandinista tunes in Costeno-style, the reggae music from Nicaragua's Atlantic Coast. The slick campaign is no hit-or-miss affair. Delgado says the Sandinista Youth prepared by polling young people on their likes and dislikes, their worries and hopes. The poll even identified the colors they found most appealing, Delgado says, flourishing an armful of T-shirts in sky blue, brilliant green, black and gray to demonstrate his point. ``Fluorescent colors!'' he exclaims. ``They love fluorescent colors, too.'' The study showed that Nicaraguan teen-agers are a lot like teen-agers everywhere in many ways. They are vain and rebellious; they are interested in sex and having fun; their heroes and role models are athletes and musicians. Their concerns, however, reflect the troubled reality of this politically divided and economically crippled nation of 3.5 million: the war, the draft, finding a job, getting a decent education and figuring out how to have a good time in a country where the inflation rate was 1,700 percent last year. The Sandinista message doesn't dwell on this dreary daily reality. ``Everything will be better,'' the main campaign slogan proclaims. The Sandinistas have been in power since the 1979 revolution that toppled the Somoza family dictatorship. The 16-year-olds who will be first-time voters Sunday were only five when the Sandinistas marched triumphantly into Managua. Ortega, 44, is the only president they have known. Without reliable polls, it is impossible to tell if Nicaragua's young people are buying the party's pitch the way their North America contemporaries buy the latest sneakers, jeans or recordings. ``Everybody in the neighborhood belongs to the Sandinista Youth,'' said high school student Marta Lorena Mendoza, 18, when asked why she belonged. But it is clear the Sandinista effort to lure the youth vote has far outstripped that of its main challenger, the United National Opposition. Mrs. Chamorro, UNO's presidential candidate, is a white-haired and aristocratic widow of 60 whose image contrasts sharply with that of Ortega. There were rumors her campaign would bring in Gloria Estefan and the Miami Sound Machine, but it didn't happen. Before some of her rallies, young women danced to a tropical beat, but it could not equal the Sandinista brio, and that's not what UNO is selling anyway. A 21-year-old who said he was proud that he served in the Sandinista army also said he was going to vote for UNO. ``It's time for a change,'' he said. Meanwhile, Ortega has shed his customary fatigues and his deadly serious, often strident manner for the trappings of celebrity. He stumps the country in flashy sports shirts, tossing baseballs, dancing with constituents, and jogging in foot races. ``Daniel. President of the Young,'' proclaim the posters and billboards. ``Daniel is Love.''

DOC.HEAD: Shop America, Iowa Cattlemen Seeks Bright Futures in Japan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The tall men in cowboy boots and Western hats stalking shoppers in a Tokyo meat market were Iowa cattlemen looking for hints on how to remodel their herds to suit Japanese tastes. Across town, a firm called Shop America Ltd. will soon allow Japanese to order everything from music to appliances from warehouses in New Jersey. Difficult though it may be for foreigners to break into the Japanese market, Americans see themselves selling tens of millions of dollars in goods on the strength of bright ideas, quality products, low prices, thorough preparation and government backing _ like the Japanese have done for years. Like Japan, the United States is trying for an economic boost through exports, and the yen-rich Japanese consumer is the prime target. ``This is a huge market, the second-biggest economy in the world,'' U.S. Ambassador Michael Armacost said in an interview. ``This is an economy where any company in any field that wants to be world-class has got to have a foothold.'' Many U.S. companies are ``doing very well'' in Japan, Armacost said, but too many still find barriers in local regulations and business practices that make it difficult to whittle away at the United States' $50 billion trade deficit with Tokyo. On Thursday, U.S. and Japanese trade negotiators resume talks that aim to change the deep-rooted factors in both nations' economies that contribute to the U.S. trade deficit. These include Japan's high savings rate and lower consumption, high land prices, complicated distribution system and corporate linkups that tend to leave outsiders in the cold. At issue on the U.S. side are low savings rates and higher consumption, low investment, the budget deficit and quality of the work force. The U.S. goal is hoping for more openings to things like Shop America and U.S. beef. Those pounding at the door include the U.S. retailer Toys `R' Us, which wants to open big stores in Japan but is faced with regulations permitting small shops to veto large stores nearby. Solomon Mester, chairman of New York-based Shop America, exults in the creation of an atmosphere in Japan encouraging sales of U.S. goods. ``They know they have to import more from the United States,'' Mester said. ``They know a backlash is building up, and they have to level the field.'' President Vernon Fraenkel set up Shop America with the idea of getting the Japanese into the U.S. habit of mail-order shopping. It took more than a year to put together, he said, and a big problem was finding the right Japanese partner. One prospect wanted to stock goods in Japan, but with high land prices it would have been too expensive. Then 7-11 Japan Co. Ltd., which has 4,000 convenience stores, came into the picture in August. It speedily completed a deal in December and expects to open for business nationwide in July. ``We had a conservative plan to roll it out. Suddenly we've got a monster with 4,000 heads,'' The parent company of 7-11 Japan, Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd, is one of the world's biggest retailers with $12 billion in sales last fiscal year. ``There are whole teams of people working here on this project,'' Mester said in an interview at Ito-Yokado headquarters. Shop America will put a computer terminal in each of 7-11's stores. Customers use a catalog to order small appliances, recorded music, perfume, sporting goods, watches, housewares, jewelry and other items. The bar-coded order flashes over a computer network to warehouses in New Jersey, and the goods are sent to Japan by mail or express delivery. ``Instead of changing their distribution setup, we're jumping over it,'' Mester said. Fraenkel and Mester said they set a goal of $20 million in sales the first year, but 7-11 Japan predicts $70 million. The Shop America executives disbelieve the old saw that the Japanese won't buy American goods even if they're cheaper. U.S. beef is finding ready buyers here at prices sometimes 50 percent below the cost of Japanese beef. Under pressure from Washington, Japan agreed in 1988 to increase its quota on beef imports gradually until 1991, when the import limits will be abolished. Tariffs will be in place until 1994. ``If we don't attempt to satisfy this market, other parts of the world will satisfy it,'' said Marshall King, chairman of the Iowa Cattlemen's Association. King, of Boone, Iowa, was one of four Iowa cattlemen and a meat scientist from Iowa State University who were exploring Japanese tastes. Jim Bradford of Guthrie Center, Iowa, vice chairman of the Iowa Beef Industry Council, said the information would help cattle breeders plan the right kind of steer for Japan, a five-year process. The Iowans visited a five-story Seiyu supermarket where posters with Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad's photo beckoned shoppers to try ``Iowa Quality Beef.''

DOC.HEAD: Utah Teachers Told to Prepare for Strike
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 16,000 Utah teachers were told Monday to prepare for a strike in a dispute with state legislators centering on salary increases and better benefits. Thousands of teachers spent their Presidents Day holiday Monday at a rally in the Utah Capitol sponsored by the Utah Education Association. ``We are still negotiating,'' association President Jim Campbell said after a three-hour, closed-door meeting Monday night with members of his board. ``We are still having teachers stay on a strike alert but we will not call a strike tomorrow morning.'' Teachers were told by officials of the union to report as usual to classrooms Tuesday. Campbell would not comment further. State lawmakers, following recommendations in Republican Gov. Norm Bangerter's $1.1 billion education budget, pumped $12 million into textbooks and offered to enable local school districts to impose higher property taxes to help relieve classroom overcrowding. They also promised to dedicate the lion's share of a $150 million 1989-90 budget surplus to education, but remained steadfast in offering educators only a 6 percent salary increase, the same as other public employees, and balked at dipping into Utah's $48 million ``rainy day'' fund or repealing a tax cut imposed last September. The nearly 16,000 members of the education association voted 3-to-1 Friday to reject the proposed raise. They also authorized the education association's 16-member board to call a strike if their demands are not met by the time the Republican-controlled Legislature adjourns its regular session at midnight Wednesday. Teachers want the Legislature to increase the amount it appropriates for education, but have not demanded a specific amount. Utah House Speaker Nolan Karras, who has been involved in negotiations, spoke briefly with Campbell on Monday and said House Republicans will consider the situation in caucus Tuesday morning. A strike could affect up to 420,000 students and Utah's 20,000 teachers. Teachers point to their average salary of about $25,000, which ranks 41st in the nation. They contend Utah has the largest class sizes in the country and spends the least per student. The education association called a statewide, one-day strike in September after the Legislature approved a $35 million tax cut but no new money for education.

DOC.HEAD: Yuppie Pool Hall: Beer Nuts Out, Gazpacho In
DOC.TEXT: This can't really be the old-fashioned neighborhood pool hall that mothers warned their sons to stay out of. There, at the bottom of the menu, is the polite admonition: ``Shootz Cafe is a smoke-free environment. Thank you for not smoking.'' Minnesota Fats could shed a few pounds at the Shootz, a yuppie bistro and billiards lounge where the customers chalk their cues over California wine spritzers, or chow down on gazpacho and a heaping antipasto of imported cheeses, prosciutto, sun-dried tomatoes and artichoke hearts. ``This is a clean, upscale billiards hall _ no smoke, no drunks,'' says co-owner Ric Adamcik. ``It's where mothers can tell their sons and daughters to go and have a good time. In fact, you can bring your mother along.'' A former Army brat, Adamcik remembers sneaking into pool halls outside the gates of military bases for a forbidden peek at the pine-paneled, male-only world where players sucked on longneck Buds and jostled with hustlers and bookies over the seductive click and thump of billiard balls on green baize. It was the kind of place where a guy could scratch, spit and talk dirty all night long, without a nagging whine from the missus. ``I remember that I didn't want to play in a place that smelled like that,'' Adamcik said. ``It stank of stale beer and cigarettes. It was so smoky it made my eyes burn. It was full of guys with packs of Camels rolled up their sleeves and `Momma' tattoos on their arms.'' The cue racks at the Shootz Cafe hang on raspberry walls. The high-tech stereo system blasts New Wave music. Earnest young professionals in starched button-downs, power ties and wide suspenders bend over 14 top-of-the-line Brunswick tables of oak and brass. For that ``homey feel,'' Adamcik says, players awaiting their turn can relax on leather sofas around a roaring fireplace. Billiards industry officials say the old-time pool halls are dying out. They have fallen victim to soaring rents, local anti-vice ordinances and state-run lotteries that have lured customers away from poolrooms that frequently served as fronts for illicit gambling enterprises. More important, the growing affluence of Americans has produced a dramatic change in the way they spend their leisure time, says Mark Cord, executive vice president of the Billiard Congress of America, the industry's trade association. ``People don't want to spend the evening alone in a dingy place where there's a lot of drinking and gambling,'' Cord said. ``Families are staying home or going out and doing things together. Smart business owners are making money by appealing to the family trade at a respectable place.'' Cord says an estimated 35 million Americans are playing billiards regularly, a 430 percent boost since the mid-1950s. That makes it the second most popular family sports activity in the United States after bowling, he says. The yuppie elegance of the Shootz Cafe is applauded by such billiards greats as Willie Mosconi and Minnesota Fats, who fondly remember the fabulous era of chandeliered salons in New York, Chicago, Detroit and other cities in the 1920s, before poolrooms turned into gambling dens during the Great Depression. Mosconi, 76, who lives quietly in suburban Philadelphia, won 15 world billiards titles before he retired from tournament play nine years ago. Minnesota Fats, whose real name is Rudolph Wanderone and was portrayed in the movie, ``The Hustler,'' by the late Jackie Gleason, is over 90, still fat and still shooting pool. ``I can beat anybody on Earth,'' Wanderone said in a telephone interview from the Nashville, Tenn., hotel where he lives. Tipping the scales at 200 pounds, Wanderone says his appetite knows no bound, not even gazpacho and artichoke hearts. ``I'm not a picky eater,'' he said. ``I'll eat anything that don't bite me first.''

DOC.HEAD: Government to Politburo: No More Plush Palaces
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new perestroika-without-perks policy is opening up a harsh new world for Politburo members, who now will have to do without their plush country homes, or dachas. The government has decided that the country's current and former leaders _ except Gorbachev and Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov _ are no longer entitled to privileges such as the dachas, and they've been ordered to move out. Valery A. Sidorov, an aide to the chairman of the Soviet legislature's Commission on Privileges, told The Associated Press Monday that the dachas have become a ``mass insult'' and their occupants will just have to get used to a ``normal lifestyle.'' Where once the Soviet high and mighty played and sipped vodka, children will roam. Sidorov said the country homes are being turned over to the Soviet Health Ministry for use as rest homes and kindergartens. As if losing the dachas wasn't enough of a blow, retired members of the Communist Party's long-ruling Politburo will also have to do without the three household workers and black Volga cars the government has been providing them virtually free of charge, Sidorov said. They also will lose the right to order food from special government stocks. The changes are part of a general attack on the perks of the Soviet elite that, under public pressure, Gorbachev reluctantly agreed to endorse only last year. In a country where shortages of housing, food and consumer goods are a major source of discontent, the network of special stores, private airports, sleek black limousines, fancy homes and high-quality medical care for the government and party elite have generated massive public fury. Maverick Communist Boris N. Yeltsin built an entire parliamentary election campaign on the issue last year, and became wildly popular because of it. More radical anti-perks movements have swept through Eastern European countries like East Germany and Bulgaria, where ousted Communist leaders face prosecution for abuses of power that included extravagent living. In the Soviet Union, regional Communist bosses have recently lost jobs after being caught amassing luxury goods not available to the masses. Most of the Soviet leadership's dachas _ some are believed to feature tennis courts and private swimming pools and fountains _ are on the outskirts of Moscow and shrouded in secrecy. They are surrounded by fences and guards and traffic police stop anyone venturing close to the secluded ``dacha rows.'' In a reflection of the secrecy, Sidorov said in a telephone interview he did not know how many dachas are affected, and he declined to provide a complete list of who would have to move out. He said, however, that his boss, privileges commission chairman Yevgeny M. Primakov, and Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev are the only people on the current 19-person Politburo who do not have government dachas. Primakov's record, however, is not untarnished. A newspaper reported Saturday that a special plane arranged for him at one of Moscow's VIPs-only airports held up dozens of other flights at other airports so the sky could be kept clear for security. Several former Politburo members _ many of them in their 90s _ are believed to live in fancy dachas, including holdovers from the Leonid I. Brezhnev era such as Geidar Aliev, Boris Ponomarev and Peter Shelest. Sidorov said many of the former Politburo members, especially Ponomarev, are not giving up their perks without a fight. He said Ponomarev had sent a protest letter to the Commission on Privileges. No deadline for the evictions was set, Sidorov said. Former residents of the dachas will be offered comparatively meager luxuries in return for moving out. They will be allowed to rent _ at their own expense _ country homes run by government agencies for a few days a month as well as a government car from a fleet for up to 20 hours a month, Sidorov said. If they want their own dachas, he said, they will have to build them themselves.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush said the listlessness of her dog Millie is due more to jealousy than illness. ``George is convinced she's sick, but it really is because she's jealous of her son,'' a big, bounding dog who belongs to one of Bush's sons and frequently visits the White House, Mrs. Bush said Monday during a visit to the village center 1{ miles from the Bush family compound. ``It's more in the mind than the body,'' she said as local children petted the dog. Later, Mrs. Bush chatted with reporters aboard Air Force One on the trip back to Washington. On the president's suggestion the day before that he might invite Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to their Maine home, Mrs. Bush said that Bush had not told her about it. But, she added, `You know me. Anybody he asks _ I'll be nice to.''

Voters just couldn't say no to Shintaro Ishihara, whose nationalist views expressed in the book ``The Japan That Can Say No'' have created a stir in the United States. The flambouyant and outspoken Ishihara, 57, was elected for the seventh time to represent his metropolitan Tokyo district in the lower house of Parliament. He was backed by the governing Liberal Democratic Party. Ishihara's 32-year-old son, Nobuteru, also won a lower house seat in Sunday's elections. The Ishiharas are the first father-and-son team to win seats in the powerful chamber in the same election, Japan's Kyodo News Service reported. In the book he co-authored with Akio Morita, chairman of Sony Corp., the elder Ishihara wrote that Japan has been too passive in its relations with the United States and argued that Tokyo must stand up and say no to unrealistic U.S. demands on military and trade issues. The book, a best seller in Japan, also accuses Americans of racial arrogance, which Ishihara says has created an inferiority complex among the Japanese, making them too willing to give in to Washington.

Britain's Prince Charles put down his polo mallet for a film role as he continued his efforts for wildlife conservation during a visit to Florida. Charles made an animal conservation film for the British Broadcasting Corp. during a three-hour visit Monday to the Kennedy Space Center. Filming took place at a national wildlife refuge, part of the 88,000-acre space center and home to eagles and hundreds of other bird species, alligators, wild pigs, deer and other wildlife. Forrest McCartney, space center director, also escorted Charles on a tour of the shuttle launch control center and an assembly building. The group saw from a distance the launch pad where the shuttle Atlantis is being readied for liftoff Thursday. During the three days preceding his visit to the cape, the heir to the British throne was in Vero Beach, where he participated in two polo matches to benefit a wildlife protection organization. Charles is scheduled to attend a conference on international business beginning today in Charleston, S.C., and to travel to Washington later this week to meet with President Bush and British Embassy officials.

Jamie Berzas, a Grammy nominee for best traditional folk recording, also is a full-time mechanic in the heart of central Louisiana's Cajun prairie land. Jamie Berzas and Cajun Tradition, a band formed 11 years ago, were nominated for their 1988 release, A La Veille Facon (In the Old Fashioned Way). Berzas said the nomination holds special significance for part-time musicians. ``It probably means a once-in-a-lifetime shot at it. It will probably be one of the biggest events in our lives,'' said Berzas, the lead singer and accordion player. Berzas works 10-hour days at Berzas' Auto Service in the shadow of the water tower in Mamou, a town of 3,000. Madeline Berzas, Jamie's wife and the band's drummer, and Mark Young, the lead guitarist and the band's co-founder, also work at the repair shop. The community of Mamou has rallied with bake sales and benefits for its honorees to help them pay for the trip to Los Angeles on Tuesday. The Grammys will be awarded Wednesday. ``We weren't nominated just for our work. We think we were nominated because of our part in trying to keep the tradition,'' Berzas said. ``When this album was nominated, all of traditional Cajun music was nominated in our eyes.''

DOC.HEAD: Natural Risks Said to Outweigh Man-Made Dangers in Food
DOC.TEXT: Nature's own cancer-causing chemicals that are an unavoidable part of everything from pot roast to peanuts represent a greater health danger than pesticides and other pollutants, a health official warns. A new estimate by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration concludes that more than 98 percent of the cancer risk in the diet results from ordinary foods _ not from additives, poisons or other man-made contributions to the food chain. ``The risk is from natural carcinogens in the diet because they overwhelm all the others,'' said Dr. Robert J. Scheuplein, director of the Office of Toxicological Sciences at the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. This does not mean that all food is dangerous or even that people can do much about the hazard. Instead, Scheuplein's analysis was intended to focus attention away from what he sees as a largely bogus health issue _ the hazards of chemical contamination. Dr. Frank Young, a former FDA commissioner who now is deputy assistant secretary of health and human services, agreed. ``The headline should not be, `All Foods Cause Cancer' or `Drop Dead. Don't Eat,''' Young said. ``The good news is, let us not as a nation focus just on the technological food additives. We ought to focus on the big issues as well.'' Instead of worrying about the vanishingly small risk of Alar in apples or dioxin in milk, Scheuplein said food scientists should be exploring ways to remove the important toxins in ordinary foods. ``Even a modestly effective attempt to lessen the dietary risk of natural carcinogens would probably be enormously more useful to human health than regulatory efforts devoted to eliminating traces of pesticide residues or other specific trace-level chemicals,'' Scheuplein said. He presented his findings Monday at a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Scheuplein based his conclusions on a statistical analysis of the quantity of cancer-causing toxins found in various parts of the diet. He said that the risk of dying from cancer from dietary exposure to all kinds of carcinogens, or cancer-inducing substances, was 7.7 percent. The risk from traditional foods alone was 7.6 percent. ``Most of the risks are people's personal choices,'' Scheuplein said. ``They are not imposed on people by corporations. Apparently that's a hard lesson. People want to blame somebody.'' The clearest cancer-causing agent in ordinary food, he said, is fat, which has been linked with several kinds of tumors. However, most foods now eaten would not pass safety tests required for new food chemicals and additives. He estimated that carcinogens make up one-tenth of 1 percent of the food people eat. Among concerns he cited were: _Well-cooked, high-protein foods, such as meat and eggs, contain bacterial substances that can cause genetic mutations. An ordinary day's protein can be as damaging to the genes as five cigarettes. _Hazardous urethane is a natural product of fermentation. It is present in beer, yogurt, bread and other foods. _Mycotoxins produced by molds are common in many foods, especially when stored in warm, humid conditions. Aflatoxins occur in corn and peanuts, zearalenone in soybeans and luteoskyrin in yellow rice. _Smoked or salted fish and pickled vegetables may cause digestive cancers. This is attributed to nitrates and funguses. _Grilling and charring fish or meat can produce potentially hazardous substances, such as nitropyrenes. _Many spices contain questionable substances. There is estragole in tarragon, eugenal in cloves, cinnamaldehyde in cinnamon, myristicin in nutmeg and anethole in fennel. Several spices, including oregano, majoram and bay leaves, may cause genetic damage. _Other naturally occurring carcinogens include d-limonene in oranges, psoralens in celery, hydrazines in mushroons and nitrates in spinach.

DOC.HEAD: Some Farmers Overpaid Through Drought Aid Program
DOC.TEXT: At least 80 farming operations were paid more than the limit of $100,000 set by Congress under 1988 drought aid legislation, according to Agriculture Department records. The payment list of top recipients under the Disaster Assistance Act of 1988 was compiled by the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service. Congress provided $3.9 billion in aid, mostly to help with crop losses suffered in the 1988 drought. As of Dec. 31, payments of more than $3.88 billion had been made to 805,152 recipients. Agency officials said the list of top payments was sent to the Office of Management and Budget, which has been reviewing large payments to farmers under various commodity and emergency programs. A copy was made available to The Associated Press. ``We're asking for our money back, if we've overpaid anybody,'' said Daniel F. Shaw, ASCS deputy administrator for state and county operations. ``The computers are set to flag anybody that goes over the $100,000 limit, even by a dollar.'' Agency rules are flexible when it comes to some kinds of farm operations, however, including joint ventures and family partnerships. Shaw was asked about the biggest payment on the 1988 list, $380,092 to the Bureau of Indian Affairs in Minnesota. ``They're a joint venture, so they didn't go over the $100,000 limit,'' he said. ``That's for an Indian tribe, and an Indian tribe is a joint venture, so every Indian in that tribe is entitled to the $100,000 limit. It's almost impossible for an Indian tribe to violate.'' Another leeway is provided in a family partnership, which ``could be made up of four people in a family,'' Shaw said. ``Each one is eligible for $100,000.'' But the ASCS computer operation in Kansas City, Mo., tracks other possible violations, including identical or similar addresses, particularly if used by different individuals. ``Single names bother me,'' Shaw said. ``They should come up flagged, and we'll be asking for our money back if there's a violation.'' If all other conditions are met properly, the agency is likely to ask only for the amount in excess of the $100,000 limit. In some cases, however, the farmer might have to return the entire amount. Not all blame can be put on the farmer if a payment is out of line. Agency officials admit mistakes are made in administering the program and some overpayments can be the result of USDA errors. But that's one reason for checking out the payments. The agency stepped up its review of drought payments after a series of Associated Press stories in December showed widespread misapplication of funds in the $3.9 billion 1988 relief program. Last month the ASCS said it was checking specific misdeeds spotted by the AP in its seven-month study of drought payments in 22 counties in eight states. The issue of large subsidies to farmers under the USDA's annual commodity programs and the drought payments is part of a developing controversy in Congress over federal crop insurance and disaster payments. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says it's too expensive to have both and Congress will have to choose between an overhaul of federal crop insurance or abandoning it in favor of permanent disaster aid. Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, who defends the drought aid program because of its emergency nature, said last week that the Bush administration is ``forcing our hand'' into enacting reforms. About half of the top 80 payment recipients exceeded the $100,000 limit by less than $100 each, according to the list provided to the AP. Overall, the 80 recipients were concentrated in Montana, 15; Michigan, 9; South Dakota, 9; Illinois, 8; Texas, 6; and Wisconsin, 6. In addition to those getting more than $100,000 in payments, the list included more than 600 others who received exactly $100,000 under the 1988 drought program.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Contras Try to Persuade Former Comrades-in-Arms to Demobilize
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: People may not recognize the faces, but the names of the two former Contras are part of the mythology of the mountains. ``Which one is Dumas?'' a woman asks in the bustle of Sunday market. ``Which one is Rigoberto?'' This is Contra country. Many families have collaborated with the U.S.-backed rebel force, losing sons, husbands, brothers, sweethearts to Nicaragua's fratricidal war. Rigoberto (Tirzo Moreno), Dumas (Cesar Chavarria), Fernando (Diogenes Hernandez) and Licenciado (Victor Sanchez) led those men into battle until they were ousted from the Contras in May 1988. Now they are back, trying to persuade rebel fighters to lay down their arms, helping the leftist Sandinista government make its case for demobilization, arguing that next Sunday's elections mean there is no longer any need for the Contras to fight. Chontales province is a rugged cattle region and these wary men and women of Los Chinamos in their boots and cowboy hats and spurs are a tough audience. The pouring rain turns into a drizzle. The road melts into a slippery ribbon of red mud. Still, people gather when the former comandantes climb onto the back of a truck in the middle of town. Some residents are confounded by the sight of the former Contras swooping in aboard a Sandinista air force helicopter, then standing side by side with government soldiers. ``Why aren't they in Honduras?'' one man mutters as he moves under an eave to escape the chilly, mistlike rain. ``How did they get here?'' Rigoberto, Fernando, Licenciado and Dumas have been living in the United States since being forced out in one of the more notorious internal battles that have bedeviled the Contras. They were deported from Honduras, where the rebels are based, after telling the CIA they believed then-chief of staff Enrique Bermudez was corrupt, and demanding a change. The next thing they knew, they were on a plane to Miami. All four deny any Sandinista government role in their return to Nicaragua. They say they came back on the eve of general elections because they believe Nicaragua is finally moving toward democracy. In the government's eagerness to see the Contras disbanded, the Sandinistas advanced the elections nine months and opened the political process. Most of the opposition has united behind publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's challenge to President Daniel Ortega in Sunday's elections. Despite the new political openness, however, few Contra fighters have come down from the mountains. The only active-duty comandante to lay down his arms, Luis Adan Fley, says the four are letting themselves be used by the Sandinistas. Fley has returned for the elections, but refuses to have anything to do with his former comrades. The Sandinista expedition included Santiago Murey and Franco Vicente of the United Nations-Organization of American States commission to demobilize the Contras. The trip to Los Chinamos, 100 miles east of Managua, is their first foray into the countryside. ``Trial by fire,'' Murey says, as he climbs onto the truck bed. He and Vicente tell the crowd that Contras who demobilize will not face sanctions or harassment. Standing in drenched shirts, they invite questions. No one speaks up. Then Rigoberto steps forward, ignoring a loudspeaker as he looks down on a sea of impassive peasant faces. ``We're here so young men won't keep dying in this land of lakes and volcanos,'' he says. ``The time has come to put an end to this war.'' He insists that the elections represent real change, a big step on the road to democracy, on the road to the cause for which they fought so long. ``There is no justification for staying in the mountains,'' Rigoberto says. A man steps forward and asks what the four former comandantes can do to end the war since they no longer have contact with the Contras. ``We're going to make contact here,'' Rigoberto replies. ``They should negotiate their own fate, their own life, without an intermediary.'' Later, they work the crowd like politicians, grabbing arms, shaking hands, slapping backs, threading their way among mules laden with cheeses. Rigoberto and his companions then clamber up a steep, muddy hillside. They set up a radio, stringing an antenna to the tallest tree. They roam the frequencies, calling out to former comrades in arms as 10 Sandinista soldiers look on. Rigoberto makes contact. ``We're not here to surrender anyone,'' he says. ``We were in the mountains for seven years. We're here looking for a solution.' The radio crackles back. ``I know you, Rigoberto,'' a voice says. A wave of static washes out his next words, then the voice comes through loud and clear. ``We don't want anyone here who sells out his homeland. We want men here with convictions and guts, you dogs.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Turn to Videotape in Store Bomb Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with copycat bomb threats, hospital evacuated; picks up 5th graf, `The videotape ...'
DOC.TEXT:
Authorities hunting for clues in two grocery store bombings said Monday they hoped for help from a security-camera videotape of people entering and leaving one of the stores. ``We have no leads at all,'' said Police Chief Jerry King. ``At this point we have no motive.'' The Saturday bombings spurred copycat bomb threats Monday, including one that prompted the evacuation of North Fulton Regional Hospital in Roswell around 9:35 p.m., said police dispatcher Charles Tyson. No bombs had been found by late in the evening. The bombs at a Kroger and a Cub Foods store in this wealthy suburb about 20 miles north of Atlanta misfired. No one was injured and only minor damage was done. Both stores had been warned about the bombs by an anonymous caller. The Kroger store was evacuated, but about 100 shoppers in the Cub Foods store ignored the warning and were shopping when the bomb detonated. The videotape was made at the Kroger store as a matter of routine because a bank is inside the store, King said. He said investigators would review the tape for any suspicious-looking people. The two bombs were basically identical, King said. ``It was not a pipe bomb. It wasn't anything that sophisticated,'' he said. The detonators fired, but did not trigger large explosions, FBI spokesman Pat Johnson said. FBI and federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agents met Monday with police to discuss the case. ATF spokesman Tom Stokes said officials could release no further information. Stokes said Sunday the devices apparently were not built by whoever made powerful bombs that killed a federal judge in Alabama and a lawyer in Georgia in December. Investigators have found absolutely no connection between the grocery bombings and the nail-filled mail bombs that killed Judge Robert Vance of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Mountain Brook, Ala., and attorney Robert Robinson of Savannah, Ga., Stokes said.
But Fulton County Youth Investigator Steve Rose said federal investigators would receive information on a 16-year-old Sandy Springs youth who purchased materials to make a bomb three days before the explosions. ``We'll pass what we have along to them and let them decide what they want to do about it,'' he said. Police said they have no evidence that would indicate that the youth was connected to Saturday's bombs. Rose said a sales clerk at C and C Hardware Co. told police the teen-ager purchased copper pipe, end caps and two boxes of kitchen matches Wednesday at the store. The youth also asked the sales clerk where he could buy aluminum pipe and wood alcohol and said he planned to make a bomb, Rose said. Rose said the sales clerk got the license number of the car the boy was driving and gave it to police.

DOC.HEAD: Mirella Freni Sings Manon Lescaut
DOC.TEXT: Usually, it's a little difficult to feel sympathetic with Manon in the second act of ``Manon Lescaut.'' After leaving her student lover, she lives luxuriously in Paris with the elderly Geronte. Even when Geronte finds out he's been two-timed and sends for the police, she delays flight to gather up her jewels. But Mirella Freni sang Manon with such depth of emotion, such phrasing and nuance, such exquisitely held notes, that one melts before her singing Puccini's beautiful melodies about true love. The Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, conducted by Nello Santi, sounded wonderful in the first ``Manon Lescaut'' of the season. The opera was last heard at the Met in the 1986-87 season. This production is by Desmond Heeley. Tenor Peter Dvorsky of Czechoslovakia sang the young lover, Des Grieux. In Act 1, he was without subtlety, blaring from soft to loud. Later, Dvorsky sounded much better. His tone didn't become magnificent but it became more of one piece. J. Patrick Raftery _ who has sung at the Paris Opera and Lyric Opera of Chicago, among other places _ was making his Met debut as Manon's brother. He wasn't projecting in Act 1 and he also was better later in the opera. His is the kind of baritone voice that remains focused, never spreading all over the tones. Act 1 in general looked and sounded underrehearsed. Italo Tajo was very good as the elderly Geronte. In Act 1, though he sounded appropriately aged, his singing came through the best of the male principals.

DOC.HEAD: Late Reggae Star's Brother Killed In Police Shootout
DOC.TEXT: A shotgun-waving young man who was killed by police after he stalked through a shopping mall was identified Monday as a brother of late reggae music star Bob Marley. Police said they hadn't been able to explain the actions of Anthony Booker, 19. ``The investigation's still going on. We don't have many details,'' said Metro-Dade Police Lt. Glen Kay. Police were called to busy Cutler Ridge Mall around 3:30 p.m. Sunday after customers saw a tall, thin young man dressed in white and carrying a pistol-gripped .12-gauge shotgun. The man was railing incoherently and mumbling to himself, witnesses told police. ``He was really mad. He was looking for someone,'' said shopper Carol Williams, who said she was shopping with her two small children when Booker pointed the shotgun at her, then continued on his way. ``He was saying: `I'm gonna get you. I'm gonna get you,''' she said. Shoppers scattered as the gunman walked through the mall until police arrived. As an off-duty Miami police officer chased him, a police helicopter hovered overhead and Metro-Dade police moved in, the gunman ran through the mall parking lot, police said. He fired at least once. Officers returned fire, killing him, police said. Booker's mother, Cedella Booker, said she didn't know what caused her son to go to the mall with a gun. ``He is just a ... humble young man. When I saw him yesterday, he didn't look like my son,'' she said. Friends and relatives said he had seemed upset since returning last week from a trip to his homeland of Jamaica. They said he hadn't been in trouble before and aspired to be a musician. Bob Marley, who brought the reggae music of Jamaica to international prominence, died in Miami of a brain tumor in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Global Warming Predictions Hindered By Lack Of Secret Military Data
With PM-Food-Dangers, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to predict the effects of global warming are being hurt by lack of access to 40 years of secret Soviet and U.S. military data on the north polar ice cap, scientists said. Submarine sonar measurements of the thickness of the ice cap are crucial to understanding ocean currents underneath the ice cap, said Michael Schlesinger of Oregon State University. Those currents must be understood if researchers are to predict accurately the rate of warming of the earth's climate as carbon dioxide is released into the atmosphere, Schlesinger said Monday at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. ``What I want is, month by month, the thickness of sea ice _ which you can only get by submarine,'' Schlesinger said. Soviet military planners have the same data on the north polar ice cap that American military officials have, Schlesinger said. But his Soviet colleagues have told him they cannot get the secret data. Satellite measurements of the monthly changes in the size of the ice cap are available, but the satellites cannot be used to measure the ice's thickness, he said. Schlesinger is one of a small number of researchers developing computer programs to simulate the effect of global warming and predict its future consequences. Such models need data on ocean currents to make accurate predictions, he said. There are five such models in the United States, and the same number in the Soviet Union, he said. ``All the models have run with some assumption of this missing term under the ice,'' he said. Syukuro Manabe, another developer of such models, said the ocean can absorb a lot of the heat produced as increasing amounts of carbon dioxide in the air trap more and more of the sun's heat. Researchers said they do not yet know exactly how much heat the oceans can absorb. The amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is expected to double by the first half of the next century, but the associated warming will probably lag by several decades because at first the heat will be lost into the oceans, said Manabe, a researcher at a National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration laboratory at Princeton University in New Jersey. The eventual temperature rise is expected to be an average of 2 degrees to 4 degrees around the world, the researchers said. Manabe hopes the abatement of the Cold War will help global-warming researchers. ``I'm hoping that this will be one of the peace dividends,'' he said, ``that the U.S. and the Soviets will exchange sea ice data.''

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Report Clashes With Contras; Observers Predict Peaceful Election
LaserPhoto MGA8
DOC.TEXT: The Sandinista government says nine people were killed in clashes with Contra rebels over the past week, but international observers are noting a lull in political violence as general elections near. The foreigners say they expect Sunday's potentially pivotal balloting to be peaceful, free and fair. ``Over the last two weeks we had been rather worried about possible violence,'' Iqbal Riza of Pakistan, local head of the United Nations mission to observe the elections, said Monday. ``Over the last few days the tone has been lowered,'' he said, ``and we are noticing a willingness by each party to avoid violence.'' Tension had shot up over the past two weeks as the leftist Sandinistas and their main challenger, the U.S.-backed United National Opposition coalition, exchanged threats of violence. President Daniel Ortega, seeking another six-year term, threatened to close the newspaper published by coalition presidential candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and confiscate her house if the Sandinistas win. He also threatened to seize the home of its vice presidential candidate, Virgilio Godoy. Godoy had threatened to ``make the Sandinistas pay the bill'' _ an ominous Nicaraguan expression that can imply anything, including death. Both threats came in campaign speeches, but both sides have since toned down their rhetoric. As Riza was speaking at a news conference at the foreign correspondents' club in Managua, the Defense Ministry issued a communique on the clashes with the U.S.-backed Contras. Th one-page statement said Sandinista troops fought Contras in Chontales province in the south on Wednesday and Friday and in Nueva Segovia province in the north on Sunday. It said five rebels died in the clashes. It did not report any army casualties. The Defense Ministry also accused the Contras of ambushing and killing four peasants in the northern province of Jinotega on week ago and of kidnapping a civilian in the South Atlantic Autonomous Region on Sunday. It said one of the peasants killed in Jinotega was a Sandinista Front militant. The four Jinotega victims were buried Monday in the town of Esteli. The Sandinistas have repeatedly accused the Contras of intimidating and killing Sandinista supporters in the countryside. The Contras have denied it. Figures obtained by The Associated Press show Managua, the capital and one of the big question marks in the election, represents the largest single chunk of registered voters nationwide. A final tally of voters registered in Nicaragua's nine regions show Managua has 462,446 registered voters, out of a national total of 1,750,550, or 26.42 percent of the vote. Many public employees and members of the armed forces live in Managua, an advantage for the Sandinistas in the voting. But the urban poor _ and Managua is by far the largest urban center in Nicaragua _ have suffered the most from a ravaged economy that the opposition blames on Sandinista mismanagement and the Sandinistas blame on the U.S. economic embargo in effect since 1985 and years of war with the Contras. The rebels began fighting the Sandinista government in 1981, two years after the revolution that toppled dictator Anastasio Somoza. In February 1988, the U.S. Congress cut off military aid to the Contras, who are based in neighboring Honduras. President Bush has said he wanted non-lethal aid to continue to the Contras to ensure that the Sandinistas hold free elections.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Groups Wary About Administration Farm Bill Contrariness
DOC.TEXT: Farm organizations are skeptical about the Bush administration's refusal to spell out precisely what it wants in new farm legislation regarding price supports and target prices. Some members of Congress aren't pleased about the foot-dragging, either. At a hearing of the Senate Agriculture Committee on Feb. 7, Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., challenged Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. ``We can't write a farm bill without an idea of what the administration wants,'' Leahy said. ``I want specifics.'' But Yeutter continued to stonewall: ``The administration will not declare today what its position is on target prices.'' He added that talks on spending ought to take place in private rather than in a public hearing. Yeutter had another opportunity to provide more details at a hearing today before the House Agriculture Committee and Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, but there wasn't much expectation he would get into more specifics than he did with Leahy. Meanwhile, the administration's fuzziness about target prices _ rates upon which crop ``deficiency'' payments to farmers are based _ has prompted doubting stares and a few fiery glances from farm groups. The American Farm Bureau Federation, which has been relatively placid about administration policies, says it isn't satisfied by the Bush farm bill proposals so far. ``Failure to address target price levels is the largest question mark that we have in our minds,'' said federation policy specialist Rob Nooter. ``That's going to be a very important element of putting together a new farm bill _ how much income support do we include?'' The federation favors freezing target prices at their 1990 levels, but without an answer from the administration, ``it's obvious that Congress is going to have to make that decision in negotiations'' with the Bush people, Nooter said. At the heart of the Bush plan is ``flexibility'' so farmers can have more choice as to what crops to plant under annual commodity programs. The basic idea appears to have strong acceptance among some farm groups, although it's not unanimous. The National Grange said the 1990 farm bill proposals announced by Yeutter on Feb. 6 would, as expected, lead to policies the administration believes will be ``more oriented to market signals'' instead of government regulation. ``Notably absent from the proposals are specific recommendations for target prices for the government's crop programs,'' the Grange said. ``Also absent was any mention of the proposals to eliminate farm subsidy payments to this nation's largest, wealthiest farmers and to tighten farm subsidy payment limits that were part of President Bush's recent 1991 budget message to Congress.'' In his budget proposal to Congress on Jan. 29, Bush said the administration will work closely with lawmakers to close loopholes in federal subsidy restrictions and to ``eliminate excessive payments to wealthy farmers.'' The Grange said the administration's proposals include features that are both supported and opposed by its members. Conservation, trade, research and grain storage proposals are close to Grange objectives, but flexibility, dairy and the administration's plan to kill federal crop insurance are at odds with current Grange policy. The National Farmers Union's appraisal of Bush farm bill strategy was characterized by NFU president Leland Swenson as a ``house with no foundation. It may look good from the outside, but you soon realize something pretty important is missing.'' Yet, the administration's general blueprint has some features the NFU finds appealing. ``Many of the recommendations closely follow those called for in the farm bill proposal we announced last July,'' Swenson said. ``But recommending changes in planting decisions, set-aside determinations, loan rate and the like, without any consideration of farm income levels, is shortsighted at best.'' The strongest appraisal of administration proposals came from the National Farm Coalition, which says it is ``made up of 40 grassroots farm organizations from across the United States.'' ``Secretary Yeutter's guidelines for a 1990 farm bill are just a continuation of the 1985 farm bill, a disaster for farmers, taxpayers, rural communities and the environment,'' said Ralph Nodland, a North Dakota grain farmer and president of the coalition. Nodland said the administration plan would further reduce farmers' income ``by keeping farm prices low.'' He said the flexibility concept ``actually amounts to an option to keep cutting prices.''

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrilla Group Releases Priest From The United States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf `The priest...' with 1 grafs to DROP extraneous ``both''; Pickup 4th graf `The radio...'
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas freed an American priest Monday night who had been kidnapped in protest of President Bush's visit to Colombia for last week's anti-drug summit. The priest, Francis Amico Ferrari, 43, said in a live radio interview that he was released unharmed in the western Colombia city of Cali. The radio network Caracol, which carried the interview, reported that Amico Ferrari is from Houston. Other priests in his parish in Cali had said last week that Amico Ferrari is from Rochester, N.Y. In Cartagena, a Caribbean port city where President Bush met with three Latin presidents last Thursday, guerrillas dynamited an electric power substation Monday night and attacked three police posts, police there told The Associated Press. Five police officers were wounded and much of the city of 530,000 people was left without power, the police said. The National Liberation Army claimed responsibility for the attack, the policeman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The group kidnapped Amico Ferrari Thursday morning in Cali while on his way to his church in a slum neighborhood. The guerrillas also kidnapped two other American citizens last week to protest Bush's visit and they remained in the hands of the group, which is led by a former priest, Manuel Perez. Those two, James Donnelly of Detroit and David Kent of Indianapolis, were kidnapped last Tuesday in the northwestern city of Medellin. Amico Ferrari said after being released that he had been lectured by the guerrillas on the need to nationalize foreign oil holdings in Colombia, Latin America's foreign debt and right-wing death squads. The Colombian attorney general's office says right-wing death squads have killed hundreds of leftists in Colombia in the last five years. Amico Ferrari said the leader of the guerrillas who kidnapped him was polite and intelligent and treated him with respect. The priest said he was treated well during his five days of captivity. Amico Ferrari is the superior of a parish in Cali that is in one of that city's poorest neighborhoods. He founded the Basilian Priests' branch in the neighborhood, San Andres, after arriving in Colombia in 1987. The National Liberation Army issued a communique through Colombian news media Friday claiming that the kidnappings were in protest of Bush's visit. The communique accused the United States of trying to impose its will on Colombia. The Associated Press obtained a copy of the communique, which declared: ``Gringos out ... El Salvador and Colombia will win!'' The National Liberation Army was organized in the mid-1970s and has followed the ideology of Cuba's Fidel Castro. There are an estimated 10,000 guerrillas in six groups in Colombia. The National Liberation Army has become the most active of the six in the last four years, blowing up oil pipelines, ambushing army patrols, attacking military bases, kidnapping people and attacking small towns to destroy police stations and rob banks. One Colombian guerrilla group, the April 19 Movement, named after the date of a presidential election in 1970, has signed a peace treaty with the government. Four other groups say they also are interested in peace talks. The National Liberation Army has vowed to fight on, however.

DOC.HEAD: Census Bureau Takes Pride in Keeping Answers Confidential
DOC.TEXT: Pssst, can you keep a secret? The Census Bureau can. The same people who churn out a seemingly endless supply of details about Americans in general, will reveal nothing about individuals. Urging people to answer the census, Bureau Director Barbara E. Bryant stresses their responses are ``completely confidential.'' ``The answers are not shared with any other government agency or individual. They are combined into statistics, with individual information kept private until the year 2062,'' she says. Confidentiality was not always the rule. Two centuries ago copies of the census lists were posted in public places so people could point out omissions and errors. But today individual privacy is both policy and law. And the Census Bureau has compiled an enviable record of protecting the information people provide. For example, even during the hysteria following the bombing of Pearl Harbor in 1941, the bureau refused to release the names and addresses of Japanese-Americans living on the West Coast. It also turned down the attorney general's demand for information about individuals suspected of being communists during a Red Scare in 1947. And in 1980 the bureau refused to comply with a federal court order demanding addresses for certain city officials. In turning down the court, bureau officials said even releasing information on the number of people living in various apartments could harm individuals by revealing those doubling-up or by disclosing the presence of squatters, welfare fathers, illegal aliens and others. Confidentiality is especially stressed in promotion efforts directed at the Hispanic community, where many people may be in the country illegally, and those who are legal often distrust government officials. The law requires the bureau to count all the people in the nation, not just citizens. So it makes a special effort to reach those who are reluctant to be included. Hence the emphasis that information given the census is not passed on to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, or the Internal Revenue Service, or the Selective Service, or anyone else. Names and addresses of individuals are collected to make sure no one is missed or counted twice. But they are not recorded in the giant computers which compile and sort the census information, officials say. Those machines merely digest the information about people living on particular blocks or census tracts across the nation, and provide that information for a variety of statistical uses. In cases where even releasing those statistics would reveal something about an individual, the numbers are kept private. For example, the 1980 Census found 2,315 people living in Census Tract 20 of Kansas City, including one black person. Normally data such as income, type of residence, employment and so forth is released by race. But not in this tract, because it would have been obvious who was being reported on. Indeed, the bureau suppresses data unless a large number of people are averaged out, so that no one can learn about an individual or family or small group. Census Bureau employees who reveal information about individuals are subject to a $5,000 fine and five years in prison. But no one has ever been convicted of releasing such data. Only after 72 years does the information on individuals become public record. Then it is made available at the National Archives for people doing research on their ancestors. That means individual data from the 1920 census will become available in two years. The only use of census data permitted earlier is for individuals who request information to prove their age. This often is needed to qualify for pension benefits or for some other purpose when birth certificates or other documents have been lost. The legal confidentiality of the census was instituted in 1910 to protect information on businesses, and in 1930 that was extended to cover the general population. Privacy was apparently not a consideration in 1790, when the first U.S. census was taken. The U.S. Marshals who took that census posted their lists in public, a practice that continued until 1830.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Trying to Muster Resources for Departing Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Congress is mobilizing for the possibility that large numbers of troops will be mustered out as a result of growing world peace. At least two lawmakers have introduced proposals providing a ``khaki parachute'' to soften the landing of soldiers into civilian life, and a law that took effect in January could lay the groundwork for making readjustment easier. Among the measures: _Legislation introduced by Rep. Thomas J. Downey, D-N.Y., to restore unemployment compensation benefits to ex-military personnel to the same number of weeks available to civilians. Veterans now must wait four weeks to start 13 weeks of benefits instead of one week to start 26 weeks of benefits. The current formula for veterans dates back to the beginning of the 1980s when an effort was made to cut off eligibility altogether. ``In an era when we are cutting defense spending at the same time we expect our fighting men and women to risk their lives in Grenada and Panama, the least we can do is provide them with 26 weeks of benefits after the coming reduction in force,'' Downey said. _A bill introduced by Rep. Jim Slattery, D-Kan., that would entitle enlisted personnel and non-commissioned officers to separation pay if they have completed five or more years of active duty before being involuntarily discharged. Officers already receive up to $30,000 in severance pay, Slattery said. ``Many men and women join the service expecting to spend their entire career serving their country,'' Slattery said. ``I think that it is unfair for the government to release them without some kind of compensation.'' An estimate prepared by the private Non Commissioned Officers Association says the cost would be $58 million to $105 million, depending on when in the fiscal year the soldiers are separated. The NCOA says that money would be offset by savings of $126 million in unemployment compensation. Those 5,000 officers were earning $9.6 million a month, the estimate says. _A package of veterans' benefits legislation that was enacted late last year set up a pilot program to provide employment and training services to members of armed forces preparing to leave. ``Oddly enough, this was not in anticipation'' of the budget or events in Europe, said John V. Meyers, deputy assistant secretary of labor for veterans' employment and training. ``However, the timing of the pilot program couldn't be better.'' The program now is borrowing staff from other functions. A report on the operations is due in May 1992, but Meyers says large-scale troop reductions could hasten full implementation. The program helps members of the military within 180 days of leaving the service. The help includes economic profiles of regions, wage rates in areas, resume preparation and help in applying skills acquired in the military to civilian jobs. The pilot program is underway at Camp Pendleton, Calif., for Marines; San Antonio, Texas, for the Air Force; Norfolk, Va., and Jacksonville, Fla., for the Navy; and Ft. Benning, Ga., and Ft. Eustis, Va., for the Army. Programs for disabled personnel are at San Antonio for the Air Force, Jacksonville for the Navy and Fitzsimmons Army Hospital, Colo. Meantime, the Department of Veterans' Affairs says it expects a large new wave of veterans to have little impact on its ability to deliver services. Most of the veterans are relatively young and healthy, so they should place little demand on the health care and compensation system, said spokesman Bonner Day. Day said he expected an increase in applications for the GI Bill, which provides payments for college or other post-high school education. But some veterans' groups say the system already is strapped as a result of tight budgets, and the biggest problem is with the time it takes to handle benefits applications. Employees who handle the GI Bill, they say, are working to ease the backlog in other areas. Discharged soldiers who fall upon hard times may try to resurrect old injuries in order to get veterans' compensation, worsening the logjam, the groups say.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor, Cop, Drug Addict: A Tale Of Three Brothers
DOC.TEXT: This is a story of three brothers. The oldest is mayor of New Haven. The youngest rose to the rank of a police detective. The middle one descended into the world of drug addiction and was charged this month with being a pusher. On Feb. 6, the 37th day of Mayor John Daniels' first term of office in this southern Connecticut city of 127,000, and 10 days before Detective Melvin Daniels was to put in for retirement, the lives of the three brothers were changed forever. Robert Daniels, 48, surrendered to Melvin to answer cocaine possession and trafficking charges, and the mayor was put on the spot to explain how brothers could be so different. Few suggest that John Daniels, 53, New Haven's first black mayor, will lose his position as a role model for this city's black youth or see his relentless anti-drug message undermined. As Melvin Daniels, the youngest of the brothers at age 45, put it: ``You can't be held responsible for an almost 50-year-old man.'' WELI radio host Steve Kalb said that when he wondered out loud whether the mayor should have kept closer tabs on his brother, ``I got jumped on.'' Mostly, callers expressed sorrow over the turn of events. A former city alderman, state senator and businessman, the soft-spoken, nattily dressed John Daniels established an unblemished record of public service as he kept his sights on the mayor's office for more than 20 years. But while John's fortunes were rising, Robert's were falling. The mayor said Robert's problems began in the late 1970s, when he got laid off from his blue-collar job and got mixed up with the wrong crowd. Family members' efforts to help met with little success. One stay in a residential treatment program had no lasting effect. When Robert Daniels was arraigned this month, he listed no assets, and was granted a court-appointed attorney. ``Some people just take a lot longer than others to hit bottom,'' said Melvin. Robert, who was using the alias of Dan Daniels, allegedly sold cocaine to an undercover officer on two occasions. A warrant was issued for his arrest following a raid on his apartment that netted $7,500 worth of cocaine. When Robert gave himself up to his brother four days after the raid, it was his first arrest. According to a court source, he entered a 28-day drug treatment program at Connecticut Valley Hospital in Middletown three days after his arrest. No trial date has been set. The brothers have gotten together only occasionally for holidays and family birthdays, although Robert did stop by for John's victory party Nov. 7. Melvin, who has spent the last five years on the front lines of New Haven's escalating drug war, is trying to forget the day he faced off against his brother in that battle. ``I don't want to keep on opening it up,'' said the police detective, whose nickname is ``Rock.'' ``I want to let that thing die.'' ``Let me put it simply for you,'' he said. ``It's part of the territory of being a police officer. Even though it hurts sometimes, you do what you got to do.'' John Daniels Jr. is the oldest of the three sons and two daughters of John and Ludelia Daniels, who were on hand to watch him sworn in as mayor. The family moved from Georgia to New Haven when John Jr. was a young boy. A star football player in high school, John attended Villanova University on a full athletic scholarship. His first job was as a teacher, and he later worked for Qunnipiac College, Yale University and a city development agency. Melvin entered the Navy after high school and worked as a mechanic before becoming a housing authority police officer in 1969. ``He is sort of a carbon copy of John,'' said Albert Rogers, the mayor's executive assistant and friend since grammar school. ``He just went out and did his job.'' Robert, who has two daughters but is separated from his wife, was always ``a very lovable and happy-go-lucky guy,'' said Melvin. In his 1960 high school yearbook, Robert listed dancing as his favorite hobby and entry into the Air Force as his ambition. Melvin said his brother did go on to join the Air Force but eventually received a medical discharge because of asthma. In the black community, sympathy was expressed for Robert's family. ``I have compassion and support for his family because I know what it feels like,'' said Lisa Sullivan, a Yale graduate student and political activist who advises the NAACP Youth Council. ``I have cousins and uncles in my family who sell drugs and are addicted to drugs. The black community is in crisis.'' The mayor told a news conference on Feb. 7 that ``if the fact that the mayor's brother can fall prey to the lure of drugs will help the rest of the community realize that it can happen in any family, to any one, then something good has come of Robert's tragedy.''
