DOC.HEAD: Spending Tops $20 Million, Month Before Primaries
DOC.TEXT: The job pays $93,432 a year, but seven candidates for governor already have spent more than $20 million trying to land it, and analysts say the final tab could hit $50 million. The bulk of the money is going for production and broadcast of television commercials, exposure that's mandatory for reaching the state's 17 million residents. Texas is so large that to blanket it, a candidate must purchase air time on more than 70 stations in 21 TV markets, including outlets in Arkansas, Louisiana and Oklahoma. ``Campaign costs are going up because of television and postage. The television advertising is so expensive and the markets are so numerous, it costs a ton to run for office,'' said George Christian, political consultant and former press secretary to President Lyndon Johnson. ``It's unfortunate,'' he said. ``But it's a fact of life in Texas.'' Four Republicans and three Democrats are vying for nominations in the March 13 primaries to succeed retiring Gov. Bill Clements, the state's only Republican governor in 100 years. Top spender is the man who according to polls is the leader in the Republican primary field: millionaire oilman Clayton Williams. He has spent $6.4 million _ more than $4 million of it from his personal bank account _ and first aired television commercials in August. State Treasurer Ann Richards, who leaped to national attention by keynoting the 1988 Democratic convention, leads in Democratic race polls but lags in fund-raising at $2.1 million. The Democratic financial lead goes to Attorney General Jim Mattox, who raised more than $4 million and spent $3.7 million, including almost $2 million on television ads in the past month alone. Former Gov. Mark White, who raised $3 million since joining the Democratic race in November. According to campaign finance reports filed by all candidates, spending on the race totaled $20.1 million by Feb. 12. And that was with a month left until the primary and two months until the expected runoff elections. Analysts in both parties have said that by November, the race will easily eclipse the state record $33.5 million spent in 1986, when Clements ousted White. Williams defends his spending as proof of his independence from special interests. ``Clayton is not beholden to anybody. Some people consider that an asset, to be able to contribute to your own campaign,'' said Williams aide Scott Bohnenkamp. Williams' GOP opponents accuse him of trying to buy the Republican nomination. Referring to Williams' cowboy image and two admitted fist fights since he turned 50, a spokeswoman for GOP hopeful Tom Luce retorted, ``I don't know how tough Clayton is, but he has a black belt in spending.'' Asked about soaring campaign costs, Mark Sanders, press secretary to Republican candidate Kent Hance, said, ``Television advertising. It's just that simple.'' Hance, a former ``Boll Weevil'' Democratic congressman who changed parties in 1985, has raised $2.2 million. Recent polls put him second in the GOP race. Candidates say collecting money takes more work than it used to since the state's oil and real estate busts. ``I don't believe they're stealing any, but they do have to beg and borrow,'' Christian said. ``It's really hurtful to campaigns because it means they have to be devoted primarily to raising money to get their message out on TV. It's not just the candidate. Everybody is hustling for money and, they're hustling against great competition right now _ there are legislative races, local races,'' he said. Mattox was criticized for raising money from law firms while serving as attorney general. But his strategy of banking money early has let him outspend the other Democrats as election day nears. ``There's a time to reap and a time to sow,'' said Mattox spokesman Kelly Fero. ``We reaped early and now we're sowing. We still have more to spend, and the bulk of it is, of course, on TV.'' Ms. Richards, who raised funds with the help of celebrities such as Lily Tomlin and Marlo Thomas, has front-runner status to help offset her smaller bank account, Christian said. ``Because she's ahead and seems to have a fairly strong base (of support) ... they didn't have to spend as much money early,'' he said. ``They have squirreled their money away for the end and will hit the television with a pretty heavy buy. When you're ahead, you can do that.'' Glenn Smith, Ms. Richards' campaign manager, said that while her $2.1 million is less than Mattox's war chest or White's, the bulk of it came from small contributors, not regular political backers.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Slightly, Nikkei Continues To Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with dollar closing up, market closing down. Pickup 7th graf ``If money...''
DOC.TEXT: The dollar held steady against the yen Tuesday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange continued its fall. The dollar closed at 144.58 yen, up 0.06 yen from its day-before level of 144.52 yen. It traded narrowly throughout the day after its 144.50-yen opening, ranging between 144.45 yen and 144.65 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which lost 237.72 points Monday, shed an additional 327.08 points, or 0.8 percent, to end the day at 36,895.52. Trading was said to be light at about 330 million shares. Brokers attributed the stock market's loss to persistent fears of another rise in the Bank of Japan's official discount rate _ the rate charged to banks _which now stands at 4.25 percent following three increases last year. Dealers said the speculation was reinforced when the central bank released figures in the afternoon showing that Japan's money supply grew by 11.5 percent in January from a year earlier. It was the second straight month of double-digit money growth, a sign of inflation, and a rise from December's growth of 10.6 percent. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno has warned repeatedly about the threat of inflation, especially in light of recent higher oil prices and the yen's persistent weakness that has been pushing up import costs. ``If money supply growth is high, then the possibility of a discount rate hike increases,'' explained a dealer at a Japanese securities firm, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said he doubted any increase would come right away. Chris Schreiber, a trader with New Japan Securities Co., said: ``You also have selling pressures ahead of year-end settlements in March.'' The Japanese fiscal year ends March 31. Other negative factors Schreiber pointed to included an oversupply of convertible bonds coming onto the market, earnings disappointments and concerns about a slowdown in the U.S. economy. ``Basically, there are no new buying incentives,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials Raise Possibility of Renewed Famine in Ethiopia
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials are warning that war and bad weather are causing new and immediate hunger emergencies in western Africa. The officials say anti-government forces in Ethiopia have shut down a port that is a key entry point for food assistance, threatening the lives of up to 5 million Ethiopians. Severely diminished harvests because of poor rainfall in northern Ethiopia are further aggravating the situation. U.S. officials say a crisis situation is also rapidly developing in the Sudan, where a bitter civil war is preventing the transport of relief supplies to rebel-held territory in the southern part of the country. President Bush sent a letter to the Sudanese president last week asking for his cooperation in restarting the international relief effort, to which the United States contributes $15.7 million. Renewed fighting has led to the suspension of food flights to southern Sudan and the government is preventing the departure of a relief train along a route where food shortages are severe. The rebels also have been blocking relief efforts. Estimates are that 1 million to 3 million Sudanese could suffer from famine. In Ethiopia, the cutoff of relief supplies through Massawa, a deep water port on the Red Sea, affects the Eritrea and Tigray provinces and portions of three other provinces. ``The next six weeks to two months is the critical time,'' said Andrew Natsios, director of the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance. ``We're trying to explore options for getting the food in.'' He added that a ``worst nightmare'' scenario is developing _ a civil war and a famine in the same area at the same time. A Western relief official told The Washington Post, ``If the port is closed for any length of time, then there is the possibility of tragedy n northern Ethiopia.'' The situation evokes memories of the 1984-85 period in Ethiopia when more than a million people died, primarily because of drought. Renewed drought last year in Ethiopia touched off a major international relief program led by the United States and the European Community, both of which funnel food donations through private voluntary organizations. Other contributing countries include Canada and Australia. The United States has either delivered or pledged more than $70 million to the relief effort. The figure for the rest of the international community is about $84 million, according to U.S. estimates. The goal of the donor countries was to compensate for severe shortages expected early this year resulting from disappointing rainfall last summer. But earlier this month, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front staged one of its most daring assaults in 27 years of warfare with its capture of Massawa and the road leading inland. Massawa had been the entry point for food for the needy in Eritrea and also for provinces further south, including Tigray, where Ethiopia's Marxist government is being challenged by yet another rebel group.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Launch Attacks in Cartagena, Free American; Police Seize Missiles
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas dynamited a power station and attacked police posts in Cartagena, and police seized 10 shoulder-fired missiles from drug traffickers four days after President Bush's visit, authorities said. Also Monday night, leftist guerrillas freed an American priest who was kidnapped on Thursday to protest Bush's visit to the the Caribbean port city that day for an anti-drug summit with three Andean presidents. Francis Amico Ferrari, 43, of Rochester, N.Y. said in a radio interview that he was released unharmed in Cali, the western city where he was kidnapped near his parish. Two other Americans remained in captivity: 65-year-old James Donnelly of Detroit and 40-year-old David Kent of Indianapolis. They were kidnapped by guerrillas one week ago in the northwest city of Medellin. In Cartagena, guerrillas dynamited an electric power substation Monday night, knocking out power to much of the city of 530,000 people, and they attacked three police posts, wounding five officers, police said by telephone. The leftist National Liberation Army, led by former priest Manuel Perez, claimed responsibility, the police said, speaking on condition of anonymity. A news release from the Administrative Security Department, the country's secret police, said the shoulder-fired missiles _ which can shoot down planes _ were found in a raid Monday on a Bogota drug hideout. It said two men arrested there were suspects in the November slaying of TV news anchorman Enrique Pulido in the capital. Pulido was one of 13 news media workers killed _ presumably by assassins working for drug bosses _ since President Virgilio Barco declared war on drug trafficers in August. The police gave few details of the raid. The U.S. Secret Service warned before Bush visited Cartagena that drug traffickers had shoulder-fired SAM-7s, surface-to-air missiles capable of downing large aircraft. The Medellin cocaine cartel has offered to dismantle its drug empire and stop its campaign of terror in Colombia if the government would agree to a truce and stop extraditing leading drug suspects to the United States to stand trial. Security forces have kept pursuing the traffickers, however. Bush went to Cartagena to meet with Presidents Barco, Alan Garcia of Peru and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia, and all reaffirmed their will to fight drug traffickers. The National Liberation Army issued a communique through Colombian news media Friday claiming the kidnappings were in protest of Bush's visit. It accused the United States of trying to impose its will on Colombia. The guerrillas also have promised a wave of violence leading up to the mayoral and congressional election March 11. Amico Ferrari said after being released that he had been lectured by the guerrillas on the need to nationalize foreign oil holdings in Colombia and other topics. He spoke in an interview with the radio network Caracol. On Sunday, the National Liberation Army blew up the country's main oil pipeline for the sixth time this year, this time near the village of Convencion, 250 miles north of Bogota, the government oil company Ecopetrol said in a news release. The attacks are an effort to force the government to nationalize U.S. and other foreign oil holdings. Officials said the pipeline would be out of service until at least Wednesday. The pipeline carries oil from the big Cano Limon field in northeastern Colombia to the Caribbean coast. The same guerrilla group tried to blow up an oil pipeline near Yopal, 125 miles north of Bogota, Sunday night, but the explosion did not break the line, Ecopetrol said. The National Liberation Army was organized in the mid-1970s and has followed the ideology of Cuba's Fidel Castro.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Leaders Doubt Major Policy Change from Reagan Era
With PM-Coal Strike-Vote, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's attitude toward organized labor appears to be a marked improvement from the Reagan era, labor leaders said, but they doubt there's been a substantive shift in policy. The Bush administration deserves credit for its involvement in the Pittston coal strike _ Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole met with both sides and appointed a ``super mediator'' _ and for compromising on labor's long-sought hike in the minimum wage, union leaders said. However, AFL-CIO leaders gathered for their annual winter meeting also complained that Bush, while praising worker movements abroad such as Solidarity in Poland, has demonstrated ``union busting'' tendencies at home by vetoing legislation to create a commission on the Eastern Airlines strike. ``Our president seems to be saying, `Workers' rights are fine in other parts of the world, but not in my backyard,''' said John Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union. The Executive Council of the 4.1 million-member AFL-CIO hopes to achieve improved relations with the Bush administration as its 33-member board meets today with Mrs. Dole. ``I give Bush and Liz Dole an A-plus on Pittston and a zero on Eastern,'' said Joyce Miller, vice president of the Amalgamated Colthing and Textile Workes Union. Many union officials considered Ronald Reagan, who fired striking air traffic controllers in 1981 and effectively killed that union, the worst president of the century for organized labor. ``President Bush and his `kinder, gentler' nation at least talks about issues that affect workers, like education, child care and health care. It took them long enough to come around on minimum wage, so we'll see on the others,'' Sweeney said. Susan Cowell, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, said Bush has been forced to improve the climate toward labor. ``Reagan created a revolution that was exposed as a fraud, and the public tide has turned against it. Bush is almost forced to be more moderate. That limits the degree to which he can hurt us,'' Cowell said. ``Bush is an odd character. He doesn't embrace an ideology the way Reagan does, but it's hard to see a policy difference,'' she said. Last year, Bush agreed to address the AFL-CIO's convention in Washington, marking the first time a president had addressed the federation since Jimmy Carter did in 1979. Reagan refused to speak in 1981 and was never invited again. At the time, AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland, who a month earlier had called Bush ``Reagan Lite,'' said the president's willingness to strike a compromise on minimum wage showed their had been some improvement over labor's strained relationship with Reagan. On Monday, Kirkland said union leaders would continue to lobby Congress for an override of Bush's veto of the Eastern Airlines legislation. As expected, the federation's Executive Council skipped a vote on pro-choice resolutions and instead appointed a 14-member committee of union leaders to determine whether a stand should be taken. Kirkland said the panel would not be swayed much by a national Right to Life Committee letter-writing campaign that urged union officials not to take a stand. ``I've been around a while, and I think I can tell grass roots from AstroTurf,'' Kirkland said, insinuating the letters were not from rank-and-file union members. The letters warned union leaders that rank-and-file members opposed to abortion would likely seek to have part of their union dues withheld if the AFL-CIO, which has sidestepped the issue for more than a decade, adopted a pro-choice position. ``I do not think the committee will be moved by threats or suggestions of reprisals. I think the committee will address the issues fairly and rationally and on the merits and will act accordingly,'' Kirkland said. National Right to Life Committee officials have said the AFL-CIO should sit the issue out because it does not impact collective bargaining or workplace conditions. Pro-choice union officials contend the issue impacts the economic well-being of working women. They note the AFL-CIO has traditionally taken a stand on a wide range of issues, including civil rights, gay rights and school busing. ``I would say that the committee probably breaks down almost 50-50,'' said Miller, a pro-choice member of the abortion panel. She predicted the AFL-CIO could adopt a pro-choice position as long as it included language acknowledging the moral and religious views of some union members. Kirkland declined to identify his personal position. The panel's chairman, William Wynn, president of the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union, is pro-choice but has said his personal feelings would not influence the committee's decision. Kirkland did not give the panel a deadline, but pro-choice officials want a decision by the council's May meeting. That would let labor leaders use the issue when making endorsements for the 1990 elections.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Hits Tokyo Area
DOC.TEXT: Buildings in downtown Tokyo swayed for more than a minute Tuesday as a strong earthquake rocked the capital area. There were no immediate reports of serious injuries or damage. The earthquake struck at 3:53 p.m. and sent office workers leaping from their desks. Trains on two high-speed ``bullet'' train lines were briefly halted, the Japan Broadcasting Corp. (NHK) reported. The Central Meteorological Agency said the quake measured a preliminary 6.6 on the Richter scale and was centered off the Izu peninsula southwest of Tokyo, an area of high seismic activity. Its epicenter was 12 miles below the ocean bed, it said. An earthquake registering 6 on the Richter scale can cause serious damage in populated areas. A quake measuring 7 is considered major and capable of widespread damage. Japan is hit frequently by earthquakes, and many buildings in the Tokyo area are designed to withstand strong temblors. The earthquake registered 4 on the Japanese scale of 7 in Tokyo, Yokohama and Tateyama, west of the capital, meteorological officials said. A quake registering 4 on the Japanese scale is strong enough to topple such objects as vases. The Japanese scale measures ground motion at particular locations and is not convertible to the Richter scale, which measures an earthquake's total strength. Each increase of one number in the open-ended Richter scale corresponds to a tenfold increase in magnitude. Meteorological officials said there was no danger of tsunami, or strong ocean waves caused by seismic activity.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
LaserPhoto VNY1
DOC.TEXT: Bronze baby shoes? Forget it. Modern fathers are going right to the source for souvenirs by smearing plaster on the ballooning bellies of their pregnant wives. The idea is pregnant with comic possibilities. But belly laughs don't bother Fred and Dionne Scobie of suburban Sherman Oaks, who call their creation Dr. Stork's Original Pregnant Tummy Cast Kit. ``Sure, it's a giggly thing. Everybody reacts the way you do. They giggle,'' Fred Scobie, 43, said Monday. ``We've had so much fun with it all this time and we decided there was some economic potential here. ``The phone has been ringing off the hook.'' The kit is available by mail order for $19.95 plus $3 for shipping and comes with everything needed to make a mold of the mother-to-be's tummy _ gauze, plaster, markers and blue and pink ribbons. After it dries, guests sign the plaster shell. ``They write things like, `Keep out front' and `It's been a long time baby,''' Scobie said. The Scobies hung the finished products for both of their children _ Dave, 4, and Jim, 3 _ on the wall in their den. ``We have them hanging next to the deer antlers. It's really a trophy,'' said Scobie. ``It is really cherished. The kids are fascinated by this. They know they came from mommie's tummy and it's just beautiful to watch them.''
Eds: The address for the plaster kits is F.C. Scobie Inc., 11684 Ventura Blvd., Suite 468, Studio City, Calif. 91604.

Seventeen-year-old Kent Bonham is rooting for his opponent to win a seat on the school board. Bonham, a Westside High School senior and editor of the school paper, spoke in favor of the re-election of District 66 school board President Helen Kelley _ his friend's mother _ at a recent nominating caucus. When no one volunteered to run against Ms. Kelley, Bonham agreed to a request that he submit his name ``just to get things rolling'' since at least two candidates are required for each position. ``I had to get home and read three acts of `Hamlet,' so I did.'' To his surprise, Bonham said, he was selected from among six candidates to run against Mrs. Kelley on May 15. ``So I guess I'm running for the school board,'' he said. ``I was kind of shocked. Mrs. Kelley is a close friend, and she knows how much I want her to win.'' Mrs. Kelley, 51, a former Westside teacher, said she is a friend of Bonham's family and her son, Rick, is a friend of Bonham. ``I have a very high opinion of him,'' she said. ``And I am proud to know he is a product of the District 66 school system.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Nepalese Soldiers Killed, Six Wounded by Shell Fire
DOC.TEXT: Two Nepalese soldiers of the United Nations peacekeeping force were killed and six others wounded when a shell hit their position in south Lebanon, a U.N. spokesman said today. The Nepalese position in the village of Byout Assiyad was hit directly by a 120mm mortar round at midday Monday, said Timur Goksel, spokesman for the U.N. Interim Force in Lebanon. ``Fifteen other mortar rounds fired from an Israeli-controlled area inside the security zone fell near the position,'' Goksel said. Israil carved out the ``security zone'' in June 1985 after it withdrew the bulk of its occupation army from Lebanon, ending a three-year invasion. Aamong the victims was a warrant officer who arrived in Lebanon on Feb. 12, said Goksel, adding that the other fatality and the six casualties had been due to leave the country next week. The spokesman said they were evacuated by U.N. helicopters and ambulances to the force's headquarters in the town of Naqoura on the Lebanese-Israeli border. The 5,800-strong U.N. force, drawn from nine nations, was deployed in the embattled south in 1978 under a U.N. Security Council resolution.

DOC.HEAD: Acid Rain May Be Culprit in Salamander Deaths
DOC.TEXT: Polluted snow from acid rain may be killing off salamanders in the Colorado Rockies, one of a series of mysterious population declines among amphibians around the globe, a researcher said. Scientists fear the decline of frog, toad and salamander populations _ even in relatively pristine national parks _ may presage ecological disaster. ``Amphibians are tough critters,'' said David Wake, director of the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology at the University of California at Berkeley. ``They survived whatever wiped out the dinosaurs, and they have thrived through the age of mammals. If they start to check out now, we better take it seriously.'' An 8-year study by John Harte, a professor at the university, indicates a link between declines of hardy, 6-inch tiger salamanders in the Rocky Mountains and an increase in the acidity of ponds in which they live. Harte's study noted that snow formed from acid rain melted in the late spring, pouring into 14 ponds he studied and raising their acid level. The study found acid levels such as those created by melting snow severely disrupted egg growth and killed developing salamander embryos, Harte said Monday. Studies in the eastern United States have shown the impact of acid rain on fish populations, but Harte's study is the first strong evidence that the same problem may be hitting the West, the university said in a statement. Harte collaborated on the project with Erika Hoffman, a scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory. The study was presented at a special meeting called by the National Research Council at the National Academy of Science's Beckman Center in Irvine in Southern California. Scientists were to meet through today to discuss ``Declining Amphibian Populations _ A Global Phenomenon.'' Amphibians are cold-blooded, moist-skinned creatures who spend part of their lives in the water and part on land. Declines in local populations on six continents were first noted in the late 1970s. In the past few years, drastic population declines have been noted in such species as the golden toad in Costa Rican rain forests, the yellow-legged frog in the Sierra Nevada, and spotted frogs in the northwestern U.S., which now are being considered for addition to the endangered species list. Suggestions about the cause of declines in specific populations range from acid rain and other water pollution to disease, exploitation for food and climactic changes.

DOC.HEAD: First Heart-Liver Transplant Patient Getting Second Operation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with surgery beginning; pick up 5th graf pvs, `The surgery is ...'
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the 12-year-old recipient of the world's first heart-liver transplant, underwent a second liver transplant early Tuesday because of damage from hepatitis. A team of surgeons began the operation around 3:15 a.m., said Liz McMahon, a spokeswoman for Children's Hospital. The surgery was expected to last 12 to 16 hours, said another hospital spokeswoman, Margy Buczynski. ``The doctors aren't expecting many complications because she is in good condition,'' Ms. Buczynski said. Stormie and her mother, Lois Purcell, flew to Pittsburgh from their home in White Settlement, Texas, on Monday. The surgery is necessary because Stormie's first donated liver no longer functions normally due to damage from hepatitis, said Liz McMahon, another hospital spokeswoman. Ms. Buczynski would not identify the donor of the new liver. Stormie's heart-liver transplant on Feb. 14, 1984, was done by a medical team led by transplant pioneer Dr. Thomas E. Starzl. Starzl will be present for part of the latest operation, but Dr. Andreas Tzakis will lead the team, Ms. Buczynski said. The first transplant took 16 hours. The donated heart and liver came from a 4-year-old girl who died in a New York car accident. Before the double transplant, Stormie had suffered two heart attacks and undergone two triple coronary bypass operations. She suffered from a rare congenital disease which increased to 10 times normal the level of cholesterol in her blood. The imbalance was caused by a faulty liver. Stormie was leading a fairly normal life until October 1988, when she was re-admitted to Children's Hospital for possible organ rejection. She improved the next month after surgeons removed a bile duct obstruction, but was back again in January 1989 because of elevated enzyme levels that interfered with her anti-rejection medication, cyclosporine. The girl started losing liver function in November and returned to the hospital once again. Starzl replaced her cyclosporine with an experimental Japanese drug, FK-506, believed to be 50 to 100 times more powerful with fewer side effects. Stormie returned to Children's Hospital on Jan. 6 with more liver problems. Tests showed no evidence of organ rejection, but rather a non-infectious form of hepatitis. Surgeons followed Stormie's 1984 operation with two more attempts at heart-liver transplants, but both patients died within a few days of surgery. Those were the only attempts in America at replacing the heart and liver in a simultaneous operation until Dec. 3, when Pittsburgh surgeons performed the world's first heart-liver-kidney transplant. The patient, Cindy Martin, 26, of Archbald, remains in critical condition in the intensive care unit at Presbyterian-University Hospital. Ms. Martin also is receiving FK-506, and has experienced no organ rejection.

DOC.HEAD: Woman With New Lung-Assist Device Dies
DOC.TEXT:
A near-terminally ill woman implanted with an artificial lung device died about 15 hours after surgery. A team of anesthesiologists and surgeons at the Penn State University center placed the device, known as the IntraVascular Oxygenator, in the woman at noon Sunday, the university said. The unidentified women died of pneumonia at 3 a.m. Monday. Dr. Michael T. Snider, director of the study at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center, said the device helped sustain the 34-year-old woman's life during the hours it was used. ``This was a woman with a near-terminal disease,'' Snider said. ``Unfortunately, her disease was too far advanced to save her.'' It was the second clinical trial of the experimental device. Melicia Harvey, 16, of Arthur City, Texas, died Feb. 7 of lung failure. She lived 4{ days on the device, known as IVOX, which had functioned normally after her operation at LDS Hospital in Salt Lake City. The device mimics the lungs' ability to filter carbon dioxide out of the blood and replace it with oxygen. It was designed to give damaged lungs time to rest and recover. The Food and Drug Administration has approved experimental use of the device for up to seven days in patients with respiratory problems. Before the lung-assist device, mechanical ventilation has been the only method to help patients who have trouble breathing. The device is a 20-inch bundle of hundreds of synthetic tubes almost as fine as human hair, with walls so thin that oxygen and carbon dioxide can pass through. It is inserted via the neck or groin into the inferior vena cava, the large vein that brings blood to the heart. Two tubes the diameter of a soda straw are attached to the bundle of tubes and lead out of the body. One delivers oxygen to the blood while the other removes carbon dioxide.
J.D. Mortensen, a thoracic surgeon and vice president for research at CardioPulmonics Inc. in Salt Lake City, conceived the IVOX and developed it.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0467 to change cycle designator.
Former Treasury Undersecretary Dies at 83
DOC.TEXT: H. Chapman Rose, a former assistant secretary and undersecretary of the Treasury in the Eisenhower Administration, has died of emphysema. He was 83. Rose, who died Feb. 17 at Sibley Memorial Hospital, also was a former national managing partner of the law firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue. In 1932 he became an associate in a predecessor firm of Jones Day in Cleveland, where he practiced law until 1976, except during his years in government service. Rose was a national managing partner of the firm, which has 17 offices in this country, Europe, the Far East and the Middle East, from 1974 to 1976. He then became a counsel to the firm and returned to Washington, retiring in 1983. Rose first came to Washington in 1931 and worked for a year as a law clerk and secretary to Supreme Court Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. He returned during World War II as an Army lawyer, having attained the rank of colonel and earned the Legion of Merit. He directed the Office of Contract Settlement from 1946 to 1947, then helped found Jones Day's Washington offices before returning to Cleveland as a partner in 1949. Four years later, at the beginning of the Eisenhower administration, Rose returned to the nation's capital as assistant secretary of the Treasury. He supervised the Coast Guard, the Customs Service and the Secret Service. In 1955 Rose was named Treasury undersecretary. He returned to private law practice in 1956. Rose is survived by his wife of 51 years, Katherine Cast Rose of Washington; a son, Jonathan Chapman of Alexandria; and a grandson.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Split on Firing of First Black School Chief
DOC.TEXT: Black members of the Boston School Committee demanded the right to veto a replacement for the city's first black superintendent, whose ouster last week has been called racist. During a two-hour meeting with committee President Daniel Burke, the four black members Monday also urged that the replacement of Laval Wilson be a minority who would be selected by a panel of community activists, parents and teachers in a nationwide search. Burke rejected the demands and said the committee would search for a successor to Wilson, 54, who was dismissed Feb. 13. ``I am very confident that the Boston School Committee with the full input of its minority members can adequately find an interim and a superintendent,'' Burke said. The black members, along with committee vice president John Grady, a strong Wilson supporter who is white, walked out of the committee meeting last week shortly before the 7-1 vote in favor of ousting Wilson was taken. Burke met Monday with the five behind closed doors at the People's Baptist Church in an attempt to reconcile the 13-member panel. Minority leaders have charged the ouster was racist, since the seven members who voted to remove Wilson are white. The group said the process deciding Wilson's fate was unfair, but did not recommend reversing the decision to buy out the remaining 18 months of his contract. ``His reputation has been so maligned, his authority so undermined that he believes it would not be in the best interests of the children to try and prolong the confusion,'' said member John O'Bryant. ``He has asked us not to fight to keep him.'' O'Bryant asked that Wilson's contract be bought out for about $200,000; Burke and other committee members have said buying out Wilson's contract would cost between $130,000 and $160,000. Critics of Wilson said he failed to work effectively with parents, students, teachers and others to improve the city's schools. They said little progress has been noticed in the school system since Wilson's appointment five years ago. Blacks, Hispanics and Asians make up about three-fourths of the city's 56,000 school population.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall Sharply Again, Dollar Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's leading index fell sharply for the second consecutive day today amid fears of higher interest rates, while the dollar rose slightly against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which lost 237.72 points Monday, plunged an additional 327.08 points, or 0.88 percent, closing at 36,895.52. Prices started lower today following Monday's decline and sank further after the Bank of Japan announced a substantial increase in the nation's money supply, seen as inflationary and likely to force the bank to raise the official discount rate, an official of Nomura Securities Co. said. The supply rose by 11.5 percent in January from a year earlier. It was the second straight month of double-digit growth, and the highest year-to-year increase since March 1988. Chris Schreiber, a trader with New Japan Securities Co., said the growth rate ``was way above what people were expecting. It's definitely cause for concern. It's a very high level compared with real economic growth.'' A broker speaking on condition of anonymity said, ``The fact that the Bank of Japan did not raise the discount rate right away probably means that they will wait until mid-March to see what long-term effects the last rise has.'' The discount rate, the interest fee charged by the central bank for loans to commercial banks, affects other interest rates. Higher interest rates generally discourage stock investment. Meanwhile, the dollar closed at 144.50 yen, up 0.06 yen from Monday's close of 144.52. It opened at 144.50 and ranged between 144.45 yen and 144.65 yen. Trading totaled $5.242 billion, down from $7 billion on Monday. An official at the Bank of Tokyo said the foreign exchange market had expected the substiaial increase in the money supply.

DOC.HEAD: Five Black African Nations To Meet De Klerk In Major Summit
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk will meet with at least five black African leaders this weekend in Zaire in what may be a major breakthrough in African politics, officials said today. In an effort to ease friction with black states, de Klerk will meet Saturday in Zaire with the leaders of that country, Rwanda, Burundi, Chad and the African Central Republic to discuss regional issues and political developments in South Africa, said the officials. Togo and Gabon may also be represented at the one-day meeting, which would be the first multi-nation conference between South Africa's white-minority government and black African states, said the officials, who declined to be identified. South African presidents have had meetings with single black heads-of-state in the past. The meeting could clear the way for South Africa to start establishing political and economic ties with black Africa after years of being isolated because of its apartheid policies, the officials said. South Africa wants to expand economic ties to help stimulate its own economy, they said. De Klerk is expected to brief the black leaders on his recent reforms, including the Feb. 11 release of Nelson Mandela and the legalization of the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups. De Klerk is seeking to end white minority rule and extend political rights to South Africa's black majority but at the same time retain some sort of veto power for whites. The Zaire meeting is expected to discuss efforts to end the civil war in Angola. Zaire President Mobutu Sese Seko has been mediating between the Angolan government and the UNITA guerrilla group headed by Jonas Savimbi. South African newspapers reported today that some black nations may be considering establishing diplomatic ties with South Africa as it moves to end white-minority rule. The reports, quoting official sources, said South Africa expects to establish formal relations with several black nations by the end of the year, but did not say which ones. South Africa has full diplomatic relations with just one black African nation, Malawi, and trade missions in Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Swaziland and Lesotho. The reports did not say which nations might extend diplomatic ties, but the Ivory Coast and Zaire reportedly are considering such a move. In addition to Mobutu, de Klerk will meet Saturday with President Hissen Habre of Chad; President Major Gen. Juvenal Habyarimana of Rwanda; President Pierre Buyoya of Burundi; and President Gen. Andre Kolingba of the Central African Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu, Bolstered by Election, Prepares New Cabinet Lineup
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, bolstered by what he called a vote of confidence in parliamentary elections, today discussed with other governing party leaders a new lineup for the Cabinet. Members of the conservative Liberal Democratic Party's powerful executive and general councils tendered their resignations at meetings this morning, clearing the way for Kaifu and party powerbrokers to begin negotiations for the top Cabinet and party posts. Party leaders also discussed strategies for battling the opposition over taxes and the budget when Parliament convenes later this month. Before Sunday's election for the lower house of Parliament, Kaifu's position had appeared shaky. He has a weak personal power base in the party and there were doubts about the Liberal Democrats' chances, tarnished as they were by an influence-peddling scandal and an unpopular sales tax. Pressed by reporters, he said he would resign, after just six months in office, if the party failed to retain at least 257 of the 512 seats in the powerful lower house. But with 275 seats won in the election and 14 conservative independents likely to join them later, the Liberal Democrats are not far behind the 295 seats they held in the outgoing house. The leading opposition Socialists won 136 seats, up from 83. Though the combined opposition fell far short of ousting the Liberal Democrats in the lower house, it holds a majority in the upper house, which must give its assent to most bills passed by the more powerful chamber. The lower house can name the prime minister, pass the budget and approve treaties without upper house assent. Kaifu said the election result ``absolved'' the party of its taint of scandal, and promptly declared that he would serve out his two-year term as party president. ``We started when the party was said to be in the greatest crisis since it was formed,'' Kaifu told reporters. ``The result of the election is a vote of confidence of the people under the constitution, and our government has passed it.'' The Liberal Democrats have held power since 1955. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe told reporters today that President Bush has congratulated Kaifu in a letter on the election results. Bush's letter said he hoped both governments would continue to cooperate closely in promoting their partnership. Analysts say Kaifu's staying power will face several tough tests _ including how he deals with Japan's chronic trade surplus with the United States _ in the coming months, and that it is possible he might misstep and become vulnerable again. If he does, a more powerful figure within the Liberal Democratic Party, former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe, is widely thought to be preparing to try to replace him. Kaifu, 59, became prime minister in August when the Liberal Democrats were on the ropes after the resignations of two prime ministers amid sex and money scandals and a big loss in the July elections for the upper house. He came from a small faction in the party, had no personal clout, and looked as if he could easily be the scapegoat if anything went wrong. Kaifu's main opponent, Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi, was also strengthened after Sunday's polling, and vowed to continue her struggles against the governing party. She attributed the elections results to the Liberal Democrats' backing by big business and their powerful political machines, built up over more than three decades in power. Voters re-elected major Liberal Democrats tainted by the scandal in which numerous politicians profited from cut-rate stocks in a subsidiary of the business information firm Recruit Co. They included former Prime Ministers Yasuhiro Nakasone, 72, and Noboru Takeshita, 65, as well as a handful of ex-Cabinet ministers. Nakasone ran as an independent.

DOC.HEAD: Magistrate Rules Journalist's Death Homicide
DOC.TEXT: A magistrate today ruled that homicide was the cause of death of a Sri Lankan reporter for a foreign news agency whose body washed ashore two days after he was abducted. Richard de Zoysa, 33, correspondent for the Rome-based Inter Press Service was abducted Saturday from his Colombo home by six armed men in a jeep normally used by police, his mother, Dr. Manorami Saravanamuttu, told acting Magistrate Jinapriya Peduruhewa. De Zoysa, whose body washed ashore Monday at Moratuwa, 10 miles south of Colombo, had two bullet wounds, one on the neck and the other on his forehead, said Peduruhewa. He was the first journalist working for a foreign news agency to be slain in Sri Lanka since ultra-nationalist Sinhalese revolted against the Sinhalese-dominated government in 1987. Police said Monday they suspected he was abducted by Sinhalese militants, who oppose the government for its offer of autonomy to minority Tamils. But police today said they were unable to name a particular group in the slaying. De Zoysa had written several articles on the Sinhalese uprising for Sri Lankan newspapers. The family had said a military official initially told them de Zoysa had been taken for questioning by the military, but later the family was informed de Zoysa was not being held by the army. A senior Defense Ministry official on Monday also denied de Zoysa was in military custody. ``I do not know why my son was killed,'' Mrs. Saravanamuttu told reporters after the inquest. ``I am lucky my son was well known,'' she said. ``I was able to see his body and will be able to bury him. There are hundreds of other mothers whose sons just disappear and nothing heard after that.'' Authorities blamed Sinhalese extremists from the People's Liberation Front for the killings of three employees of the government-owned television station last year. At least 6,000 people have been killed in hit-and-run attacks by the militants and retaliation by the police and army since the uprising began.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Gets Injunction at Armory Standoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sheriff, state officials due in court 2 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: A sheriff who commandeered a National Guard armory to ease overcrowding at the county jail won initial approval for the action from a judge. Superior Court Judge John F. Moriarty on Monday issued a temporary restraining order prohibiting the state from evicting Sheriff Michael Ashe and 15 prisoners from the armory. Moriarty also ordered armory commander Col. William Whitman to give Ashe keys to the building's showers and kitchen. Ashe's deputies have been transporting the prisoners to the Hampden County jail for showers and food has been brought into the armory. Ashe also wants access to the armory telephone, said his lawyer, Edward J. McDonough Jr. ``Our feeling is that what the sheriff has done is lawful,'' McDonough said. Ashe took over the armory ``to keep the peace in Hampden County ... to keep sentenced convicts off the street.'' McDonough said Ashe and state officials would appear in court today to discuss a final solution to the conflict. Ashe's move was sparked by Westfield District Judge Philip Contant's decision to detain two Hampden County deputies for five hours after they refused to take a prisoner to the overcrowded Jail, built to hold 279 inmates. A federal judge ordered that no more than 500 inmates may be housed in the jail. That cap was exceeded this week, and sheriff's spokesman Richard McCarthy said the usual remedies of early release, late sentencing and housing prisoners elsewhere in Massachusetts had not provided enough space. A new prison in nearby Ludlow has been approved but will take two to three years to build. McCarthy blamed the jail space crisis on tougher sentencing laws combined with the public's reluctance to finance jails or live near them. ``My belief is that what we have in Hampden County is a real perfect microcosm of the whole national dilemma,'' McCarthy said. ``There's no constituency for corrections. Liberals find it distasteful and conservatives find any commitment of resources to be coddling.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The headline should not be, `All Foods Cause Cancer' or `Drop Dead. Don't Eat.' The good news is, let us not as a nation focus just on the technological food additives. We ought to focus on the big issues as well.'' _ Dr. Frank Young, deputy assistant secretary of health and human services, on a new federal estimate that natursl cancer-causing chemicals may pose a greater health danger than pesticides and other pollutants.

``It was horrifying.'' _ Pierre LaBossiere, a reporter who saw three of the four would-be rescuers fall into the frigid waters of California's Convict Lake while trying to save three teen-agers who plunged through the ice. None of the seven reappeared.

``I've been around a while, and I think I can tell grass roots from AstroTurf.'' _ Lane Kirkland, AFL-CIO president, insinuating that letters urging union officials to take no stand on abortion were not from rank-and-file union members but a national Right to Life Committee letter-writing campaign.

DOC.HEAD: New Bishop Named for Nation's Fifth-Largest Diocese
DOC.TEXT: Bishop Thomas V. Daily of Palm Beach, Fla., will succeed Brooklyn Bishop Francis J. Mugavero as spiritual leader of the nation's fifth-largest diocese, the U.S. Catholic Conference announced. Mugavero submitted his resignation to Pope John Paul II in June after turning 75, the church's retirement age. Daily's appointment is effective immediately, the conference said in a statement issued Monday. There are more than 1.5 million Catholics in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, fifth largest of 185 Catholic dioceses and archdioceses in the United States. Pope Paul VI named Mugavero to head the diocese in 1968. Born in Belmont, Mass., Daily, 62, was named the first bishop of the newly created diocese of Palm Beach in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower in early European trading today, and foreign currency dealers said they didn't expect much movement until the U.S. market reopens after Monday's Presidents Day holiday. Gold prices rose. ``It's all very trendless right now,'' said a currency trader at a U.S. bank in Frankfurt. ``No one has any really good idea of the direction.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar edged up 0.06 yen to a closing 144.58 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 145.10 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _ 1.6695 West German marks, down from 1.6765 _ 1.4828 Swiss francs, down from 1.4885 _ 5.6815 French francs, down from 5.6955 _ 1.8813 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8870 _ 1,240.50 Italian lire, down from 1,243.00 _ 1.1997 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1993 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.7089, compared with $1.7030 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $419.25 a troy ounce, up from $416.50 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $419.05. In Zurich, the bid price was $419.00, up from $416.60 late Monday. Bullion dealers said gold prices were pushed higher by a combination of continued dollar buying and an expected bout of buying by Japanese investors. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.26 to close at a bid $418.50. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.35 a troy ounce, from Monday's 5.33.

DOC.HEAD: Risk-Takers Most Effective School Leaders, Study Finds
DOC.TEXT: Principals who broke traditions and ``refused to let bureaucracy strangle innovation'' were able to build better schools, a nationwide study concluded. Those principals also helped improve teacher and student satisfaction, according to the report released Monday at the National Association of Secondary School Principals' annual convention. ``Good principals are like Tom Cruise in `Top Gun' _ they are on the edge of what can be allowed out there. They're flying their jets upside down,'' said Leonard Pellicer, a member of the organization's study team that conducted the research. The study found a relationship between an individual school's success _ measured by students' eagerness to learn and staff satisfaction _ and the willingness of its principals and assistant principals to gamble on new ideas. Faculty stability also was an important factor. ``The more risks taken ... the better the outcomes,'' said the 97-page report, which examined the role of principals and their assistants at 74 schools nationwide during 1988. ``Risk-taking behavior is probably necessary because of the bureaucratic nature of schools and school districts. Principals were regularly frustrated with their inability to deal with problems unique to the local school,'' it said. ``They were forced to `go through channels.' The more successful principals often bypassed the red tape or acted pending approval. They simply refused to let bureaucracy strangle innovation.'' According to the report, four factors critical to a school's success were the degree of autonomy given the school by its district; amount of authority vested in the principal; degree of community support; and the competence, diversity and stability of the school staff. In cases where principals met resistance from a district, they sometimes exercised ``creative insubordination.'' ``It's easier to ask forgiveness than it is to ask permission,'' said Pellicer, director of the South Carolina Educational Policy Center and an education professor at the University of South Carolina. To deal with the disparate interests requires a principal who is more than the disciplinarian of yesteryear. ``When we started out with education in America, we basically brought kids to school and taught them reading, writing and arithmetic. Now we transport them, we feed them, give them career counseling, personal counseling. We discipline them, and develop them socially. Everything is so much more complicated and it takes a different kind of person to maintain a grasp of what's going on,'' Pellicer said. Others on the study team were James Keefe, the director of research for the Reston, Va.-based principals' association; Edgar Kelley, a professor in the Department of Educational Leadership at Western Michigan University; and Lloyd McCleary, a professor in the Department of Educational Administration at the University of Utah.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Shows Poles Oppose Reunified Germany
DOC.TEXT: A poll taken in eight Eastern and Western European countries indicates that only Poles fear the eventual reunification of Germany. When asked if they favored or opposed to the reunification of the two Germanys, 64 percent of Poles surveyed said they were either somewhat opposed or very opposed, in the results published in several newspapers Monday. Twenty-six percent said they were rather favorable or very favorable. By contrast, of the seven other countries polled, opposition was only 17 percent in West Germany, 6 percent in Spain, 23 percent in France, 27 percent in Britain, 13 percent in Italy, 22 percent in Hungary and 30 percent in the Soviet Union. Postwar II Poland includes some former German territory, while it lost some of its own land to the Soviet Union. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has promised that a unified Germany would not to lay claim to the lost territory, but he and other German leaders oppose Poland's request that it be granted a role with the four World War II Allies in the reunification process. The survey was coordinated by France's CSA Institute polling organization and involved a national sampling of people 18 years old or more in all of the countries except the Soviet Union, where the poll was carried out only in the Moscow region. In France, 1,024 people were questioned. Asked if they thought the evolution in Eastern Europe would guarantee a period of peace; not really lessen the risks; or possibly provoke a new world conflict; the Poles were the most wary with 56 percent saying risks were not really lessened and 19 percent saying a new conflict was possible. The second most cautious were the French, 50 percent of whom said the risks remained the same and 13 percent that conflict was possible. Altogether, eight polling organizations took part in the survey. The published poll provided no further details on how it was conducted or the margin for error.

DOC.HEAD: Davis, Battling Cancer, Reportedly Also Had Pneumonia
DOC.TEXT: Entertainer Sammy Davis Jr. is putting up a tough fight in his battle with a recurrence of throat cancer, his publicist said today, but she could not confirm a report that he also fought pneumonia. The Daily News in New York, quoting an unidentified source, reported today that the 64-year-old Davis developed pneumonia as a complication to his cancer treatment at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. The News said doctors were able to clear up the pneumonia infection last week. Davis' publicist, Susan Reynolds, said she could not confirm the report, and hospital spokesman Ron Wise said he also had no information about it. The versatile singer-dancer, whose career has stretched from poverty to the Las Vegas stage and motion pictures, was diagnosed as having throat cancer in September and re-entered the hospital a month ago after suffering a recurrence. ``He has been receiving treatment. He's able to walk around and is in touch with friends and family,'' Reynolds said. Davis has been inundated with letters and flowers from fans around the globe _ including a letter from Norway addressed simply, ``Sammy Davis Jr., USA,'' Ms. Reynolds said.

DOC.HEAD: More Snow in Southwest; Cold in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: The winter storm that struck the Southwest over the holiday weekend moved eastward today with snow expected in southern Colorado, the mountains of Arizona and New Mexico and the Oklahoma-Texas panhandle. Strong northerly winds brought snow squalls to parts of the Great Lakes and ushered arctic air into the Northeast. Flurries and wind chills as cold as minus 60 were expected. After several days of heavy rain that triggered severe flooding across the Southeast, showers abated along the rain-swollen Gulf Coast and the southern Atlantic Coast. But more rain was forecast today for the Florida peninsula, and for the Southeast later in the week. In the Pacific Northwest, rain fell along the coast and snow was expected in higher elevations of the Cascade Mountains. In the Southwest, New Mexico's mountains looked for 8 to 16 inches of fresh snowfall by late today A winter storm watch was posted for the state's middle and upper Rio Grande Valley. Colorado expected another 5 to 10 inches of snow in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains. Snow advisories were called for the San Juan Mountains and the Four Corners area. Up to 15 inches of snow in the Texas Panhandle was possible by Wednesday morning. Humid gulf air should mix with the storm front to spawn rain Wednesday in east Texas and Louisiana. The holiday weekend storm in the Southwest left Williams, Ariz., under 22 inches of snow and Flagstaff beneath 18 inches. The Grand Canyon's southern rim received 17 inches. Snow fell today in the lower Great Lakes, northern New England and upstate New York. Lows of about 15 below and wind chills as cold as minus 60 were expected tonight in northern Maine. The temperature in Reno, Nev., fell Monday to a record low of 7 below, breaking the 87-year-mark by 14 degrees. Other record lows for the date included 39 in Oakland, Calif., and 33 in San Jose, Calif. Tucson, Ariz., received six-tenths of an inch of snow Monday for un unprecedented fifth measurable snowfall of the winter. Record high temperatures set for Feb. 19 were 55 degrees in Bridgeport, Ct., and 89 in Lakeland, Fla. _ the nation's high for the day. DOC.HEAD: Lava Flow Threatens More Homes on Hawaii Island
DOC.TEXT: Civil defense officials have an around-the-clock watch on a lava flow from the Kilauea Volcano that is threatening to overrun a 125-home residential area. Another lava flow from the volcano already has destroyed one home and threatened four others. Residents of the Kalapana subdivision met with Hawaii County officials Monday to discuss evacuation procedures as lava came within three-quarters of a mile of the development, said Bruce Butts, assistant administrator of Hawaii Island Civil Defense. ``We're in a wait-and-see pattern to see what direction the flow will take,'' he said. Meanwhile, a separate flow from the volcano that toppled an abandoned home Saturday went around a second home Monday but continued to pose a threat to the four remaining homes in the isolated Royal Gardens subdivision, said Butts. Kilauea has claimed 75 homes in Royal Gardens and the neighboring communities of Kalapana and Kapa`ahu since the eruption began Jan. 3, 1983. Jack Minassian, fire management officer at Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, said Monday the flow forced the evacuation of two residents by helicopter on Sunday. Royal Gardens was composed of 1,500 one-acre lots sold in the 1970s. About 60 homes were built. More than half of the homes have been destroyed. Kilauea has caused more than $20 million in damage since the eruption began. It has engulfed 2{ miles of roads, two miles of water lines and two miles of utility lines.

DOC.HEAD: Britain To Press European Community To Drop Ban On South African Investment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with meeting beginning, compromise possible. Picks up 5th pvs, `The foreign...'
DOC.TEXT: Britain today pressed fellow European Community members to drop the wealthy trading bloc's ban on new investment in South Africa, hinting that it might otherwise lift the embargo unilaterally. But as the meeting began in the medieval Dublin Castle, Irish sources suggested that as a compromise, the community could send a fact-finding team to South Africa to determine whether the white-led government's reform program warrants easing the embargoes. The team would likely consist of officials from France, Ireland and Italy _ possessors of the past, present and next European Community presidents, the sources said. The presidency of the 12-nation organization rotates every six months. Earlier, Irish officials said British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd appeared isolated in his demand for an immediate easing of sanctions. The community's Commissioner for External Relations, Frans Andriessen, added in an Irish Radio interview that the one-day meeting ``will not be easy. But there might be much more understanding than people believe there to be.'' The foreign ministers also were expected to focus on rapid moves toward German unification. Ireland announced last week that it would call a special European Community summit in April because of the pace of developments. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, the West's most outspoken opponent of sanctions against South Africa, argues that the community's relatively mild embargoes should be lifted gradually to reward the white-led government's reforms. She also says that unless South Africa's president, F.W. de Klerk, can show some international response to his legalizing of the African National Congress and release of Nelson Mandela this month, he may be toppled by a white backlash. Mrs. Thatcher unilaterally lifted academic and cultural restrictions when de Klerk announced his reforms this month. She moved again, saying Britain would encourage such contacts, when ANC leader Mandela was released Feb. 11. Apart from Britain, the community includes three of South Africa's other major trading partners: West Germany, Italy and France. Hurd, in angry exchanges with opposition legislators in the British Parliament last week, said that if there is no agreement in Dublin, ``the government must reserve its right to act on its own if necessary.'' Mrs. Thatcher has said she will not drop unilaterally binding embargoes agreed on by the community in 1986. They consist mainly of bans on the imports of iron, steel and Krugerrand gold coins. Other, non-binding embargoes, which Mrs. Thatcher wants lifted quickly, are bans on the promotion of tourism, on new government loans to South African agencies and state funding of trade missions to South Africa. Britain has been at the center of fierce disputes over South African sanctions at meetings of the Commonwealth, the largely Third World association of Britain and its former colonies. The community, however, showed little enthusiasm for tightening embargoes after 1986 and its measures are far less comprehensive than those imposed by the United States. In the past two years, South African exports to the European Community have more than doubled to nearly $15 billion. International Monetary Fund statistics show West Germany is South Africa's largest trading partner, followed by Japan, Britain, the United States, Italy and France. Mandela, who has called for continued embargoes until apartheid is dismantled, said from his home in Soweto Monday that Britain's policy on sanctions was of ``primary importance.'' He said he planned to telephone Mrs. Thatcher about it after putting an undisclosed plan to fellow leaders of the ANC.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Shoots Two UCLA Medical Center Employees, Kills One
DOC.TEXT: Police continued to search today for a gunman who strode into an office at the UCLA Medical Center and opened fire, killing one employee and seriously wounding a second. The motive and identity of the killer remained a mystery, but police said he appeared to know his way around the labyrinthine medical center and seemed to have ``knowledge of a victim and a room.'' The shooting occurred in the hospital's patient-escort dispatch office at 5:40 a.m. Monday. The office is away from patient rooms in an area where laboratories and other offices are located. Diondra Ann Picou, 22, of Gardena, died of multiple gunshots to the chest and Norma S. Arellano, 30, of Los Angeles, underwent surgery for multiple gunshot wounds and was in serious condition. Police said the gunman, carrying a large caliber handgun, opened an unlocked door to the office and opened fire. ``The suspect had a pretty good knowledge of where that particular room is located. We don't think this was a random incident,'' said police Lt. Ron Hall. Ms. Picou, who had worked as a patient escort for six months, was struck in the chest as she sat at a table. Arellano, a 10-year medical center employee, was shot several times in the leg and torso, Hall said. Ms. Arellano managed to telephone a co-worker, who summoned campus police, Hall said. UCLA campus police were able to question Arellano before she was taken into surgery, he said. Access to the hospital is restricted from 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. and employees must show identification badges to guards before entering. But the restrictions are lifted at 5 a.m., said hospital spokesman Rich Elbaum. UCLA campus police, who also were investigating, refused to comment on the shooting.

DOC.HEAD: 14 Injured In Explosion At Steel Works
DOC.TEXT: Leaking gas from a steel works furnace erupted in a fireball today, injuring 14 workers, two seriously, police said. The plant, at Port Kembla on the east coast of New South Wales state, sustained minimal damage, said a spokesman for BHP, which operates the facility. Police and hospital officials said most of the injured were hurt by flying glass while walking on a road outside the coke oven. BHP officials determined leaking gas was the cause of the blast and said they expected operations to resume later in the day. An explosion at the Port Kembla plant in 1975 killed three people.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Companies Agree to Voluntary Safeguards for Tankers
DOC.TEXT: The grounding of three cargo ships along the stretch of coral reefs off the Florida Keys has led to an agreement by owners of 60 oil tankers to keep six miles away from the fragile reefs. Fifteen of the nation's largest oil companies agreed Monday to put more distance between their tankers and the 200-mile-long barrier reefs to guard against grounding and oil spills, said Gov. Bob Martinez. ``The coral reefs will be a much safer place,'' Martinez told reporters. There were no spills from the three groundings last fall. Some 60 tankers regularly transit the Straits and about 250 other vessels occasionally passing through will stay outside the buffer zone. Some tankers carry as much as 21 million gallons of cargo. The agreement, which takes effect April 1, will increase the cost of traveling the route, said Amoco Transport Co. President Ed Roland, but the buffer zone will give cleanup crews considerably more time to contain a spill. He could not estimate the extra costs. Roland, who is chairman of the Marine Transportation Committee of the American Petroleum Institute, called the agreement ``a major step in further safeguarding the southern Florida environment.'' Under the agreement, the ships will stay 10 nautical miles, or 12 statute miles, from the shoreline and five nautical miles, or six statute miles, from the edge of the shallow reefs. Ships sailing from the Atlantic Ocean into the Gulf of Mexico often hug the corral banks to avoid the strong, fuel-eating currents of the Gulf Stream. ``Twenty-five percent of the (tanker) traffic will be more seaward than it is today,'' Martinez said.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Clash With Police Outside Parliament; 80 Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with 80 injured, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TPE1
DOC.TEXT: Rock-throwing protesters demanding greater democracy battled club-wielding riot police around the Legislature today, burning police vans and smashing windows. At least 80 people were injured, authorities said. The violence broke out after about 1,000 demonstrators gathered outside the Legislature to harass aging lawmakers of the governing Nationalist Party entering the building to elect a new speaker of the Legislature. The demonstrators, mostly supporters of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, demanded that the aging politicians, who last faced election on the Chinese mainland more than 40 years ago and dominate the assembly, be replaced by Taiwan-elected lawmakers. Police said the clash erupted when police tried to disperse protesters who battered a taxi they suspected of carrying an elderly legislator. Police said protesters burned two police vans, damaged 10 others, overturned six police cars and smashed several cars carrying the elderly lawmakers. Chiang Kung-liang, a 77-year-old legislator, fainted in the chamber and was rushed to a hospital for intensive care. Riot police, numbering more than 2,000, swung clubs and shields to break up the crowd, which fought back with rocks and placards. Police arrested three men, blood streaming down their faces, and later released them. The two-hour clash ended when an additional 500 riot police backed by water cannon arrived at the legislature. Police said about 50 policemen were injured by rocks thrown by the demonstrators, and about 30 protesters were also wounded in the clashes. Officials of the opposition party said at least five demonstrators were hospitalized with head injuries. Inside the building, 21 Democratic Progressive Party legislators raised procedural issues during a 10-hour debate, forcing the election of the speaker to be postponed a week. The Nationalist Party, whose members control the assembly, has nominated veteran politician Liang Shu-jung, 69, to be the speaker in an attempt to appease old guard conservatives in the party. The opposition party has 21 of the 283 seats in the Legislature, while 143 legislators were elected in China before the Nationalist government fled to Taiwan in 1949 upon losing a civil war to Communist forces. They have been frozen in office in support of the Nationalist claim to still be the legitimate ruler of all China.

DOC.HEAD: Out-of-Court Settlement Reached in Store Collapse Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A $33.1 million out-of-court lawsuit settlement will be shared by the families of most of those who died or were injured in the 1988 collapse of a Brownsville department store, attorneys said. The three-story Amigo Store came crashing down the afternoon of July 7, 1988, during a torrential thunderstorm in the border city, killing 14 and injuring several dozen others. Many of those injured or killed were from Matamoros, Mexico, just across the Rio Grande from downtown Brownsville. John Lewis, a lawyer who represented plaintiffs suing on behalf of families of four of the dead and four of the injured, said a committee of plaintiffs' lawyers arrived at the agreement Monday with the last of nine defendants. The case had not gone to trial. Litigation was still in the discovery phase in which investigators review evidence and witnesses give depositions, Lewis said. Monday's settlement was for the families of 13 who died and 32 who were injured, according to attorney Mark Cantu, who also represented some of the plaintiffs. Others among the injured have reached independent settlements, Cantu said. The family of one of the dead did not sue, he added. Defendants included Amigo Stores Inc., Brownsville's Public Utilities Board, the city of Brownsville, and several construction companies and materials suppliers, Cantu said. The store site is now a parking lot. The defendants' insurance companies have agreed to pay varying amounts, depending on the percentage of liability attributed to them in the settlement, Cantu said. The amounts range from $100,000 to $10 million, he said. Attorneys for the defendants were not in their offices late Monday and could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Precede CLARK AIR BASE
Cheney to Seek Boost in Japanese Support for U.S. Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 7 grafs new with Cheney arrival in Tokyo; picks up at pvs 4th graf, ``I also''
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney flew here today for talks aimed at boosting Japan's financial support for American forces stationed in Japan, as Philippines President Corazon Aquino signaled a new willingness to discuss differences over compensation for U.S. bases in her country. ``The Japanese are very understanding and are very willing to help us as much as they can,'' said a Pentagon official traveling with Cheney, speaking on condition of anonymity. The official said that in his three days of talks, Cheney did not intend to deal in specific figures with the Japanese, who each year provide around $2.4 billion of the $7 billion it costs to base 50,000 U.S. troops here. However, he said, ``We're confident they understand our requirements ... we're hopeful that over the years, we'll see a sizeable increase in Japanese support for U.S. forces here.'' Cheney, on a two-week tour that also took him to Hawaii, South Korea and Hong Kong, arrived in Tokyo from Clark Air Base in the Philippines, stopping briefly on the Japanese island of Okinawa to tour American bases. Mrs. Aquino had snubbed Cheney during his two-day visit to the Philippines, but she sounded a more concilatory note in a statement issued as the defense secretary ended his visit. ``I welcome the statement of support for this government and Philippine democracy made by Secretary Cheney on behalf of the United States,'' she said. ``I also welcome his reiteration that the United States will make its best efforts to meet its pledge for foreign assistance,'' she added, referring to the $96 million shortfall in the $481 million in aid the Bush administration promised for the use of six military bases. Mrs. Aquino said the problem ``appears to be with the U.S. Congress and its funding priorities. But we are as ready as the Americans to discuss these difficulties in sincerity and good faith.'' Talks on the future of the bases, whose lease expires in September 1991, are expected to begin in April. Columnist Manuel Martinez wrote in the independent newspaper The Manila Times today that Americans were exploiting the Philippines. ``When you think of your visit here, Mr. Cheney, remember you are coming to a country whom you massively looted and maimed and occupied,'' Martinez said. ``And what do you do to the ordinary Filipino? You destabilize his democratic government. You bamboozle his lady president. You wring his neck with foreign debts.'' On Monday, Cheney met with Philippine defense officials angry over what they believe is American failure to honor commitments made in 1988 to maintain the bases. Cheney told them the United States will abandon its bases in the Philippines if it finds that keeping them is too expensive or that Americans are unwelcome. The United States ``will stay only as long as the Philippine people wish it to stay _ and only if the terms negotiated are acceptable to both parties,'' Cheney told reporters after the meeting. Mrs. Aquino was so upset over the cut in U.S. aid made by Congress that she announced before Cheney began his trip that she would not see him, leaving that task to her defense minister, Fidel Ramos. Security was tight during the brief visit to Clark Air Base, where Cheney inspected U.S. military aircraft. Last September, communist rebels killed two American civilian employees of Camp O'Donnell, about 15 miles north of the base, on the day Vice President Dan Quayle arrived in Manila. On Monday, about 300 leftists clashed with police during a demonstration at the base demanding that Clark and the five other U.S. bases be closed. Police also dispersed about 200 protesters in front of the U.S. Embassy in Manila. ``We recognize there is a shortfall of $96 million over what we had anticipated,'' Cheney said after meeting with Ramos. ``I also pointed out that in East Asia, in this part of the world, the United States provided a little over $600 million, and about $500 million of that comes specifically to the Philippines.'' An influential Filipino minority is pressuring Mrs. Aquino not to renew the agreement. In addition, leading Filipino congressmen have urged her to postpone those discussions until this year's cuts are restored. There are about 18,000 U.S. military personnel in the Philippines, plus 20,000 dependents. Ramos acknowledged that the Bush administration needs congressional approval for aid commitments but said he had told Cheney that ``time is of the essence'' in meeting current U.S. obligations. The secretary said Ramos had been ``very direct and very forthright'' in presenting his government's position. Asked whether he could say that his government wanted the base to remain, Ramos declined to answer the question, saying the issue was under discussion in the Philippine Congress. U.S. war jets from Clark flew air cover for government forces during the coup attempt, and it is widely believed the move was decisive in crushing the rebellion. Cheney, who heads back to Washington on Saturday, is touring the Asian nations with U.S. bases in preparation for an April 1 assessment he is to give Congress on the nation's military posture in the Pacific. He has been telling officials in each nation that there is a limit to the Pentagon pocketbook and that budget pressures may force 10 percent to 12 percent cutbacks in U.S. military forces based in Japan, South Korea and the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: African Foreign Ministers Meeting In Ethiopia
DOC.TEXT: Africa must face the future expecting less economic aid as the West turns its attention toward Eastern Europe, Africa's foreign ministers were told today. ``The rapid changes in Eastern Europe have drastically altered the political thinking and strategic considerations of the West,'' said Salim Ahmed Salim, secretary general of the Organization of African Unity. ``The need for our economic unity is made all the more urgent in the face of the shift of priority by the West to Eastern Europe,'' he told the ministers, who met on the second day of their annual five-day conference. Abebayo Adedeji, executive secretary of the U.N. Economic Commission for Africa, also urged the foreign ministers to prepare for the future. ``We should be ready for a new political world map and we should be prepared to fit into that new map, not as a residual component but as a full and essential part of it,'' he said.
