Some African leaders have expressed concern that Western nations would abandon the continent and divert aid they previously gave Africans to Eastern Europe, where Communist hard-liners have been replaced by reformist leaders. Another item on the agenda is political changes in South Africa, where President F.W. De Klerk recently legalized the African National Congress and freed prison Nelson Mandela, the best known of the liberation movement's leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Let Them Eat Grass, Cuban Ambassador Says
DOC.TEXT: Cubans would rather eat grass than McDonald's hamburgers to preserve the purity of their Communist revolution, a Cuban diplomat was quoted as saying today. ``We don't have McDonald's in Cuba, but nobody's starving,'' Ambassador Elises Estrada Lescaille said in today's editions of the daily newspaper Horizons. ``We'll eat grass, if necessary, to defend our revolution.'' Lescaille appeared to be referring to the recent opening of a McDonald's restaurant in Moscow. The hamburger chain's Big Macs and fries were well-received by Muscovites. Relations between Cuba and the Soviet Union have grown strained in recent months as President Fidel Castro insists on retaining the hard-line communism rejected by Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Perestroika, Gorbachev's program of restructuring Soviet political and economic life, ``cannot be applied in all countries,'' Lescaille told the newspaper. ``The problem with the U.S.S.R. isn't with the Communist Party or the government but with the forces that have sprung up along with perestroika,'' he said. The Cuban ambassador said it was possible that Moscow could renege on its aid agreement with the Castro government in 1990, but that so far all pledges had been fulfilled, the newspaper reported. Cuba is heavily dependent on Soviet economic aid and there have been signs the $5 billion in annual assistance is being pared. Lescaille said Cuba enjoys good relations with China and praised the late Communist Party chairman Mao Tse-Tung as ``a great leader,'' the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Students Protest Ouko Slaying; Scotland Yard Asked to Investigate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th pvs, `Scotland yard...' to CLARIFY detectives from London police.
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 students marched in the streets of the capital today and hijacked two buses to demand an impartial investigation into the slaying of Kenya's foreign minister, police said. The demonstration came a day after the government issued its first detailed report on the death of the minister, Robert Ouko, and announced two British detectives and a pathologist were joining the investigation. The students, from the University of Nairobi and Kenyatta University, were demonstrating for a fourth day. The protesters carried green branches and chanted ``Who killed Bob?'' ``No cover-up!'' and ``We want justice!'' They taunted police with shouts of ``Where were you?'' Police on Friday discovered Ouko's partially burned body in the brush, about four miles from his family farm in Koru, near Lake Victoria in western Kenya. He had been missing for four days. The students _ estimated by one police officer to number 1,000 _ gathered today around the statue of Kenya's first president after independence, Jomo Kenyatta, in the heart of the capital. They then marched past government offices and demanded that Hezekiah Oyugi, the permanent secretary in the Office of the President, resign. Oyugi is in charge of internal security. The students commandeered two buses, which were driven to Ouko's suburban Nairobi residence. The British investigation team comprises Superintendent John Troon and Inspector Graham Dennis of Scotland Yard and Dr. Ian West, the government said late Monday. The move was seen in part as a government attempt to allay fears of a cover-up. Since Kenya gained independence, the murders of three prominent politicians have gone unsolved and the former Kenyatta government was accused of covering them up. Scotland Yard is the commonly used name for the London police. Kenya is a former British colony and its security personnel continue to receive training from Britons. Ouko disappeared one week ago, apparently without telling colleagues or family members. His disappearance was reported two days later. The government on Monday said pathologists found a bullet hole in the 58-year-old minister's head. In a statement, it said police also found a .38-caliber revolver near Ouko's right hand, and the Central Firearms Bureau, which licenses guns, identified the weapon as belonging to the minister. Near his body, police also found a gas can and a plastic bag containing a pair of jeans, a shirt, and a leather jacket. The jacket pockets contained four bullets and Kenyan currency equivalent to $18. The clothes were identified as belonging to Ouko, and a storeman said the gas can resembled one previously stored at the minister's home, the statement said. Ouko was considered one of the most articulate and able members of President Daniel arap Moi's Cabinet. He first served as permanent secretary in the Foreign Ministry in 1963 when Kenya gained independence from Britain. Ouko later held other high-ranking government jobs before being tapped by Moi to head the Foreign Ministry in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: West German Ambassador Tells Jewish Audience: `Trust Us'
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's U.S. ambassador, acknowledging Jewish concerns about German reunification, told American Jewish leaders that Germans would stand up against any violations of human rights. But Monday's speech by Ambassador Jurgen Ruhfus met a skeptical response and repeated questions about what a new German state would do to ensure that centuries-old conflicts among Christians, Jews and Moslems would not explode. ``There is no guarantee,'' Ruhfus told about 500 delegates Monday at the national convention of the American Jewish Congress. ``But I can from my deepest convictions say that you can trust us,'' he said, prompting groans from the crowd in a hotel meeting room. ``You can count on Germans to stand up against any infringement of human rights.'' It was Ruhfus' first public address to a Jewish audience since serious discussions began of a union of East and West Germany. The ambassador said Germans have worked for four decades to ensure Nazi atrocities won't be repeated. The German state, he added, would be accountable not to nationalism but to a new European federation based on individual freedoms and human rights. ``We Germans are aware that a Germany growing together will be viewed in part with concern, with considerable concern,'' he said. ``We are convinced that this fear is unjustified.'' Henry Siegman, executive director of the American Jewish Congress, said afterward that Jewish concerns in the aftermath of the Holocaust ``are not easily susceptible to dissipation by some simple, even rational, political formula.'' However, he added, ``To the extent that a Jewish audience can be reassured that the German political leaders understand their concerns ... the ambassador's presentation was extremely well-received and considered reassuring.'' Ruhfus said West Germany has accepted responsibility for the Hitler era deaths of some 12 million people, including 6 million Jewish victims of the Holocaust. ``I understand the feelings of those who have suffered,'' Ruhfus said. ``If we want to shape the future, we must be aware of the past.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Allows Funds Withheld From States Not Complying with Speed Limit
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today allowed the federal government to withhold highway funds from states that do not comply with a national speed limit. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by Nevada officials who want to set the speed limit at 70 mph on some state highways. Congress established a 55 mph national speed limit in 1973 in response to the Arab oil embargo. The law was aimed at conserving oil, although it also was endorsed as a safety measure. The limit was raised to 65 mph in 1987 for rural highways. That move blunted most protests, primarily from Western states, over the 55 mph limit. The 1987 law affects about three-fourths of the 43,000-mile interstate system, and makes another 7,000 miles of federal, state and local highways eligible for the 65 mph limit. Most states raised the speed limit to 65 mph on affected rural roads after Congress allowed it. The Nevada Legislature in 1985 increased the state's limit to 70 mph, and in 1986 that limit was posted on a 33-mile stretch of Interstate 80. But the higher speed limit was withdrawn when federal officials threatened to cut off highway aid to the state. Nevada officials then sued in federal court, saying the state had no real choice but to comply with the national speed limit because otherwise it would lose about 95 percent of its highway funds. The state officials said the national limit violates the Constitution by coercing compliance by the states. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last August rejected the state's arguments. ``The impropriety of making judicial judgments regarding a state's financial capabilities renders the coercion theory highly suspect,'' the appeals court said. It noted that Nevada, one of several states with no income tax, could increase its tax revenue to make up for a cut-off in federal funds. Moreover, the appeals court said, Congress could order states to adhere to a national speed limit _ not merely cut off funds for non-compliance. The appeals court relied in part on a 1987 Supreme Court ruling that upheld a federal law threatening to reduce highway aid to states that refused to adopt a minimum drinking age of 21. The case is Nevada vs. Skinner, 89-686.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses To Hear Colorado Appeal In Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: Colorado lost a high-stakes fight today with the federal government over money and other property seized from drug traffickers as the Supreme Court refused to hear the state's appeal. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that the proceeds of drug transactions automatically are forfeited to the federal government. In the case that had been appealed, the government later transferred nearly all the money to local police departments. The case involved $1.5 million in cash and gold bars. Colorado Attorney General Duane Woodward had contended that a state's claim on such money and property to satisfy owed taxes sometimes should take precedence. Police in Lakewood, Colo., seized the cash and 12 gold bars from the home of Albert and Victoria Levy during a Nov. 21, 1982 search. The money and gold were the proceeds of a cocaine deal. The next month, state tax authorities assessed taxes totaling $194,000 against Albert Levy based on alleged narcotics sales of almost $3 million in 1982. A state judge, ruling on a tax lien imposed, said the money could come from the seized proceeds. Federal authorities, meanwhile, went into a federal court in Denver seeking forfeiture of the seized loot. They said a 1978 law gave the federal government a superior claim to the proceeds because forfeiture dates back to the commission of the crime. U.S. District Judge John Kane Jr. ruled that part of the state's tax lien should be paid from the cocaine deal proceeds, but Justice Department lawyers appealed his ruling. The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last April 21 reversed Judge Kane's ruling, and ordered that all the proceeds be forfeited to the federal government. The appeals court ruled that the 1978 law permits a federal claim to seized drug-trafficking proceeds at the time a crime was committed, which always will come before a state's attempt to attach a tax lien. In the state's appeal, Woodward said the appeals court ruling unduly interferes with state taxing powers. The appeal also argued that the federal forfeiture law was ``permissive,'' not mandatory. Bush administration lawyers urged the court to reject the state's appeal, noting that Congress in 1984 amended the law to say explicitly that ``the interest of the United States vests at the time of the act giving rise to the forfeiture.'' They argued also that the forfeiture law is mandatory. Last October, Judge Kane ordered the cash and gold bars released to the federal government. Last Dec. 7, U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh authorized transfer of about 90 percent of the forfeited property's value to five police and sheriff's departments in Colorado. The Lakewood Police Department received the bulk, 63 percent, of the revenue-sharing transfer. The case is Colorado v. U.S., 89-699.

DOC.HEAD: Apartment Owner, Manager Settle Discrimination Lawsuit for $450,000
DOC.TEXT: The owners and managers of an apartment complex have agreed to pay a record $450,000 to settle a lawsuit accusing them of discriminating against blacks, attorneys said. The out-of-court agreement, made Friday but announced Monday, followed an undercover investigation by a housing rights group and is one of the largest ever in a housing discrimination case. ``Racial discrimination is still a very entrenched problem in this country,'' said Patrick O. Patterson, an attorney for the plaintiffs. ``If you looked at the evidence in this case, attitudes that many people hoped would have been gone years ago are very much present.'' Until a 1988 amendment to the federal Fair Housing Act, punitive damages in such cases were limited to $1,000. The largest previous settlement in a housing discrimination case was $375,000 in a New York case which was appealed after a jury awarded $500,000 to the plaintiffs, according to the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund. In addition to the money, the defendants agreed to open the apartment complex to black residents, and the percentage of black renters has increased from 2 percent to 17 percent, Patterson said. The dispute began in October 1987 when Allan Lopez, 29, who is black, was refused permission to share the apartment of Robert Patrick O. Beaumont, 31, who is white. Managers at the Belford Park Apartments had Lopez fill out a rental application, then rejected him on grounds of his credit history, Patterson said. Many of the white tenants either had significantly worse credit histories than Lopez or were not required to fill out rental applications, the attorney said. The non-profit Westside Fair Housing Council sent three undercover investigators to the apartment complex to pose as prospective tenants. A black investigator was told there were no vacancies, while the two white investigators were told units were available, Patterson said. Lawsuits were filed in federal and state court against Los Angeles-based Westchester Investment Co., which owned the complex, Gutweiler-Woolley Properties, which managed it at the time, and a couple who were the on-site managers. The owners and mangers were not available for comment. Phone messages left with Westchester Investment's answering service were not returned, and there was no listing for Gutweiler-Woolley. The couple who managed the complex have moved out of state.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Hear Appeal in Pizza Connection Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to hear an appeal by a man convicted in the so-called pizza connection case in which prosecutors said tons of imported heroin and cocaine were distributed through a network of pizza parlors. The court, without comment, let stand the conviction and 30-year prison sentence of Filippo Casamento, who said he was only a peripheral figure in the drug ring. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last October upheld the convictions of Casamento and 14 other men convicted in 1987 in New York City after a 17-month trial, one of the longest and costliest in history. Federal prosecutors said the drug ring brought narcotics valued at $1.6 billion into the country from Turkey, Sicily and Brazil. All told, there were 21 defendants and numerous charges of conspiracy, racketeering, money laundering and other offenses on three continents dating back to the 1970s. Not all those convicted appealed to the 2nd Circuit court. In the appeal acted on today, Casamento's lawyers described him as a ``small fish caught up in a flood of evidence concerning Mafia wrongdoing and international narcotics dealings.'' They said his rights were violated because he was not tried separately. The 2nd Circuit court said that while it had misgivings about the length and complexity of the trial and the number of defendants, the rights of the accused were not violated. The appeals court also suggested some new guidelines, including possibly limiting the number of defendants if a joint trial is expected to last more than four months. As for Casamento, the appeals court said there was sufficient evidence for the jury to conclude he engaged in illegal drug deals. The leading defendants in the case were Gaetano Badalamenti, reputed former head of the Mafia in Sicily, and Salvatore Catalano, the ring's reputed New York boss. Both were sentenced to 45 years in prison. The case is Casamento vs. U.S., 89-1178.

DOC.HEAD: Director Spike Lee Has Pointed Remarks in Talk at Syracuse University
DOC.TEXT: Spike Lee may have been wearing a Georgetown University cap and sweatshirt, but he got a far warmer reception from Syracuse University students than he did from Academy Award voters. In a lecture and question-and-answer session Monday, Lee shrugged off the academy's icy treatment of his latest movie, ``Do the Right Thing,'' and blamed it on generational politics. The 1989 film, widely hailed by critics, received only two Academy Award nominations, and isn't being considered for best picture or best director. The academy's membership consists mainly of ``old people,'' the 32-year-old Lee said. He said they were ``a lot more comfortable with the black chauffeur in `Driving Miss Daisy''' than with the angry characters in his film. ``I still feel we made the best film of the year,'' he said. Asked if racism might have been involved in the academy nominations, Lee replied, ``Racism's involved in everything.'' Despite the cap and sweatshirt, Syracuse students welcomed him as one of their own. ``He's an African-American, one of the first ones to make it (as a producer and director), and he's addressing the issues and concerns affecting our community,'' Syracuse senior Deron Harris said. ``That's why we're so proud of him.''

DOC.HEAD: Protection Of Government Workers In Sex Abuse Cases Stands
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that shields government social workers from being sued for placing children in foster homes where they are sexually abused. The justices, without comment, refused to review a federal appeals court ruling that the social workers enjoy absolute immunity if their child-placement decisions were approved by a court. In a decision that set a legal precedent for nine Western states, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said social workers in such cases share the absolute immunity that shields judges, prosecutors and others in judicial proceedings. The scope of such judicial immunity was the sole issue before the high court in a case from Washington state. The justices last October let stand a different federal appeals courts ruling in a Maryland case that children who are abused by foster parents may not sue the government social workers who placed them in those homes. In that case, the appeals court did not rely on immunity. Instead, it ruled that child abuse by foster parents is private, not governmental, violence. The Supreme Court last year ruled that public officials may not be sued in federal court when their alleged gross negligence permits a child to be abused by a parent _ what the court called ``private violence.'' That decision said a state has no constitutional duty to protect people, including abused children, who are not in the state's custody. But it left undecided whether a constitutional duty exists to protect children from foster parents chosen by government officials. In the case acted on today, two caseworkers with the Washington Department of Social and Health Services were sued by three sisters who said they were repeatedly raped, sodomized and sexually assaulted by their foster father over an 18-month period in 1982-83. The girls were ages six, eight and 12 when the attacks allegedly began. The foster father, Lee Michael, subsequently was convicted of statutory rape and indecent liberties. He is serving a 55-year prison sentence. Michael was the girls' uncle. The girls' mother, who committed suicide in 1978, was a sister to Michael's wife. The girls' civil rights lawsuit named social workers Wanda Tyler and Mark Bronson as defendants. The suit alleged that the social workers had violated the girls' interest in being free from harm while in state custody. Ms. Tyler in the spring of 1982 placed one of the girls, all of whom were then residing with their father's parents in Richland, Wash., with Michael. Bronson, who took over the case from Ms. Tyler, placed the two other girls with Michael shortly thereafter. A federal trial judge refused to dismiss the suit, but the 9th Circuit court reversed that ruling last Sept. 6. Finding the social workers' role to be an integral one in the judicial process, the appeals court said they are entitled to absolute immunity. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for the girls noted that most foster care placements are court-approved and involve periodic court reviews. Federal law bars states from obtaining federal reimbursement for foster care if the placements are not court-approved. The appeals court ruling is binding law in Washington, Arizona, Alaska, California, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Nevada and Oregon. The case is Babcock vs. Tyler, 89-912.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lets Stand Ruling Limiting Authors' Rights
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact a ruling that drastically limits the right of authors to quote unpublished material such as diaries and letters. The court, without comment, refused to hear an appeal by a company that published a biography attacking the late L. Ron Hubbard, founder of the Church of Scientology. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in a ruling last April that was denounced by scholars, publishers and free-speech advocates, imposed strict limits on the use of quotations from unpublished material. The appeals court said federal copyright law generally bars use of such material without permission. The appeals court rejected arguments that the ban violates constitutionally protected free expression. The April ruling relied, in part, on an earlier 2nd Circuit court decision barring Random House from publishing a biography of author J.D. Salinger unless quotations from, and paraphrases of, Salinger's letters were deleted. Because of a technicality, the appeals court refused to block further publication of the Hubbard biography, entitled ``Bare-Faced Messiah.'' The appeals court said the copyright owners, who are affiliated with the Scientologists, waited too long to seek a court order blocking publication. Ironically, that made Henry Holt and Co., publisher of the biography, the technical winner before the appeals court. The company, nonetheless, filed the appeal acted on today. The appeal argued that Holt suffered damages because U.S. publication of ``Bare-Faced Messiah'' was blocked for nearly a year before the appeals court ruled. Moreover, the company said the principle is of overriding importance. It called the April ruling a grave threat to the publishing industry because the 2nd Circuit court is based in New York City, home to most of the nation's major book publishers. Lawyers for Holt said the ruling means the copyright law that was ``intended to promote the progress of the useful arts is now repeatedly being used to muzzle responsible biographers and historians.'' The publisher also said the Hubbard estate and the Scientologists were largely successful in ``using their copyright monopoly to manipulate the public perception of Mr. Hubbard and to prevent disclosure of the uncomfortable truth about a man who held himself out as a prophet.'' Numerous groups, such as the American Historical Association and the Authors Guild, supported the Holt appeal. ``Bare-Faced Messiah,'' written by Russell Miller, accuses Hubbard of fakery and deception. Holt said quoting from Hubbard's unpublished letters and diaries was intended to expose the church founder's lies. New Era Publications, a Danish corporation, is the church affiliate that holds the copyright on Hubbard's unpublished material. The case is Holt vs. New Era Publications, 89-869.

DOC.HEAD: Richard Chamberlain Series Scratched
DOC.TEXT: ``Island Son,'' a CBS television show starring Richard Chamberlain, is sinking rapidly into the Hawaiian sunset, says an actor in the locally filmed medical drama. Chamberlain learned the show was canceled Friday during a telephone conversation with Lorimar Productions in Los Angeles, said Glenn Cannon, who heads the local Screen Actors Guild and had a continuing role in the series. ``It was quite an enormous suprise and blow to everyone involved,'' Cannon said. ``There really was no warning at all, and the decision left a variety of people from Los Angeles scrambling to get back to the mainland and find other work.'' In New York City, CBS spokesman Michael Silver said he could not confirm the report. The cancellation would put an estimated 80 drivers, production crew and actors out of work. Members of the Interntional Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employees were told that Tuesday would be the last day of filming, an official of the organization said.

DOC.HEAD: Some Parents Suspected of Child Abuse May Be Jailed Indefinitely
DOC.TEXT: Parents suspected of child abuse may be jailed indefinitely for refusing to disclose the whereabouts of their children, the Supreme Court ruled today. The court said society's need to protect children from harm generally outweighs a parent's constitutional right against self-incrimination. By a 7-2 vote, the court upheld the indefinite jailing of a Maryland woman until she tells authorities where her young son can be found. The boy is feared dead. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, writing for the court, said forcing parents in such cases to reveal the whereabouts of children is aimed at protecting the children and not gathering incriminating evidence. ``Even when criminal conduct may exist, a court may properly request production and return of the child ... for reasons related entirely to the child's well-being and through measures unrelated to criminal law enforcement or investigation,'' O'Connor said. Justices William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall dissented. The court ruled against Jacqueline Bouknight, who has been in a Baltimore jail since April 1988 for refusing to disclose the whereabouts of her son, Maurice. The boy has been missing since September 1987, when he was 11 months old. Maurice was admitted to a Baltimore hospital on Jan. 23, 1987, when he was 3 months old, for treatment of a broken leg and other injuries. For a while, he was held in protective care after his emotionally troubled mother was observed throwing Maurice into his crib during the infant's hospitalization. Maurice was returned to his mother's custody on July 17, 1987, after she agreed not to punish him physically and to undergo training in parenting skills. Nine months later, social workers said Bouknight no longer was cooperating with them. Also, they said Maurice's father recently had been shot to death in a drug-related killing and Bouknight was using drugs. The mother was held in contempt of court by a judge on April 28, 1988, after she refused to disclose Maurice's whereabouts. But the Maryland Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, ruled in December that jailing her for refusing to disclose the information violates her constitutional protection against self-incrimination. She has remained in jail under an order by Chief Jusice William H. Rehnquist that suspended the effect of the state court ruling. Some compared the Bouknight case to that of Dr. Elizabeth Morgan of Washington, D.C., released from prison on Sept. 25 after more than two years behind bars for refusing to let her daughter visit the girl's father, Morgan's former husband. Morgan went to jail rather than produce the girl for court-ordered visits with the father. Morgan accused her former husband of sexually abusing the child, charges he repeatedly has denied. In the Bouknight case, O'Connor said the mother _ as custodian of a child officials have determined has been abused _ has an obligation to produce her son for authorities. ``These orders to produce children cannot be characterized as efforts to gain some testimonial component of the act of production,'' O'Connor said. ``Concern for the child's safety underlay the efforts to gain access to and then compel production of Maurice.'' She hinted that prosecutors may be barred from using any testimony Bouknight gives in producing the child. But Marshall, in his dissenting opinion, said that is little comfort now for the mother. ``I am not content to deny Bouknight the constitutional protection required ... now in the hope that she will not be convicted later on the basis of her own testimony,'' he said in an opinion joined by Brennan. The case is Baltimore Department of Social Services vs. Bouknight, 88-1182.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Want Crackdown on Rallies; Lithuanians Press Independence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with resolution to curb rallies; Pickup 13th graf pvs, `Although reporters ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Soviet legislature today urged a crackdown on illegal demonstrations planned for Sunday and said authorities should exercise tight control over permitted rallies, the official Tass news agency reported. The legislators said they feared extremists and criminals will exploit the demonstrations to destabilize the Soviet Union's political situation. The rallies are being organized by political groups in Moscow, Leningrad and other major cities ``to express their attitude to changes taking place in the country,'' Tass said. The resolution, introduced by Deputy Nikolai Pivovarov, urged authorities to curb unsanctioned rallies and force legal demonstrations to be held in specifically assigned places. On Monday, Lithuania's Communist Party urged the Kremlin to begin talks on granting independence to the republic, Tass reported. The committee adopted a statement saying it ``views as its chief objective the restoration of an independent Lithuanian state and the ensuring of its international recognition,'' the official news agency said. The Lithuanian Communist Party declared itself independent from the Soviet party on Dec. 20, creating the first major crack in the monolithic party that has ruled the Soviet Union since the 1917 Bolshevik revolution. The Lithuanian statement said restoration of a Lithuanian state must be achieved through ``parliamentary constitutional means,'' Tass said. ``Official negotiations between the Soviet Union and Lithuania should begin soon with the aim of establishing stable international relations and economic cooperation between the U.S.S.R. and Lithuania,'' the news agency quoted the statement as saying. Lithuania, a Baltic republic with a population of 3.4 million, was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 along with the other Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who helped set in motion nationalist movements by encouraging democratic reform, went on a personal mission to the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius to try to dissuade the republic's people from leaving the Soviet fold. But the Lithuanians showed themselves resolved to establish an independent state. Last week, in an acknowledgment of slipping central authority, the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee voted to end the party's constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on power and compete for the right to govern. On Monday, the Supreme Soviet legislature devoted a closed-door session to ethnic and nationalist unrest and sources said debate focused on the restive southern Caucasus. Gorbachev chaired the session and supported a proposal for Armenian and Azerbaijani delegates to begin negotiations on their dispute, the sources said. It urges neighboring republics to draft a treaty on their territorial dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh, a mainly Armenian enclave in Azerbaijan, but the Azerbaijanis rejected the proposal and walked out of the session, said Arkady N. Murachev, a Moscow delegate. Although reporters were barred from the seven-hour meeting, two participants _ Murashev and Vitautas A. Statulyavicus of Lithuania _ gave details in telephone interviews. Deputies agreed in a few days to vote on a resolution on the dispute, the source of bloody feuding between the ethnic groups for two years. But previous Supreme Soviet action has failed to calm tempers in the Caucasus. On Jan. 20, Soviet troops stormed into the Azerbaijani capital of Baku to put down a nationalist revolt and end attacks on members of the ethnic Armenian minority. Official reports say 139 people were killed, including 106 civilians, 28 troops and five policemen. Azerbaijani delegates blamed the army for the civilian deaths. But Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov contended Azerbaijani extremists were to blame.

DOC.HEAD: William Reed Huntington, Was Quaker Representative to U.N.
DOC.TEXT: William Reed Huntington, the former Quaker representative to the United Nations, has died of lung cancer at age 83. Huntington, who died Sunday at home, was active for years in the American Friends Service Committee, an organization of Quakers. He also served as the director of the United Nations Quaker program. A native of New York City, he was the grandson of the Rev. William Reed Huntington, longtime rector of Grace Episcopal Church in New York. After graduating from Harvard College, he received a master's degree in architecture from the University of Virginia. He practiced architecture in St. James, N.Y., and Vermont, where he retired in 1982. During World War II, Huntington was co-director of a camp for conscientious objectors at Big Flats, N.Y. After the war he was co-commissioner for relief operations in Europe for the American Friends Service Committee. From 1961 to 1963, he was director of refugee assistance operations in Tunisia and Algeria in connection with the French-Algerian war. He served after that as the Quakers' U.N. representative. Huntington is survived by his wife, Leonie, a brother, three daughters, three stepchildren and three step-grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Court Makes It Easier for Disabled Children to Win Welfare Benefits
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today made it easier for disabled children to win some federal welfare benefits. By a 7-2 vote, the justices struck down a government regulation that gave children seeking the benefits less protection than adults. The Bush administration said the decision could force officials to re-evaluate benefits for more than 250,000 children. The court ruled in favor of disabled children seeking what is called supplemental security income from the Department of Health and Human Services. The benefits are provided to the disabled of all ages. An adult is considered disabled if he or she ``is unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity by reason of any medically determinable physical or mental impairment'' lasting at least a year. Children under 18 are considered disabled if they suffer ``from any medically determinable physical or mental impairment of comparable severity.'' The definitions were interpreted by HHS officials in a way that made it more difficult for children to qualify. If an adult's mental condition does not meet one of those listed in HHS regulations, he or she is entitled to an individual assessment to determine the extent of the functional impairment. But the HHS rule struck down today did not permit such individual determinations for children. The Bush administration said treating adults differently makes sense because they are evaulated with regard to their ability to work. But Justice Harry A. Blackmun, writing for the Supreme Court, said a similar analysis can be used with regard to children. ``An inquiry into the impact of an impairment on the normal daily activities of a child...is no more amorphous or unmanageable than an inquiry into the impact of an adult's impairment on his ability to perform...gainful work,'' Blackmun said. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Byron R. White dissented. The case stemmed from an appeal by Brian Zebley of Pennsylvania, who suffers from congenital brain damage that has caused retardation and other problems. The government cut off the supplemental benefits when the boy turned 4 in 1982. Justice Department officials said a victory for the Zebley boy could force HHS to re-evaluate more than 250,000 cases in which children have been denied benefits between 1983 and 1988. HHS estimated the cost of the re-evaluations alone would be more than $41 million. The case is Sullivan vs. Zebley, 88-1377.

DOC.HEAD: Last All-Male Eating Club at Princeton Votes to Admit Women
DOC.TEXT: A century-old tradition of male-only membership at two Princeton University eating clubs could end within a year. Tiger Inn, one of the last two all-male eating clubs, voted Monday to end its policy of excluding women from membership. The vote came less than a week after Ivy Club, the only other all-male institution on the central New Jersey campus, voted in favor of admitting women. Under club rules, a final policy change at each club requires a second confirming vote in one year, which must then be approved by each club's graduate board, made up of alumni. The Ivy Club and the Tiger Inn are the last two of the school's 13 private eating establishments that do not admit women. Most juniors and seniors take their meals at the clubs, which are housed in private homes near the campus. Despite pressure from opponents of the all-male policy, many undergraduate women have attended the clubs, which allow women to visit and use their facilities but not to join. ``I think women go there to all-male clubs because of their laid-back attitude,'' sophomore Julie Slattery said. ``We always have fun at their parties.'' Tiger Inn President Mike Salerno said the decision to admit women would enhance the club. ``Some here decided this day and this year that it will be a positive change,'' he said. News of the vote pleased opponents of the male-only policies. ``I'm really happy and surprised,'' said Jen Weiner, a junior who directs the Coalition for Coeducated Eating Clubs. ``I was concerned that there would be some backlash because of Ivy's decision in that the members might want Tiger to remain the last bastion of all-maleness.'' The two clubs have maintained their male-only positions for 11 years in the face of a sex discrimination lawsuit filed by Sally Frank, a Princeton graduate. Ms. Frank filed a lawsuit against three eating clubs that continued to deny membership to women after the university began admitting female students in 1969. The other 10 voluntarily opened their doors to women after the school went coed. Cottage Club, the third eating club originally sued by Ms. Frank, voted to end its discriminatory practices in 1986 and settled with Ms. Frank for $20,000. The university was originally named in the suit but also settled in 1986, paying Ms. Frank $27,500 in legal fees and pledging to disassociate itself from sexually segregated clubs. In May 1987, the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights ruled in Ms. Frank's favor and ordered Tiger Inn and Ivy Club to admit women. However, the Superior Court of New Jersey Appellate Division reversed that decision in October 1988 due to procedural errors following the clubs' appeal. The case is pending in the New Jersey State Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: And the $40,000 Winner Is ... A Blueberry Poppy Seed Brunch Cake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with winners; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A blueberry poppy seed brunch cake won $40,000 for a marathon-running tax accountant today in the 34th Pillsbury Bake-Off Cooking and Baking Contest. Linda Rahman of Petaluma, Calif., a graduate student at Golden Gate University and a mother of two, won with a cake judges said offered a refreshing flavor blend of blueberry, lemon and poppyseed, combined with easy preparation and an appealing appearance. Ms. Rahman also won a $10,000 kitchen makeover from Bake-Off co-sponsor Sears. One man and four other women also won $10,000, and two men were among the $2,000 winners. En route to selecting the 100 finalists in December, including a record 12 men, the Pillsbury Co. considered more than 100,000 recipes. Illness forced one woman to miss the competition. Recipes were considered in one of four general groups _ Indulgent Treats, Healthful Alternatives, Ethnic Specialties or Quick Ideas, the latter being the group in which Rahman's cake was entered. Winners were further categorized by the type of Pillsbury product on which their recipes centered _ for instance, mashed potato flakes. Rahman's cake was made with flour. The $10,000 winners included Paula Cassidy of Berkeley, Calif., in the refrigerated pie crust category; Christine Vidra of Maumee, Ohio, cake and brownie mix; Scott Wolf, Salem, Ore., frozen vegetables; Nancy Woodside, Sonora, Calif., canned vegetables and mashed potato flakes; and Sharon Richardson, Dallas, Texas, refrigerated crescent dinner roll, biscuit and pizza crust. Debra Wolf, 20, Scott Wolf's sister and a $2,000 winner who is also from Salem, Ore., said her creations often are inspired while sleeping. ``It's mostly when I sleep or dream ... sometimes you'll see things and then you think, `Hmmm, I could use that for the Bake-Off,''' Ms. Wolf said Monday as contestants baked their creations three times for the panel of judges. ``It's kind of like doing a poem _ you think it through and you just do it,'' said Ms. Wolf, whose qualifying recipe was a coconut fudge crescent tart. Besides Ms. Wolf, the $2,000 winners in the Refrigerated Crescent Dinner Roll, Biscuit and Pizza Crust Category included Marie Mickelson, Columbia Heights, Minn., and Gloria Pleasants, Williamsburg, Va. Also winning $2,000 were: Refrigerated Pie Crust _ Robert Holt, Mendota Heights, Minn.; James Sloboden, Puyallup, Wash.; and Eugenia Ward, Amherst, Wis.; Cake and Brownie Mix _ Helen Peach, Pensacola, Fla.; Frances Sheppard, Corsicana, Texas; and Janice Weinrick, La Mesa, Calif.; Frozen Vegetable _ Jeanine Alfano, Montauk, N.Y.; Vesta Frizzel, Independence, Mo.; and Joan Schweger, Elburn, Ill.; Canned Vegetable and Mashed Potato Flake _ Birdie Casement, Denver, Colo.; Mary Lou Cook, Fallbrook, Calif.; and Ellen Nishimura, Fair Oaks, Calif.; Flour Category _ Anita Atoulikian, Parma, Ohio; Constance Dudley, Stanardsville, Va., and Jean Olson, Wallingford, Iowa.

DOC.HEAD: US Considering Biological Warfare on Cocaine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with comments by Bennett spokesman, details from drug control strategy
DOC.TEXT: The government is looking into whether to enlist swarms of caterpillars in the war against cocaine in Peru and Bolivia by setting them loose to eat coca plant leaves, officials said today. But a spokesman for national drug policy director William Bennett emphasized that the program is in the experimental stage and that any unleashing of the caterpillars would have to be approved by the Peruvian and Bolivian governments. The updated National Drug Control Strategy, released Jan. 25, seeks $6.5 million for Agriculture Department research in fiscal year 1991, starting Oct. 1, a $5 million increase over the $1.5 million to be spent this year. The Washington Post, which first reported on the plan in today's editions, described the program to develop chemical and biological agents to destroy drug crops as secretive. However, Bennett's spokesman, Don Hamilton, said: ``It's out there in the strategy. It's in the budget documents. If we didn't look into this stuff, I think we'd be irresponsible.'' Hamilton stressed that, ``The United States is not considering biological warfare against anyone or anything. ``These are experimental programs looking at all drug plants to try and learn as much as we can about them, including herbicides and natural enemies of the plants,'' he said. ``This isn't something that is an option yet. It's a prospect of an option.'' The proposed experiments, he said, ``would have to show that one of these things was safe and effective ... and then, you would have to talk to the governments involved and see if they're interested. Until you do that, you don't have anything,'' the spokesman said. The Post said the principal focus of the effort is the malumbia, a white moth that in its caterpillar stages eats the leaves of the coca plant. Growers in Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley, where more than half the world's cocaine originates, douse their crops with insecticide to kill the native malumbia caterpillars. The newspaper said researchers believe that if they could breed the insect in mass quantities, hundreds of millions of malumbia eggs or caterpillars could be airdropped over the coca-growing regions, thwarting the growers' efforts at crop protection. Waldemar Klassen, associate deputy administrator for the Agricultural Research Service, told the Post, ``This is quite a voracious caterpillar. If we could put them down there in sufficient number, we could then defoliate the plants.'' Klassen was not immediately available to discuss the report. Both Klassen and program leader Larry Christy were in meetings this morning, according to aides. The Post reported that there has been no public disclosure of the project, and one official told the newspaper he was reluctant to discuss it for fear of upsetting Latin American leaders. Hamilton denied that the research was secret, adding that general outlines were included in the strategy update and accompanying budget document. The strategy does not specifically mention the caterpillar experiments or provide details of research plans, but it notes: ``Great advances have been made in agriculture through the development of biological agents to enhance or reduce the productivity of various crops .... Such endeavors may also have applicability to various aspects of the drug war.'' The strategy says this is the reason for the $5 million increase in the Agricultural Research Service drug budget request and says the research findings would be ``shared with, and be made available to, foreign governments.'' The drug strategy budget summary document says the $5 million would be used in part to ``support increased research and development on nonherbicidal methods of control.'' President Nixon encouraged work on a biologically engineered worm during the height of the heroin epidemic in the 1970s. More recently, scientists have been working on an herbicide to kill drug-producing crops. Both efforts were not been carried forward because of political resistance by Latin American governments. ``We're not looking for some magic bullet here,'' Hamilton said. Even if the caterpillar successfully wiped out coca crops, he said, ``You've still got other drugs. ... This doesn't end everyone's problems by any stretch of the imagination.''

DOC.HEAD: Modrow: Talks Should Begin Under 2-plus-4 Formula.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Modrow saying experts should start immediate talks on `2-plus-4' conference; Pickup 7th pvs, `The subsidies...' ^LaserPhoto BER6
DOC.TEXT:
Communist Premier Hans Modrow today urged East German and West German experts to start immediate talks on reunification under a formula negotiated with the World War II Allies last week. Meanwhile, a joint commission led by Cabinet ministers of the two Germanys met today for the first time for talks on monetary and economic union between the two states, a major step on the road to unification. Modrow, addressing the East German Parliament, said experts from the two German states should ``begin preparing the `2-plus-4' conference as soon as possible.'' At a meeting in Ottawa, Canada, the victorious World War II Allies _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ agreed with the two German states on a two-stage plan to achieve German unification. In the first stage, experts from the two Germanys would discuss political, economic and legal steps to achieve unity. In the second stage, the two states would be joined by the four allies to discuss the international implications of unification. The formula became known as ``2-plus-4.'' Parallel to these talks, preparations should be made for the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, Modrow said. Modrow also said the German states should issue a joint statement guaranteeing Poland's western borders. He again ruled out membership in NATO for a united Germany. The Soviet Union wants a united Germany to become neutral, while West Germany and its Western allies insist it should remain in the alliance. Earlier in his address to Parliament, Modrow appealed to East Germans not to hoard food, following announcement that subsidies would be removed soon. He said he had heard of runs on grocery stores to stock up while prices remain low. ``I ask every citizen to show restraint and not to buy beyond normal needs,'' he said. On Monday, representatives of 16 organizations, including the Communist-led government, the pro-democracy parties and labor unions, agreed to abolish state food subsidies before the March 18 free elections. The subsidies are being lifted in part to stop a run by West Germans on cheaper food across the border, and to put prices in line with the cost of production. Modrow did not specify which areas of East Germany were suffering from panic food-buying, and no unusual crowding was noticed at East Berlin stores. Modrow also urged East Germans to keep their money in the banks. East Germans, worried about their savings becoming worthless under a monetary union with West Germany, have been withdrawing their funds from banks. He repeated his rejection of a monetary union before the election and again urged the West German government to approve massive immediate aid for the struggling East German economy. In Bonn, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl met with industrial leaders to discuss German economic cooperation. He said there would be no bailout unless East Germany adopts wide reforms to encourage private investment, including accepting the West German mark as the official currency. Leaders in both states hope a monetary union would stem the daily exodus of 2,000 East Germans to their rich neighbor. Walter Romberg, the minister without portfolio heading East Germany's side in the talks, said the panel would attempt to define exactly what a monetary and economic union is and what is needed to achieve it. Romberg said East Germany will demand safeguards to protect his country's pensioners, unemployed and the savings of its citizens against losses in the event of monetary union. Horst Koehler, the state secretary in the Bonn Finance Ministry leading the West German delegation said no target date for concluding the negotiations had been set. East German Economics Minister Christa Luft said Monday she believed a monetary union was possible before the end of the year. Kohl earlier this month offered a quick monetary union, believing it would give East Germans confidence in their future. But East Germans fear unemplyoment, as inefficient factories are forced to close under a more competitive, capitalist system. While talks on reunification opened, another piece of the Cold War headed into oblivion as East German border guards started dismantling the Berlin Wall between the Reichstag building and the Checkpoint Charlie border crossie next month, the wall will be removed until the entire 1.2-mile stretch between the parliament building, or Reichstag, and Checkpoint Charlie is gone. Since East Germany opened its borders on Nov. 9, numerous crossings have been opened in the wallng. Over th. Thousands of souvenir hunters have chiseled away huge chunks of the concrete, leaving gaping holes. Despite euphoria over removal of the hated wall, the two countries' moves toward unification is provoking unease. According to a survey commissioned by West Germany's ZDF television network, two-thirds of West Germans think the process is unfolding too fast. The survey also revealed 71 percent of West Germans want Berlin to become the capital of reunited GermanSlug PM-Drought Payments. Sent as a0421. By Farm Writer Don Kendall.
With PM-Drought-List.
DOC.HEAD: FOOD: Natural Risks Said to Outweigh Man-Made Dangers
DOC.TEXT:
NEW ORLEANS _ Nature's own cancer-causing chemicals that are an unavoidable part of everything from pot roast to peanuts represent a greater health danger than pesticides and other pollutants, a health official warns. Slug PM-Food Dangers. Sent as a0420. By Daniel Q. Haney.
_ NEW ORLEANS-dated Secret Data: Efforts to predict the effects of global warming are being hurt by the lack of access to 40 years' worth of secret Soviet and U.S. military data on the north polar ice cap, scientists say.
DOC.HEAD: STORMIE JONES: Texas Girl Undergoes Second Liver Transplant
DOC.TEXT: PITTSBURGH _ A team of surgeons worked to replace 12-year-old Stormie Jones' diseased liver today, almost six years to the day after the suburban Dallas girl became the world's first recipient of a heart-liver transplant. Editors: Operation began about 3:15 a.m. EST. It's expected to last 12 to 16 hours. Hospital expects no updates before the operation is over. Slug PM-Stormie Jones. Sent as a0484. By Jeffrey Bair. LaserPhoto PG1, Stormie Jones upon arrival in Pittsburgh.
DOC.HEAD: NORWAY: Shattered Economy Is Forcing Many Norwegians Out
DOC.TEXT: TROMSOE, Norway _ The tough Norwegians of the north can ride out the savage storms, the isolation and the winter darkness that lasts for two months. It is the region's shattered economy that is forcing many to leave. Slug PM-Arctic Woes. Sent as a0407. An AP Extra by Doug Mellgren.
DOC.HEAD: SHOOTZ CAFE: Beer Nuts Out, Gazpacho In at Yuppie Pool Hall
DOC.TEXT: BETHESDA, Md. _ This can't really be the old-fashioned neighborhood pool hall that mothers warned their sons to stay out of. There, at the bottom of the menu, is the polite admonition: ``Shootz Cafe is a smoke-free environment. Thank you for not smoking.'' Slug PM-Yuppie Pool. Sent as a0416. By Robert M. Andrews.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Child Pornography Charges Against Albany Man
DOC.TEXT: New York's highest court today upheld child pornography charges against an Albany man in a case involving only the purchase of pornography, not its distribution or production. But the court disappointed prosecutors by stopping short of a precedent-setting decision that could have outlawed the possession of child pornography throughout the state. The Court of Appeals decided 7-0 that Albany County prosecutors had properly secured a five-count indictment against William Keyes for promoting a sexual performance by a child. A lawyer for Keyes, 41, contended that although Keyes bought the magazines and videotapes with titles including ``Wonderboy'' and ``Lolita Colour Special 7'' from undercover police officers, he had not ``procured'' the magazines and videotapes under the meaning of the state anti-pornography statute. To fall under the law, Albany lawyer Terence Kindlon argued, Keyes would have had to arrange for under-age models to appear in a pornographic performance, or he would have had to sell the items himself to other people. The court rejected those arguments. In a decision by Judge Fritz Alexander III, the court concluded that the state Legislature clearly meant for the purchase of child pornography to fall under the acts covered by the word ``procure'' when creating the statute a decade ago. Alexander said the statute is ``directed at the consumers of child pornography as well as at its manufacturers and distributors.'' However, the court did not make the kind of blanket anti-child pornography pronouncement that prosecutor George Barber had hoped it would make. Alexander did call child pornography a ``social evil.'' But because Keyes was charged with ``promoting'' the items rather than possessing them, Alexander said it was not necessary for the court to address the question of whether possession of child pornography is constitutionally protected. Thirteen states have explicitly outlawed possession of child pornography, and Barber said he had hoped the court today would remind New York's Legislature that it could follow suit. Keyes, an auto body worker and partially disabled Vietnam War veteran, faces a maximum of 3{ to 7 years in prison on each of the five counts. He had been on 5 years' probation for a conviction for promoting a sexual performance by a child at the time of his arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Got Permission to Take Own Life Will Speak to Georgia Senate
DOC.TEXT: A quadriplegic who received court permission to turn off the machine that keeps him alive plans to ask the Georgia Senate on Wednesday to take steps to help people in his situation. Larry McAfee, 34, who since has abandoned plans to take his own life, has said he plans to ask the lawmakers ``to review their policies of keeping people like myself cooped away in nursing homes.'' He said he also will talk about his general dislike of nursing homes, which he said cause patients to lose control of decisions about their everyday lives. McAfee, a Georgia resident, was sent to Briarcliff Nursing Home at Alabaster in August because it is one of the few residences with special units for patients dependent on ventilators to help them breathe. Last fall, he got permission from the Georgia Supreme Court to turn off his ventilator. McAfee, a mechanical engineer and sportsman before a 1985 motorcycle accident left him paralyzed below the chin, changed his mind about the ventilator after he was befriended by several people who work at the nursing home. McAfee will speak to the lawmakers at the request of state Sen. Hildred Shumake. An aide, Vinyl Baker, said Shumake plans to work to change the system that forces McAfee and other disabled people to remain in institutions. Because his federal disability payments are not enough to pay for his care, McAfee must depend on Medicare and Medicaid. Neither federal insurance program will pay for living expenses outside an institution, although advocates for the disabled say such arrangements generally would be less expensive than nursing home care. McAfee said he believes educating lawmakers and the public about the things disabled people are forced to endure is the only way of changing the system. ``If it doesn't help me, I am hoping that at least it will help others,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: School District Must Pay Legal Fees In Handicap Appeal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf and 5th graf, bgng, The Muscogee, to CORRECT that case is from Georgia, not Oklahoma.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected the appeal of a Georgia school district ordered to pay lawyer fees incurred in administrative hearings by a couple who won a ``free and appropriate'' education for their handicapped daughter. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the federal law guaranteeing educational opportunity for handicapped youngsters authorizes such lawyer-fee awards. Lawyers for the Muscogee County School District had argued that lawyer fees may be awarded only when parents who invoke the federal law prevail in court, not in administrative proceedings. The school district lawyers told the justices that federal appeals courts are divided over the issue of awarding lawyer fees incurred in administrative hearings. The Muscogee County controversy began when Paige Mitten, a 13-year-old girl with cerebral palsy, partial blindness and mental retardation, moved with her family to Columbus, Ga., in 1985. Paige had been attending public schools in Texas, where an individualized education plan was developed for her. County school officials refused to permit Paige to enter the public school system or to develop a new individual education plan for her. Instead, they recommended she be placed in a state-run center in Columbus. Paige's parents objected to placing her in the center but did so on a temporary basis. At an administrative proceeding in late 1985, a regional hearing officer ruled that the school district violated the federal Education of the Handicapped Act by not providing Paige with the required free and appropriate education. School district officials appealed, but a state hearing officer upheld the regional hearing officer's findings. But the state hearing officer also concluded that the Mittens would have to sue in federal court in their attempt to recover legal fees incurred in their fight to get Paige an education. A federal judge ruled that no lawyer-fee awards are available under the Handicapped Children's Protection Act for administrative proceedings. But the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reversed that ruling last July 20, and ordered the judge to determine how much the school district should pay. The school district then sought Supreme Court review. The case is Muscogee County School Distict vs. Mitten, 89-905.

DOC.HEAD: Government Orders Army to Maintain Order in Kosovo
DOC.TEXT: The government today ordered the army to maintain order in the troubled Kosovo province, where growing violence between ethnic Serbs and Albanians has claimed nearly 30 lives this year. The order means that the army will for the first time be directly engaged in quelling the unrest together with the police, sources close to the Yugoslav leadership told The Associated Press. The army has deployed heavy reinforcements in Kosovo over the past year, but until now, it apparently was deployed only as a show of force. The decision was reached during a rare emergency session of the eight-member state presidency in charge of the armed forces. The presidency ``has decided to partially engage units of the Yugoslav Peoples' Army in Kosovo with the aim of protecting constitutional order and preventing violence,'' the presidency said in a statement carried by the state Tanjug news agency. The use of the army comes amid continuing protests by the ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo and the rival Serb minority there. Ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of the region's 1.9 million inhabitants. The presidency's statement said the ``security situation in Kosovo has seriously deteriorated'' because of the unrest ``which could have tragic consequences for all citizens in this province and for the country as a whole.'' Parts of Kosovo have been under a virtual state of emergency for the past year, with heavy troop presence in the region, particularly during the last month of renewed unrest. At least 27 people have been killed this year. Serbs in the province today threatened to take up arms to defend themselves against what they claim is harassment by the ethnic Albanian majority if authorities do not take action. Thousands of ethnic Albanians staged work stoppages or stayed away from schools in the province today to protest a state of emergency in the region. Several thousand also demonstrated in the provincial capital and in other Kosovo towns, in some instances clashing with security forces. Some 4,000 ethnic Albanian university students from Kosovo's capital Pristina marched through the city chanting ``Democracy! Democracy!'' and demanding a multiparty system, free elections, the release of political prisoners and an end to the state of emergency. About 10,000 Serbs rallied in Kosovo Polje, a suburb of Pristina, demanding swift police action against ethnic Albanians who have been demonstrating sporadically for almost a month to press demands for more autonomy and democratization.

DOC.HEAD: White House Was Aware of Drug Missile Threat
DOC.TEXT: The White House was aware of the possibility that drug traffickers in Colombia had surface-to-air missiles in advance of President Bush's trip last week to a four-nation drug summit, his spokesman said today. But press secretary Marlin Fitzwater added that, despite security concerns over the prospect, there was no hard evidence to confirm the reports. On Monday, guerrillas dynamited a power station and attacked police posts in Cartagena, Colombia, four days after the drug summit there, and police seized 10 shoulder-fired missiles in Bogota from drug traffickers, authorities said. Asked about the missile seizure, Fitzwater told reporters, ``I don't have specific information. There was intelligence before we left of various kinds, about missiles and rockets and other kinds of equipment, with various plans.'' ``There is no question that there has been terrorist activities in that country, and that the kind of people operating there, the drug cartel, were capable of this,'' the spokesman added. Two Americans remained in captivity: 65-year-old James Donnelly of Detroit and 40-year-old David Kent of Indianapolis. They were kidnapped by guerrillas a week ago in the northwest city of Medellin. In Cartagena, guerrillas dynamited an electric power substation Monday night, knocking out power to much of the city of 530,000 people, and attacked three police posts, wounding five officers, police said. Authorities said the shoulder-fired missiles _ which can shoot down planes _ were found in a raid Monday on a Bogota drug hideout. ``I think we said at the time that we did not have any confirmable information that there was a threat for SAM-7 missiles (the shoulder-mounted variety),'' Fitzwater said. ``To my knowledge that has not changed. But there's intelligence suggesting all kinds of capabilities and these always have to be matters of concern.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Congratulates Japanese Winners
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today congratulated Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and the Liberal Democratic Party on their election victory and expressed hopes for an easing of trade tensions between Washington and Tokyo. ``We believe our two nations can now begin to solve many of the economic problems that exist between us,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. ``We look forward to working with the new government in the days ahead.'' He said Bush was interested in meeting with Kaifu. ``We don't have any specific plans although I know President Bush is certainly willing to meet him at the earliest convenience, but nothing's been worked out at this point.'' In Sunday's elections for the lower house of Parliament, the Liberal Democratic Party and its allies won a controlling majority in the 512-seat assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Block Libel Lawsuit Against NAACP
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf, bgng, Police and, to CORRECT, deleting reference to National Guard, and 5th graf, bgng, Aaron Wheeler, to CORRECT name of newspaper to remove hyphen.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to block a state court libel lawsuit against the NAACP by a Virginia Beach, Va., white policeman who fatally shot a 22-year-old black man. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that the suit against the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and one of its officials must be tried in state, rather than federal, court. Eddie Upchurch shot and killed Fred T. Gilchrist on June 20, 1987. Upchurch said he fired unintentionally when Gilchrist tried to grab his gun. Aaron Wheeler of the local NAACP branch was quoted in the Virginia Pilot as calling the shooting a murder. ``This is a senseless murder and something has to be done about it,'' the newspaper quoted Wheeler as saying. In his libel suit, Upchurch said Wheeler's remarks were false and that the civil rights official knew they were false or spoke them with reckless disregard for the truth. The officer's suit contended that the NAACP had approved Wheeler's comments. Wheeler and the NAACP sought to move the case from state to federal court to determine whether the the sued-over statements were assertions of fact or libel-proof expressions of opinion. Wheeler and the civil rights group also contended that a black accused of libeling a white cannot get a fair trial in Virginia state courts. They cited ``the lingering viability'' of an 1847 state law that said ``a Negro shall be punished with stripes'' _ a whipping _ ``if he uses provoking language or menacing gestures to a white person.'' U.S. District Judge J. Calvitt Clarke Jr. said there are no grounds for believing blacks will be denied fair treatment in Virginia courts. The judge said Wheeler and the NAACP were unable to cite any laws or court cases to support their claims. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld Clarke's ruling last July. Virginia Beach on other occasions has been the scene of racial tensions. Law enforcement officers were accused of civil rights violations while quelling a riot among a crowd of 100,000 youths there over the Labor Day weekend this year. Police used clubs to disperse the crowds, which largely consisted of students from predominantly black East Coast colleges attending the annual end-of-summer Greekfest. The case is Virginia NAACP vs. Upchurch, 89-506.

DOC.HEAD: Olympic President: South African Sports Ban Continues
DOC.TEXT: The president of the International Olympic Committee today dismissed reforms in South Africa as cosmetic and said a sports ban against the white-ruled African state will continue. ``The ingredients for eradicating apartheid have not been lifted, therefore the international sanctions should be maintained to pressure South Africa to lift its policy of apartheid,'' Juan Antonio Samaranch told a news conference. ``There will be no relaxation in efforts to put an end to apartheid in sport in South Africa,'' he declared. Samaranch said any decision to lift the ban will be taken only after consulting with other African nations. He said South Africa's sporting links with other countries were limited to cricket and rugby. But he noted that the IOC has no control over those two sports. Samaranch spoke after meeting in Kuwait with the IOC Apartheid and Olympic Commission and later with representatives of a special United Nations anti-apartheid commission.

DOC.HEAD: A Gift For the Socialists on the Bus
DOC.TEXT: Socialists in the European Parliament have come up with a gift to help their East European counterparts along the road to democracy: a campaign bus _ red, of course. The nine-seat minibus will first be used by the East German Social Democratic Party in the campaign for March 18 elections. It will then be used in Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia. Rental costs of the bus will be met by a special fund set up by the Socialist Group. Members of the 180-strong group, the largest in the 518-seat assembly which usually meets in Strasbourg, France, agreed to donate the allowance of $177 they each get for every day they are on business in Brussels or Strasbourg. The group matches the amounts thus raised from its own funds. The Socialist members will continue to donate all or part of their daily allowance until the elections are over, said Tony Robinson, a spokesman for the group. The bus will be handed over to the East German SPD by Socialist group chairman Jean-Pierre Cot and Confederation of EC Socialist Parties' chairman Guy Spitaels in a ceremony at the European Parliament on Wednesday. In addition to the bus, the group assigned staff to assist the East European parties to set up and run their campaigns. A major election rally with leaders of West European Socialist parties is due to be held in the Hungarian capital, Budapest, on March 9.

DOC.HEAD: Court To Hear Discrimination Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to settle a dispute over deadlines for filing lawsuits charging on-the-job discrimination. The court said it will hear an appeal by Shirley W. Irwin, a handicapped former employee of the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Waco, Texas. Irwin said the VA fired him illegally on April 17, 1986. He sought help from the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. But the commission rejected his claim, delivering its decision to the office of Irwin's attorney on March 23, 1987. The lawyer was out of the country on Army Reserve duty, and Irwin said as a result he did not learn of the EEOC decision until April 10. Irwin filed a federal suit charging illegal job discrimination on May 6. But a judge threw out the case because Irwin missed a deadline of filing suit within 30 days of an adverse decision by the EEOC. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the judge last June, ruling the federal courts lacked jurisdiction in such cases when deadlines are missed. The case is Irwin vs. Veterans Administration, 89-5867.

DOC.HEAD: China Fails Stop Student Leader Address U.N. Commission
DOC.TEXT: An exiled leader of last June's pro-democracy movement went before the U.N. Human Rights Commission on Tuesday and condemned Beijing for continued repression in a speech that a Chinese delegate failed to stop. Wu'er Kaixi told the 43-nation panel that ``systematic violations of human rights'' continue in his native country and urged the international community to keep a close watch on the situation there. Wu'er, who is continuing his studies in the United States, said underground resistance networks are still trying to organize in major Chinese cities. ``We believe that the measures taken in Beijing after the lifting of the martial law are nothing but an attempt to dismantle and eradicate this type of organization,'' he said. ``At the same time, the massive campaign of arbitrary arrests and executions launched in June _ most of them secret _ has not yet ceased,'' he added. Wu'er, 22, spoke as a member of the delegation of the Paris-based International Federation of Human Rights, one of more than 100 non-governmental organizations that have been granted a consultative status with the U.N. body and are allowed to address the session. As soon as Wu'er began speaking, the Chinese delegate to the commission, given the floor on a point of order, protested his presence. ``This speaker is a criminal wanted by the Chinese security organs,'' said the delegate, Shiqiu Chen. ``He is here as a tool of certain anti-Chinese elements abroad who engage in slanderous attacks on China.'' He repeated his attack in a brief exchange with the president of the commission, Purificacion Quisumbing of the Philippines. She then asked Wu'er to continue after telling Shiqiu that Wu'er was a ``duly accredited member of a duly accredited organization.''

DOC.HEAD: Floods Recede in Southeast, Snow Closes Major Road in Southwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 4th graf, `Lamerdin slept ..., to UPDATE with possible cause of I-80 slide, and 3 grafs after 9th graf pvs, `One to ..., to UPDATE with more snow today in Colorado, New Mexico; pick up 10th graf, `In the ...; SUBS last graf, `The Chickasawhay ..., to give identify town as Shubuta.
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rains that caused nine deaths abated in the South but high waters continued to rise and threatened new flooding, while deep snow bedeviled the West, closing 200 miles of a major east-west highway. Federal officials surveyed east-central Illinois to determine whether the area qualifies for disaster relief. Workers struggled to restore power to thousands of residents in Champaign after snow and ice storms last week. A teen-ager made good use of survival training during a night outdoors in near-zero temperatures after searchers found her at a Lake Tahoe ski resort, authorities said. Maureen Lamerdin, 14, became lost Sunday while skiing in an unmarked area and was found Monday, suffering only cold toes. Lamerdin slept in a snow cave she built and exercised when she got cold. She was released to her home in Glenbrook, Nev., after doctors examined her. Highway crews continued to remove mud from Interstate 80 near Auburn, Calif., and the California Transportation Department said that a ruptured water flume might have contributed to a mudslide that closed the highway for most of Sunday. However, a spokesman for Pacific Gas & Electric Co., which operates the flume, said the utility doesn't accept any responsibility for the slide. ``We are denying that the flume was any part of the problem,'' said PG&E spokesman Tim Leong. He said an investigation is continuing to determine the cause of the slide and the utility planned to send its own geologist to the site. reported. Heavy snow fell early Monday across the high country of northern Arizona and state officials closed a 200-mile stretch of east-west Interstate 40, a major east-west route from North Carolina to California. Along I-40, Flagstaff, at an elevation of almost 7,000 feet, got 13 inches of snow. The south rim of the Grand Canyon got 17 inches, and nearby Williams 24. ``No, it hasn't gotten any better, we got about 15 to 17 inches overnight,'' said Chris Harris, desk clerk at Bright Angel lodge at the south rim of Grand Canyon National Park. ``You can't really get around. You can get up here but I wouldn't recommend it. The roads are pretty packed with snow and ice,'' Harris said late Monday. One to two feet fell in the mountains of southern Utah, snow moved into New Mexico and in Colorado two skiers triggered an avalanche when they skied out-of-bounds Sunday near Crested Butte, authorities said. One of the skiers was rescued Monday but the other's body was found under 7 feet of snow. Interstate 25 over Raton Pass in northern New Mexico was closed because of poor visibility caused by blowing snow, authorities said this morning. The National Weather Service issued a winter storm warning for the southern foothills and all of southeastern Colorado, where an additional 4 to 6 inches of snow was forecast today. A heavy snow warning was posted for the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, which could receive another foot of snow. ``This is a very good deal for southern Colorado,'' said Joe Baskin, a forecaster at the weather service office in Denver. ``They've been dry. They're well below their usual moisture levels across the southern part of the state.'' In the South, floods since late last week have been blamed for three deaths each in Georgia and Alabama, two in Mississippi and one in North Carolina. Federal and state emergency officials were expected to request federal disaster assistance today in Georgia from Gov. Joe Frank Harris, who promised speedy action. ``Just as soon as we have the proper information to make application, which is routine, we will be sending that information on to the federal government,'' Harris said. Only light rain fell early Monday on soggy northwestern Georgia, where 12 inches of rain Friday caused extensive flooding that forced more than 1,000 to leave their homes. The Oostanaula River was expected to crest at about 31 feet before slowing falling today. A National Weather Service spokesman said the Alabama River was expected to crest today by late evening in Montgomery at about 43 feet, eight feet above flood stage. Downstream at Selma, where the Alabama crested about 3 feet above flood level in June 1979, it reached 5 feet above flood stage Monday and was expected to crest there Wednesday. Thunderstorms and heavy rain expected Wednesday night and Thursday could bring the worst flooding in the state in more than a decade. Mississippi Gov. Ray Mabus took advantage of a break in the rainy weather Monday to make a helicopter tour of flooded areas.
