Even before his tour, Mabus declared a state of emergency for all 82 counties. ``We do not have an exact figure but a ballpark estimate would be about 400 homes affected by flooding,'' Mississippi Emergency Management Agency spokesman Dusty Perkins said Monday. ``There could be more when we complete a door-to-door survey.'' Roads were impassable in many areas. The Chickasawhay River in the east-central Mississippi town of Shubuta was at 42.6 feet Monday after climbing eight feet in 24 hours. Flood stage is 30 feet and the river was forecast to crest near 45.0 feet early Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Indian and Pakistan Troops Exchange Fire
DOC.TEXT: Pakistani and Indian troops exchanged fire for several hours today after a Pakistani soldier became the first military casualty on the troubled Kashmir border, officers and a western observer said. The soldier was shot in the leg Sunday at a ceasefire line, several miles from the village of Chaukothi, officials said on condition of anonymity. They said there were no reports of casualties from today's firefight at the line, which divides Kashmir between Pakistan and India. The nations have twice gone to war over the Himalayan state, in 1948 and again in 1965. The former princely state was divided between the two nations after British colonial rule ended in 1947. Relations between the neighbors have become increasingly strained since Jan. 20 when Indian troops launched a military crackdown on Moslem separatists in turbulent Jammu-Kashmir. The militants want India's only majority Moslem state to either become independent or join Pakistan. Jammu-Kashmir is an aberration in India, where 82 percent of the country's 880 million people are Hindus. The leaders of both countries have tried to soothe tempers in the dispute and have said another war over the region is unlikely. However, Pakistani forces have now sealed off the border area at Chaukothi, forbidding civilians from entering the area. The border crossing was the scene of a bloody confrontation on Feb. 11 between Indian troops and Pakistani students, who were marching in solidarity with activists in Indian-held Kashmir. Indian troops killed three students and wounded several during that confrontation, a Pakistan defence ministry spokesman said. The two armies also exchanged gunfire for about 30 minutes before calm was restored. A Paksitan army captain, who said he witnessed the firefight, said unlike the occasional shootings in the past, Indian soldiers appeared to be aiming at Pakistani troops. The western observer said Sunday's shooting of the Pakistan soldier appeared to back up that assertion. In another sign of increased tensions, Pakistani and Indian officers are no longer accompanying United Nations' military observers as they pass through the borders. ``It is not a normal situation,'' the officer said. ``The border is extremely tense.'' Pakistan officials said they were taking steps to quell what one official called ``war fever'' on the Pakistan side. ``We are trying to tie the people down,'' said Amir Alan Khan, a retired lieutenant colonel who heads Kashmir's civil defence. He said hundreds of retired soldiers have approached him ``to ask for orders'' to fight the Indian army.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide Issue on Exclusion of Blacks as Jurors
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether prosecutors who exclude blacks as jurors because of their race violate the rights of white defendants. The justices said they will review the case of a white Ohio man, Larry Joe Powers, convicted of two murders by a state court jury after seven blacks who could have served as jurors were excluded. The high court in 1986 ruled that when prosecutors disqualify potential jurors based on their race it violates the 14th Amendment's guarantee of equal protection. But that case involved a black defendant and black jurors. The court never has said whether unlawful racial discrimination in jury selection occurs when the defendant is of a different race than the excluded jurors. In a decision announced Jan. 22, however, five of the court's nine justices implied that excluding blacks as jurors because of their race does discriminate unlawfully against white defendants. The court in that decision ruled that a separate right _ the 6th Amendment guarantee of an impartial jury _ is not violated when prosecutors exclude blacks as jurors if the defendants are white. Although it was not an issue in the case, five justices _ Thurgood Marshall, William J. Brennan, Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens and Anthony M. Kennedy _ seemed to agree that such race-based exclusions do violate any defendant's 14th Amendment right. Powers was convicted of the July 27, 1985, murders in Columbus of Gary Golden and Thomas Kicas. He was sentenced to 50 years to life in prison. During jury selection at the trial, Powers' lawyer objected to the prosecution's exclusion of the seven black jurors. The presiding judge overruled the objections. A state appeals court upheld the convictions. The case is Powers vs. Ohio, 89-5011.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu to Form New Cabinet
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the governing Liberal Democratic Party agreed Tuesday that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu should stay in office and form a new Cabinet. Because of his weak power base in the party, Kaifu's position had been considered uncertain despite an election victory Sunday that gave the Liberal Democrats a comfortable majority in the powerful lower house of Parliament. Kaifu had said he would resign if the party, which was formed in 1955 and has governed Japan since, lost its majority. Doubt was cast on the party's chances by a widespread influence-buying scandal and an unpopular sales tax, but it won 275 of the 512 seats in the lower house, which chooses the prime minister and controls the budget. If 14 conservative independents join them as expected, the Liberal Democrats will not be far short of their 295 seats in the outgoing house. The leading opposition Japan Socialist Party won 136 seats, up from 83. The party leader is expected to vote for a leader soon and Takako Doi, the chairwoman who led the Socialists in Sunday's election, is expected to win. Japan National Broadcast Corp. said a Socialist election would be held March 25-26 and no one would challenge Mrs. Doi. A vote for the Socialists was widely viewed as a protest of the new 3 percent sales tax and scandals in the ruling party. The Socialists entered only 149 candidates and could not have won a majority. Ms. Doi attributed the outcome to the powerful political machines of Liberal Democrats and support from big business. Sunday's results illustrated the tendency of Japanese voters to forgive indiscretions of the ruling party eventually, which has helped the Liberal Democrats weather several scandals. Voters registered their dissatisfaction over the latest one, which involved insider stock deals and large political contributions by the Recruit Co. information conglomerate, by depriving the party of its majority in the less powerful upper house in July 1989. Most senior Liberal Democrats tied to the scandal were re-elected Sunday, including former Prime Ministers Yasuhiro Nakasone, 72, and Noboru Takeshita, 65, and some former Cabinet ministers. Nakasone ran as an independent. Dozens of influential business and political figures resigned because of the scandal and 12 are being tried for giving or taking bribes. Popularity ratings had plummeted when Kaifu, 59, became prime minister in August. He was untainted by the Recruit affair and helped clean up the party image by promising reforms. Kaifu also has promised to ease the sales tax on food and some other basic items.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Cite Problems With Arabs In Holding Up Direct Flights To Israel
DOC.TEXT: Despite a strong U.S. plea, the Soviet Union is unwilling to renew diplomatic relations with Israel or begin direct flights of Jewish immigrants to Tel Aviv, U.S. officials said Tuesday. ``We're disappointed that they have not approved those (flights),'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said. ``But we're hopeful it still might happen.'' Both issues were raised by Secretary of State James A. Baker III with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze during talks in Moscow two weeks ago. Baker also expressed concern about flashes of anti-Semitism, particularly threats of pogroms on specified dates by anti-Jewish groups. ``Considering what has happened with Armenians, the threats are not far-fetched,'' said a U.S. official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The source said Baker was told that one of the unfortunate results of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness, is that ``nasty views get an airing.'' At the White House, Fitzwater said President Bush ``is concerned about reports of growing anti-semitism in that country. He heard from American Jewish leaders just a week or two ago who voiced great concern on that issue.'' Soviet relations with Israel were broken by Moscow in 1967 after Israel defeated Egypt, which has been armed by the Soviet Union, and other Arab states in a Mideast war. In 1988, an Israeli delegation, including Russian-speaking Jewish emigres, went to Moscow to check conditions at the former Israeli embassy. A group of Soviet diplomats went to Tel Aviv the following spring. The exchange was generally seen as a move toward restoration of relations. In the meantime, Israel is restoring ties with Soviet allies in Eastern Europe, beginning with Hungary late last year, with Czechoslovakia on Feb. 9 and with Poland next week. Discussions are under way with East Germany and Bulgaria. Romania never broke with Tel Aviv. Asked why Moscow was not renewing its ties, as well, the U.S. officials said, the Soviets replied they were ``looking into it.'' The Soviets also cited the settlement of some Jewish emigres _ about 100 of the thousands who have poured into Israel in the last few months _ on the West Bank as ``a complicating factor.'' The Bush administration has criticized the settling of Jews on the West Bank and in Gaza as an obstacle to peace talks. Additionally, the officials said, the Soviets continue to say that Israel must take ``further steps toward the Palestinians.'' More than 4,500 Soviet Jews emigrated to Israel last month as a result of Gorbachev's lenient emigration policy and U.S. pressure over the last several years. Israeli officials estimate at least twice as many would make the exodus if the Soviets permitted direct flights to Tel Aviv. The Soviet airline Aeroflot and the Israeli airline El Al signed an agreement last year for direct flights. It was due to be implemented Jan. 1. When Baker asked about the delay, the Soviets ``weren't encouraging,'' an official said. ``They didn't specifically say they are never going to do it,'' the source said. ``They cited problems with the Arabs about settlements and Soviet immigrants. We pointed out the number on the West Bank are minuscule.'' And yet, the official said, ``they clearly did not encourage us they were going to move on this soon.'' The administration is eager to have the air accord implemented because U.S. admission of Soviet Jewish refugees is limited to 50,000 under a quota set by President Bush in October. Thousands more are able to leave. At the same time, the administration is closing U.S. processing centers in Vienna and Rome where thousands of Jews who left with exit permits for Israel are waiting to be resettled in the United States. ``We believe that direct flights would be helpful in increasing the number of people that can get out,'' Fitzwater said. Last Friday, the administration concluded an agreement with the Council of Jewish Federations and the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society to fly up to 8,000 refugees _ most of them Jews _ to the United States. The Jewish groups will pay for processing and transporting the refugees, and also their medical examinations, placement and initial resettlement for two years after they enter the country. The estimated cost is about $30 million.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Halts Publication of Former Leader's Memoirs
DOC.TEXT: The country's High Court has banned the publication or sale of the memoirs of former leader Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo. The injuction, issued Monday and published Tuesday, came at the request of Judge Taslim Elias, a judge of the International Court of Justice in The Hague who is suing Obasanjo for alleged libel in the book, ``Not My Will.'' Elias alleges the publication portrays him as incompetent in managing Nigeria's judicial affairs while chief justice of this West African nation in the 1970s. He is claiming $15 million in damages from the retired general, whose book outlines events in Nigeria under his leadership from 1976 to 1979. Obasanjo returned Nigeria to civilian rule, but it lasted only until 1983, when elected civilian President Shehu Shagari was ousted by the military. The present leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, has promised a return to civilian rule in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: As Expected, Paula Zahn Joins ``CBS This Morning''
LaserPhoto NY17
DOC.TEXT: CBS News made it official Tuesday, announcing that former ABC anchorwoman Paula Zahn will succeed Kathleen Sullivan as co-anchor of ``CBS This Morning'' starting Monday. CBS' formal announcement came after two weeks of news reports that the move was pending. Sullivan indirectly confirmed the shift during her farewell to viewers Friday. Her CBS contract expires in November. Erik Sorenson, the program's executive producer, said today that ``it wasn't so much that we wanted to replace Kathleen as that we wanted to get Paula Zahn. It was one of those judgment calls that you make.'' Sullivan, 36, was co-host of the show with Harry Smith since it began in November 1987. Like Zahn, she was a morning news anchorwoman at ABC before joining CBS. Sorenson said CBS officials were impressed with Zahn when she recently filled in for Joan Lunden on ABC's ``Good Morning America'' for a week. They called Zahn's agent to ask when her ABC News contract ended and she'd be available for contract talks, he said. He quoted the agent, Richard Leibner, as saying there were only eight days in February when she'd be available. Sorenson said he and CBS News president David Burke spent three days weighing the pros and cons of hiring Zahn, 33, ``and it was not an easy decision because Kathleen is a helluva broadcaster.'' However, he said in a phone interview, the show's ratings ``hadn't exactly been going through the roof'' and there was a need to make a long-range decision for the show.

DOC.HEAD: Liege Considers Selling a Picasso to Reduce Debt
DOC.TEXT: The debt-ridden city of Liege is considering the sale of a Picasso masterpiece to keep its museums open, an official said. ``Either we sell this Picasso or we have to close a dozen museums for lack of funds,'' Culture alderman Hector Magotte told the daily newspaper Het Belang van Limburg. The City Council hopes to make $57 million from the sale of the 1903 painting of the Soler family, a masterpiece of Picasso's ``blue period.'' The industrial city of 200,000 people on the river Meuse had a debt of $2.14 billion, but the national government assumed $1.29 billion of that, said city spokesman Andre Cuipers. The City Council will make a final decision on the sale next month.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Tuesday by the Supreme Court.
JAILED MOTHER
The court ruled that parents suspected of child abuse may be jailed indefinitely for refusing to disclose the whereabouts of their children. The justices said society's need to protect children from harm generally outweighs a parent's constitutional right against self-incrimination. By a 7-2 vote, the court upheld the indefinite jailing of a Maryland woman until she tells authorities where her young son can be found. The case is Baltimore Department of Social Services vs. Bouknight, 88-1182.
SOCIAL WORKERS
The court let stand a ruling that shields government social workers from being sued for placing children in foster homes where they are sexually abused. The justices, without comment, refused to review a federal appeals court ruling that the social workers enjoy absolute immunity if their child-placement decisions were approved by a court. The case is Babcock vs. Tyler, 89-912.
SPEED LIMIT
The court allowed the federal government to withhold federal highway funds from states that do not comply with a national speed limit. The justices, without comment, rejected an appeal by Nevada officials who want to set the speed limit at 70 mph on some state highways. The case is Nevada vs. Skinner, 89-686.
DISABLED CHILDREN
The court made it easier for disabled children to win some federal welfare benefits. By a 7-2 vote, the justices struck down a government regulation that gave children seeking the benefits less protection than adults. The Bush administration said the decision could force officials to re-evaluate bendefits for more than 250,000 children. The case is Sullivan vs. Zebley, 88-1377.
DRUG MONEY
The court handed Colorado a defeat in a high-stakes fight with the federal government over money and other property seized from drug traffickers. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that the proceeds of drug transactions automatically are forfeited to the federal government. In the case that had been appealed, the government later transferred nearly all the money to local police departments. The case is Colorado vs. U.S., 89-699.
JURORS
The court agreed to decide whether prosecutors who exclude blacks as jurors because of their race violate the rights of white defendants. The justices said they will review the case of a white Ohio man, Larry Joe Powers, convicted of two murders by a state court jury after seven blacks who could have served as jurors were excluded. The case is Powers vs. Ohio, 89-5011.
CHALLENGER SUIT
The court refused to revive a lawsuit by the widow of one of the seven astronauts who died when the space shuttle Challenger exploded in 1986. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that shields the federal government and a NASA engineer from being sued. Navy Commander Michael J. Smith was one of the seven killed when the Challenger exploded 74 seconds after its Jan. 28, 1986 launch. His widow, Jane, sued for damages and to bar Morton Thiokol, manufacturer of the shuttle's booster rockets, from bidding on any future National Aeronautics and Space Administration projects. The case is Smith vs. U.S., 89-607.
SOUTH AFRICA
The court let stand Baltimore, Md., ordinances requiring the city's public employee pension plans to withdraw all investments in companies doing business with South Africa. The justices, over one dissenting vote, rejected a challenge that said the divestment ordinances, among other things, impermissibly intrude on the federal government's power to conduct foreign relations. The case is Lubman vs. Mayor and City Council, 89-889.
SCIENTOLOGISTS
The court left intact a ruling that drastically limits the right of authors to quote unpublished material such as diaries and letters. The court, without comment, refused to hear an appeal by a company that published a biography attacking the late L. Ron Hubbard, founder of the Church of Scientology. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in a ruling last April that was denounced by scholars, publishers and free-speech advocates, imposed strict limits on the use of quotations from unpublished material. The case is Holt vs. New Era Publications, 89-869.

DOC.HEAD: Great Northern Agrees to $65.75 A Share Takeover By Georgia Pacific
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to include total value of buyout, CORRECT number of outstanding shares to 57 million sted 54, reflecting company figure; pick up 3rd graf: `Great Northern ...; ADDS byline. A longer version moved on the business wire.
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. today agreed to a buyout by Georgia-Pacific Corp. for $65.75 a share that would end the paper product company's four-month fight to remain independent. The offer for Great Northern's 57 million outstanding shares would total some $3.7 billion. It was announced jointly by the companies and topped Georgia-Pacific's previous $63 a share offer. All litigation between the companies will be cancelled, as will a March meeting at which Great Northern shareholders would have voted on whether to oust the company's board of directors in favor of a slate nominated by Georgia-Pacific. Great Northern chairman William R. Laidig had said last week his company was seeking other buyers who would pay more than $63 per share. Today, he issued a statement saying: ``I encourage our employees to work as enthusiastically with their new associates as they have in the past to make the combined concern the best in the industry.'' The merger will create the nation's largest forest products company, ``with the enhanced strength and flexibility required to succeed in today's more competitive and global marketplace,'' said Georgia-Pacific chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. The merged company will have an estimated $14 billion in sales, about 30 percent higher than its closest competitors, Weyerhaeuser Inc. and International Paper Co. All litigation between the companies will be cancelled, as will a March meeting at which Great Northern shareholders would have voted on whether to oust the company's board of directors in favor of a slate nominated by Georgia-Pacific. Great Northern's stock rose $1.50 a share to $65.37{ on the New York Stock Exchange in midday trading following the announcement. Georgia-Pacific was down 87{ cents at $44.25 a share. The merger is subject to approval by Great Northern shareholders. Georgia-Pacific, based in Atlanta, originally bid $58 a share for Great Northern on Oct. 31, an offer Great Northern rejected as inadequate and illegal on antitrust grounds. Great Northern, based in Norwalk, Conn., filed suit in U.S. District Court in Bridgeport, Conn., alleging the merged company would have a monopoly in some areas such as check paper. Litigation also ensued in federal court in Maine, where Great Northern is incorporated. That action focused on alleged antitrust violations as well as the legality of Great Northern's anti-takeover defenses. Georgia-Pacific has agreed to sell some check paper operations to eliminate one antitrust question.

DOC.HEAD: Observers Say Chances For A Clean Vote Are Good in Nicaragua
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The campaign has been contentious, filled with threats and accusations of foul play, but international observers say chances are good that Sunday's election will be clean. Credibility is a critical issue in an election that amounts to a referendum on a decade of Sandinista rule. Both sides rely on the observers to ensure a fair election, but for different reasons. President Daniel Ortega and the Sandinistas expect to win, and approval by the observers will lend legitimacy. The United National Opposition, whose presidential candidate is Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, says only international observers will keep the Sandinistas from cheating. More than 1,000 observers are fanning out by jeep, boat, plane and horseback to watch the election from the first votes cast to the last counting. One of the most visible observers is Jimmy Carter, the former U.S. president who denounced cheating in last year's Panamanian election while the votes were being counted. His prestige and anger helped destroy the credibility of the election, which Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega later nullified. The largest observer missions are from the Organization of American States, which has 450 people, and the United Nations, with 200. Nicaragua is the first country to invite U.N. election observers. Sandinista officials hope a verified victory will bring better relations with Washington and international aid for an economy ravaged by mismanagement, war with U.S.-supported Contra rebels and a U.S. economic embargo. ``A credible election can be the foundation for getting us out of this crisis,'' said Adolfo Beteta, spokesman for the Supreme Electoral Council. ``There has never been an election with more observers.'' Since the Sandinistas overthrew President Anastasio Somoza in 1979, Nicaragua's economy has shrunk by more than half, wages have fallen to less than 10 percent of their former value and private consumption is down by 70 percent. The currency was devalued 39 times in 1989. Officials of the U.N. and OAS observer missions, and a representative of Carter's Council of Freely Elected Heads of Government, have been in Nicaragua for months. They have mediated disputes about opposition access to state-controlled media, use of government resources by the Sandinistas, intimidation, campaign violence and many other subjects. ``I expect a clean election, but if there are irregularities on a large scale, we will be able to detect them,'' said Jennifer McCoy, head of the Carter mission. Leonel Zuniga of the OAS said his observers plan to visit 2,500 of the nation's 4,391 polling places. Many unofficial observers will help, from U.S. congressmen to church workers. ``Between the OAS and the other observers, I would guess almost 100 percent of the polling places will be covered,'' Zuniga said. ``We hope for and we expect a clean election.'' To keep them from voting more than once, citizens will have to dip their fingers in bright blue ink that takes days to wash off. To prevent stuffing of ballot boxes, each precinct will be assigned a number chosen by poll watchers when it opens, and the number will be stamped on every ballot. Ballots will be counted twice, once at the precinct and at one of nine regional centers. International observers will watch the counting at many precincts and all regional centers. The U.N. and the OAS missions will get copies of the returns, and will do their own sample counts to check against official returns. Some potential problems still exist. Voter identification cards do not bear photographs, and each side accuses the other of buying cards, stealing them or duping people into giving them up. Leaders of the opposition alliance, known as UNO, express concern that their poll watchers will be frightened into resigning before the election, but say they expect to have people at about 95 percent of the voting stations. Angelica Hunt, spokeswoman for the U.N. mission, said: ``We're a deterrence. Our presence makes a difference, but it's absolutely essential for UNO and the other opposition parties to have their poll watchers in place.''

DOC.HEAD: NRC to Vote on License for Seabrook Nuclear Power Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details, background; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission announced today that it will decide on March 1 whether to license the Seabrook nuclear power plant, setting the stage for an intense legal battle. The commission is expect to approve the licensing, and challenges to that decision are considered certain. Plant spokesman Ron Sher said preparations for full-power operation would begin immediately after a license is issued. He said the gradual ascension to full-power commercial operation would take two to three months, although the plant would produce a small amount of electricity within a month. A key question for whatever court handles the promised appeals to a license would be deciding whether to stay operation of the plant pending resolution of the appeals. The $6.4 billion plant, the scene of huge anti-nuclear demonstrations in the late 1970s and 1980s, was completed in mid-1986. It has remained idle for lack of a federal operating license, mainly because Massachusetts officials contend that the safety of people living around the plant could not be assured in case of a major accident. The federally mandated 10-mile emergency planning zone around the 1,150-megawatt reactor includes six Massachusetts communities. Challenges to a license also allege flaws in emergency plans for New Hampshire towns. Seabrook critics, including Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon, have said the issuance of a license by the NRC is a foregone conclusion, and that the real fight will be in court. Shannon and others argue that while NRC officials have deemed emergency evacuation plans for Seabrook adequate to protect the public safety, the commission has never spelled out its definition of adequate. Commission Chairman Kenneth Carr said in January that such broad issues would not be addressed in the NRC decision on Seabrook. Carr said the decision will instead focus on specific issues directly relating to the plant. A 1979 New Hampshire law targeted at Seabrook bars utilities from charging their customers for unfinished and canceled power plants. Unable to bill customers for Seabrook and faced with repeated cost increases and delays, Seabrook's main owner, Public Service Company of New Hampshire, entered bankruptcy reorganization two years ago. A proposed settlement calls for Public Service to be acquired by Connecticut-based Northeast Utilities.

DOC.HEAD: Michael Powell, Director of `Col. Blimp,' Dead at 84
DOC.TEXT: Michael Powell, innovative director of ``The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp,'' ``The Red Shoes,'' and 30 other films, has died at age 84. Powell, who fell ill two weeks ago in New York, died Monday night at his home in Avening in Gloucestershire, the National Film Archive said Tuesday. ``Of his generation, he was unquestionably the most innovative and most creatively brilliant filmmaker this country ever boasted,'' said fellow director Sir Richard Attenborough. ``He broke new ground and set standards of quality which almost no other filmmaker ever did and he will be deeply, deeply missed.'' Powell was fired from his first film job for dropping photographic plates, but he later found work as a still photographer for Alfred Hitchcock, working with him on three silent films. In 1931, Powell directed his first films, ``Two Crowded Hours'' and ``Rynox,'' both 40-minute melodramas. Powell and screenwriter Emeric Pressburger, who died in 1988, formed one of the most creative partnerships in British cinema. Their first movie was ``Spy in Black'' in 1938, devised for the German actor Conrad Veidt. It was titled ``U-Boat 29'' in the United States. ``49th Parallel,'' starring Laurence Olivier, followed in 1940. Titled ``The Original Story of the Invaders'' in the United States, it won an Academy Award for best original story (by Pressburger) and was nominated for best picture and best script. In 1941, the partners made ``One of Our Aircraft is Missing'' about British fliers forced to parachute into Nazi-occupied Holland. The script was nominated for an Academy Award. Pressburger and Powell formed the Archers Film Producing Co. in 1942. The team took joint credits for producing, directing and script, but Powell was largely responsible for directing. ``The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp,'' the first Archers' film, offended Prime Minister Winston Churchill. The 1942 movie was named after a cartoon character. Britons loathed Blimp-type bureaucrats who ran offices while others fought, but Churchill claimed the film was too defeatist. ``The Red Shoes'' (1948) was about a ballerina, played by Moira Shearer in her first screen role. Brian Easdale won an Academy Award for the film's score, and it was nominated for best picture and best original story. ``The Tales of Hoffman'' in 1951 combined opera, ballet and rich production design. The Archers company disbanded after making two more war movies, both in 1956, ``The Battle of the River Plate'' (titled ``Pursuit of the Graf Spee'' in the United States) and ``Ill Met by Moonlight'' (shown in the United States as ``Night Ambush''). Powell and Pressburger remained close friends and in 1972 worked together on a children's movie, ``The Boy who Turned Yellow.'' Powell's last film was ``Return to the Edge of the World'' in 1979. Powell was born Sept. 30, 1905, in Bekesbourne, near Canterbury in southeastern England. His first wife, Frances, died in 1983. They had two sons. In 1984, Powell married Thelma Schoonmaker, who had worked as a film editor for American director Martin Scorsese. A memorial service will be held at an unspecified date.

DOC.HEAD: Dog Wounded While Thwarting Robbery Of Owner and Neighbor
DOC.TEXT: A 2{-year-old golden retriever leaped at two armed men and was shot in the shoulder, giving her owner and a neighbor a chance to run to safety. ``There's no question she saved our lives,'' Chris Dittmar said Monday of his dog, Chelsea, a normally docile, 60-pound pet. The dog survived and neighbors treated her to a steak. Dittmar was near his house chatting with neighbors Bill and Jeannie Ridlehuber last Thursday night when four young men began walking up and down driveways. Dittmar told Mrs. Ridlehuber to call the police. Then two of the men walked up and pulled pistols on him and Ridlehuber. ``They had two guns pointed toward our heads and they told us to step out into the street,'' Dittmar said. ``And at that moment Chelsea sensed something wasn't right. She could smell our fear.'' ``She just leaped between our feet and went after both guys holding guns,'' Dittmar said. ``They lowered the gun from our heads and aimed for her instead. I saw her get hit in the shoulder _ I could see her take the slug.'' ``She is normally this wonderful, sweet dog but when it counted, she leaped for the throat and took a bullet in the process,'' said co-owner Kathy Page. After shooting the dog, the gunmen fired three shots at Dittmar and Ridlehuber, who were able to run into a garage and shut the door. Dittmar grabbed a shotgun from his house and went out in search of Chelsea. ``I called her name and she came limping out of the shadows,'' he said. ``She was scared but she came to me. She just put her head on my knee and I looked at her and she had blood coming out of her shoulder and I cradled her underneath the shotgun and took her home.'' Veterinarians found that the .38-caliber slug had traveled beneath Chelsea's skin and lodged against the chest wall, missing bones and internal organs. The bullet will be removed later this week.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Looks For Higher Japanese Aid
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney arrived Tuesday from the Philippines seeking what the United States hopes will be a ``sizable increase'' in Japan's $2.4 billion annual support for American troops stationed here. Cheney's visit came as Philippine President Corazon Aquino signaled a willingness to work out differences over U.S. bases there, despite her refusal to meet with Cheney during his stay in Manila the previous three days. The defense secretary had a warmer reception in Tokyo. ``The Japanese are very understanding and are very willing to help us as much as they can,'' said a senior Pentagon official traveling with Cheney. And even though it was known that Cheney intended to explore with Japanese officials possible 10 percent to 12 percent cuts in U.S. troop levels in Asia, Japanese government spokesman Taizo Watanabe said officials were not worried by such a development. The positive tone set by both sides at the opening of Cheney's visit was in marked contrast to the scenes he has encountered at the other major stops on his two-week Asian tour. In Manila, the defense secretary was burned in effigy by demonstrators who protested U.S. military bases in their country. In Seoul, Cheney met with South Korean officials who were described as ``horrified'' by his cost-cutting messages and projections of possible troop reductions. Despite the coolness of his Manila stopover, Mrs. Aquino said Tuesday, ``I welcome the statement of support for this government and Philippine democracy made by Secretary Cheney on behalf of the United States. ``I also welcome his reiteration that the United States will make its best efforts to meet its pledge for foreign assistance,'' she said, referring to a $96 million reduction in money for the use of six military bases this year. The military sessions in Tokyo appear free of the tense wrangling that scars the two nations' economic relations, given that the United States looks to Japan as the anchor of its Asian military strategy, and the Japanese prosper under the protective U.S. military wing. ``The Japanese are the linchpin of our military strategy in Asia,'' the U.S. official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``They're very supportive of our presence.'' Cheney was expected to tell the Japanese what he already has told the South Koreans _ that he is under congressional pressure to get them to double over the next three years their financial support for basing U.S. troops in their countries. The official traveling with Cheney said the defense secretary did not intend to press the Japanese to put forward an exact amount at this juncture. Each year, the Japanese provide around $2.4 billion of the $7 billion it costs America to base the 50,000 troops here and in Okinawa. ``We do not have any numbers. ... We're confident they understand our requirements,'' the official said, adding, ``We're hopeful that over the years we'll see a sizable increase in Japanese support for U.S. forces here.'' The U.S. official said Washington had received indications of such increased support from Japanese officials during preliminary talks leading up to the Cheney visit. Pentagon sources have said they are studying plans by which at least 10,000 to 12,000 troops could be withdrawn from the 120,000 based in the Pacific Rim nations. That would mean a reduction of 5,000 troops in Japan. The study is part of a reassessment of the U.S. military role in the Pacific that Cheney must send to Capitol Hill by April 1. Some lawmakers are demanding cuts in overseas forces in light of reduced superpower tensions. The official traveling with Cheney said the Japanese didn't appear to be disturbed by a reduction in non-combatant troops, given that they face much less of a direct threat than South Korea does, and also because they are more concerned about the long-term U.S. presence in their arena. ``We understand the U.S. Congress is looking for ways to reduce government expenditures and as long as (the United States') fundamental position has not changed, we are not worried,'' Watanabe said. Cheney's Japanese counterpart, Juro Matsumoto, also expressed understanding of the American position. He said that while the United States may carry out some ``streamlining,'' it has ``no intention of reducing its fighting strength.'' Cheney's schedule here is a mix of business and pleasure, as he lunches with some influential Japanese citizens and visits U.S. troops at the Yokosuka Naval Base on Wednesday. He confers with Japanese officials nearly the entire day on Thursday. After delivering a speech on U.S.-Asian relations Friday at the National Press Club, the secretary was to be taken by Japan's famed high-speed ``Bullet Train'' for a trip to the ancient city of Kyoto. He was scheduled to return to Washington on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Asks Cameras to Lay Off Florida Clinic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 4th graf, Arraignment on, with attorney asking for court delay
DOC.TEXT: A spokeswoman for Mayor Marion Barry Jr. says journalists' harassment of him is getting so bad that one television reporter tried to sneak into the center where Barry is being treated for alcohol abuse. In a statement issued in Washington by his press secretary, Barry asked Monday for ``some consideration'' from reporters and camera crews have who camped outside the Hanley-Hazelden Center in West Palm Beach, Fla., where the mayor enrolled last month following his arrest on a drug charge. Barry, according to aides, is scheduled to leave the clinic on Wednesday. City government sources said today he will go to Fenwick Hall Hospital near Charleston, S.C., to continue treatment although he still faces arraignment in Washington on an eight-count indictment on perjury and drug charges. Arraignment on the charges had been tentatively set for Wednesday, but Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, today asked for a postponement. No specific date was requested. Earlier reports had said Barry might go to the Betty Ford Clinic in Rancho Mirage, Calif. In the statement issued Monday, Barry said, ``I am asking the media to be considerate. ... Members of the media who are camped outside the treatment center should cease their ... behavior that is disruptive to all who are here seeking to heal themselves.'' The mayor's press secretary, Lurma Rackley said the mayor had complained of ``cameras positioned on top of trucks to shoot over into the center's courtyard at the patients and that camera operators and reporters are standing near the entrance of the center unnerving patients and their relatives who come and go.'' Rackley said a reporter from WRC-TV in Washington tried to enter the rehabilitation center over the weekend to check on Barry's treatment. WRC-TV news director Bret Marcus denied the allegation. ``Our policy is not to interfere with the treatment or well-being of Mayor Barry or any other patient at the Hanley-Hazelden Clinic or any other similar facility,'' Marcus said. ``We respect the right and even the necessity of privacy as part of his medical treatment. We were in Florida reporting on the visit by City Administrator Carol Thompson and Chief of Staff Maudine Cooper who were there on official city business.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Mount Final Effort To Prove Hazelwood Was Drunk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with morning testimony; picks up 5th graf, `On Friday ...
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in the trial of ex-tanker captain Joseph Hazelwood saw a videotape today of the Exxon Valdez stranded on a reef, surrounded by a sea of black oil. The tape, which graphically depicted the disaster caused when the tanker struck Bligh Reef last March 24, was introduced in evidence by the prosecution. Daniel Lawn, an environmental engineer with Alaska's Department of Environmental Conservation, testified that he shot the footage after he was summoned by the Coast Guard to visit the stricken ship and record details of the nation's worst oil spill. He called the tape ``mental note-taking,'' explaining how he accompanied Coast Guard investigators to the 987-foot ship. The tape, which lasted about 10 minutes, first showed the ship sitting in the darkness, its lights glowing. The video then switched to a period after dawn, when the ship's deck was more visible and a contrast was shown between the gooey black oil on one side of the tanker and the clear blue water on the other. Also visible were chunks of ice which the vessel had sought to elude in its course into Prince William Sound. Long narrated the tape, showingwhich tanks were leaking oil, saying at one point: ``You can see it bubbling out.'' The tape was offered as prosecutors began a final barrage of evidence aimed at proving that Hazelwood, skipper of the ship, was drunk and reckless the night the tanker went aground. After two weeks of testimony from 23 witnesses, assistant district attorneys Brent Cole and Mary Ann Henry plan to conclude their case late this week or early next. On Friday, Coast Guard Investigator Mark Delozier told of boarding the grounded tanker in the early morning hours of March 24 and confronting Hazelwood, who smelled of liquor. He said the smell was ``very intense and very obvious.'' Delozier also testified that in the captain's quarters he found two empty cans of a low-alcohol beer. He said there were more cans of the beer in a refrigerator. The defense may cite the presence of the beer to explain why Hazelwood tested positive on a blood-alcohol test administered 10{ hours after the Exxon Valdez grounding and some 15 hours after he was seen at a bar in Valdez. The blood test showed Hazelwood had a blood alcohol level of .061, under the limit for driving in Alaska but above the federal limit for operating a commercial vessel. The 43-year-old skipper is charged with second degree criminal mischief, a felony, and three misdemeanors, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, his maximum penalties could be 7\ years in prison plus $61,000 in fines. The Exxon Valdez, a 987-foot tanker, ran aground on jagged Bligh Reef, gashing holes in its oil tanks and spilling almost 11 million gallons of oil into the clear waters of Prince William Sound. The spill was the nation's largest, killing countless birds, fish and wildlife and blackening hundreds of miles of rocky shore. Delozier's testimony focused on the much-debated question of whether Hazelwood was drunk at the time of the accident. Testimony has been inconclusive on how many drinks Hazelwood had during an afternoon in the town of Valdez before the ship sailed. Ship's officers who accompanied him say he had two or three drinks over a period of about three hours. The prosecution maintains he was in a bar for about six hours and kept ordering vodka on the rocks. The only point on which all witnesses seem to agree is that Hazelwood never appeared to be drunk on the Exxon Valdez. Even Delozier, who smelled alcohol on him, said he did not stagger, slur his words or appear impaired by alcohol. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone was considering a prosecution proposal to call as witnesses experts who claim they can tell from listening to tape recordings of a person's voice whether they are intoxicated. Prosecutors want the experts to give their opinions about Hazelwood from listening to the tape of the skipper reporting the Exxon Valdez grounding to the U.S. Coast Guard.

DOC.HEAD: Luella Wilson Settles Out of Court In Negligence Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A settlement was reached today in a negligence case against a 92-year-old widow who stood to lose her home and life savings for helping her nephew buy a car that later was involved in a serious accident. Luella Wilson refused all pre-trial settlements, proclaiming, ``I want a trial by jury.'' Arriving at the courthouse this morning, Wilson said she would take the stand in her own defense ``if I am able. ``It's the only way I can clear my name,'' she said. ``I didn't do nothing wrong. It's terrible what happened to that boy, but I'm not responsible for what happened.'' Details of the settlement were not released, but Wilson claimed victory, saying she will keep her home and property. The agreement came during the noon hour, after lawyers had presented opening arguments and testimony had begun. Wilson had been found negligent for giving her great-nephew money to buy a car that later was involved in an accident that left a man partially paralyzed. The case was being heard again to decide if that negligence should be shared. On Monday, Wilson was presented with a number of settlement offers, most of which would have left her home and assets to the accident victim when she died. She refused them all. ``My husband Harry would roll over in his grave if I ever did that,'' she said. The trial struck a sympathetic chord with the public because Wilson stood to lose $950,000, the value of her home, 80 acres of property and her savings. After her story appeared in newspapers and on television, Wilson received letters of support and cash from around the nation. Legal experts and professional groups, including bankers and car dealerships, kept a close eye on the case because it could mark a legal precedent for negligence. Had the trial gone to the jury, Wilson, an automobile dealership and its president would have had to prove they were not negligent in helping Wilson's great-nephew, Willard Stuart, buy a car in 1984. Stuart had no drivers' license or insurance at the time. Shortly after he bought the car, Stuart drove it off a bridge after drinking beer and whiskey and smoking marijuana with a group of young men, including Mark Vince, according to court records. Vince, a back-seat passenger, was partially paralyzed as a result of the accident and later had one leg amputated. He sued Wilson for negligence, under the legal concept of negligent entrustment, for giving her nephew $6,300 to buy the 1981 Chrysler LeBaron. Prosecutors claimed that Wilson was negligent not by buying the car outright, but by providing the money for the nephew to purchase it. A 1987 Superior Court jury agreed, and awarded Vince $950,000. Wilson was too ill to attend that trial. While refusing to reverse that decision on appeal, the Vermont Supreme Court later ruled that a jury should decide if Ace Auto of Bennington and its president and salesman in the deal, Gary Gardner, should share the liability for selling the car to Stuart. After the high court's ruling, Superior Court Judge Arthur O'Dea opened the way for a retrial, saying jurors could also decide if Vince shares the liability for entering the car when he knew the driver had been drinking and smoking marijuana.

DOC.HEAD: With Banks Closed, It's Cash 'n' Carry For Some Finns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to recast. SUBS 20th graf ``The bank ...'' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Tuesday's action by Finance Ministry, quote from finance minister, more background.
DOC.TEXT: With banks closed for the third week, Finns are learning to live without cash _ or with bags of it. Commercial, savings and deposit banks were shut Feb. 1 in a wage dispute that has been unusual in its intensity for this Scandinavian country known for quiet negotiation and consensus. Only the Post Office bank, which has its own union, remained open. The cash flow problems are causing many small businesses to suffer, and many layoffs are looming. Bank customers had plenty of warning before the financial institutions actually closed their doors, and most took precautions. ``When I knew the banks were going to shut I withdrew all my money and keep it in a box at home,'' said office worker Kaisa Harris. ``But with all that cash lying around, I'm actually spending more than I would normally.'' Supermarket-owner Veikko Still, unable to deposit his daily receipts, said he carries around bags filled with money to pay his 70 employees. ``Often we have up to a million marks ($250,000) in cloth bags,'' according to Still, who adds that he has tripled his insurance and increased security. Police said there has been a sharp increase in burglaries and warned companies not to move large amounts of money. In some cases, police provided armed escorts on paydays. Many shoppers are living on credit and business has barely slowed in downtown Helsinki. Electronics stores reported normal post-Christmas sales. Restaurants, bars and movie houses are as full as ever. Hotels and most retail stores still accept credit and bank cards, even though they cannot collect until the banks reopen. In 1988, there were 4.5 million credit cards, one for every Finn. Others stores provide interest-free credit of several months with no down payment for expensive consumer goods. Small- and medium-sized companies, however, are feeling the squeeze as salaries, taxes and various tariffs must be paid. Jussi Jarventaus, vice-president of the Central Association of Finnish Entrepreneurs, said 400 workers have been issued warnings they may lose their jobs, and some firms have gone bankrupt. ``These figures will be multiplied by a significant amount if the government does not come to our assistance. We are dealing with a very dangerous situation,'' he said. Trade officials said imports were dropping by 50 percent as companies were being forced to pay import duties in cash. More than 95 percent of businesses in Finland are as small or medium-sized, employing fewer than 20 people. Only 0.2 percent employ more than 500 people, Jarventaus said. ``We can survive for just a couple of weeks, that's all,'' said Kai Bjorn, manager of a furniture-installing company that already has told 10 of its 16 workers they may have to be let go. ``We have been in this business for two years now and have been growing at a steady, promising rate. Now everything is in danger of falling apart,'' Bjorn said. He reported an 80 percent drop in orders and a sharp fall in income because customers can't pay. The Finance Ministry rejected a new appeal Tuesday by the Central Association of Finnish Entrepreneurs to waive taxation and other duties to be paid by small- and medium-sized companies. According to Finance Minister Ulla Puolanne, most companies are not in such deep trouble to warrant special measures, national radio reported. Jarventaus told the radio that he was surprised by the ministry's decision. The bank dispute involving 38,000 workers is over demands for a 10 percent wage increase. State Mediator Jorma Reini said he expected the banks to stay closed a long time. Bank employees, who earn an average monthly salary of about $2,000, claim their income has lagged behind that of other workers. They said they wouldn't budge from their demand for a 10 percent increase and have rejected an offer of 6.2 percent. Postpankki, the state-owned Post Office Bank, has become a safety valve for the public. Postpankki has regular banking customers, and also provides cash and bill payment services for anyone in 3,000 post offices throughout the country. Assistant Director Ara Hopia said Postpankki has opened up to 10 times the normal number of new accounts since the bank strike. Offices have been forced to lock their doors for a few hours every day to deal with backlogs and massive lines of customers. ``It's ridiculous _ our workload has suddenly doubled, in some cases even trebled or more,'' Hopia said. ``Something has got to give soon _ we can't take this for very much longer.''

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Leader Asks Walesa to Condemn Anti-Semitism
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa met Tuesday with World Jewish Congress President Edgar Bronfman and pledged to oppose anti-Semitism in Poland. Bronfman, continuing a visit to Poland that included meetings Monday with President Wojciech Jaruzelski and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, also traveled to the Auschwitz concentration camp in southern Poland. ``There is nothing to be said here, only the wail remains,'' Bronfman wrote in the visitors' book at the camp where officials estimate up to 2.5 million Jews were killed by the Nazis during World War II. During the meeting with Walesa, Bronfman expressed concern about what he termed a reappearance of anti-Semitism in Poland. Noting that there are only 10,000 Jews left in all of Poland, compared with a pre-World War II population of 3.5 million, he said it was unprecedented for anti-Semitism to remain in a country where there are so few Jews. He asked Walesa for a public condemnation of anti-Semitism. ``I have condemned anti-Semitism everywhere,'' Walesa replied. ``I have always been doing so and I will do so.'' Walesa called it ``a great loss that there are so few Jews in Poland.'' Jews have lived in Poland for nearly 1,000 years and made up 10 percent of Poland's population before World War II. But despite that long history of coexistence, relations between Polish Catholics and Polish Jews have often been marked by tension and hostility. The Solidarity-led government of Mazowiecki has pledged to improve Polish-Jewish relations and oppose any resurgence of anti-Semitism. It plans to restore diplomatic relations with Israel next week, and has moved to speed up construction of an alternate home for Roman Catholic nuns whose convent next to Auschwitz has offended Jews and others.

DOC.HEAD: Released ANC leader to Travel Outside Country Next Week
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela met Tuesday with chiefs from his tribe and a Swedish diplomat, and plans were made for him to travel to Zimbabwe and Zambia next week. The National Reception Committee, which has coordinated Mandela's schedule since he was released Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison, said Mandela would go to Harare, Zimbabwe, on Monday. On Tuesday, he will go to Lusaka, Zambia, where he will meet with exiled ANC leaders. Jan Lundvik, a representative of the Swedish legation in South Africa, said after a meeting at Mandela's Soweto home that preparations were being made for his forthcoming visit to Sweden. ANC president Oliver Tambo, Mandela's former law partner, is recovering from a stroke in Stockholm. Chief Anderson Joyi, a leader of the delegation of chiefs from Tembuland in the Transkei homeland, said they had come to ask Mandela to visit the graves of his dead relatives in the Xhosa-speaking homeland. Mandela is a member of the Tembu royal clan of the Xhosa tribe and grew up in Transkei. The South African government declared Transkei an independent republic during his imprisonment for sabotage, but its military ruler is considering a referendum on rejoining South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Girl Undergoes Second Liver Transplant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with surgery ended, Stormie in critical condition; picks up 3rd graf pvs: `Stormie and ...; SUBS 6th graf to conform; CORRECTS spokeswoman's name to Lynn, sted Liz, McMahon.
DOC.TEXT: A team of surgeons worked about 10 hours today to replace the diseased liver of 12-year-old Stormie Jones, who became the world's first recipient of a heart-liver transplant six years ago. Lead surgeon Andreas Tzakis and six other doctors started the operation at 3:15 a.m. and finished at about 1 p.m., hospital officials said. Transplant pioneer Dr. Thomas Starzl was present for part of the procedure. ``The word was everything went fine,'' said Children's Hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon. Stormie was listed in critical condition, considered normal following transplant surgery. Stormie and her mother, Lois Purcell, flew to Pittsburgh from their home in the Dallas suburb of White Settlement, Texas, on Monday, arriving at the hospital about 7 p.m. As she was wheeled from her plane to a waiting ambulance, Stormie joked, ``I feel like I'm in a straitjacket'' because of the stretcher's confining straps. Doctors were optimistic because a donor liver was found only a week after Stormie's name was placed on the nationwide transplant list. The success rate of a second liver transplant is estimated at 65 percent to 70 percent, hospital officials said. Hepatitis damaged Stormie's first transplanted liver and the organ no longer functions normally, said McMahon. Hepatitis, which is caused by a viral infection, inflames the liver. ``She was last hospitalized here in January,'' McMahon said. ``The doctors suspected a virus or hepatitis at that time. They feel at this time their only option is another liver transplant.'' Stormie's first transplant on Valentine's Day 1984 took 16 hours and was headed by Starzl, who replaced the girl's heart and liver with those of a 4-year-old girl who had died in a New York car accident. Before that operation, Stormie suffered two heart attacks and underwent two triple coronary bypass operations. She suffered from a rare congenital disease which increased to 10 times normal the level of cholesterol in her blood. The imbalance was caused by a faulty liver. Pittsburgh surgeons followed Stormie's 1984 operation with two more attempts at heart-liver transplants, but both patients died within a few days of surgery. Those were the only attempts in America at replacing a heart and liver in the same operation until last Dec. 3, when Pittsburgh surgeons performed the world's first heart-liver-kidney transplant. The patient, Cindy Martin, 26, remains in critical condition in the intensive care unit at Presbyterian-University Hospital. She is receiving FK-506, an experimental Japanese drug, and has experienced no organ rejection. Stormie had no serious complications until October 1988, when Children's Hospital doctors removed a bile duct obstruction. She started losing liver function and returned to Children's Hospital in November.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Prize Recipe: Quick, Attractive, Flavorful
With PM-Bake-Off
DOC.TEXT: Linda Rahman of Petaluma, Calif., won the $40,000 Pillsbury Bake-Off grand prize and a $10,000 kitchen makeover from co-sponsor Sears for this blueberry poppy seed brunch cake judges called attractive, quick and flavorful:
DOC.HEAD: Cake
DOC.TEXT: 2-3 cup sugar { cup butter or margarine, softened 2 teaspoons grated lemon peel 1 egg 1{ cups Pillsburg's BEST All Purpose or Unbleached Flour 2 tablespoons poppy seed { teaspoon baking soda \ teaspoon salt { cup dairy sour cream
DOC.HEAD: Filling
DOC.TEXT: 2 cups fresh or frozen blueberries, thawed, drained on paper towels 1-3 cup sugar 2 teaspoons flour \ teaspoon nutmeg
DOC.HEAD: Glaze
DOC.TEXT:
1-3 cup powdered sugar 1 to 2 teaspoons milk
Heat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease and flour bottom and sides of 9- or 10-inch springform pan. In large bowl, beat two-thirds cup sugar and butter until light and fluffy. Add lemon peel and egg; beat 2 minutes at medium speed. Lightly spoon flour into measuring cup; level off. In medium bowl, combine 1{ cups flour, poppy seed, baking soda and salt; add to butter mixture alternately with sour cream. Spread batter over bottom and 1 inch up sides of greased and floured pan, making sure batter on sides in \-inch thick. In medium bowl, combine all filling ingredients; spoon over batter. Bake at 350 degrees F. for 45 to 55 minutes or until crust is golden brown. Cool slightly. Remove sides of pan. In small bowl, combine powdered sugar and enough milk until glaze is desired drizzling consistency; blend until smooth. Drizzle over top of warm cake. Serve warm or cool. 8 servings. High Altitude _ Above 3,500 feet, increase flour in cake to 1} cups. Bake as directed above.
Eds: Upcoming shortly is a 5th Ld-Writethru to PM-US-Czechoslovakia, a0584, with granting of most-favored trade status to Czechoslovakia.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Supreme Soviet Asks Curbs on Unsanctioned Demonstrations
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet legislature on Tuesday urged a crackdown on illegal demonstrations scheduled for Sunday and said authorities should exercise tight control on legal rallies, the Tass news agency reported. The legislators, saying they feared that extremists and criminal elements will exploit the demonstrations to destabilize the political situation, adopted a resolution urging law enforcement agencies to take special measures to keep demonstrators in line. The rallies were organized by various political groups in Moscow, Leningrad and other major cities ``to express their attitude to changes taking place in the country,'' Tass said. ``As far as newspaper reports indicate, forces interested in destabilizing the situation also intend to join the demonstrators,'' the news agency said. The resolution, introduced in the Supreme Soviet legislature by Deputy Nikolai Pivovarov, said unsanctioned rallies should be curbed and legal demonstrations be held in specifically assigned places. ``In order to prevent actions by militants and, possibly criminal forces, the Supreme Soviet has asked the government and local authorities to adopt all necessary measures to protect law and order,'' Tass said. The news agency quoted several deputies as saying there had been an increase in demonstrations under the ``perestroika'' reforms of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and that many of them had taken on an anti-state character, with some demonstrators exhorting people to violence. ``The predominant motive of many rallies is usually `down with something' or `away with something,''' an unidentified deputy and member of the Committee on Glasnost was quoted as saying during the debate on the resolution. ``Anti-state remarks that sometimes contain open appeals for violence have become a permanent fixture of their vocabulary,'' he was quoted as saying. Tass said the resolution was adopted after the debate, but did not break down the vote. The Supreme Soviet on Tuesday also approved a bill that would allow individuals to own land, but sent it to committee for refinement before voting on an article-by-article basis that is expected next week. Land currently is the property of the state, and passage of the law would also require reworking of the Constitution. Some lawmakers expressed concern the law could disrupt farm production. A law that would allow individuals to hold private property was sent back to a committee for revision last week. Both bills are intended to unleash individual initiative by giving citizens a greater say in how they live.

DOC.HEAD: UNESCO Chief Says Hostages Must Not Be Forgotten
DOC.TEXT: The director of UNESCO said in a meeting Tuesday with the sister of Terry Anderson that the U.S. journalist and the 17 other Westerners being held hostage in Lebanon must not be allowed to slip into oblivion. Federico Mayor expressed the hope that ``these victims of violence'' would be released soon. Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, said she was aware of the many efforts of the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to secure the release of her brother and the other hostages, ``and I made this trip to Paris to say thank you and express my appreciation.'' Mayor has sent personal representatives to the Middle East to try to determine the fate of the hostages, and also spoken about them with ambassadors to UNESCO from countries in the area. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985, and is believed held by Shiite Moslem extremists with close ties to Iran. He has been held longest of the Western captives, who include seven otehr Americans. Mrs. Say is accompanied by Larry Heinzerling, deputy director of World Services for the AP, which supports her efforts financially and logistically while pressing its own efforts for Anderson's freedom. She is on a ``humanitarian pilgrimage'' to gather international support for the release of Anderson and the other hostages. Mrs. Say has met with Javier Perez de Cuellar, secretary-general of the Uited Nations; Pope John Paul II; and Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Mayor, citing the upheaval in Eastern Europe and changes in South Africa, and said his impression was that those holding the hostages ``cannot continue going against the winds of history.'' He said Mrs. Say's trip might lead national leaders to realize ``that this situation must come to an end. There is no justification for it continuing.'' She presented Mayor with a prayer bracelet bearing her brother's name and a quotation from the Bible to ``remember those in prison.'' Mrs. Say leaves Paris on Wednesday for Damascus to meet with the Syrian foreign minister, Farouk al-Sharaa. After that, she will go to London to see Robert Runcie, the archbishop of Canterbury. Runcie's personal envoy, Terry Waite, disappeared Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving his Beirut hotel to negotiate with kidnappers for the release of Anderson and other Americans.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actress Kim Basinger hooked up with a Chicago company to help pay the $20 million price tag for this Georgia town. Her partner is American Information Technologies, one of seven so-called baby Bells formed in the breakup of American Telephone & Telegrah Co. ``We have invested in the property in and around Braselton,'' company spokesman Steve Ford told the Gwinnett Daily News in an interview published Tuesday. ``We're investing where we think there's an opportunity for good long-term growth,'' he said. Neither the company, known as Ameritech, nor Miss Basinger would disclose details of the partnership. The founding family of Braselton, which is near Miss Basinger's native Athens, agreed last March to sell the actress about 1,700 acres _ the bulk of the small town in northeast Georgia. Among property included in the deal is a bank, an industrial park, 50 other buildings and two miles of interstate highway frontage. Tentative development plans include a movie studio, said Charles Sheron, a local developer. Miss Basinger, 36, was featured in the movies ``Batman,'' ``My Stepmother is an Alien'' and ``9{ Weeks.''

Actress Mariel Hemingway and other celebrities bugged about aerial pesticide spraying against the Medfly were among hundreds of protesters demanding a halt to the overhead dustings. Actor John Ratzenberger, who portrays letter carrier Cliff Clavin on ``Cheers,'' and actress Allyce Beasley, who played secretary Agnes Dipesto on ``Moonlighting,'' also turned out for a demonstration Monday at the federal building on the city's west side. ``It seems those politicians with a head-in-the-sand attitude are building a gallows with this issue, and I'm more than happy to be standing up there with the rope,'' Ratzenberger said. The state is spraying 400 square miles of Los Angeles and Orange counties to wipe out the worst infestation of the crop-destroying bug since 1981-82. Helicopters drop a mixture of the pesticide malathion and sticky corn syrup bait. Leon Spaugy, agriculture commissioner for Los Angeles County, has repeatedly contended the spraying is safe. He says it will be stopped when the state can find enough sterile Medflies to stall breeding. Critics say too little is known about malathion's long-term effects on humans.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Boxing heavyweight champion James ``Buster'' Douglas will be on the other side of the count Friday _ as a wrestling referee. The World Wrestling Federation announced Monday that Douglas, who knocked out Mike Tyson Feb. 11, will be a special referee for a match between Hulk Hogan and Randy Savage. ``Having knocked out Tyson, Douglas is a man who has enough guts and determination to come between bitter enemies Hogan and Savage and call a fair match,'' the federation said in a statement. The wrestling match at Joe Louis Arena was to be broadcast live Friday at 10 p.m. EST on NBC-TV.

Country singer Rodney Crowell says he forgot about his Grammy-nominated tune ``After All This Time,'' until he found a portion of it in a box years after he wrote it. ``I wrote the first two verses when I was living in L.A. in 1978,'' Crowell said. ``I had some boxes that I hadn't unpacked since I moved to Nashville from L.A. I started going through them and I found these lyrics.'' Crowell sat down and finished writing the song, which tells the story of two people who work to stay together. It's been nominated for best country song. Crowell has also been nominated for best country male vocal performance for his rendition of the song. The Grammys were to be broadcast live at 8 p.m. EST Wednesday on CBS-TV.

DOC.HEAD: White House Was Aware of Terrorists' Missile Threat at Summit
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Tuesday that the Secret Service had known there was a possibility that drug terrorists had surface-to-air missiles when President Bush flew to Colombia for last week's four-nation drug summit. Ten such weapons were seized by Colombian police Monday. ``There was intelligence before we left of various kinds about missiles and rockets and other kinds of equipment, about people with various plans,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. But he added that the reports were difficult to confirm at the time. The weapons seized Monday in a raid on a Bogota drug hidout were capable of downing large aircraft. Two men were arrested. Bush's meeting Thursday with presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia, Alan Garcia of Peru and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia in the port city of Cartagena was held amid extremely tight security. Security preparations included manuevers to lessen the chance of a missile attack on the presidential aircraft. Air Force One did not fly directly into Cartagena, where the approach would have been over land, but into a more secure airport in Barranquilla, where the approach was over the sea. Hhis helicopter then flew fast and low into Cartagena, accompanied by four other copters that zigzagged in a diversionary pattern. The helicopters took a roundabout route to stay over water as much as possible. Bush had brushed aside concerns of some senior aides in deciding to attend the summit. The officials expressed deep relief on the return trip once Air Force One was out of Colombian air space. Fitzwater, who was asked at his daily White House news briefing about the weapons seizure, said warnings that the terrorists had shoulder-held SA-7 missiles and might use them against the president were not deemed to be ``confirmable information.'' ``There's intelligence suggesting all kinds of capabilities that always have to be matters of concern, but nothing that we could confirm, ...'' he said. ``Suffice to say that the Secret Service was aware of these kinds of activities there, but I would not specifically say what we knew and didn't know, '' Fitzwater said. ``We don't talk about security information because we don't want others to know how much we know and how we find it out and how we work with other governments to get these kinds of information. And, ... for political reasons, it does no good to try to embarrass the host country,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Angola, Cuba Agree to Resume Cuban Troop Withdrawal
DOC.TEXT: Angola and Cuba agreed Tuesday to resume a withdrawal of Cuban troops from the African nation, one month after the pullout was suspended, the Angolan foreign minister said. The withdrawal of the estimated 28,000 Cubans still in Angola would start again Sunday to comply with U.S.-brokered regional peace accords signed in December 1988 by the two countries and South Africa, said Foreign Minister Pedro de Castro Van Dunem. ``It is a sovereign decision of Angola and Cuba ... that reflects our political maturity,'' he said. Van Dunem headed the Angolan delegation at talks with Cuba that began Monday and led to the decision, which also was announced by the Cuban news agency Prensa Latina. Havana suspended the troop withdrawal Jan. 25, after four Cubans died in an attack by rebels of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known as UNITA. The incident occurred in western Angola above the 13th parallel, currently the southernmost limit for Havana's soldiers, according to the peace accord. Van Dunem said the two nations adopted a declaration requesting U.S. guarantees to prevent the rebel attacks on Cubans. He said the attacks endangered the New York accords. Van Dunem also criticized U.S. aid to UNITA, and what he called Washington's ``not very positive'' attitude toward Angola's Marxist government. ``We would like the United States to cease its interference in the Angolan question,'' van Dunem said. ``We're sure that if they want to use their influence with UNITA, there will be no more attacks on Cubans.'' UNITA chief Jonas Savimbi, in a broadcast on the rebels' Black Cockerel radio Tuesday, said there was no proof Cuban soldiers fought in a recent government offensive. He said he sent a letter to Cuban leader Fidel Castro apologizing for the January attack in which seven Cubans were also wounded. ``We guaranteed (Castro) the death of the Cuban soldiers was involuntary and that no such incident will be repeated,'' Savimbi said, ``It's in our interests that the Cubans go home.'' UNITA receives a reported $50 million a year in U.S. assistance, including sophisticated ground-to-air Stinger missiles. The government forces are equipped with Soviet weapons. More than 31,000 Cubans of an estimated 50,000 were withdrawn before the Jan. 25 suspension. Under the New York accords, 33,000 are to have left by April 1. All are to be gone by mid-1991. Fighting has flared in recent weeks in southeast Angola, where government and rebel troops are battling for control of a strategic airstrip and rebel base near Mavinga, 700 miles southeast of Luanda. A UNITA statement Tuesday in Lisbon, Portugal, said rebels attacked government soldiers carrying supplies to troops near Mavinga. It said Monday that rebels bombarded a government garrison at Cuito Cuanavale, 90 miles to the northwest. The statement repeated rebel claims that Soviet-supplied government planes were dropping chemical bombs behind UNITA lines, south of Mavinga. A separate UNITA statement said seven experts from Austria, Belgium, France and Spain arrived Tuesday at rebel headquarters in Jamba, 120 miles south of Mavinga, to verify the claims. UNITA also said its forces killed 13 government fighters Sunday at Barraca garrison, Bengo province, near Luanda. There was no independent confirmation of the claims, but the Angolan state news agency said 10 rebels died in clashes in central Huambo, Cuanza South and Benguela provinces last week. The battle for Mavinga, said to be the heaviest in the 15-year conflict, has darkened hopes of getting government and rebel representatives back to the negotiating table. Peace talks collapsed only weeks after Savimbi and President Jose Eduardo dos Santos sealed a truce before 18 African leaders at Gbadolite, Zaire, on June 22. The rebels have sabotaged power and water supplies to Luanda several times in the past month. UNITA has been fighting to force the government to share power since shortly after Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Back on Sale in France March 1
DOC.TEXT: New shipments of sparkling Perrier water will arrive on French shelves March 1 bearing a special label showing they were bottled after last week's worldwide recall, the company said Tuesday. Source Perrier SA told its domestic distributors that its representatives would visit them in the next week to collect bottles withdrawn from sale. Perrier representatives at the company's headquarters were unavailable to say when the bottled water might return to the United States and other foreign markets. When the recall was announced Feb. 14, company executives said 2{ months might be needed to withdraw 160 million bottles from sale in 120 countries and replace them with water without the cancer-causing chemical benzene. Traces of benzene have been discovered in Perrier samples in several countries, including the United States, where 72 million bottles have been pulled off the shelves. Benzene entered Perrier's bottling line at Vergeze in southern France when workers failed to replace a filter that carries carbon dioxide gas from the underground spring to the plant, executives said. The benzene occurs naturally, they said. The recall operation is expected to cost the company $200 million.

DOC.HEAD: Fresh MiGs Sent To Cuba; US Concerned
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Tuesday that Cuba has received a new shipment of high-performance Soviet fighter planes that the United States ``simply cannot tolerate'' such developments. Under questioning, department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler denied that the statement constituted a threat to Cuba. She referred reporters to recent testimony before a Soviet legislative committee by Secretary of State James A. Baker III in which he said Cuba posed no threat to the United States. In confirming a delivery of new MiG-29 jet fighters, Ms. Tutwiler gave no figure. The Washington Times, which reported the shipment in Tuesday's editions, put the number at six. The report said the combined total of MiGs in Cuba's arsenal has now risen to more than 300, most of them older models. Ms. Tutwiler noted Baker had told the Soviet legislators during a visit to Moscow two weeks ago that the United States has difficulty understanding why the Kremlin continues to send MiG-29s to Cuba, particularly at a time when Cuba has been so critical of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform policies. Ms. Tutwiler also quoted Baker as saying, ``Cuba is actively supporting the insurgency in El Salvador and it is these kind of activities close to the shores of the United States that we simply cannot tolerate.'' Initially, Ms. Tutwiler dismissed as ``hypothetical'' a question as to whether the statement was meant as a threat to Cuba. She later said no threat had been intended.
