Ms. Tutwiler also attached little significance to the internal reforms announced recently by the Cuban Communist Party. She said the reforms appear aimed at consolidating the strength of Cuba's one-party system. The announcement, Ms. Tutwiler added, ``distances Cuba from the current wave of reform sweeping Eastern Europe by rejecting any attempt to duplicate foreign models, permit democratic processes or allow a multi-party system. ``In other words, the Cuban government seems committed to maintaining a rigid, one-party Marxist-Leninist dictatorship, the very system which socialist states in other parts of the world are now reforming.''

DOC.HEAD: Rival Christians Reinforce Positions; Mediators Work for Peace
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces reinforced their positions Tuesday and mediators sought ways to end a 3-week-old war for supremacy that has killed more than 650 people, most of them civilians. A cease-fire agreed upon Saturday by Gen. Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea, commander of the Lebanese Forces militia, appeared to be holding. Sniper fire could be heard throughout the day in Christian east Beirut, but no major battles were reported. The 19,000 troops loyal to Aoun trucked in large quantities of arms and ammunition to bases in the east Beirut districts of Furn el-Shubbak, Tahwita and Horsh Tabet. In adjacent Ashrafiyeh, one of two militia strongholds in east Beirut, Lebanese Forces chief of staff Fuad Malek inspected positions and said his men were prepared to fight on if necessary. ``The Lebanese Forces fighters are ready ... to teach the attackers a new lesson,'' said Malek, a retired army major general. ``Ashrafiyeh cannot be taken.'' Ashrafiyeh, on Beirut's highest hill, commands the network of roads linking areas held by Aoun with Beirut port, which the militia controls. Aoun appeared to have backed off a weekend ultimatum to Geagea to surrender the port and east Beirut's Karantina district, his headquarters area next to Ashrafiyeh, by Tuesday night or face an all-out assault. A source close to the three-member mediation committee said it had succeeded ``in extending the truce on a day-to-day basis,'' but that amounted to little more than ``the hope that an agreement of some sort might emerge.'' Aoun attacked Geagea on Jan. 30, trying to establish sole authority over the 310-square-mile enclave east and north of Beirut, where 1 million Christians live. The Lebanese forces, with 6,000 regulars and thousands of reservists, is Lebanon's largest Christian militia. Police say 667 people had been killed and 1,872 wounded in the worst fighting between Christians in a Moslem-Christian civil war that has cost more than 150,000 lives since April 1975. The general's forces control about one-third of the Christian enclave and Geagea holds the rest. They agreed Monday to a six-point plan designed to consolidate the truce, but it falls far short of an overall settlement. Many observers see it as a temporary compromises allowing both sides to regroup. Geagea agreed to formation of an eight-man ``national authority'' in the enclave under Aoun's leadership, the source close to the mediators said, but he added: ``Even if Aoun goes along with this, it would not mean that a political settlement has been reached.'' He said there were ``no indications'' Aoun would drop his demand the Lebanese Forces be disbanded and turned into a political party, or that Geagea would accept it. Mediators met with Aoun Tuesday in his bunker beneath the shattered presidential palace in Baabda, a Christian suburb east of Beirut. President Elias Hrawi, elected by Parliament in November with a mandate to implement a Lebanese peace plan Aoun opposes, dismissed him as military commander but the general will not step aside. Aoun does not recognize Hrawi's authority and refuses to turn over the presidential palace.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Refinery Explosion Kills Two, Injures Three
DOC.TEXT: A truck loading liquefied petroleum gas into a storage tank caught fire and exploded at an Amoco Oil Co. refinery Tuesday, killing two people and injuring three others, authorities said. The accident occurred shortly before 10 a.m. near the main storage area of the refinery, prompting evacuations of nearby residents and closing streets and highways. No storage tanks were ignited, Amoco spokeswoman Lisa Houghton said. The names of the dead were not immediately released. Amoco firefighters brought the blaze under control by noon, authorities said. Ms. Houghton said five trucks were in the loading area at the time of the blast. Three truck drivers were taken to St. Catherine Hospital in nearby East Chicago, where they were in fair condition with undisclosed injuries, said Donna Yanas, a hospital spokeswoman. Two other drivers who were in the area were not injured, Ms. Houghton said. Pablo Unat, a police dispatcher, said about 100 people within a one-mile radius of the fire were evacuated. A church and school were made available to them.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Americans love to eat, but many spice their pleasure with a splash of worry and a dash of guilt, a Gallup poll released Tuesday indicates. More than nine in 10 respondents to the telephone survey said they enjoy food and nearly six in 10 said they enjoy it a lot. At the same time, 56 percent said they worry about fat and cholesterol in the foods they eat. Women were more conscious of their diets and also more worried about chowing down. More than four in 10 of the women surveyed said they feel guilty about eating foods they like. Fewer than three in 10 men agreed. There were other disparities between the sexes. Seventy percent of the women said they were eating more fiber and 57 percent of the men said the same thing. Six in 10 women were consuming more calcium. Fewer than four in 10 men joined them. Nearly three-quarters of those surveyed said they were trimming fat from their diets and roughly two-thirds reported cutting back on saturated fats, cholesterol and fried foods. The Gallup Organization conducted the survey of 772 American adults Dec. 11-28 for the American Dietetic Association and International Food Information Council. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.

Buckling up may pay off some day in West Virginia. State Sen. Ned Jones introduced a bill Monday that would give police officers the authority to hand out lottery tickets to belt-wearing motorists. The bill would exclude drunken drivers or motorists who violate the speed limit by more than 10 mph. It would be up to the state police to figure out how to dole out the lottery tickets, which would not be awarded unless everyone in an auto had their seat belts on. The Legislature recently voted down a bill to require motorists to wear seat belts. Jones said his approach is just the ticket. ``Now we're using the carrot instead of the stick,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Tukwila: the Town, the Newspaper Column, and Rex and Debby
DOC.TEXT: The suburb of Tukwila has achieved fame, or embarrassment, with a newspaper column that has made the town a euphemism for an act between two consenting adults. Reaction in Tukwila to the town's new civic image ranges from rage to amusement, and some folks feel any advertising for the town is good advertising. It began when Seattle Times columnist Eric Lacitis wrote recently about Rex and Debby Allen, who volunteered the information that they had sex 500 times in nine months last year. They kept track on their calendar, Mrs. Allen said. Lacitis decided to use the euphemism ``visiting Tukwila'' for the activity in which the Allens engaged so often. The Allens are considering printing bumper stickers reading: ``Have You Gone to Tukwila Today?'' But the Tukwila City Council denounced the column. ``We're tired of Tukwila being known as the Rodney Dangerfield of King County _ we get no respect,'' declared Councilman Clarence Moriwaki. ``Whenever people need something to poke fun at, they think of Tukwila,'' said Councilman Joe Duffie. ``It's a big disgrace to the city.'' A local television comedy show, ``Almost Live,'' created a skit called ``Visiting Tukwila,'' which produced such other euphemisms for the same activity: ``Riding the Monorail,'' ``Working at Boeing'' and ``Shooting Herschel,'' the collective name given troublesome sea lions that eat steelhead trout swimming through on their way to spawn. Tukwila was previously most famous as the site of a shopping mall, and City Administrator John McFarland commented: ``Any publicity that's in fun or positive we don't mind.'' He noted that Tukwila is derived from an Indian phrase meaning ``land of the hazelnuts.'' Carlo Macri, a 26-year Tukwila resident, also said the free advertising is just fine. ``I'm not offended at all,'' he said in an interview at a local bar. ``The more recognition we get, the better.'' In the meantime, Allen, 37, an engineering inspector, and his wife, a 29-year-old technician, have set a goal of 750 visits to Tukwila for 1990. ``There are worse things we could do,'' Mrs. Allen said.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Front Threatens Shuttle Launch
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Atlantis, due to lift off Thursday on a secret military mission, faces a 70 percent chance of delay due to threatening high winds, clouds and thunderstorms, NASA said Tuesday. Despite the dismal forecast, NASA officials said the countdown that began Sunday was continuing smoothly. ``Everything's still going smoothly ... no hitches whatsoever,'' said space agency spokeswoman Lisa Malone. ``Weather is the only issue right now.'' Forecasters said a front that moved through Monday night had stalled south of Cape Canaveral and was expected to shift back to the north on Wednesday night. On Monday, the weather forecast had been 60 percent favorable but dropped overnight as the weather system advanced. A low cloud cover prevented the astronauts from taking part early Tuesday morning in routine practice flights aboard a shuttle training aircraft. Instead, the five men reviewed flight data and prepared for a possible practice flight Wednesday, NASA spokesman Kyle Herring said. The astronauts were in bed by early afternoon, adjusting their hours to match the sleep time they will have in space, from about noon to 8 p.m. Because of the secrecy surrounding the mission, NASA was not providing precise countdown information and would say only that liftoff will occur between midnight and 4 a.m. Thursday. It will make the count public nine minutes before the planned blastoff. Sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said Atlantis will lift off at 1 a.m. Atlantis is the sixth flight in 34 missions dedicated solely to a national security payload. Officials say the secrecy makes it harder for Soviet reconnaissance satellites and a spy ship off Cape Canaveral to track the shuttle and learn its mission. The sources said the astronauts are to deploy a 37,300-pound satellite to snap high-resolution reconnaissance photos and to listen in on military and diplomatic communications around the world. They said the shuttle will be launched into an orbit that will fly over most of the Soviet Union. The satellite, known by the code name AFP-731, and other reconniassance spacecraft will help verify whether the Soviets are complying with U.S.-Soviet disarmament agreements being forged. The Soviets have their own spy satellites to monitor U.S. compliance. Navy Capt. John O. Creighton is commanding the crew. The other astronauts are Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Lt. Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot.

DOC.HEAD: Health Secretary Puts Cost of Smoking to Society at $52 Billion a Year
DOC.TEXT: Health Secretary Louis Sullivan continued his campaign against tobacco companies Tuesday and issued a report showing that smoking costs the country more than $52 billion annually in health care costs and lost productivity. Sullivan condemned tobacco company advertising practices that target women, minorities and young people, saying ``they must stop their irresponsibility.'' In testimony before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, he also called on advertising agencies to join anti-smoking efforts by renouncing tobacco ads and said television stations should donate free air time to help educate viewers about the dangers of smoking. Sullivan also said that while the Bush administration supports the intent of legislation to increase regulation of tobacco products and educate about the risks of smoking, it believes the bill, which would cost an estimated $185 million, is unnecessary. The Tobacco Product Education and Health Protection Act of 1990 would establish a center as part of the federal Centers for Disease Control to expand education efforts on smoking, conduct smoking-related research and regulate tobacco products much as the Food and Drug Administration regulates food products. The center also would administer a paid advertising program to discourage smoking and provide incentive grants to states to encourage enactment and better enforcement of laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco to minors. Sullivan said his department yearly spends about $79 million on anti-smoking programs, many of which duplicate the efforts proposed in the legislaton. He said free public service announcements about the risks of smoking are preferable to government-paid ads in light of other demands on the federal budget. He also said that regulating the additives in cigarettes, envisioned in the bill, would send the wrong message. ``We're concerned that this would suggest that we believe that under certain conditions, with certain monitoring, that tobacco is safe,'' he said. ``We would rather see our efforts on reducing and elmiminating by the year 2000 all tobacco from our society.'' However, Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass. and chairman of the Senate committee, noted that bottled Perrier water was pulled from the market when it was found to contain benzene at levels up to four times what is allowed under federal standards, while a surgeon general's report estimated the benzene content of cigarettes is 2,000 times higher than that. ``The consumer has a right to know the key ingredients and additives to a pack of cigarettes when they purchase the product,'' Kennedy said. Sullivan agreed that consumers should have such information. Charles O. Whitley, representing The Tobacco Institute, noted in testimony submitted to the committee that Congress previously considered and rejected disclosure of ingredient information because it contains trade secrets. This information is supplied to the health and human services secretary, but it does not identify the company or brand of cigarettes. Whitley also said other provisions in the bill aren't needed because young people are already aware of the risks of smoking. He also denied that the industry targets young people in advertising campaigns to encourage them to take up the habit. He also defended the industry against critics who say that tobacco companies target women and minorities, saying the industry is not trying to encourage people to start smoking but rather hopes to retain or gain market share from competitors. Sullivan released a report on the economic consequences of smoking that estimated smoking-related disease costs each American $221 a year largely in health-care and insurance costs. He said the costs average $1 billion per state annually, but range from a high of $5.8 billion in California to a low of $82 million in Alaska. The report's analysis, the first of its kind, is based on 1985 statistics. Smoking causes an estimated 390,000 deaths in the United States annually and about 29 percent of adults smoke, he said. Sullivan recently criticized R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. for its plans to market a cigarette targeted at blacks. Reynolds subsequently dropped those plans, but now intends to test-market a cigarette called Dakota. News accounts have said the company was considering gearing the cigarette toward young women with a high school education or less. Sullivan has been concerned about minorities because they have higher rates of smoking than whites and have a higher rate of smoking-related disease and death. Among high school seniors, the smoking rate has leveled off at around 19 percent, he said, while lung cancer has surpassed the incidence of breast cancer among women.

DOC.HEAD: Rates on T-Bills Rise
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in Tuesday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $7.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.80 percent, up from 7.65 percent last week. Another $7.6 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.77 percent, also up from 7.65 percent last week. The rates were the highest since three-month bills sold for 7.83 percent on Feb. 5, and six-month bills averaged 7.92 percent on Oct. 2, 1989. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.07 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,802.80 and 8.20 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,607.20. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 8.05 percent last week, down from 8.13 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: `Music Box' and Oliver Stone Get Golden Bear Awards
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. film ``Music Box,'' starring Jessica Lange as an attorney who defends her father against charges of war crimes, won a Golden Bear award Tuesday as the 40th Berlin film festival came to a close. The Golden Bear is the top award at the prestigious festival. ``Music Box,'' directed by Costa-Gavras, shared its Golden Bear with a 1969 Czech work titled ``Skylarks on the String.'' The latter film, which criticizes the former communist state, was banned by authorities there for 20 years. Another Golden Bear went as a special anniversary prize to American director Oliver Stone for his film ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' starring Tom Cruise as a paraplegic Vietnam War veteran who becomes a champion of the anti-war movement. A short animated film from Italy called ``Mistertao'' won the third and final Golden Bear awarded this year. The event, which ranks with the Cannes and Venice film festivals as the most important in the world, was held for the first time in East Berlin as well as West Berlin. The 12-day festival brought a shower of famous stars down on the city, including Ms. Lange, Stone, Sally Field, Daryl Hannah and Michael Douglas. Other U.S. entries included ``The War of the Roses'' with Douglas and Kathleen Turner and ``Shadow Makers,'' starring Paul Newman. All together 22 feature films and 16 short works were in the running for the Bears. Seven Silver Bears were presented in various categories at the end of the festival. One went to American actor Morgan Freeman and actress Jessica Tandy for the best joint performance in Bruce Beresford's ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' Another was awarded to Michael Verhoeven as best director for the West German entry ``The Nasty Girl.'' The film deals with the rejection a young woman faces from her home town when she begins investigating her neighbors' Nazi pasts. A film about homosexuals called ``Coming Out'' _ East Germany's only entry _ won a Silver Bear for its ``sensitive handling of the dilemma of minorities _ whatever kind,'' the jury said in a statement. Four other Silver Bears went to entries from Great Britain, the Soviet Union, China and Brazil.

DOC.HEAD: Hearings Planned on Whether Foreign Companies Pay Enough Taxes
DOC.TEXT: A House Ways and Means subcommittee announced Tuesday that it will hold hearings into whether foreign companies' U.S. subsidiaries are paying their fair share of taxes. Rep. J.J. Pickle, D-Texas, chairman of the subcommittee that oversees the IRS, made the announcement during a hearing on efforts by the Internal Revenue Service to increase collections of delinquent taxes. ``The IRS does take this question seriously,'' IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. said when asked about the auditing of subsidiaries of foreign corporations. He said he does not know whether the audits include investigation of fraud by any subsidiary. The IRS confirmed Monday a New York Times story that it is investigating whether numerous U.S. arms of foreign companies underpaid billions of dollars in taxes in the 1980s. The IRS said more than half of 36,800 foreign-owned companies that filed tax returns in 1986 reported no taxable income. Earlier, a report by the staff of the congressional Joint Committee on Taxation concluded ``there is some indication that the level of tax payments of foreign-owned businesses in the United States is unusually low.''

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan Is Guardedly Optimistic That Nation Can Avoid Recession
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan on Tuesday expressed ``guarded optimism'' that the country can avoid a recession this year, but his warnings on the dangers of accelerating inflation helped send financial markets into a tailspin. Setting up a potential clash with the administration, Greenspan said the central bank was looking for the economy to grow at a rate far below the one on which the administration based its 1991 budget. Wall Street, which has been battered this year by rising foreign interest rates, took Greenspan's inflation warnings and growth forecast as further evidence that the central bank is intent on pursuing a tight money policy to battle inflation and thus will not move anytime soon to lower interest rates. At mid-afternoon, interest rates on long-term government bonds had jumped sharply while the prices, which move in the opposite direction, fell as much as $18 per $1,000 in face value. The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 stocks was down more than 38 points at the close of business. ``We're in an area where (inflation) is in danger of accelerating,'' Greenspan said in his appearance before a House Banking subcommittee. He called the performance of inflation so far this year ``horrendous'' although he said the January's jump in prices was attributable in large part to temporary factors stemming from severe cold in December. But he said that the risks of higher inflation in the present circumstances were ``larger than we should be willing to tolerate.'' In the new Fed economic forecast, the central bank projected that the economy, as measured by the gross national product, will grow at an anemic rate of between 1.75 percent and 2 percent this year, the slowest annual growth rate since the 1981-82 recession. The Bush administration, in a forecast released last month with its 1991 budget request, forecast growth almost a full percentage point higher at 2.6 percent, when measured from the fourth quarter of 1989. The administration also predicted that interest rates would drop sharply from their current levels, a decline that would lower the government's borrowing costs on the $2.9 trillion national debt. With the Fed expected to keep interest rates high to restrain inflationary pressures, economists said both the administration's growth and interest rate assumptions would prove to be too optimistic, thus ballooning the federal budget deficit by billions of dollars. ``The Greenspan testimony is a clear indication of a toughened central bank stance against inflation,'' said Alan Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``The message is that interest rates will stay high and perhaps go higher as the central bank keeps the economy throttled back to bring down inflation.'' From June through December, the central bank had been gradually easing short-term interest rates out of concern that weakness in the economy might spell the end of the seven-year-old economic recovery, the longest in peacetime history. While economic growth did slow to a barely discernible 0.5 percent annual rate from October through December, the worst performance in 3{ years, Greenspan in his testimony that he believed the danger point for an imminent recession had now passed. He cited a variety of January statistics from rising auto sales to a surge in new home construction to bolster his belief that a modest rebound was occurring and that the ``weakest point may have passed.'' ``While we cannot be certain that we are as yet out of the recessionary woods, such evidence warrants at least guarded optimism,'' he said. The Fed's economic forecast for 1990 represented only a modest change from a preliminary estimate of 1.5 percent to 2 percent GNP growth made last June. But the central bank did significantly alter its forecast on inflation, predicting consumer prices would rise 4 percent to 4.5 percent this year, down from a June forecast of a 4.5 percent to 5 percent increase. Analysts took this revision as another sign that the Fed was toughening its inflation-fighting resolve. ``The ultimate objective of economic policy is to foster the maximum sustainable rate of economic growth,'' Greenspan said, adding, however, that the economy might have to undergo sub-par growth for a period of time in order to make sure inflation remained contained. On other topics: _Greenspan said that there was not ``at any time'' a desire on the part of federal officials to rescue Drexel Burnham Lambert, the large securities firm which got into financial difficulties because of its aggressive marketing of junk bonds. _He expressed his belief that the current turmoil in junk bonds would stabilize and that the sales of these high-yield, high-risk securities would continue, although at a lower level. _The Fed, in its economic outlook, said that the near-term prospects for a moderation in labor cost pressures were not favorable and added that the recent declines in the value of the dollar would also worsen inflation by boosting the price of imported goods.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed in Pro-democracy Protests
DOC.TEXT: By RAJU GOPALAKRISHNAN=

Police in southeastern Nepal fired Tuesday on pro-democracy protesters who tried to burn down a police station, killing at least three demonstrators, the government said. Also Tuesday, youths battled riot police on the streets of Bhaktapur, seven miles east of the capital. There were no reports of deaths or injuries in that protest. A Home Ministry statement said a man wounded Monday when police fired into a crowd in Bhaktapur died Tuesday. That brought to 11 the number of people killed since Sunday, the first day of nationwide demonstrations against a 29-year-old ban on political parties. Witnesses said at least two more people have been killed in the clashes. According to the government, police have arrested 175 people throughout Nepal in recent weeks. Opposition sources put the number at more than 400 in Katmandu alone. Nepal's estimated 2,000 lawyers went on a one-day strike Tuesday to protest the detention of suspected supporters of the campaign, said Basu Deb Dhungana, president of the Nepal Bar Association. ``We are always for the rule of the law and human rights,'' Dhungana said. Also in the capital, riot police were deployed near the Bir Hospital, where the victims of Monday's protests were taken. Many people gathered outside the gates of the hospital, but there were no demonstrations. Tuesday's deaths occurred in Jadukuha, 100 miles southeast of Katmandu, when police fired on a mob trying to burn down a police station, the government said in a statement. A protester and three policemen also were injured in the violence, it said. Police fired in self-defense after a baton charge and tear gas failed to disperse the crowd, the statement said. No further details were given. In Bhaktapur Tuesday, young men hurled stones at police in riot gear who occasionally charged the crowds but mostly kept their distance. ``You dogs!'' yelled one man aiming a slingshot at steel-helmeted policemen, ``you killed our people.'' The policemen, wearing chest pads and shin guards over brown uniforms, took shelter behind pillars of the 17th century temples that dot the town. When police charged with batons, the rioters scampered into the narrow, stone-paved alleys of the town's main marketplace. In the two-story red brick houses along the alleys, women and children huddled behind half-open windows. ``This fight will continue,'' said a demonstrator who ran into an alley after hurling stones at officers. Police said they had orders not to use force and were content to keep the demonstrators at bay. ``Yesterday (Monday) we were on the offensive, today we are on the defensive,'' one officer said on condition of anonymity. At least four people were killed and fifteen injured Monday in Bhaktapur when police fired on demonstrators. That number included the protester who died Tuesday. Four people were killed Sunday in clashes between police and demonstrators elsewhere in Nepal, the Himalayan kingdom nestled between India, China and Tibet. Under the present constitution, the king is head of state. He commands wide influence in the country's 140-member National Assembly, which is headed by a prime minister. The assembly's 112 elected members, chosen through national balloting, cannot claim affiliation to any political party. Another 28 members are nominated by the king. Nepal's two-year experiment with democracy ended in 1960, when King Mahendra, the father of the present monarch, Birendra, dissolved the government and banned all political parties, accusing them of misusing power. The government says the campaign for democracy, sponsored by the Nepali Congress and the United Left Front, runs counter to a national referendum held in 1980, when the apolitical system was retained by a slight majority. The government also accuses the parties of trying to impose their version of democracy on Nepal. Nepal, a landlocked country of about 17 million people, is one of the poorest in the world, with an annual per capita income of $160.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Trade Policies Attacked in Congressional Hearing
DOC.TEXT: With German reunification speeding Western Europe's drive to create a 12-nation single market by 1992, President Bush's trade policies were attacked sharply Tuesday by both Democrats and Republicans in Congress. ``We're going to be dealt out of the deal,'' Rep. Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn., told top trade officials in the State and Commerce Departments and the White House Office of the U.S. Trade Representative. Rep. Toby Roth, R-Wis., complained that Bush ``is still living in the 1950s and '60s when we had free trade'' while the European Community is about to join Japan in erecting barriers to U.S. exports through its EC '92 directives. Gejdenson, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee's trade subcommittee, said adminstration officials assured him a year ago told that Europe '92 ``is going to be the best thing since sliced bread.'' But in the past nine months, he said, General Electric and United Technologies have decided to move some of their jet engine facilities to Europe to assure continued market access there. For the same reason, several semiconductor manufacturers have reversed their initial plans to build new plants here and are instead going to put them in Europe, he said. ``Companies in this country have decided that you're not going to get the job done, so they're moving their investments to Europe,'' he asserted. Administration officials cited statistics at a hearing before Gejdenson's subcommittee showing that for the first time in five years, the United States in 1989 enjoyed a trade surplus with Europe _ a slight $1.7 billion. While claiming success in knocking down proposed barriers for keeping U.S. trucking companies and banks out of a unified European market, they admitted losing key rounds on broadcasting and agriculture products. ``We were not successful in the EC broadcast directive,'' said Peter Allgeier, the assistant U.S. trade representative for Europe. ``But we have not left the playing field on that one, let me assure you.'' Gejdenson complained that the administation hasn't even taken the field yet, citing a congressional directive last May to augment the U.S. delegation monitoring the negotiations in Brussels with three career Foreign Service officers from the Commerce Department. Administration officials said two of those positions should be filled by this summer. ``Our single biggest trading partner is changing all the rules of the game'' and this is being treated as ``something we can get around to in the lazy days of summer,'' Gejdenson snapped. ``It just boggles the mind,'' he said. ``This isn't a simply a debate about between liberalization and protectionism. It's about the survival of American manufacturing and European dominance over us economically.'' Assistant Secretary of State Eugene McAllister said moves in the past week toward reunifying East and West Germany ``could very well help speed up'' the adoption of a single-market economy for all of Western Europe. ``Many of the EC nations are intent upon keeping Germany Western-oriented and they see EC '92 as a very important contributing factor to that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Increases Borrowing for Thrift Bailout Agency
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, under pressure to speed up its savings and loan cleanup, said Tuesday it will borrow $11 billion by the end of March for its thrift bailout agency. The new money should start flowing to the Resolution Trust Corp. by the end of this month, said William Taylor, the chief staff officer of a Treasury-led board overseeing the agency. Without the money, the RTC would face a cash crunch that would virtually halt the disposal of failed thrifts after this week, according to RTC spokesman Stephen J. Katsanos. Bailout legislation enacted in August provides $50 billion through next year to cover the losses of failed thrifts. But the trust corporation needs to borrow as much as an additional $100 billion in ``working capital.'' The $11 billion is the first leg of the borrowing, which is to be repaid as the government sells loans, real estate and other assets inherited from the failed thrifts. The agency hasn't announced its borrowing plans for subsequent quarters, but Taylor said the amount in the April-June period ``could be more'' than $11 billion. Tuesday's announcment follows a ruling last week by the Justice Department, which found the RTC a government agency eligible to borrow through the Treasury. Although the trust corporation is overseen by a Treasury-led panel, its work is performed by an independent banking agency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Members of Congress and private analysts have harshly criticized the arrangement as bureaucratic and prone to delays. However, the establishment of the new borrowing plan likely will shift the brunt of pressure from the administration's oversight board to the FDIC. ``We're going to try to stay out of their way as much as possible,'' Taylor told reporters. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan, a member of the oversight panel, told a House Banking subcommittee Tuesday he expected ``a significant acceleration of activity.'' At the end of last week, the RTC had disposed of only 49 of the 368 failed thrifts it has seized. The agency has made little headway in selling the $180 billion in assets owned by the S&Ls. It is projecting an increase in resolutions to 50 institutions per quarter, approximately double the pace of its first six months of operation.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Report Rips Management of Military Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: A Pentagon report released Tuesday said that the Air Force colonel who resigned last week as editor of the Pacific Stars and Stripes newspaper violated military regulations by manipulating the paper's news content. Col. Edwin J. Montgomery resigned Friday, citing the report by ombudsman Philip Foisie. Foisie was hired by the Defense Department last year to assess the free flow of information to the military readership of the Toyko-based Pacific Stars and Stripes and its European sister publication based near Frankfurt, West Germany. Montgomery had said he was disappointed that Foisie viewed his editing practices as ``news management'' but was pleased he had not been accused of censorship. In his report, Foisie said that the editing process at Pacific Stars and Stripes under Montgomery was ``seriously flawed'' but that there was no censorship in the sense of readers being systematically deprived of any specific type of news. ``In my professional judgment, Col. Montgomery has too often infringed on the common practice of good journalism,'' Foisie wrote. ``If `censorship' is the wrong word, `news management' is probably the right description of these infringements, and it is expressly prohibited ... in the military regulations. ...'' Civilian journalists at Pacific Stars and Stripes have publicly complained of censorship by military editors, news management and harassment of journalists who raise objections. Foisie said Montgomery, who assumed the role of commander and editor-in-chief of the newspaper in 1986, was ``seriously miscast'' due to a lack of journalistic experience and had failed to delegate many editing duties. Foise credited Montgomery with improving the newspaper's financial position and said some of Montgomery's critics on the paper had exaggerated the ``news management'' problem by claiming he frequently killed stories unfavorable to the military. But Foisie said Montgomery was preoccupied with the details of editorial content and had introduced what many staff journalists consider ``an ideological element'' in deciding which stories were printed and how they were displayed in the paper. This, Foisie, wrote, ``has had a chilling effect on the staff and has induced a degree of self-censorship.'' Foisie said the Tokyo newsroom had fallen into disarray and was plagued by ``very low morale, an incipient staff revolt and one might say a staff conspiracy.'' Reiterating a recommendation he made in a preliminary report last month, Foisie said the newspaper should put a civilian in the post of top news executive. That would make the paper less vulnerable to charges that the military censors it, he said. The Stars and Stripes papers are ``authorized but unofficial publications,'' the Pentagon says. Their charter says they are to provide ``a free flow of news and information ... without censorship or news management.''

DOC.HEAD: Income Prospects Bright, but Still Under Record
DOC.TEXT: Prospects for farm income continue bright, although there is some slippage from the record level of two years ago, an Agriculture Department report said Tuesday. Net cash income may be in the range of $52 billion to $57 billion, compared with an estimated $53 billion in 1989 and the record of $57.2 billion in 1988. That is the money left for farmers after deducting cash expenses from gross cash income in a calendar year. It can include proceeds from sales of commodities held over from previous years. Net farm income, another method of bookkeeping, may be in the range of $44 billion to $49 billion this year, compared with $48 billion in 1989 and $42.7 billion in 1988. This method measures income from farming during a specific year, including changes in the value of inventories, allowances for family dwellings and depreciation. Figures for both accounting methods were unchanged from projections made by the department's Economic Research Service the last two months. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter noted in testimony before the House Agriculture Committee earlier Tuesday that ``virtually all indicators of farm sector well-being have improved'' the last few years. ``Farm income is up, farm failures are down, farmland values are recovering and debt-to-asset ratios have improved,'' Yeutter said. ``Commodity surpluses have all but disappeared, some idle land has returned to production, and farm program spending is down.'' The agency report said farmland values have been revised, based on the 1987 census of agriculture. The average U.S. price of farmland as of February 1989, for example, was revised upward to $667 per acre from the earlier estimate of $597. No state figures were included.

DOC.HEAD: Black Leaders Call for New Trial in Civil Rights Slaying
DOC.TEXT: Black leaders have renewed demands for new charges against a former fertilizer salesman who was tried and freed in the slaying of civil rights activist Medgar Evers 26 years ago. The Rev. L.D. Bass, a longtime civil rights leader in Jackson, contended Monday at a rally that prosecutors are not adequately pursuing a new trial against Byron De La Beckwith. ``We're not going to rest until Byron De La Beckwith is brought to justice in Mississippi,'' Bass told about a dozen people gathered for the protest in front of the Hinds County Courthouse. Murder charges against Beckwith, a white supremacist, were dropped after two all-white Hinds County juries were unable to reach verdicts in 1964. Prosecutors said Monday they are continuing to determine whether sufficient evidence exists to reopen the case. Evers, 37, who was a field secretary for the Mississippi NAACP, was killed June 12, 1963, by a bullet in the back as he emerged from his car at his Jackson home. Beckwith's rifle, bearing one of his fingerprints, was found near Evers' home. Beckwith contended the rifle had been stolen from him. The rifle and all other evidence from the two trials disappeared several months ago, presumably from the Hinds County circuit clerk's office where such documents and property were supposed to be kept. ``We are just as interested as anyone else in bringing the killer of Medgar Evers to justice, but it takes evidence to do that. Right now, we just don't have that evidence,'' Assistant District Attorney Bobby DeLaughter said Monday. Beckwith, 69, lives in Signal Mountain, Tenn. Last year, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and Jackson City Council asked for the case to be reopened after reports that the state's old segregation spy agency, the Sovereignty Commission, screened potential jurors before Beckwith's second trial. Prosecutors investigated and said they found no evidence of jury tampering. The local offices of the FBI, state Department of Archives and History and the Jackson Police Department failed to turn up the missing evidence, DeLaughter said. A search also was made of the FBI's Washington office, but DeLaughter had no word on the results. ``They have swept it (the case) under the rug and they're not even moving at a snail's pace,'' Bass said. ``We want the district attorney to come forward and bring this case to justice.'' Aaron Henry, president of the state NAACP who also attended the rally, questioned the sincerity of the hunt for the missing evidence. ``Keep on looking because whenever we don't want to do something, we find reasons not to do it,'' he said. Beckwith said by telephone Monday that he might return to Mississippi some day to seek political office. He ran unsuccessfully for lieutenant governor in Mississippi in 1967. ``If things get much worse in Mississippi, I plan to run for lieutenant governor so that people will know men and women of white Christian lineage will not put up with this deviltry,'' Beckwith said.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed in Kosovo; Army to Maintain Order
DOC.TEXT: An ethnic Albanian demonstrator was reported killed Tuesday in Kosovo, and the federal government decided to give the army a direct role in maintaining order in the restive southern province. State television said the demonstrator was killed in Titova Mitrovica, 28 miles northwest of Pristina, the provincial capital. It gave no details of the death, but reported ``numerous injuries among demonstrators and the police.'' Twenty-eight ethnic Albanians have been reported killed since January in Kosovo, an impoverished province of 1.9 million people where ethnic Albanians outnumber Slavs 9 to 1. According to official figures, the same number of people were killed a year ago after Serbia made constitutional changes that gave it near-total control. Until then, Kosovo had been an autonomous province within Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics. In an emergency meeting, the eight-member national presidency decided for the first time to involve the army, which has been deployed in Kosovo since last year, in quelling the unrest. A statement from the presidency carried by the official news agency Tanjug said it ``has decided to partially engage units of the Yugoslav Peoples' Army in Kosovo with the aim of protecting constitutional order and preventing violence.'' It said the ``security situation in Kosovo has seriously deteriorated'' because of the unrest, ``which could have tragic consequences for all citizens in this province and for the country as a whole.'' Parts of Kosovo have been under virtual martial law, particularly during the last month of renewed unrest. Serbs in Kosovo said Tuesday they would take up arms to protect themselves if the central government did not act. Serbs claim harassment by the majority in Kosovo, which is adjacent to Albania. Thousands of ethnic Albanians conducted strikes and stayed away from school Tuesday to protest the state of emergency in the region. Several thousand also demonstrated in Pristina and other towns, in some cases fighting with police. About 10,000 Serbs rallied in Kosovo Polje, a suburb of Pristina, to demand firm police action against ethnic Albanians demonstrating for more autonomy and democracy. The Serbs said in a statement they would ``take up arms'' if police did not arrest ``the ringleaders of Albanian separatism and terrorism.'' Serbian leaders in Kosovo have rejected dialogue with opposition movements, insisting that several prominent ethnic Albanian intellectuals who helped establish the groups are ``hostile elements'' who should be jailed. About 4,000 ethnic Albanian university students marched through Pristina chanting ``Democracy! Democracy!'' Tanjug said they urged ethnic Albanians to end street protests ``because they are being used'' by authorities ``as an excuse for the continued bloodshed, violence and repression.'' International human rights organizations and officials of the liberal Yugoslav republics of Slovenia and Croatia have accused Serbian authorities of violating human rights in Kosovo.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Cites Faster Lifting of U.S.-Canada Tariffs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday notified Congress that the governments of the United States and Canada had reached agreement on the quick lifting of tariffs on some 400 products worth $6 billion in trade. For the products covered, the agreement speeds up the timetable for lifting duties under the landmark U.S.-Canada free-trade agreement that took effect Jan. 1, 1989. That pact calls for phasing out all tariffs by 1999. U.S. products on which duties will be eliminated at once under the speeded-up agreement include chemicals, pharmaceutical products, photographic film, telecommunications equipment, electric motors and generators, hydraulic pumps, printed circuits and scientific instruments. Canadian products that will benefit include diesel engines, chemical plastics, machinery, textiles and certain food products. Two-way trade in goods and services between the United States and Canada is roughly $200 billion. About 70 percent is currently duty free. However, many products _ notably Canadian steel, lumber, paper and other forest products _ remain under tariffs that are being phased out under terms of the original free-trade agreement. These were not affected by Tuesday's action.

DOC.HEAD: King Says Toll-Free Phone Network a Success Despite Busy Signals
DOC.TEXT: Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King on Tuesday defended the agency's nationwide toll-free telephone network as a ``success story,'' but acknowledged that callers too often get busy signals. Mrs. King said the agency was preparing television and newspaper public service announcements encouraging people to ``have breakfast with Social Security'' by calling between 7 and 9 a.m. when lines are less busy. The telephone network, which went nationwide in October, was expected to handle about 250,000 calls a day, but more than 1.5 million people try to get through on peak days, and many call between 10 a.m. and 2 p.m., she said. ``The 800 number is the biggest success story we've had,'' Mrs. King said at a media briefing. ``We just have too a big a success on our hands ... the trick is how to manage it so that it works better.'' The telephone network _ reached by dialing 1-800-2345-SSA _ is staffed from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. local time across the country, and allows callers to take care of many matters without going into a Social Security office. However, congressional critics have complained that people often are unable to get through on the toll-free lines and that many don't get full and accurate information when they do get through. A House Ways and Means subcommittee was scheduled to hold a hearing Wednesday on the network. Mrs. King said a study by the Inspector General's Office of the Department of Health and Human Services found that 67 percent of those who used the toll-free line said they would use the telephone again to do business with Social Security, up from 53 percent in 1984. Eighty-two percent of those who contacted Social Security using the 800 number reported the service was good or very good, she said. ``What we are finding is that when people do get through, they find the service is courteous, they're very happy with the information they received,'' she said. In January, traditionally a busy month for the agency, an estimated 52 percent of calls to the toll-free number were met with busy signals, compared with 14 percent in December, 51 percent in November and 30 percent in October, Mrs. King said. Her goal is to reduce the busy rate on peak days to 35 percent by the end of the year. Mrs. King also announced three steps to improve morale and service at the Social Security Administration, where many workers have complained that they are overworked and unable to provide good service because of huge staff cuts during the Reagan administration. Mrs. King said she is: _Dispatching four ``strike teams'' to visit field offices throughout the country and approve additional employees and equipment where needs are the greatest. About 400 employees could be added, she said. _Suspending all numerical performance goals, such as handling a certain number of cases per day or per month. Mrs. King said the agency would come up with a new set of goals to better measure workloads and performance. _Naming Bill Rogers, a former Social Security employee from the Seattle area, as ombudsman to hear complaints and ideas from Social Security managers and employees.

DOC.HEAD: Senate OKs Labor Statistics Treaty
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Tuesday unanimously ratified an International Labor Organization convention agreement aimed at improving the collection and reporting of labor statistics around the world. The ILO Convention on Labor Statistics was approved 94-0, nearly five years after it was approved by the U.N.-affiliated labor organization in Geneva, Switzerland. President Reagan transmitted the treaty to the Senate on Jan. 3, 1989, less than three weeks before he left office. Reagan recommended its ratification at the time, as did Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Labor Secretary Ann McLaughlin. The Reagan Cabinet officers noted that the United States already was collecting and reporting basic labor force, employment and economic statistics of the kind the ILO was seeking in its convention on statistics. But these officials said that since the United States could readily abide by the terms of the treaty, there was no reason not to ratify it. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., told colleagues Tuesday that the labor statistics treaty afforded the Senate a good opportunity to go on record in supporting the work of the ILO.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Stresses Need To Combat Drugs At Home
With AM-Cocaine-Caterpillars, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Tuesday the ``most critical challenge'' facing the United States in combatting illegal drug use is the problem of domestic consumption rather blocking supplies from abroad. ``As long as the demand for drugs by Americans remains voracious, our nation faces an endless, uphill struggle to halt supply,'' Baker said. His remarks were prepared for delivery in New York at the U.N. Special Session on Narcotics. A text of his remarks was released by the State Department. Baker expressed hope that a U.N.-led effort to act against drug smuggling will help the world come closer to ending the drug scourge. He added that to be successful any such program must entail concrete commitments and be fully implemented by U.N. agencies. ``Certainly, we the member governments cannot ask the United Nations to do things that we will not do at home,'' he said. Baker's appearance at the U.N. session, just five days after the drug summit in Colombia, was aimed at reinforcing the high priority the Bush administration is attaching to the drug issue. He said the domestic anti-drug budget has increased to $7.6 billion, a 67 percent increase while, internationally, the increase has been 73 percent, to $3.1 billion. ``We fully realize that attacking the problem of domestic consumption is our most critical challenge,'' Baker said, indicating he is sympathetic to Latin appeals that the administration shift its emphasis to combatting drug abuse on the home front instead of the supply source. He added, however, that U.S. drug-control strategy calls for an attack on the drug problem in all its aspects _ consumption, trafficking, illicit production, treatment and rehabilitation.

DOC.HEAD: Plant Explosion Kills Two
DOC.TEXT: An explosion at an experimental factory for the production of pure hydrogen in the Ukrainian city of Rovno killed two people and injured three, the state news agency Tass reported Tuesday. An engineer ordered the evacuation of the plant on Monday after discovering a leak in the pumping station, but the explosion occurred before all the workers could get out, the agency said. The plant was destroyed. Tass, citing experts, said the blast caused no environmental pollution in Rovno, 600 miles southwest of Moscow. It said the accident was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Top Congressional Democrats Considering Income Tax Credit
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley offered praise on Tuesday to a proposal to allow people to partially offset the costs of the Social Security payroll tax by taking a credit on their income tax returns. The plan is one of several options under study by a task force of top House and Senate Democrats weighing what to do about the vast surpluses accumulated each year by the Social Security trust funds. The issue has attracted attention in recent weeks after Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., proposed reducing the surpluses by cutting the payroll tax. The Democratic leaders are considering a list of proposals compiled by aides. The lawmakers are expected to recommend a course of action as early as this week. Foley, D-Wash., called the income tax credit idea ``a very interesting proposal'' in his daily briefing with reporters, but provided no details. ``It would I think tend to restore some progressivity to the tax system, and it has other features I think are worthy of very serious consideration,'' Foley said. Workers pay a 7.65 percent Social Security payroll tax, an amount that is in addition to their income tax. Employers must also pay the government an equal amount on behalf of each employee. Critics have charged that the payroll tax discriminates against low- and middle-income workers because it is levied only on the first $51,300 of annual earnings. People pay no payroll tax on their wages above that amount, and pay no payroll tax at all on income from interest, dividends, rents and other non-wage earnings. Sources speaking on condition they not be identified said there are several formulations of the income-tax credit plan. No final decisions have been made on the credit's amount, who would qualify, or when it would begin. What it would accomplish, supporters say, is sidestep the criticism the Bush administration and other Republicans have leveled at Moynihan's proposed tax cut: that it tinkers with Social Security, a highly sensitive political issue for Congress. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater has said Moynihan's idea will eventually lead to offsetting tax increases or cuts in Social Security benefits. ``Its one great source of appeal obviously is you don't have to do anything about the Social Security trust fund,'' said one source. Moynihan's plan would cut the government's payroll tax collections by $62 billion over the next two years, a sizable addition to what is already an expected $138 billion budget deficit for this year. It has been criticized by Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas; House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill.; the American Association of Retired Persons and the National Association of Manufacturers. But the plan is believed to have the support of many members of Congress because it would cut taxes. Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said Tuesday that there is ``a large, fluid body'' of senators undecided about Moynihan's bill, and predicted there ``could be a stampede if favor of the Moynihan proposal'' should there be a vote on it. The Social Security task force consists of Bentsen, Rostenkowski, Sasser, Senate Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. This year, the Social Security trust fund is expected to have a $66 billion surplus. Moynihan and others say those collections make the federal deficit appear smaller that it really is.

DOC.HEAD: Fifteen Held, None Yet Charged in Killings of Americans in Panama
DOC.TEXT: Former members of the Panamanian Defense Forces are among 15 people in custody in Panama in connection with the murders of an American citizen and a U.S. Embassy employee, the FBI said Tuesday. Those in custody include both potential witnesses and ``possible participants'' in the killings of Raymond Dragseth, an American living in Panama City and Fernando E. Brathwaite, a U.S. Embassy employee, the FBI said. Panamanian authorities are expected to bring formal charges in the near future, FBI officials said. The bodies of both men were found Dec. 21, the day after U.S. troops invaded Panama. The FBI said its investigation determined that members of the PDF abducted Dragseth from his house at gunpoint on Dec. 20. Brathwaite was abducted later in the day. Both men were taken outside the city and shot to death, the FBI said. The former PDF members in custody were members of a special anti-terrorism unit of the Panamaniam military under the government of deposed leader Manuel Antonio Noriega, said a law enforcement source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The investigation was conducted by the FBI along with the Panamanian Technical Judicial Police and the U.S. Embassy.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Defends Shortwave Station in Israel
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Tuesday defended construction of a $300 million shortwave relay station in Israel, with one official saying ``tremendous attention'' was given to ensure the project doesn't hurt the environment. Malcolm Forbes Jr., chairman of the Board of International Broadcasting, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee that more than $2 million had been spent on environmental studies. ``Please know that the BIB shares these concerns and has given them tremendous attention throughout the design phase of the project,'' Forbes said. ``There have been no significant findings whatsoever that this station will have a detrimental effect on the environment in the Negev.'' Environmentalists have raised concerns that the project in the Negev desert 30 miles south of the Dead Sea near the border of Jordan could damage the ecology, particularly the path of migrating birds. The project, conceived three years ago, will consist of 16, 500-kilowatt transmitters and 37 curtain antennas. The transmitters will be used by the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty, government-funded stations. The Board of International Broadcasting is the parent of Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty. The transmitters will give the stations added power to reach Asian regions of the Soviet Union, as well as listeners in Africa, India and Pakistan. Despite Forbes' assurances, environmentalists and Rep. James Scheuer, D-N.Y., continued to oppose the project. ``It's quite time for the project to be reappraised,'' Scheuer said, adding it would be more suitable to put the station in Asia. Scheuer also argued that events in Eastern Europe, where democracy is emerging, have lessened the need for the station in Israel. U.S. officials disagreed. The ``situation in Yugoslavia and Bulgaria _ both intended audiences for this relay station _ remains fragile,'' the BIB said in a statement. Brent Blackwelder, vice president of Friends of the Earth, an environmental group, said the project should be rescinded and the money channeled elsewhere. Because the station is a complex project of towers, cables and guy wires, it will ``present a major visual impact in this desert area and will have the potential to impact in this desert and will have the potential to impact the very significant (bird) flyway connecting Africa to Europe and Asia,'' Blackwelder said.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Reached in Precedent-Setting Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A 92-year-old woman's legal fight to save her home and life savings ended in victory Tuesday with a court settlement that lets her keep both. The settlement, reached on the first day of a negligence trial, effectively overturned a 1987 jury verdict that penalized Luella Wilson for loaning her great-nephew the money to buy a car that he drove off a bridge. Under the verdict, Wilson stood to lose her home in North Bennington and her savings of about $950,000. But shortly after noon Tuesday, Wilson received a telephone call from her lawyer. ``You've won, Luella. You can keep your land and we have won the case,'' he was quoted as saying. None of the parties to the case would disclose details of the settlement. Sitting at her kitchen table, drinking a shot of whiskey, Wilson said she was happy to win. ``I don't feel very damned good. I can't walk, but I did win,'' she said. The case grew out of Wilson's decision in 1984 to loan Willard Stuart the money to buy a car, despite his poor driving record and lack of a driver's license. Shortly after that, Stuart drove the car off a bridge after drinking beer and whiskey and smoking marijuana with a group of young men. One of his companions, Mark Vince, was in the back seat during the accident and was seriously injured. He later had one leg amputated. Vince sued Wilson. A 1987 jury found her liable and ordered her to pay Vince $950,000, which amount to all of her assets. While refusing to reverse the 1987 decision on appeal, the Vermont Supreme Court later ruled that a jury should decide if Ace Auto of Bennington and its president and salesman in the deal, Gary Gardner, should share the liability for selling the car to Stuart. In opening arguments at the trial Tuesday morning, Wilson's lawyer, Frederick Harlow, told jurors that Vince, not Wilson, must bear the blame for the fact he is mostly paralyzed and has lost a leg. That theme was echoed by J. Fred Carbine, the lawyer for the car dealership that sold Stuart the car. ``I say use your common sense,'' he told jurors. ``This was a bad day for Mark Vince, a day that ruined his life, but we didn't do it.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Approves Indefinite Jailing for Parents in Abuse Cases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 3 grafs on Morgan case at end
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that parents suspected of child abuse sometimes may be jailed indefinitely for refusing to disclose the whereabouts of their children. Voting 7-2, the justices permitted the indefinite jailing of a Maryland woman for refusing to tell authorities where her young son can be found. Th boy is feared dead. Society's interest in protecting the boy from harm prevails over the mother's claim that her right against self-incrimination will be violated if she is forced to reveal the child's location, the court said. Although narrowly written, the ruling could provide a new weapon for officials seeking to protect children from parental abuse. In other action, the court: _Made it easier for disabled children to win some federal welfare benefits. The 7-2 decision in a Pennsylvania case could force the government to re-evaluate benefits for some 250,000 children. _Agreed to use an Ohio case to decide whether prosecutors who exclude blacks as jurors because of their race violate the rights of white defendants. _Left intact Baltimore, Md., ordinances requiring the city's employee pension plans to divest themselves of all investments in companies doing business with South Africa. _Rejected an appeal by Nevada officials, letting the federal government withhold highway money from states that do not comply with a national speed limit. _Refused to revive a lawsuit against the federal government and a NASA engineer by the widow of one of the astronauts who died when the space shuttle Challenger exploded in 1986. _In a case involving the private papers of Church of Scientology founder L. Ron Hubbard, left intact a ruling that limits dramatically the right of authors to quote unpublished material. _Rejected an appeal by Colorado officials seeking proceeds of drug transactions that were forfeited to the federal government. In the case of the jailed Maryland mother, Jacqueline Bouknight has been behind bars since April 1988 for refusing to disclose the whereabouts of her son, Maurice. The boy has been missing since September 1987, when he was 11 months old. Maurice was admitted to a Baltimore hospital in early 1987, when he was 3 months old, for treatment of a broken leg and other injuries. He temporarily was held in protective care. Maurice was returned to his mother's custody, after she agreed not to punish him physically and to undergo training in parenting skills. Nine months later, social workers said Ms. Bouknight no longer was cooperating with them. The mother was held in contempt by a judge after she refused to disclose Maurice's whereabouts. The Maryland Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, ruled that jailing Ms. Bouknight for refusing to disclose the information violates her constitutional protection against self-incrimination. That ruling was overturned Tuesday. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote for the court that Ms. Bouknight's claim that her constitutional rights are being violated is particularly weak because of her agreement with welfare officials. Moreover, O'Connor said, in most missing-children cases officials are trying to help the children and not prosecute parents. ``Concern for the child's safety,'' O'Connor said, ``underlay the efforts to gain access to and then compel production of'' Bouknight's son. ``The government demands production of the very public charge entrusted to a custodian and makes the demand for compelling reasons unrelated to criminal law enforcement and as part of a broadly applied regulatory regime,'' she said. ``In these circumstances, Bouknight cannot invoke the privilege (against self-incrimination) to resist the order to produce Maurice.'' O'Connor noted that the mother never said she was unable to produce the child because she did not know where he is. O'Connor also hinted that prosecutors might be barred from using any testimony Bouknight gives in producing the child. But Justice Thurgood Marshall, in a dissenting opinion, said that is little comfort now for the mother. Accusing the court of ``riding roughshod'' over individual rights, Marshall said, ``I am not content to deny Bouknight the constitutional protection required ... now in the hope that she will not be convicted later on the basis of her own testimony.'' Marshall was joined in dissent by Justice William J. Brennan. Benna Ruth Solomon, chief counsel for the State and Local Legal Center, said the decision gives significant help to welfare officials. ``We're happy to have won this case,'' she said. ``I suppose it would have been more helpful to child-protection people in the field to have gotten more guidance, but I see no reason to be pessimistic.'' Some have compared the Bouknight case to that of Dr. Elizabeth Morgan of Washington, D.C., released from jail last September after more than two years behind bars for refusing to let her daughter visit the girl's father, Morgan's former husband. Morgan went to jail rather than produce the girl for court-ordered visits with the father. Morgan accused her former husband of sexually abusing the child, charges he repeatedly has denied. The right against self-incrimination was not an issue in that case, so the Bouknight ruling appears to have no bearing on it.

DOC.HEAD: Arens To Meet Baker, Split in Likud Emerges
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Moshe Arens will meet with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III this week to discuss the stalled Middle East peace process, the Foreign Ministry announced Tuesday. A potentially damaging split, meanwhile, emerged in Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc following the resignation of the hard-line trade minister, Ariel Sharon. A Foreign Ministry statement said Arens will stop in Washington for two days following a visit to Mexico and will meet Baker Friday. The visit ``is in the framework of continuing contacts to advance the peace process,'' the statement said. It gave no further details. Baker has proposed a three-way meeting with the foreign ministers of Egypt and Israel to discuss the peace process and resolve differences over the composition of a Palestinian delegation for proposed Israeli-Palestinian talks. The three-way meeting would be aimed at reviving an Israeli proposal for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip as a first step toward peace. The Israeli plan offers limited autonomy to the 1.7 million Palestinian residents of the territories, captured by Israel from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. But it stops short of meeting Palestinian demands for an independent state and for talks with the PLO. Israel considers the PLO to be a terrorist organization. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has been under fire by rebel ministers within his own party who fear the U.S.-sponsored talks could provide a back-door entry for the PLO and could lead to an Israeli surrender of occupied lands, including Arab east Jerusalem. Last week, hard-line Trade Minister Ariel Sharon announced he was resigning from the Cabinet and challenged Shamir's leadership of Likud. The resignation was effective Tuesday. Also Tuesday, five of Sharon's allies threatened to pull out of Likud _ which would make the rival Labor Party the largest in Parliament. However, it was not clear if the rebels' threat was serious or they were only playing for more power within Likud. Sharon told reporters he had not sanctioned the split, but added: ``All these things, to my regret, are because of one thing, an absence of leadership'' in Likud. In a surprising display of strength, Shamir appointed three of his allies to replace Sharon at the Trade Ministry and on the decision-making Inner Cabinet, and to fill a vacancy in the full Cabinet. He appointed Moshe Nissim, a member of the former Liberal Party, as trade minister. He also appointed long-time ally Moshe Katzav to Sharon's position in the 12-member Inner Cabinet and legislator David Magen to the Cabinet. The appointments must now be approved by Parliament, where they are expected to face little opposition, Israel radio said. The rebel legislators, headed by Economic Affairs Minister Yitzhak Modai, submitted a letter on Monday to Parliament, demanding recognition as an independent faction. Their letter, made public by newspapers Tuesday, said the group would ``cease to be part of the Likud faction in Parliament'' if the Knesset House Committee granted their request. A decision on whether to recognize the separate faction was expected next Monday, Israel radio said. Such a move would reduce Likud to 35 seats in the 120-member Knesset, or Parliament, compared to 39 for the center-left Labor Party. The five rebels all are members of the Liberal Party, which earlier merged with Likud. One of the rebels, legislator Pinchas Goldstein, noted on Israel radio that the break with Likud was not final, but refused to specify what their demands were. The radio said a Likud split could convince Labor to leave the coalition Cabinet and try to form its own government with small parties should Likud-Labor disagreements on the peace process come to a head. Labor favors accepting the U.S.-proposed compromises to revive Israel's stalled plan for holding Palestinian elections. Shamir has publicly opposed most of the suggested compromises.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Panel OKs Sterile Screwworm Exports
DOC.TEXT: In an effort to save Africa and Europe from a pest that once plagued the Western Hemisphere, the House Agriculture Committee on Tuesday approved a bill allowing sale of sterile screwworms to other countries. Sterile screwworm flies mate with fertile screwworm flies, but produce no offspring, causing the population to eventually disappear. Through intensive efforts, the pest was declared eradicated in the United States in 1982. The government has spent millions of dollars to kill it off in Mexico and Central America so it doesn't return to the United States. ``The discovery of the pest in North Africa causes deep concern because it potentially could spread to the Middle East and southern European nations bordering the Mediterranean Sea,'' said Rep. Kika de la Garza, chairman of the Agriculture Committee. The screwworm fly is a flesh-eating parasite that attacks all warm-blooded animals, even humans, and is a serious threat to livestock. De la Garza said that in countries, such as those in North Africa, where drought and famine have weakened human health, people are abnormally vulnerable to the insect. ``This could lead to the need for additional requests for food aid and public health assistance in a region already burdened with over $140 billion in external foreign debt,'' he said. He said that shortly after the screwworm was discovered in Africa, the U.N. Food and Agricultural Organization asked the joint U.S.-Mexico Screwworm Commission to help. The only facility mass producing sterile screwworms has been operated since 1976 by the commission in Tuxtla Gutierrez, Mexico. ``The USDA (Agriculture Department) reports that it is possible the screwworm could become the most devastating livestock and wildlife pest on the African continent,'' said de la Garza. ``This bill would provide the necessary authority for the USDA or the USDA working through the commission to sell sterile flies to the Food and Agricultural Organization.'' The legislation is not controversial and is supported by the Bush administration. Though the Senate has not yet acted, speedy movement through Congress is anticipated.

DOC.HEAD: Senate OKs Extension of Dropout Program
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Tuesday passed legislation extending for two years a federal program aimed specifically at helping stem a rising tide of school dropouts. The bill, approved 96-0, extends a two-year grant program, authorizing $50 million each year to upgrade existing programs and set up new projects. Supporters of the legislation cited what they said was a worrisome Education Department report that found that 28 percent of the country's 18- and 19-year-olds have not graduated from high school. ``Over 750,000 American students will drop out of school this year,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., chairman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee. ``They will have many reasons for doing so, including poor teachers, broken homes, devastated communities, poverty, drug use and the need to go to work. Whatever the cause, their decision is a tragedy for them and the nation.''

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Has Stitches Removed
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush had 12 stitches removed from above her lip Tuesday in a procedure performed at the White House, her spokeswoman said. ``She sounded great,'' said Anna Perez, who talked with the first lady by telephone but did not see her during the day. Mrs. Bush received the stitches last Wednesday to close an incision by Dr. Gregory O. Dick, a plastic surgeon, where a small skin cancer was removed.

DOC.HEAD: Chancellor Sees No Cause to be `Scared to Death' of Unified Germany
DOC.TEXT: A network of international agreements has eliminated cause to be ``scared to death'' of a reunited Germany, Austrian Chancellor Franz Vranitzky said Tuesday. Vranitzky, who spoke at the National Press Club, also met with President Bush at the White House, where they discussed changes in Eastern Europe. ``It must be a universal delight in terms of those changes in your neighboring countries,'' Bush told him. ``Absolutely right,'' said Vranitzky. ``A good deal of people have second thoughts or apprehension when they hear about a united Germany,'' Vranitzky told the press club, recalling how Germany wielded its power earlier in this century. But, he said, European democracy has developed to the point where large countries don't exert pressure on smaller ones. Vranitzky said he sees no prospect for a repeat of 1933, when Adolf Hitler came to power in Germany, or 1938, when Germany annexed Austria and part of Czechoslovakia. ``Secondly, Europe today is characterized by a broad network of international agreements, ... a very well-knit network for international cooperation and for stability and security,'' Vranitzky said. ``So I do really not think that, as somebody said, we should be scared to death by German unity,'' he added. Vranitzky, asked whether many Austrians favored a closer political and economic union with Germany, said, ``No. The answer is no, clear no, definite no.'' Vranitzky, whose country decided to become permanently neutral when the victors of World War II ended their occupation in 1955, was asked whether he thought a united Germany should be neutral. ``I do not think that it is realistic to believe that Germany will become a neutral country within any foreseeable future,'' said Vranitzky.

DOC.HEAD: Webster Sees Only Modest Immediate Reduction In East Bloc Spy Threat
DOC.TEXT: Political reform in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe has made the Soviet KGB spy agency less confrontational but the threat from foreign spies will decline only modestly for now, the head of the CIA said Tuesday evening. ``I think the KGB has become less confrontational in the sense that they avoid doing blatant or flat-footed things that would create a major press issue,'' the CIA director, William Webster, said in remarks prepared for delivery to the Baltimore Council on Foreign Affairs. ``But the activity is there and it will continue.'' The agency released a text of his remarks in Washington. ``Within the Soviet Union, however, there does seem to be a movement toward relaxing KGB repression of Soviet dissidents,'' Webster said, noting a similar withering of internal secret police activity among the KGB's allied spy agencies in Eastern Europe. Webster predicted the Eastern European agencies would reduce their cooperation with Moscow but that no major reduction in their effort to gain U.S. secrets would occur so long as the Warsaw Pact remains in place.
