He also said that, as economic competition replaces political and military tension between East and West, ``attempts to acquire sensitive technology _ by all nations _ is increasing and becoming more sophisticated.'' Webster presented a complicated picture in Eastern Europe, where spy agencies have operated since World War II as proxies for the KGB. ``Their subservience to the KGB and GRU (Soviet military intelligence) is due for careful review,'' he said. He noted that the Hungarian foreign ministry publicly disassociated itself recently from the alleged spying efforts of U.S. Army Sgt. Clyde Lee Conrad, arrested in West Germany in 1988 on charges of spying for a Hungarian intelligence officer. The foreign ministry ``declared it `an erroneous policy' pursued by the previous leadership without regard to the country's national interests,'' Webster said. But the intelligence chief cautioned that ``espionage and counterintelligence are widely recognized in Eastern Europe as necessary functions and the apparatus for this work is likely to remain in place. ...The work will continue.'' The Warsaw Pact, he said, requires that East European intelligence services cooperate with the Soviet Union, ``so I don't expect military intelligence collection efforts to abate _ certainly not in the near future.'' Overall, he said, his agency hopes that new political leadership in Eastern Europe ``will reduce some hostile intelligence activity _ such as passing sensitive technology to the Soviets _ an activity which is incompatible with requests for U.S. loans. But fundamental changes in intelligence missions are not likely while the Warsaw Pact treaty connections are still in place.'' In addition, he said the current spy managers in East Europe were ``picked from the old Communist loyalists and trained in the Soviet Union'' and may be ``difficult to replace.'' Webster said all the changes would ultimately depend on the success of Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's efforts ``to put the Soviet Union on the road to a more democratic government.'' ``But the new system he is trying to create is not yet ready to take the place of the old one he is discarding,'' Webster added. ``Economic conditions have deteriorated. Crime is increasing. Ethnic turmoil is escalating.'' Whether Gorbachev's responses ``will satisfy the Soviet people, quite frankly, we don't know and neither do they.'' He also outlined two separate rates of political change in East Europe. ``Profound transformation is going on in Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Poland, where Communist parties are in full retreat,'' Webster said. ``But in the Balkans, the process of transformation is more complicated.'' ``Political opposition is not well-developed in many of these countries. In Bulgaria, for example, Communists stand a good chance of playing a major role in the government after elections in May. And in Romania, some, particularly the intellectuals and students, are concerned that the national salvation front will simply replace the Communist party and not offer the hoped-for change.'' He also cited ethnic strife in Romania and Yugoslavia as an obstacle to reform.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says United Germany Must Respect European Borders
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev said a united Germany must respect Europe's current borders and only the four victorious Allies of World War II can determine Germany's final status, Tass reported Tuesday. Gorbachev addressed the issue of German unity in an interview with Pravda carried by Tass before it appeared Wednesday in the Communist Party newspaper. Progress toward reunificaion has accelerated in recent weeks. Premier Hans Modrow of East Germany, plagued by mass emigration and a crumbling economy, asked on Tuesday for immediate reunification talks under a formula worked out with the Allies. Modrow and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany both visited Moscow this month to discuss unification with Gorbachev, the Soviet president. Kohl said he had Gorbachev's assurance the Soviet Union would respect the desire of Germans to have one nation. In the Pravda interview, Gorbachev said Germans should decide the form and schedule of reunification, but emphasized that Germany unity also concerns others and ``any encroachment upon the borders of other states must be ruled out.'' He specifically mentioned Poland's western border. Kohl's failure to make a public pledge to respect that border prompted Poland to request a roll in talks on reunification between the two Germanys and the Allies. Both Germanys are bound by treaties to respect the frontier, but a united country would not be, and some conservatives in West Germany have suggested reunification be sought within the 1937 borders. In 1937, one-third of what is now Poland was German territory. Gorbachev spoke in the interview of the rights of nations to protect their interests, and said: ``I refer primarily to Poland. The inviolability of its postwar borders, like the borders of other states, must be guaranteed. Only an international legal act can provide such a guarantee.'' About a united Germany's relationship with NATO and the Warsaw Pact, he said the alliances retain a role as a new European security system evolves, and any disruption of the military-strategic balance is unacceptable. East Germany is Moscow's most important military ally and about two-thirds of the 575,000 Soviet troops in Eastern Europe are stationed there. Emergence of a reunited Germany as a powerful economic and military force in Central Europe has aroused concern, and Gorbachev said in the interview: ``No one has a right to ignore the negative potential formed in Germany's past, especially as it is impossible to fail to consider people's memory of war, of its horrors and losses. Therefore, it is very important that Germans, deciding the question of unification, should be aware of their responsibility. ``This applies particularly to our country, to the Soviet people. It has an inalienable right to expect, and the possibility to exert efforts to ensure, that our country should not sustain either moral or political or economic damage from German unification.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Group Alleges Soldiers Killing Suspects Deliberately
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf, `According to...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE toll, ADD Palestinian death. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian human rights group charged Tuesday that Israeli soldiers were carrying out ``deliberate, cold-blooded'' killings of Palestinian suspects instead of arresting them. Officials of Al Haq-Law in the Service of Man told a news conference that its researchers documented three such cases and were investigating 15 possible other such killings in the past year in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. An Israeli military spokesman denied Israel had any policy of deliberate killings, and the army issued a five-sentence statement saying it ``categorically rejects the baseless and unfounded accusations detailed'' in the 692-page report. The report cited several changes in Israeli policy in the past year that have been acknowledged by the government but which Al Haq and other human rights organizations see as violations of international law. Among these were: _ Increasing the initial time a suspect in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip can be held without charges or trial under ``administrative detention'' from six months to one year. _ Allowing soldiers to open fire at masked Palestinian suspects, even if they are unarmed, when the suspects ignore orders to halt. The army has said soldiers first must fire warning shots in the air and then shoot at the suspect's legs. Al Haq noted that 17 of the 31 Palestinians killed by soldiers in October were masked men. _ Sealing houses of people suspected of throwing stones. Previously, sealings and demolition of houses were used for those suspected of firebombings or other, more serious attacks. The U.S. State Department and Amnesty International have complained about administrative detentions and house demolitions as violations of international law. Fatah Azzam, administrative director of Al Haq, said not enough international pressure had been put on Israel, and the report itself complained of unwillingness by Israeli authorities to respond to criticism. ``While the use of illegal measures to suppress the uprising has been intensified, attention has been deflected ... through the periodic issuance of new regulations and policy statements intended to reassure the international community,'' it said. As to the charges of deliberate killings, Al Haq said all three of the victims were shot at close range, and that in two cases they were denied needed medical attention. Yaser Abu Ghosh, 17, was shot by a soldier who took careful aim and fired from a distance of seven yards as the teen-ager was being chased July 10 in Ramallah, the report said. It said the victim apparently received no medical treatment for more than two hours. Nidal Al-Habash, 21, was shot as he raised his hands to surrender after being surrounded following a chase by soldiers in the West Bank city of Nablus on Oct. 9, Al Haq said. Atwa Harzallah, 27, was stopped with four other Palestinians on Feb. 27, 1989, in the West Bank village of Deir Ibzi and, while all five raised their hands, soldiers shot Harzallah twice in the head, the report said. It said two of those with Harzallah were later arrested. The Al Haq report noted the army had maintained that proper procedures were followed in the shooting of Abu Ghosh, including shouted warnings and first shooting at the suspect's legs, but added that eyewitness accounts contradicted this version. It also noted that authorities claimed Harzallah was killed during a stone-throwing incident. It said a lawyer for his family requested an investigation in April but has not yet received a response. On Tuesday, an army spokesman said he was checking the status of the three cases but he denied any policy of deliberate killings. ``We totally and completely deny any policy which calls upon soldiers to premeditatedly kill Palestinians,'' he said. The army statement said: ``Al Haq is known as an organization made up entirely of Palestinians and their supporters. It is no surprise that the report it has presented is one-side and negative.'' Al Haq, which is affiliated with the International Commission of Jurists in Geneva, Switzerland, listed 379 killings of Palestinians by soldiers, Israeli settlers and collaborators with Israel during the year. It did not give an accounting of killings of alleged collaborators by other Palestinians and, despite repeated questions at the news conference, its officials refused to criticize directly the Palestinian groups who may have carried out the killings. Mona Rishlawi, an attorney for Al Haq, said the organization had no way of investigating ``underground'' killings and had to hold Israel responsible as the occupation authority. ``As long as the de facto authority is in the hands of the Israeli military, it is they who are responsible,'' she said. According to statistics kept by The Associated Press, 658 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since the uprising began 26 months ago. At least 187 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration. Forty-three Israelis have died. In the latest casualty, a 14-year-old Palestinian youth died Tuesday in Tel Aviv of a gunshot wound suffered Sunday in a clash with troops. Soldiers also shot and wounded five Arabs in the occupied Gaza Strip, Arab hospital officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Blast Shakes English Town, Hurts Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout, UPDATING with new details; CORRECTS that bomb was near van, not under it. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded near an army van in the center of Leicester just before rush hour Tuesday evening, injuring two people, blowing pedestrians off their feet and shattering windows, officials said. No group claimed responsibility, but suspicion fell on the Irish Republican Army, which has been fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland. Assistant Chief Constable Tony Butler said the van had traveled a few hundred yards from an army recruiting center when the bomb exploded at 4:40 p.m. Two army sergeants were inside. One, from the Women's Royal Army Corps, was taken to a hospital suffering from shock but her colleague from the Coldstream Guards was unhurt, the Defense Ministry said. Butler said a civilian passer-by was cut by flying glass. ``I was blown off my feet,'' 82-year-old Henry Riley told the Leicester Mercury. ``I was within yards of the explosion and it was massive. I remember bombs falling on the city in the war. And this sounded just the same.'' ``The van was not badly damaged,'' said Mercury reporter Red Williams. ``The main force of the explosion seems to have been at the back of the vehicle, probably on the ground.''AH MESCE=

Health Secretary Louis Sullivan continued his campaign against tobacco companies Tuesday and issued a report showing that smoking costs the country more than $52 billion annually in health care costs and lost productivity. Sullivan condemned tobacco company advertising practices that target women, minorities and young people, saying ``they must stop their irresponsibility.'' In testimony before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, he also called on advertising agencies to join anti-smoking efforts by renouncing tobacco ads and said television stations should donate free air time to help educate viewers about the dangers of smoking. Sullivan also said that while the Bush administration supports the intent of legislation to increase regulation of tobacco products and educate about the risks of smoking, it believes the bill, which would cost an estimated $185 million, is unnecessary. The Tobacco Product Education and Health Protection Act of 1990 would establish a center as part of the federal Centers for Disease Control to expand education efforts on smoking, conduct smoking-related research and regulate tobacco products much as the Food and Drug Administration regulates food products. The center also would administer a paid advertising program to discourage smoking and provide incentive grants to states to encourage enactment and better enforcement of laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco to minors. Sullivan said his department yearly spends about $79 million on anti-smoking programs, many of which duplicate the efforts proposed in the legislaton. He said free public service announcements about the risks of smoking are preferable to government-paid ads in light of other demands on the federal budget. He also said that regulating the additives in cigarettes, envisioned in the bill, would send the wrong message. ``We're concerned that this would suggest that we believe that under certain conditions, with certain monitoring, that tobacco is safe,'' he said. ``We would rather see our efforts on reducing and elmiminating by the year 2000 all tobacco from our society.'' However, Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass. and chairman of the Senate committee, noted that bottled Perrier water was pulled from the market when it was found to contain benzene at levels up to four times what is allowed under federal standards, while a surgeon general's report estimated the benzene content of cigarettes is 2,000 times higher than that. ``The consumer has a right to know the key ingredients and additives to a pack of cigarettes when they purchase the product,'' Kennedy said. Sullivan agreed that consumers should have such information. Charles O. Whitley, representing The Tobacco Institute, noted in testimony submitted to the committee that Congress previously considered and rejected disclosure of ingredient information because it contains trade secrets. This information is supplied to the health and human services secretary, but it does not identify the company or brand of cigarettes. Whitley also said other provisions in the bill aren't needed because young people are already aware of the risks of smoking. He also denied that the industry targets young people in advertising campaigns to encourage themhabit. He also defended the industry against critics who say that tobacco companies target women and minorities, saying the industry is not trying to encourage people to start smoking but rather hopes to take up the to retain or gain market share from competitors. Sullivan released a report on the economic consequences of smoking that estimated smoking-related disease costs each American $221 a year largely in health-care and insurance costs. He said the costs average $1 billion per state annually, but range from a high of $5.8 billion in California to a low of $82 million in Alaska. The report's analysis, the first of its kind, is based on 1985 statistics. Smoking catates annually and about 29 percent of adults smoke, he said. Sullivan recently criticized R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. for its plans to market a cigarette targeted at blacks. Reynolds subsequently dropped those plans, but now intends to test-market a cigarette called Dakota. The company had considered gearing the cigarette toward young women with no more than a high school education, but threw out the plan late last year and instead will target all smokers of Philip Morris' Marlboro, Reynolds Chairman James Johnston said. Sullivan has been concerned about minorities because they have higher rates of smoking than whites and have a higher rate of smoking-related disease and death. Among high school seniors, the smoking rate has leveled off at around 19 percent, he said, while lung cancer has surpassed breast cancer a cause of death among women.

The African National Congress said Tuesday it has lobbied African governments to boycott proposed talks with South African President F.W. de Klerk scheduled for this weekend in Zaire. The organization also urged European governments to ignore British calls to ease economic sanctions against South Africa. Britain Tuesday failed to persuade the European Community to ease sanctions and said it would act alone to remove a British embargo on new investment. De Klerk, in an effort to ease friction with black states, is to meet Saturday in Zaire with the leaders of that country, Rwanda, Burundi, Chad and the African Central Republic to discuss regional issues and political developments in South Africa. Togo and Gabon may also be represented at the one-day meeting, which would be the first multination conference between South Africa's white-minority government and black African states, said South African officials, who declined to be identified. South African presidents have had meetings with single black heads of state in the past. The meeting could clear the way for South Africa to start establishing political and economic ties with black Africa after years of being isolated because of its apartheid policies, the officials said. South Africa wants to expand economic ties to help stimulate its own economy, they said. De Klerk is expected to brief the black leaders on his recent reforms, including the Feb. 11 release of Nelson Mandela and the legalization of the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups. In Lusaka, ANC international affairs chief Thabo Mbeki said the organization had approached foreign ministers of the 50-member Organization of African Unity currently meeting in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, and urged them to stop the Zaire talks. ``We see no reason for De Klerk to be received. OAU policy is to isolate apartheid. Nothing has changed. Apartheid is still there every day,'' Mbeki told reporters in Lusaka. Earlier Tuesday, the ANC urged European governments to ignore British calls to ease economic sanctions against South Africa. It said it had appealed to all European Community governments to coincide with a meeting of EC foreign ministers in Dublin, Ireland. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has argued that the recent political changes introduced by de Klerk deserve an easing of the world trade and investment boycott. Mbeki said the ANC reminded European governments of an agreement in Strasbourg last December by their leaders, including Mrs. Thatcher, that sanctions would only be reviewed after there was ``profound and irreversible change'' to end the apartheid system of racial separation in South Africa. ``We are saying the EC ought to respect international agreements it enters into,'' he said. He said an easing of the sanctions would encourage de Klerk to believe he had made sufficient reforms, ``therefore he can take his time about ending apartheid and this is to prescribe further suffering for our people.''

DOC.HEAD: Anglican Bishops Urged to Reject Report on Homosexuality
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Church of England were urged on Tuesday to reject an unpublished report that recommends homosexuals be treated with more sympathy by the church. The report was commissioned by the bishops in the church's policy-making General Synod who wanted advice on dealing with matters of homosexuality. But they decided not to publish it. The Rev. David Holloway, a traditionalist clergyman, told the synod's regular February session that leaked copies of the report indicated it contradicted a 1987 synod decision that homosexual acts fell short of the Christian ideal. He said the leaked version appeared to suggest that only one-third of the bishops held to the biblical and traditional view of the church, which opposes homosexual relationships. ``While most bishops, in the words of the report, `would not sponsor or ordain anyone whom they knew to be homosexually active,' presumbly some would. We need reassurances,'' Holloway said. Holloway sought an emergency debate to discuss church leaders who favored the homosexuality report, but no debate or vote followed on the first day of the three-day session at Westminster. The synod is a 574-member body of bishops, clergy and laity. Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie said the bishops had no plans to authorize publication of the report. ``It is not an accepted policy document. It is advice and we are now considering it,'' said Runcie, spiritual head of the church and leader of the world's 70 million Anglicans, including 2.5 million U.S. Episcopalians. Holloway told reporters later the bishops suppressed the report for 18 months and when it was leaked it did ``enormous damage'' to the church. ``What we want to discuss is the way we have got into the mess we have got into,'' he said. Richard Kirker, general secretary of the Lesbian and Gay Christian Movement, said: ``The decision to repress the report runs contrary to principles of open government which apply in church. If the church is not an unconditionally welcoming community determined by love, we have no business to call ourselves Christians.'' The suppressed document is known as the Osborne report after its chairwoman, the Rev. June Osborne, a deaconess working in London's East End. In 1986, the bishops asked the seven-member working party of clergy and laity that she headed to advise them on ``how to handle homosexuality matters in the Church of England.'' The report was completed in 1988 but remained unpublished. This month, copies were leaked to a television company and some newspapers. The 134-page report, as summarized in the Anglican Church Times weekly, said: ``We have been made very conscious of the poor experience of the church encountered by many homosexual people. ... The bishops ... have a particular responsibility to set a tone of welcome and acceptance in these matters.'' A Church Times editorial on Friday said the report offered people in the Church of England the chance to re-examine their thinking about homosexuality. It said the last synod debate on the subject in 1987 showed that numbers of churchpeople disapproved of it but that was no longer an adequate response. ``There are probably at least a million homosexuals in the United Kingdom,'' the weekly said. ``The Church of England has homosexuals among its priests, ordinands and worshipers. These are people who have the same need for sexual expression in its many forms, for companionship, for acceptance, as heterosexuals. It becomes increasingly difficult to deny them those things and argue that the denial is merciful or truthful or practical.''

DOC.HEAD: Cooking Contest Winner Claims $50,000 in Cash, Prizes
LaserPhoto PN3
DOC.TEXT: A recipe contest rookie won the Super Bowl of baking Tuesday with a brunch cake inspired by her family's taste for blueberries. Linda Rahman, a Petaluma, Calif., tax accountant who had never entered a recipe contest before, was so surprised by her selection as the grand champion in the 34th Pillsbury Bake-Off that she had no immediate plans to use the $40,000 in first-prize money. But she had no question about the worth of a $10,000 kitchen makeover included in her winnings. ``I've been in the same kitchen for 18 years,'' she said. Mrs. Rahman, four other women and a man were winners in six categories involving use of Pillsbury Co. products. Each received $10,000, with Mrs. Rahman getting another $30,000 for devising the top recipe overall. Scott Wolf of Salem, Ore., one of a record 12 men in the final field of 100, made Bake-Off history by becoming the first male to win a product category. Pillsbury said it receives more than 100,000 recipes in the Bake-Off, which is held every two years. Applicants may submit as many recipes as they want, but only one will be accepted per finalist. Mrs. Rahman, a 44-year-old mother of two, enjoys running in the 7.8-mile Bay to Breakers distance race each spring, but said her winning poppy seed brunch cake _ which was in the flour category _ wasn't health-inspired. ``Perhaps ingredients like blueberries and poppy seeds are perceived as healthful and wholesome, not quite as decadent as chocolate,'' she said. ``I got no negative feedback when I served it to the neighbors.'' She said her sons, Brian, 22, a senior in electrical engineering at Washington State University, and Kevin, 21, a junior in mechanical engineering at Sacramento State, both ask for steak whenever they come home ``because we don't send them very much money for food.'' Mrs. Rahman graduated from San Francisco State University nine years ago and works as a tax accountant for Pacific Bell in San Francisco. Although many contestants in the 1990 event had qualified earlier, the first time was the charm for Wolf, a 21-year-old who loves flying and works for a company that makes aviation-navigation equipment. He said he would use his prize money to move into an apartment, complete ground school and spend another 30 hours in the air to obtain a private pilot's license. Wolf's entry _ garden rice-stuffed chicken breasts _ was in the frozen-vegetables category. Other $10,000 winners included Paula Cassidy of Berkeley, Calif., for use of refrigerated pie crust; Christine Vidra of Maumee, Ohio, cake and brownie mix; Nancy Woodside, Sonora, Calif., canned vegetables and mashed potato flakes; and Sharon Richardson, Dallas, refrigerated crescent dinner roll, biscuit and pizza crust. Debra Wolf, 20, of Salem, Ore., Scott Wolf's sister and a three-time finalist, was among the $2,000 winners.

DOC.HEAD: Modrow Asks Immediate Unification Talks Under Allied Formula
LaserPhoto BER9
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Kohl addressing campaign rally in East Germany, quotes. Pick up 3rd pvs, `More than...'
DOC.TEXT: East German Premier Hans Modrow, pressed by mass emigration and a crumbling economy, appealed Tuesday for immediate reunification talks under a formula worked out with the Allied victors of World War II. Helmut Kohl, the West German chancellor, urged Modrow's government to create a social security system as generous as West Germany's as a means of stopping the flight. Kohl made a campaign trip to East Germany, lending his support to conservatives there and telling a rally of 90,000 that his government will provide aid to help the troubled country's social safety net. The chancellor, a Christian Democrat, was repeatedly cheered by the large crowd in the city of Erfurt, who waved West German flags and shouted for quick unification. He tried to justify his refusal to give massive aid to the current interim, Communist-led government. ``I was not ready to invest billions in a system if I can't see that the citizens will benefit,'' Kohl said. The crowd responded by shouting, ``Helmut, Helmut.'' More than 400,000 people have left the East for West Germany in the past year, most of them skilled workers, after giving up hope of significant improvement in living conditions at home. Kohl met with West German industrial leaders Tuesday to draft plans for ``solidarity with East Germany,'' and told journalists his government would help finance unemployment benefits and pensions for East Germans. He was vague about the degree to which West Germany would underwrite the costs of East Germany's transition to capitalism, however, saying only that Bonn could provide ``start-up financing'' for the benefits. His references to German ``social unity'' reflected a growing realization among West Germans that they must pay for reunification. Kohl's government has been reluctant to make firm deals with Modrow, a reform-minded Communist whose interim Cabinet will govern only until free elections March 18. East Germany's parliament passed a constitutional amendment and legislation Tuesday setting rules for the elections. The new parliament will have 400 seats, 100 fewer than the current People's Chamber, and no minimum percentage of the vote will be needed for a party to win seats. In West Germany, a party must get 5 percent of the vote. Modrow, addressing the parliament, said representatives of the two Germanys should ``begin preparing the `2-plus-4' conference as soon as possible.'' At a meeting in Ottawa, Canada, last week, the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France agreed with East and West Germany on a two-stage plan for reunification. In the first stage of what became known as the ``2-plus-4'' formula, German experts would discuss political, economic and legal steps to unity. In the second, the Germanys would be joined by the Allies to discuss international ramifications. Modrow said parallel plans should be made for a meeting of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. He again expressed regret that Bonn would not provide the $9 billion in immediate aid he requested. ``Such aid is in my opinion necessary to counter a further exodus, and this should be of common interest'' to both governments, the premier said. West Germany has approved the equivalent of about $3.5 billion for projects over which Modrow's government has little control. East and West Germany should issue a statement guaranteeing Poland's western borders, Modrow said. Kohl, concerned about conservative support in the December elections, has not made a public, unequivocal declaration that he recognizes those borders. About one-third of Poland was part of Germany before World War II and the Poles have demanded inclusion in the ``2-plus-4'' because of concern over possible German claims to its territory. Modrow supported that position Monday, but West Germany has resisted it. A joint government commission of East and West Germany met in East Berlin on Tuesday to discuss ways of achieving monetary and economic unity. Earlier this month, Kohl offered to make the West German mark the official currency of both countries. He said that would give East Germans confidence in their future, but the East Germans fear unemployment as inefficient factories are forced to close under a more competitive capitalist system. Leaders of both countries hope monetary union will stem the flight of about 2,000 people a day from East to West, but no agreement is expected until after the March elections. East Germany is planning to end subsidies, and Modrow appealed to citizens Tuesday not to hoard food. He reported hearing of runs on grocery stores while prices remain low, but journalists saw no unusual crowding at food stores in East Berlin. Modrow urged people to keep their money in the banks. East Germans worry about their savings becoming worthless under a monetary union with West Germany and have been withdrawing funds. He also appealed to East Germans to stay home and work for change.

DOC.HEAD: Spokesman Says Sihanouk Will Live in Bamboo Hut in Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who ruled Cambodia until he displeased the Americans by keeping it out of the Indochina war, will return and live in a bamboo hut until his country is free, a spokesman said Tuesday. Sihanouk was overthrown in 1970, fled Cambodia when the Vietnamese invaded in December 1978 and has lived since in the palaces and luxury hotels of Beijing, Pyongyang, Paris and Bangkok. He now leads guerrillas fighting the government of Premier Hun Sen, whom the Vietnamese installed, and spokesman Ek Seryewat said he would take up residence Friday in a ``liberated zone'' of northeastern Cambodia. Ek, a spokesman for Sihanouk in Bangkok, said the prince would live in Oddar Meanchey province, bordering Thailand, in a house built of bamboo. Before returning to Cambodia, the 67-year-old prince was scheduled to hold another round of peace talks Wednesday with Hun Sen in Bangkok, their first meeting in Thailand. All parties involved in the Cambodian conflict are scheduled to confer Monday and Tuesday in Jakarta, Indonesia. The three-faction guerrilla alliance Sihanouk leads has made substantial gains in western and northwestern Cambodia since Vietnamese troops were withdrawn at the end of September 1989. ``Hun Sen may live in a palace in Phnom Penh, but there are no palaces in the liberated zone,'' Ek said. He said Sihanouk would continue to travel on diplomatic missions, but his home would be in Oddar Meanchey until ``the liberation of the whole of Cambodia.'' International support has grown for a negotiated peace involving the United Nations in an interim administrative role. Hun Sen's government has rejected guerrilla demands that it be dismantled before elections, contending that would leave the way open for the Khmer Rouge to regain power. The Khmer Rouge ruled Cambodia from April 1975 until the Vietnamese invasion, and more than 1 million people were killed or died of starvation or disease. It now is far stronger than either of the other two, non-Communist, guerrilla factions. Sihanouk and Hun Sen last met at the Paris International Conference on Cambodia in August, but their meeting and the conference achieved little. The French put Sihanouk on the throne of Cambodia when he was 19 and he led his country to independence in 1953. He was ousted by a right-wing coup in 1970 after resisting U.S. attempts to draw Cambodia into the war. In rural areas of a nation that has known little but war for decades, Sihanouk still is revered as a god-king who brought peace. Many of the old and new elite either dismiss him as irrelevant or consider him a traitor who helped destroy Cambodia.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Parliament Elects New Leader
DOC.TEXT: Cuban lawmakers elected a new parliamentary president Tuesday, four days after the Communist Party called for a study on overhauling government institutions, the Cuban news service Prensa Latina said. It said Justice Minister Juan Escalona, 59, a member of parliament since 1981, was the only candidate and was elected in secret, direct balloting with 458 of the 468 votes. The agency did not account for the other 10 votes. Escalona presided over the 1989 prosecution of high-ranking Interior Ministry and army officials sentenced to death for drug trafficking, the news service said in the dispatch, which was monitored in Mexico City. It said the vote followed the resignation of acting parliamentary president Severo Aguirre, 78, who had served since the former president, Flavio Bravo, died in early 1988. President Fidel Castro attended Tuesday's special legislative session, at which deputy Zoila Benitez was elected parliamentary vice president, it said. Aguirre said new leadership in parliament could contribute to renovating the state, according to Prensa Latina. The Communist Party Central Committee on Friday called for a party congress in March 1991 and proposed a study of to improve government operations. It was the first indication Prensa Latina has given that Cuba may consider reform. Escalona took part in the revolution that overthrew dictator Fulgencio Batista in 1959, and served as chief of staff for the western army division, Prensa Latina said.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Says Captain Should Delegate
DOC.TEXT: A key responsibility of a tanker captain is delegating authority to other officers, an Exxon official testified Tuesday at the trial of the skipper who gave control of the Exxon Valdez to his third mate. However, ship crew coordinator William Deppe of Walnut Creek, Calif., testified at the trial of former tanker skipper Joseph Hazelwood that he would have remained on the ship's bridge during a maneuver to avoid hitting ice. The Exxon Valdez was outside normal shipping lanes to avoid ice in Prince William Sound when it struck Bligh Reef, ripping open its hull and spilling more than 10 million gallons of crude oil. The disaster killed countless birds, fish and marine mammals, and blackened hundreds of miles of rocky shore. Deppe, who holds a shore position with Exxon, represented the company at the National Transportation Safety Board's hearing into the nation's worst oil spill. He also took control of the grounded Exxon Valdez after Hazelwood left to meet with investigators. Deppe holds a captain's license, and Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole asked him numerous questions on how he would have handled the grounding of the Exxon Valdez. Deppe was reluctant to answer on many points, saying he was not there and didn't have enough information. But he appeared to support Hazelwood's decision to let Third Mate Gregory Cousins navigate through Prince William Sound. ``One of the responsibiltiies a master has is to delegate a lot of responsibility to other people,'' he said. ``If I had an officer I had confidence in to carry out commands,'' Deppe indicated he would trust him. But when Cole pressed him on what he would have done while steaming past ice in Prince William Sound, he said: ``I probably would have been on the bridge and not left it to the third mate.'' Hazelwood, 43, is charged with second-degree criminal mischief, a felony, and three misdemeanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, he could be sentenced to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. Deppe testified after jurors were shown a videotape of the Exxon Valdez sitting on Bligh Reef, surrounded by floating black oil. The man who shot the footage, Dan Lawn, then told of boarding the ship and encountering Hazelwood, who Lawn said appeared sober. Lawn said that at one point on the morning after the accident, he smelled what resembled ``stale beer'' on the captain's breath. Deppe later testified that while Exxon forbade alcohol on its ships, the company did allow Moussey, a low-alcohol beer from France, to be taken on board. The defense appeared to be laying groundwork to contend that Hazelwood drank Moussey long after the accident, explaining why he had a low level of alcohol in his blood 10{ hours after the accident.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Convenes Special Session on Fighting Narcotics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Baker's remarks. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, The debate ...; ADD 4 grafs further Baker remarks.
DOC.TEXT: The General Assembly convened its first special session on narcotics Tuesday with major drug-producing nations and major drug-consuming nations seeking to forge an international battle plan for the 1990s. The four-day session is expected to shift the previous emphasis on stopping drug production in poor countries to a more balanced approach which includes fighting consumption in wealthier nations. It is expected to consider wider issues of distribution, marketing and money laundering, the related arms trade and sale of manufacturing chemicals. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told the session the ``most critical challenge'' facing the United States in combating narcotics abuse is the problem of domestic consumption. ``As long as the demand for drugs by Americans remains voracious, our nation faces an endless, uphill struggle to halt supply,'' Baker said. A text of his prepared remarks was released by the State Department. The debate began with Colombian Foreign Minister Julio Londono Paredes telling the 159-nation assembly that for too long the burden in the drug fight has been borne by a small number of developing nations. Action must be taken on many fronts, he said, including action against the production of manufacturing chemicals and against corrupt officials and increased aid to developing countries to reducing the demand for drugs. Paredes said Colombia believes that to fight drugs there must be sustained growth in the producing countries and that requires the creation of jobs, external financing and easier access of exports to external markets. International cooperation is necessary, he said, but he emphasized the responsibility of each state to control drug trafficking. Responsibility also must include respect for the sovereignty of other states, he said, without using drug traffic as a lever for applying economic pressure. The session, with more than 100 speakers, is an effort to develop a blueprint for international cooperation against illegal drug supply, demand, trafficking and distribution. U.N. officials said the session would not focus on production by poor Third World nations, where many farmers have little choice in cultivation, but would look at a broad spectrum of issues. The session aims to enhance the effectiveness of U.N. agencies in the battle against drugs and seek more money for them. Mexico's attorney general, Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, called drugs ``the universal social disease ... the plague of the modern world.'' But he said Mexico is opposed to the creation of all multinational military or paramilitary forces and added: ``The sovereignty of peoples and territorial integrity are not open to discussion. Multilateral cooperation should rest on the principle of respect for the rights of others.'' Del Castillo said his government supports application of an international legal framework. He said it was pointless to debate whether producing or consuming nations were more to blame. ``We all are responsible,'' he said. He noted that Mexico's drug consumption is relatively low, regular users numbering only about .8 percent of the population, mostly urban youth. Brazil's foreign minister, Roberto de Abreu Sodre, said the focus has been on production of illegal drugs, but today there is a greater understanding that effective action must address many facets, from cultivation to consumption. Elimination of illicit crops, he said, only can be achieved through integrated programs of rural development that provide economically viable alternatives. There also is growing concern to address the problem of the covert flow of arms to drug traffickers and to curb the participation of mercenaries in drug-related criminal activities. In his address, Baker expressed hope that a U.N.-led effort to act against drug smuggling will help the world come closer to ending the drug scourge. He added that to be successful, any such program must entail concrete commitments and be fully implemented by U.N. agencies. ``Certainly, we the member governments cannot ask the United Nations to do things that we will not do at home,'' he said. Baker's appearance at the session, five days after the drug summit in Colombia, was aimed at reinforcing the high priority the Bush administration is attaching to the drug issue.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Discusses Resolution Marking `Armenian Genocide'
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Tuesday opened discussion of a contentious resolution remembering ``Armenian genocide'' amid potential strains in U.S.-Turkish relations and a rift between some Republicans and the Bush administration. The resolution, which would set April 24 as a day of remembrance of the ``Armenian genocide of 1915-1923,'' is sponsored by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. About 1.5 million Armenians died during the period, victims of the Ottoman Empire's attacks on the ethnic group. The Ottoman Empire is now Turkey. ``It's time for the United States, officially, to commemorate the Armenian genocide,'' Dole said on the floor of the Senate. ``For too long, we have ignored history. ... For too long, we have failed to speak the truth about the tragedy of genocide. ... It is time, finally, for all of us to do what is right.'' Turkey, a NATO ally, is fiercely opposed to the measure and has objected to the term ``genocide'' to characterize what happened to Armenians during the period. Turkish Prime Minister Turgut Ozal made his views known in meetings last month with Dole and other senators. ``I am deeply concerned that if the Senate passes the resolution, it will unwittingly slap the face of a very important NATO ally,'' said Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., an opponent of the resolution and the only senator to speak against it Tuesday. He said passage of the measure could jeopardize the upcoming round of negotiations on base rights. The Turks already have banned ports of call by U.S. nuclear-powered warships and barred flights by training missions into a gunnery range, according to Mike McNamara, who represents Turkey. Byrd called ``genocide'' a specific legal term as defined by the Geneva Convention. ``I do not know whether what happened to the Armenians constitutes `genocide,''' he said. Whatever happened was wrong, he said. Discussion was expected to continue until Thursday when the Senate is scheduled to vote to cut off debate with a cloture vote. Sixty senators are needed to end talk so a vote can be taken. Dole had 61 co-sponsors when he introduced the resolution last year. However, the measure now has only 46 co-sponsors. ``What has changed is the launching of a massive lobbying effort against the resolution _ by the administration, by the government of Turkey, by American businesses who operate in Turkey and, regrettably, by some private organizations and individuals who ought to be supportive of the resolution.'' The Bush administration has publicly opposed the resolution, although George Bush indicated during the 1988 presidential campaign that he would be inclined to remember victims of the Armenian slaughters. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., quoted Bush as saying in 1988 that the United States ``must acknowledge the attempted genocide'' of the Armemians. ```I would join Congress in commemorating the victims of that period,''' Simon quoted Bush as saying. ``Clearly a different signal is coming from the White House today,'' Simon said. Dole, who said he was not trying to embarrass the Turkish government, said he is willing to introduce legislation to ban any possible reparations to the Armenians.

DOC.HEAD: Calif., Tenn., Kan., Tenn. Officials Appointed to Wetlands Board
DOC.TEXT: Interior Secretary Manual Lujan on Tuesday announced appointments of four state officials and three leaders of conservation organizations to be initial members of the new North American Wetlands Conservation Council. Two Interior Department officials are ex-officio members of the council, formed by legislation last year to guide the purchase of wetlands important for migratory birds. The legislation carries out a 1986 agreement between the United States and Canada aimed at improving 6 million acres of wetlands in both countries. The new council will recommend acquisitions and other projects to the existing Migratory Bird Conservation Commission. Mexico agreed in 1988 to cooperate with the effort. President Bush has said he wants a goal of ``no net loss'' of wetlands. The new appointments: _Peter F. Bontadelli, director of the California Department of Fish and Game. _Gary Meyers, executive director, Tennessee Wildlife Resources Agency. _W. Alan Wentz, undersecretary of the Kansas Department of Wildlife and Parks. _James A. Timmerman Jr., executive director, South Carolina Wildlife and Marine Resources Department. _Matthew B. Connolly Jr., executive vice president, Ducks Unlimited. _John C. Sawhill, president of the Nature Conservancy. _William W. Howard Jr., executive vice president and chief operating officer of the National Wildlife Federation. John F. Turner, director of the Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service, and Charles H. Collins, executive director ot the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, are ex-officio members of the council. Terms are for three years, but to arrange staggered terms, Wentz and Sawhill will serve two years and Timmerman and Howard will serve one year.

DOC.HEAD: Chancellor Goes on Campaign Trip to East Germany
With AM-Germany
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl told a rally of 90,000 cheering East Germans Tuesday that his government will provide massive aid to help the troubled country's social safety net. West German politicians, who themselves face the voters in December, are increasingly using East Germany's election campaign to promote their own causes. With plans for reunification moving quickly, West German politicians are also trying to enlist supporters in East Germany for future elections. The West Germans also are lending campaign support to their inexperienced sister parties in East Germany and allied groups that have sprung up since the peaceful pro-democracy revolution in October and the ouster of the hard-line Communist government. The country's first free elections are on March 18. Kohl, a Christian Democrat, was lending support to East Germany's conservatives. He was repeatedly cheered by the large crowd waving West German flags and calling for quick unification. The rally was organized by the so-called ``Alliance for Germany,'' a group comprising the East German Christian Democrats, the German Social Union and Democratic Awakening. The Christian Democrats are trying to shake off 40 years of past association with the Communists. Kohl took a swipe at the opposition Social Democrats and their veteran leader Willy Brandt, saying Brandt only one year ago dismissed German unity as unrealistic. East German Social Democrats are widely predicted to win the March election. Brandt remains hugely popular in East Germany and has often spokesn at rallies there. East German Social Democrats have said they will make Brandt their honorary chairman as well. Addressing fears about the planned introduction of the West German mark as East Germany's currency, Kohl said his government will help East Germany develop a similar comprehensive social security network that is enjoyed by West Germans. East Germans have expressed fears that the switch to West Germany's mighty mark will wipe out their savings, erode the value of pensions and trigger massive umemployment as the transition to capitalism forces unprofitable enterprises to close. But Kohl said his government will take care of the jobless, pensioners and others who might be affected by the switch in currency. Kohl tried to justify his refusal to give massive aid to the current interim, Communist-led government. ``I was not ready to invest billions in a system if I can't see that the citizens will benefit,'' Kohl said. The crowd responded by shouting, ``Helmut, Helmut!'' Lothar de Maiziere, the Christian Democrat leader, received loud cheers when he said German unity will come ``because the people want it.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspension Clouds Settlement of Strike
With AM-Coal Strike, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The expected suspension of 13 striking United Mine Workers chilled any celebration in this eastern Kentucky coal town over Tuesday's end to the strike against the Pittston Coal Group. Some area business owners and residents were relieved to hear that the UMW rank and file in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky approved the contract, 63 percent to 37 percent. ``Everybody's just tickled that it's over,'' said Eva Ryan, who operates a motel in Toler near the Kentucky-West Virginia border. ``Everybody's for the miners. We want them to get what they want.'' In the Charleston, W.Va., area, sighs of relief also replaced the tension. ``We are overjoyed,'' said Mark Spurlock, a Logan County commissioner. ``It is always a source of concern to everyone in Logan County when there is an interruption of work in the coal mines. It's hard on everyone, specifically the miners. ``When the mining industry gets sick, Logan County gets pneumonia. We're overjoyed that it's been settled, apparently with a contract that's well thought of by the miners, who are going back to work.'' Gov. Gaston Caperton's spokesman also welcomed the announcement. ``The governor's principal viewpoint was that there are many families here who have suffered some real hardship during the 10-month coal strike,'' said spokesman G.C. Morse. ``For their sake and their communities, this is certainly a good day for West Virginia.'' The topic on the minds of many, however, was the fate of the 13 miners the UMW expects Pittston suspend for alleged misconduct during the strike. Members of Local Union 5737 at McAndrews campaigned to defeat the contract because it failed to guarantee the 13 miners' jobs. Three of them belong to the local in eastern Pike County. Many miners had expected the local to handily defeat the contract as a statement of union solidarity for the 13 workers. They spoke bitterly about the local's surprisingly narrow rejection of the agreement: 93 votes in favor and 96 against. ``To me, it's the end of the union,'' said Ann Osborne, the wife of a striking miner. ``I still say a man who voted yes on that contract is no better than a scab who went to Virginia.'' Mrs. Osborne, who runs Osborne's Midnite Video, said the narrow vote in Kentucky revealed a fatal crack in unity among the miners. Jack Clevenger Jr., a retired miner, said those who voted for the contract ``were independent people voting for themselves.'' The high rate of approval for the contract probably will cause tension in the local, he said. ``It's a sore and it's going to take time to heal it. But time will heal it,'' Clevenger said. The specific allegations against the 13 miners would be detailed after contract ratification, said Glenn Stanley, the local's president. The cases then would be turned over to an arbitrator for settlement. Dave Scott, a striking miner, said the suspended miners were meeting in Virginia to discuss their fates with UMW Vice President Cecil Roberts.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Weather Moves Into Plains
DOC.TEXT: Snow continued to cover parts of the Plains, West and Pacific Northwest on Tuesday, while rains that had caused flooding in the South abated. Winter storm warnings were posted Tuesday for parts of New Mexico, the panhandles of Oklahoma and Texas, and west-central and southwest Kansas. Up to 5 inches of snow fell in the Dalhart, Texas, area, and as much as 5 inches of snow across three Kansas counties. Two inches fell at Guyman, Okla., and as much as 6 inches in Oklahoma's Cimarron County. Advisories for snow across parts of Colorado were lifted Tuesday morning. after 8 inches of new snow covered Trinidad, 12 inches across the south side of Trinidad, 8 inches at Walsenburg, and 7 inches at La Junta. A winter storm warning was posted for the Washington Cascades Tuesday after Snoqualmie and Stevens Passes both got about 8 inches of snow. Early Tuesday afternoon snow fell across northern New Mexico, much of Colorado, southwest Nebraska, western Kansas, the Oklahoma Panhandle and the northwest part of the Texas Panhandle. Rain extended across the rest of the Texas Panhandle into northwest Texas. Snow also fell in eastern Washington state. Rain in western Oregon and western Washington became snow in higher elevations. Storms that dumped nearly 3 inches of rain Sunday night in south Alabama increased the concern of residents, especially with the predictions of another storm system due to enter the state around Thursday. ``It's not going to be good because all the reservoirs are basically full and the ground is still saturated,'' said Brian Peters, a meterologist with the National Weather Service in Birmingham. The weather service at Mobile predicted 5 to 8 inches of rainfall by Thursday, and meteorologist Jim Hyder said the Tombigbee, Alabama and Mobile rivers in Alabama can expect crests well above flood stage this week and next. Advisories for wind chills Tuesday were in effect for northern Maine and New Hampshire. Winds gusted to 53 mph at Montpelier, Vt. Gusty winds and cold temperatures combined to produce very cold wind chills. Record low temperatures for the date were set in the West. Redding, Calif., reached 27 degrees, breaking the 1985 record of 32; Reno, Nev., cooled to 6 degrees, plummeting below the 9-degree reading of 1903, and the Alameda (Calif.) Naval Air Station broke the 1976 record of 42 with a 39-degree reading. The low for the Lower 48 Tuesday: 24 degrees below zero at West Yellowstone, Mont. In Alaska, there was no place like Nome, where the average daily temperature for the first 19 days of February was 17 degrees below zero. That's more than 20 degrees lower than normal. Monday was the 10th day at Nome with a high temperature of 10 degrees below zero or lower. The nation's temperatures at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 1 degree below zero at Limestone, Maine, to 84 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista, Opposition Trade Boasts and Accusations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Chamorro speech; pickup 8th graf pvs, `The whole...' DELETES last graf to CONFORM.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA1
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Sandinistas traded boasts and accusations with the opposition Tuesday, and outside observers checked everything from paper ballots to computers for the weekend election. ``In the remote chance that we lose, I will personally congratulate my adversary the way they do it in all the democracies,'' opposition presidential candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro said in a speech to 400 chanting supporters. It was the second campaign speech billed as the last of her campaign. By law, campaigning stops at midnight Wednesday and the United National Opposition alliance that backs Mrs. Chamorro held a rally Sunday that she said would close out her public campaign. President Daniel Ortega's campaign manager said the Sandinistas would win an election certified as fair by international observers, and predicted the United States would be friendlier afterward. ``We're optimistic about the future,'' Bayardo Arce told reporters. ``We expect President Bush to divorce himself from the policies that he inherited from President Reagan.'' Reiterating a Sandinista campaign theme, Arce said a U.S. embargo and Washington's support for the Contra rebels were responsible for Nicaragua's economic crisis. He said the voters knew that, and ``also know the efforts the government has made to implement policies to protect the poorest sectors of society.'' Alfredo Cesar, chief strategist for Mrs. Chamorro, predicted UNO would win on Sunday with 55 percent of the vote to 40 percent for the Sandinistas. Arce said the Sandinistas would relinquish power in the ``hypothetical case'' of an opposition victory, but other Sandinista officials have said they would not necessarily give up control of the army or police. ``The military will have a place in our society but they will not be the directors of national life,'' Mrs. Chamorro said. ``The whole thing is in Ortega's hands,'' Cesar said in an interview. ``If he concedes defeat, there's nothing the others can do.'' Ortega agreed to the election as part of a Central American accord also designed to disband the Contra force organized in 1981, two years after the Sandinistas overthrew President Anastasio Somoza. It pits the Sandinistas against the 14-party UNO coalition and eight other parties. A president, vice president, 90-member National Assembly and local officials are to be chosen for six-year terms. Recent independent polls have shown the Sandinistas leading, but their accuracy is questionable because so many Nicaraguans are afraid to reveal their true feelings to a stranger. Hotels were filled long ago by official observers, unofficial observers and journalists. Some late arrivals said they were bumped despite numerous confirmations and sought beds in private houses. Every rental car in Managua was gone by Tuesday and the government was getting $100 a day plus mileage for battered Soviet-made Ladas. Official observer missions use white buses and four-wheel-drive vehicles. Among the observers arriving Tuesday was Elliot Richardson, a former U.S. attorney general who heads the U.N. team. ``The mission has over the last week significantly increased its observer force, amounting now to over 200 election monitors who will be deployed in 100 teams of two across the length and breadth of the national territory,'' he said in a statement. A practice run-through of election procedures was being planned at the central election center. The Supreme Electoral Council issued a statement saying it would make the official count and issue the results, however many observers were present. Arce congratulated Mrs. Chamorro on the ``conciliatory'' tone of her final campaign speech Sunday, but said ``violent elements'' in the opposition were ignoring her. He said 14 Sandinista party activists had been killed by Contra rebels since December and repeated accusations that Mrs. Chamorro's supporters hoped to obscure a Sandinista victory with violence. On Monday the government said nine people had been killed in the past week in clashes with Contras, but claimed that was not an increase in rebel activity. The civil war has continued at a low level despite the end of U.S. lethal aid to the Contras. Government sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they did not expect any real disruption by the Contras. The opposition accused the Sandinistas of political murder in the shooting death Monday of Fernando Jesus Moya Jimenez, an 18-year-old alliance activist. Relatives gathered Tuesday at his coffin, which was draped with a UNO banner. Police said Moya was shot while trying to rob a woman on the street. In downtown Managua, where blocks of buildings wrecked in a 1972 earthquake have not been rebuilt, workmen constructed a podium and grandstands for the closing Sandinista rally Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Former Shock TV Talk Show Host Files Bankruptcy Reorganization Papers
LaserPhoto NR1
DOC.TEXT: Former ``shock TV'' talk show host Morton Downey Jr. has only $100 in his pocket, and is seeking protection from a limousine company and other creditors under federal bankruptcy laws, court papers indicate. Downey listed liabilities of nearly $2.4 million, including a mortgage of $628,000 and federal taxes of $500,000, in a petition filed Friday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court seeking protection under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law. Downey, who lives in suburban Englewood, listed assets that include commissions and syndication rights worth $6.3 million and $500,000 in real property, according to financial statements that also say he has only $320 in the bank and $100 cash on hand. Downey attorney Brian D. Spector would not comment on whether Downey's financial troubles were related to the demise of ``The Morton Downey Jr. Show,'' a nationally syndicated talk program that featured the host ranting about issues and taunting guests until it was canceled after two years. In May 1989, Downey said he was attacked by skinheads who cut his hair and drew swastikas on his face in a restroom at a San Francisco airport. No arrests were made, and police said they had no evidence to support his claim. Downey's creditors include more than 75 banks, businesses and agencies _ including posh New York boutiques and restaurants _ a New Jersey limousine service and New York City's Parking Violations Bureau, court papers said. Listed among the 20 largest unsecured creditors are the exclusive New York jewelers Bulgari and Cartier, which he owes $24,000 and $9,000, respectively. The list includes debts of $76,000 on American Express Platinum and Gold cards, the court papers said. Downey also acknowledged owing money to Flexilease, an Aberdeen leasing company that sued him last year for $35,000, claiming a Lincoln limousine he leased was returned with shoddy repair work and urine in the crystal decanters. ``He made the car into a trash can,'' Flexilease owner Frank McGrath said, adding that Downey defaulted on monthly payments. Spector said his client was out of town until next week, and he would advise him not to comment because of the sensitive nature of bankruptcy filings. A pioneer of shock television, ``The Morton Downey Jr. Show'' initially enjoyed good ratings after its debut in October 1987, but began a slide as Downey repeatedly got in trouble with the law. The show was canceled in September 1989. Downey was charged at least twice with assaulting guests on the show, including a gay-rights activist. In April 1989, Downey was acquitted on charges that he slapped the gay-rights activist. The other case was dropped.

DOC.HEAD: Boat People Injured In Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Fighting between Vietnamese boat people armed with homemade weapons broke out Tuesday at the troubled Whitehead Camp detention center, and seven people were injured, an official said. Four of the seven were hospitalized, he said. Earlier in the day, four Vietnamese at the same camp slashed their abdomens in apparent protest of the Hong Kong policy to repatriate boat people against their will. The four men, ages 25 to 40, were hurried to a hospital after injuring themselves with homemade weapons, said government spokeswoman Winnie To. Their wounds were not serious and they left the hospital after refusing treatment, she said. Four other boat people facing repatriation injured themselves in a similar fashion earlier this year at the detention center. They all survived, but another Vietnamese man hanged himself Friday after being denied refugee status. About 44,000 Vietnamese boat people languishing in Hong Kong camps face repatriation to their communist homeland unless they can show a well-founded fear of persecution. Tension has increased in the detention centers since a first batch of Vietnamese were sent home against their will in December, and there have been several outbreaks of factional fighting. About 60 boat people were involved in the clash Tuesday in a section of the camp housing Vietnamese from the northern port city of Haiphong, said Ish Bhagat, a top official in charge of the camps. Tension reportedly was running high among Haiphong people from different areas of the city. Reinforcements were called in to help 120 police and other security forces quell the violence, Bhagat told government-funded radio.

DOC.HEAD: UN Panel Approves Measure Opposed by U.S., Panama, Others
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Human Rights Commission, ignoring a plea from Panama, censured the United States Tuesday for the invasion that toppled the regime of Manuel Antonio Noriega last December. The 43-nation body voted 14-8 to adopt a resolution introduced by Cuban Deputy Foreign Minister Raul Roa that denounced the action as a ``flagrant violation of international law'' and stressed the right of the people of Panama ``to decide its future in free and sovereign fashion.'' Panama, the United States and six other Western countries cast dissenting ballots. Seventeen delegations, including most Third World nations and some Western countries abstained, arguing that the commission was not an appropriate forum to discuss the issue. Four nations did not vote. Panama's chief delegate, Osvaldo Velasquez, who headed his country's human rights commission for 10 years under the military regime, said there was ``no sincerity'' in the measure sponsored by Libya, Vietnam, and Nicaragua. ``Never in these 10 years did we ever hear Cuba defend the human rights of the Panamanians who suffered the worst breaches of those rights in the world,'' he told the commission. U.S. Ambassador Morris B. Abram said the United States was voting against the resolution ``with regret that such a document was ever presented.'' Voting in favor of the resolution on the U.S. invasion were Brazil, Bulgaria, China, Cuba, Cyprus, Ethiopia, Hungary, India, Iraq, Mexico, Sri Lanka, Soviet Ukraine, Soviet Union and Yugoslavia. Voting against were Canada, West Germany, Italy, Japan, Panama, Portugal, Britain and the United States. Abstaining were Argentina, Belgium, Botswana, Colombia, France, Ghana, Madagascar, Morocco, Nigeria, Pakistan, Peru, the Philippines, Somalia, Spain, Swaziland, Sweden and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Bohlen Gets Nod for State Dept. Environmental Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday announced the nomination of Curtis Bohlen, vice president of the World Wildlife Fund, as assistant secretary of state for oceans and international environmental and scientific affairs. Bohlen has been senior vice president of the fund since 1981 and previously served as a consultant to it, as well as vice president of Eastern Environmental Controls Inc. in Chestertown, Md. He has previously worked for the Interior Department in various capacities and at the State Department.

DOC.HEAD: Police Kill 11 Guerrillas in Two Jungle Battles
DOC.TEXT: A police patrol killed 11 leftist guerrillas in two jungle battles, the interior ministry said Tuesday. The ministry said in a communique that a 30-man police patrol killed five guerrillas Saturday near the jungle town of Andamarca, 165 miles east of the capital. Police pursued rebels who escaped the battle and caught up with them Sunday, killing six, the statement said. Police recovered arms, ammunition and explosives after the battle, it said. The communique reported no casualties among the police. It did not specify which rebel group the guerrillas belonged to, but police said previously that Maoist Shining Path rebels have been involved in recent attacks in the Andamarca area. The Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, a smaller and less radical guerrilla movement, also operates in the region. The Shining Path launched its armed insurgency in 1980 in the southern highlands, while the Revolutionary Movement took up arms in 1984. The government says more than 17,500 people have died in the 10 years of violence, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Guards Suspended in Alleged Beating of Inmate
DOC.TEXT: The FBI said Tuesday it was investigating possible civil rights violations in the savage beating of a state prison inmate allegedly attacked by guards, three of whom were suspended with pay. Corrections Department spokesman Joseph DiNitto confirmed that three guards were suspended Jan. 17 in connection with the Nov. 19 beating of Donald R. Coulter, who was held on a charge he assaulted his girlfriend's 13-month-old son. ``We completed our investigation on these three people ... and feel that there might be some need for prosecution,'' DiNitto said. FBI spokesman Paul Cavanagh in Boston said the bureau had begun an inquiry at the request of Corrections Department officials and would work with federal prosecutors in Providence as well as the Justice Department's civil rights section in Washington. ``I think it will be less complicated than some,'' Cavanagh said of the investigation, but gave no details. Two other guards who cooperated in the investigation were put on administrative leave after they complained of harassment by their colleagues, said John Sabalewski, president of the Rhode Island Brotherhood of Corrections Officers. DiNitto refused to discuss those two guards, but Sabalewski confirmed that they alleged fellow guards had harassed them and refused to work with them. ``They did have a hard time for various reasons, but I don't want to get into them because the investigation's still going on,'' said Sabalewski, who would not identify them. He said the administration had declined his offer to meet over the pair's grievances. Administrative leave ``doesn't solve anything,'' he said. ``If anything, it creates a problem. When they do come back they still have to deal with the problem.'' DiNitto said the three guards would remain suspended until a departmental hearing next week. Sabalewski called the process ``a farce'' and charged that discipline decisions were made beforehand. He said the guards denied the charges. ``There's a possibility the inmate was beaten before he ever got into the institution,'' Sabalewski said, declining to elaborate. Coulter, 33, of Cranston, who was charged with first-degree child abuse, was beaten so badly the day of his arrest that he was hospitalized and missed his court appearance the next day, The Providence Journal-Bulletin reported. He allegedly was cornered in a holding cell at the Adult Correctional Institutions and beaten by guards, the newspaper quoted an unidentified source as saying. Corrections officials refused comment at the time, even after Coulter was admitted to Rhode Island Hospital with multiple bruises, a swollen face and broken ribs. Doctors also found a spinal abnormality they said could have been caused by the beating, the newspaper said. Coulter, who has been unable to post $150,000 bond, remains in protective custody, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Bans BBC Reporter
DOC.TEXT: Iran's government said Tuesday that the British Broadcasting Corp.'s Iranian correspondent in Tehran will not be allowed to report for the network in retalitation for Britain's deportation of Iranians earlier this month. The official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the government ``closed down the British Broadcasting Corp.'s office in Tehran in reprisal for London's hostile attitude toward Iranian citizens in that country.'' The British Home Office deported nine Iranians, including the bureau chief of the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting networks, for ``reasons of national security because their activities were not conducive to the public good.'' The BBC does not have a bureau in Tehran. A BBC editor in London, who declined to be identified, told The Associated Press earlier this month the state-financed broadcasting system does ``not have a staff correspondent in Iran at present.'' IRNA referred to an Iranian working part time for the BBC's London-based radio service as ``the head of the BBC in Iran.''

DOC.HEAD: Recording Artists Tune Up for Music Industry's Big Night
DOC.TEXT: The cavernous Shrine Auditorium bustled with activity Tuesday as producers tuned up musicians, performers, presenters and stage crews for the recording industry's 32nd annual Grammy Awards show. Stars such as Bette Midler and Michael Bolton rehearsed songs they will perform Wednesday during the three-hour CBS-TV broadcast of the presentations, while show workers and executives were fitted for tuxedos. Miss Midler's recording of ``Wind Beneath My Wings'' from the movie ``Beaches'' drew a nomination for best female pop vocal and song of the year. Bolton is up for best male pop vocal for ``How Am I Supposed To Live Without You,'' against the stiff competition of Prince, Richard Marx, Billy Joel and the late Roy Orbison. The show required 150 tuxedos for band members, camera operators and production executives, among others. Lower-ranking workers got a ``basic'' tuxedo; VIPs had a choice of single- and double-breasted Pierre Cardin tuxedos, said outfitter Frankie Windom of Frankie's Formal Attire. ``We'll probably be working into the late, late night,'' Windom said. The catering company Ambrosia, for two years the caterer to the Academy Awards' Governors Ball, prepared to serve 1,500 meals from eight menus for everyone from technical service workers to celebrities, starting at 8 a.m. The celebrity menu featured upscale, healthy and easy to eat food, including organic vegetable crudites, chicken pecan skewers and homemade potato chips and fruit platters, said Ambrosia owner Carl Bendix. The Grammys, so called because the trophy is shaped like an old-fashioned gramophone, are presented by the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences. This year there were 388 nominees in 77 categories. Sixty-one awards will be presented in a non-televised ceremony from 2:30 p.m. to 4 p.m. Wednesday. Sixteen trophies will be awarded during the broadcast portion. Tape-delayed on the West Coast, the broadcast goes live to the East beginning at 5 p.m. PST. Comedian and television star Garry Shandling was to be the host and more than a dozen nominated artists are scheduled to perform. Paul McCartney and jazz artist Miles Davis will each receive the Academy's Lifetime Achievement Awards. The show could turn into an ersatz Beatles reunion. In addition to McCartney's award, George Harrison is up for a Grammy as a member of the all-star Traveling Wilburys and Ringo Starr was nominated along with Buck Owens for best country vocal collaboration on the single ``Act Naturally.''

DOC.HEAD: Britain to Lift South Africa Investment Embargo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD Italian concern over emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, SUB last 2 grafs with 3 grafs; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DUB3
DOC.TEXT: Britain on Tuesday failed to persuade the European Community to ease sanctions against South Africa and announced it would go ahead and lift an embargo on new investment. It said it had U.S. support for such an action. ``We need to give support to ... (South African) President de Klerk, who has taken his political life in his hands,'' British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd declared after a daylong meeting of foreign ministers of the wealthy, 12-nation trade bloc ended in deadlock. ``It is not enough to sit back and say, `That's encouraging, let's see what you do next,''' he said. Hurd said President Bush wrote British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Tuesday ``analyzing the legal situation imposed by Congress.'' Bush is prevented by Congress from lifting sanctions until South Africa fulfills strict conditions. ``He (Bush) went on to say the steps we are taking are positive and added that he feels very strongly that when someone does what you are asking him, you should recognize that fact,'' Hurd said. The foreign ministers rejected a British compromise to delay action if all 12 nations pledged to scrap the 1986 investment embargo when South Africa lifts the state of emergency and to end all embargoes when black and white leaders start negotiations. The community said in a statement that the white-dominated government's political reforms ``while welcome ... do not yet go far enough.'' The ministers decided to send a three-nation, fact-finding mission to South Africa. The countries _ France, Ireland and Italy _ are the past, present and next holders of the community's rotating presidency. Hurd said while Britain did not oppose the mission, ``It did not meet the case. It would be interpreted as a signal by the 12 delaying rather than encouraging.'' Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins said unilateral action would damage ``the credibility of European political cooperation.'' ``This would be a dangerous precedent ... and I would appeal to everyone here not to embark on such such a course.'' Collins said the community did agree to lift cultural and scientific restrictions, on the understanding ``that our objective in doing this is to contribute to the ending of apartheid.''
