DOC.HEAD: Western Sanctions Against China, Never Strong, Are Eroding
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Citing national interest, humanitarian causes and business competition, Western democracies are slowly dismantling the sanctions they imposed on China after the bloody suppression of the democracy movement last spring. Western officials are coming back to renew contacts with Chinese counterparts, but tourists and businessmen, still apparently wary, haven't returned in the numbers they came in before. The West remains committed, in principle, to limits on high-level visits, arms sales and new aid packages. But with the beginning of the year ``exceptions'' have become the rule and some sanctions, never strong to start with, are withering away even though repression continues. The turning point was the surprise visit in December by U.S. National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and disclosures that he had made a previous visit in July, just a month after the army killed hundreds, perhaps thousands, in snuffing out the pro-democracy movement. President Bush was assailed in Congress for his overtures to the hardline Beijing government, but other Western nations quickly followed suit in easing bans on high-level contacts. But the tourists and businessmen who had poured into China after it opened up to the West a decade ago are staying home. Tourist-hotel occupancy rates are only about half what they were a year ago and the China market seems to have lost its luster for businessmen as the government reasserts central controls and puts off new market-oriented reforms. ``Businessmen were the first to argue we really ought to get back in,'' said an Australian diplomat. ``Now they are some of the most reluctant to come back.'' John Frisbie of the U.S.-China Business Council said: ``There is little direct correlation between sanctions and business, but the direction of Chinese policy was positive before. Now businessmen are uncertain and will be for some time.'' The renewed contacts are chiefly governmental. The European Economic Community decided in mid-January that political visits short of the ministerial level were acceptable. Australia said on Jan. 23 that visits by Cabinet ministers would be allowed on a case-by-case basis. In January, Japan played host to the head of China's State Planning Commission, and Britain disclosed that Sir Percy Cradock, senior foreign policy adviser to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, held secret talks in Beijing in December. More crucial to China has been the lifting of bans on credit and aid. In December the EEC gave its 12 member nations the go-ahead to extend export credits to China, and Spain responded by announcing a $30 million development loan in early January. On Feb. 2, the U.S. Export-Import bank signed a $9.75 million loan with a Chinese oil corporation. A week later the bank announced a $10.4 million grant, part of a $23.1 million package to encourage China to buy American equipment for a Shanghai subway project. The bank said contracts won by American companies would have been jeopardized if financing had not been finalized. West Germany has provided $275 million in preferential credit for the subway project. Only a few private syndicated loans have been made since June but, as one West German diplomat said, ``Everyone is waiting for the World Bank.'' The Chinese ``are almost passionate about World Bank loans,'' said one U.S. official. He said Chinese officials constantly bring up the $780 million in World Bank concessionary credit suspended since June and blame the United States for it. ``They say, `If the World Bank loans do not come through, we will retaliate against you,''' the official said. On Feb. 8, the World Bank, following a White House decision to back loans for ``human needs,'' approved a loan package of $30 million to aid an earthquake-struck area of northern China. The ban, with 151 nations as members, is still withholding the big development loan package, but a positive decision could open the floodgates, particularly from China's main creditor, Japan. Japan continues to discourage commercial lending but has also given the go-ahead to ``human need'' loans and has started talks on a five-year, $5.6 billion package of development aid. Other signs of encroaching normalcy in relations are showing up. A $600 million U.S. project to develop avionic equipment for Chinese fighter planes is on course; Chinese engineers were allowed to return to their jobs at U.S. plants in October. A vote by the U.S. Congress in late January to codify sanctions drew howls of protest from China, but Congress allowed Bush to waive sanctions if it was in the ``national interest,'' a right he exercised in approving the export of three U.S.-made satellites to be launched by Chinese rockets. The U.S. Department of Agriculture recently announced China was authorized to buy an additional 1 million metric tons of wheat at subsidized prices and U.S.-China trade in general expanded by nearly 40 percent in 1989 over 1988. Talks are under way to resume the Fulbright program. The Peace Corps, unable to send its first volunteers last year, hopes to start its program this year. Canada announced in January its first new cultural project since last year, a community college exchange program. Bush and other Western leaders have argued that the Chinese people should not suffer from sanctions and that it's bad policy to isolate the Chinese government. So far, however, China has done little to reciprocate the West's conciliatory gestures. The government, in moves mainly intended to improve its international image and obtain badly needed foreign credit, lifted martial law in Beijing in January and announced the release of 573 participants in the pro-democracy movement. But political repression continues, with dissent outlawed and thousands of activists languishing in jails without being formally tried and forbidden to see families and lawyers. Government leaders continue to say China's economic reforms and open door policy go on, yet the Communist Party is reasserting controls over industry and the propaganda line is that Western technology is fine but Western values must be repudiated. As a consequence, it's hardly ``business as usual'' with China. Foreign Minister Gareth Evans of Australia has said his country's continued ban on new aid projects and concessional lending ``reflects the reality that unhappily nothing much has changed since last June.'' Japan's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Taizo Watanabe, concurred: ``We are ready to cooperate as soon as possible in the direction of the modernization of China. But the developments under which we can conduct normal relations have yet to arrive.'' Tourism, a major source of foreign exchange for China, has picked up only slightly. Occupancy rates at Beijing's main foreign tourist hotels averaged around 30 percent in January, compared to nearly 60 percent a year earlier. No major new joint venture projects have been put together since June. China's trade ministry said foreign loans implemented in 1989 were down 51 percent from the previous year to $4.8 billion, and technology import contracts were off 25 percent. Asked about the prospects for a quick return to normal business transactions, Liu Xiangdong, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade, said, ``We do not have any unrealistic fantasies.''

DOC.HEAD: City Hospitals Abandoning Trauma Care, Citing High Costs
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The helicopter appears as a pinlight on the northern horizon, the brightest star in a dark blue sky. Coming closer, it shoots a wide beam of light over the rooftop at Jackson Memorial Hospital and settles down with a shuddering blast of tropical air. Two men inside have been shot twice each with 9mm bullets, and one is dying. Dr. Jeff Vaughan, waiting on the landing pad, turns to a nurse. ``You're going to see blood now, sister,'' he says. But spilled blood is routine at Jackson Memorial's trauma center. Already this evening, the trauma crew has treated a woman shot by her boyfriend, a man dumped 30 feet off a scaffold, a 10-year-old bicyclist hit by a car and a prison inmate stabbed with a homemade knife. That roster accounts for every serious injury suffered in the Miami metropolitan area in the preceding six hours. If you're badly hurt in Dade County these days, the only place to go is Jackson Memorial. That distinction puts Jackson, a publicly financed teaching hospital, at the forefront of a dismal national trend. It is one of a shrinking number of big city hospitals offering special care for trauma, the medical name given to life-threatening injuries. In Los Angeles, Chicago, Philadelphia and elsewhere, private hospitals have been shutting down trauma units, most of which opened in the mid-1980s, the specialty's boom years. The resulting squeeze threatens not only quality of health care, but also the financial stability of the hospitals left carrying the load. Gunfights, car crashes, the occasional industrial accident _ these are the lifeblood of trauma care centers. The American College of Surgeons estimates that 250 to 350 trauma centers operate around the country, ranging from such giants as New York's Bellevue Hospital and Miami's Jackson Memorial to the N.T. Enloe Hospital in Chico, Calif., and Easton Hospital in Easton, Pa. Trauma units are usually affiliated with, but distinct from, ordinary emergency rooms. ERs handle broken legs, concussions, poisonings, the lesser varieties of mayhem. Trauma units take over in more serious cases of multiple injuries _ when lives are on the line. Trauma centers are staffed by surgeons, and major trauma hospitals keep full staffs of specialists on duty around the clock. If you need a neurosurgeon at 3 a.m., Jackson Memorial will have one. In rural and suburban areas, trauma is almost always the result of auto accidents, and the drivers are usually insured. In these areas, trauma centers pay their way, even make profits. But in inner cities, patients increasingly are members of what doctors caustically refer to as ``the knife and gun club.'' Club members have a couple of things in common: They are almost always involved in drugs; they are almost never insured. At Jackson Memorial, which handles 6,000 trauma cases a year, about one-third of the patients are admitted for ``penetrating trauma'' _ knife or bullet wounds. About one-third of the patients are uninsured. These are expensive injuries, and ``blunt trauma'' injuries suffered in car crashes can be even costlier. It's not unusual for trauma-care bills to mount into the tens or even hundreds of thousands of dollars. ``Even with the paying patient, trauma is going to cost more than the average treatment, more than what insurance will probably pay,'' said Jeanne Eckes, a registered nurse who coordinates Jackson's trauma service. Jackson estimates the trauma unit will lose at least $1.2 million this next fiscal year. In addition to direct losses, the hospital loses money when trauma patients ``bump'' regular patients out of operating rooms and intensive care beds. That happens nearly every day. Of four patients admitted to Jackson's trauma center so far this evening, three have been sent to the operating room or intensive care. The lone exception is the luckless prison inmate, who's been treated for his stab wounds and sent back to jail. It is already a grueling evening, filled with split-second, life-or-death decisions. Even the janitor is busy, mopping up blood from the trauma room floor. On a break in the action, Vaughan and another doctor, Alan Rosenberg, wolf down dinner in the cafeteria. They are there when Air Rescue calls about 10 p.m. Two men with gunshot wounds had shown up at a hospital eight miles away. They couldn't be treated there _ the hospital doesn't handle trauma. They are being flown to Jackson. On the elevator to the roof, Rosenberg and Vaughan turn goofy with excitement. They stretch out on the two gurneys and joke and slap five. They don't get serious until the helicopter is down, and then, with the blades still blurring overhead, they get serious in a hurry. Vaughan is first into the elevator with the more seriously wounded man. Before the doors shut, he is frantically at work. ``He's not moving any air, man,'' he says, his voice tight with tension. He shoves a tube down the man's nose and squeezes a bulbous green bag. A hole in the patient's chest gurgles with blood. When the elevator reaches the ground floor, Vaughan runs with the gurney to the trauma room. His patient is slipping away. Patients like this are flown to Jackson every day. The hospital tallies more than 1,000 helicopter landings a year in what some doctors say is a legacy of the Vietnam War _ the airborne rescue. Some people say the entire modern system of trauma care grew out of the military's medical experience in Vietnam; others say it evolved in large urban hospitals in the 1960s. Trauma care grew rapidly after research in the late 1970s proved trauma centers routinely saved lives that would be lost with ordinary emergency care. By the early to mid-1980s, trauma had become hot business. In search of prestige and profits, hospitals jumped at the opportunity to treat trauma victims, despite the expense of maintaining a 24-hour staff of surgical specialists. Some cities established trauma networks to ensure patients were sent to the closest trauma hospital. Miami's network, established in 1985, ultimately consisted of six private hospitals and the public Jackson Memorial. B. Boyd Benjamin, the blunt-talking, gravel-voiced chairman of the board of the Dade County Public Health Trust, recalls what happened then. ``It was wonderful,'' he said. ``Big committees met, everything was fine. And the first thing that happened, I guess, was some poor sonofabitch got run over and didn't have a penny and he ends up at one of these for-profit hospitals. And they want to ask, `Where's your insurance?' `I don't have any insurance.' ... They found out very quickly that this was going to be a loser.'' In the space of six months in 1987, all six private hospitals dropped out of the network, leaving Jackson the only metropolitan area hospital willing to accept adult trauma patients (Miami Children's Hospital accepts injured children). A similar winnowing process has taken place in other big cities as hospitals discover their expected profits are elusive. ``They see it as fiscally irresponsible,'' said Dr. Gerald O. Strauch, director of the Trauma Department at the American College of Surgeons in Chicago. ``We all know that hospitals have become big business, and they're managed like a big business.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, Feb. 25, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: MIAMI: big business.''
DOC.TEXT: In Los Angeles County, a regional trauma network with 23 hospitals has shrunk to 13. Chicago had 10 adult trauma hospitals two years ago; the loss of another hospital this month will reduce the number to six. Houston is down to just one Level I trauma center, capable of handling the most serious cases. One of Philadelphia's major trauma centers, Temple University Hospital, recently announced it was leaving a regional trauma system. The hospitals that remain are increasingly overwhelmed, their trauma centers resembling nothing so much as military MASH units in the heat of battle. Indeed, the military sends its physicians to inner city trauma centers to prepare them for combat. The consolidation of trauma care raises some daunting questions. What happens to the patient who's in a serious auto accident and has to be taken 25 miles to a hospital instead of five? Worse, what happens when a plane crashes? ``It's gotten to the point where, no matter who you are, if you're injured in a city, your chances of getting to a trauma center that has everything it needs are getting slimmer,'' said Dr. Jeff Augenstein, one of the attending surgeons in charge at Jackson. Jackson's administrators believe they've found a solution. Having accepted their hospital's role as the city's only trauma-care center, they intend to capitalize on it. They are now trying to raise $25 million for what Benjamin, the public health trust's board chairman, calls a ``state of the art, world class, self-contained, free-standing shock-trauma center.'' The idea is to get trauma patients out of the main hospital, leaving more room there for regular, paying patients. ``Our projections show that we will at least break even,'' Benjamin said. Hospital officials hope the new center will become a magnet for research dollars and talented staff. In the meantime, doctors at Jackson insist they can handle anything that comes their way. It is 10:14 p.m. when Jeff Vaughan wheels the gurney into the trauma room. Half a dozen people jump to action. One slips an oxygen mask over the patient's face, another takes blood. Vaughan examines the body. It is young and strong and has bullet holes in the chest and shoulder. Two police officers stand to the side, watching. ``Where's X-ray?'' Vaughan hollers. ``C'mon, Hector, let's get a quick film.'' At 10:18, Vaughan inserts a tube nearly the width of a garden hose into the left side of the man's chest. It begins pumping hemorrhaging blood out of the chest cavity and into intravenous tubes for transfusion. Vaughan's rubber gloves and gown are covered with blood; red dots shine on his eyeglass lenses. ``What's his pressure?'' someone shouts. ``Very, very low,'' Vaughan yells back. ``He's got serious problems in his chest.'' He goes to the other side and inserts another tube. ``We've got blood on this side too, guys, and lots of it.'' Within minutes, the crisis ebbs. The patient's systolic blood pressure, about 50 when he entered the trauma room, is up to 110. His pulse is strong. He breathes with the aid of the oxygen mask. The gurney is pushed out the door and up to the operating room. ``He's a long way from being OK, but he's got a chance,'' Vaughan says. Bloody footprints mark the path down the hall. It has been a remarkable display of grace under pressure, but it isn't enough this time. The patient dies 10 minutes into surgery. His buddy survives, and not for the first time. Medical records show he's been treated at Jackson before for gunshot wounds _ six times. ``Hey, man, you gonna get some frequent flier miles if you keep coming in here,'' Vaughan tells him. Police say the two men claimed to have been attacked on the street for no reason; the cops' tone suggests disbelief. Vaughan drifts into an employee lounge for a Dr Pepper and a smoke. He is about 18 hours into a 24-hour shift and it is beginning to show. He speaks bitterly about the strains of the job and patients who ``would just as soon kill us as look at us.'' ``It's a war zone,'' he says. ``And it's like this in every major city.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Feb. 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Price Tag Grows for Alaska's Generosity Toward Senior Citizens
DOC.TEXT: Alaska is a young frontier state where old-timers still are called pioneers. And being a pioneer has its benefits. The state runs six bargain-rate retirement homes, pays residents 65 and older $250 a month regardless of need, provides them a property-tax exemption or rent rebate, and issues free hunting and fishing licenses. There also are local sales-tax exemptions, free university tuition and free transportation on state ferries. Compared to other states, Alaska is generous to its elderly. But that may not last the decade. They are exacting a growing cost as Alaska's population ages. And a severe drop in oil revenues expected this decade already has led to changes in the most expensive programs. The residency requirement for the $250-a-month ``longevity bonus'' was increased from one to two years Jan. 1, and the Legislature is considering phasing out the program over the next two decades. And rates at the state's ``pioneers' homes'' were increased by as much as 52 percent recently. After planning their retirement around the programs, many older residents fear they may be ``left out in the street'' in their final years, said Barbara Bathony, director of the state Pioneers' Benefits Division. ``It is traumatic for a person in their later years to have to think, `What is going to happen to me?''' said Joe Alter of Juneau, a 74-year-old retired civil engineer who moved to Alaska 46 years ago ``when nobody thought of retiring here.'' Changes are inevitable, said Rep. Red Boucher of Anchorage, who is 69. If changes are made carefully and over time, he said, senior citizens will adjust. ``We treat them as good as any other state in the union, if not better,'' he said. ``I think that's good. We just have to achieve a balance in it. I don't know of a single Alaskan who wouldn't agree with that.'' Alaska began caring for its older residents long before it became a state in 1959. The first pioneers' home opened in Sitka in 1913. This year the state expects to spend more than $25 million to run the homes for about 540 residents. More than double that amount is spent on the unique longevity bonus program, created in 1972 to reward people who had helped settle the Alaska territory. At first it provided $100 a month to Alaskans 65 and older who had lived in the state continuously for at least 25 years. ``It started out as a great idea for those people who came here in hard times and made many sacrifices,'' Boucher said. In 1984, however, the Alaska Supreme Court ruled the 25-year residency rule unconstitutional. The number of recipients and the program's cost increased sharply. Today more than 19,000 Alaskans claim the bonuses, at a cost of about $62 million a year, including administrative expenses. Proponents say that investment pays off economically and socially. For many older Alaskans, the bonus helps them meet the state's high cost of living. ``There's a strong feeling that senior citizens want to become part of this society. They don't want to be isolated,'' Alter said. ``Some of those benefits make it possible for these people to stay here economically. Otherwise they'd be going south.'' ``When they leave they take their savings accounts, their pensions and their retirement money out of state,'' said Connie Sipe, executive director of the state Older Alaskans Commission. The programs apparently have kept the elderly in Alaska and brought in a few more. The number of Alaskans over 65 has grown at a rate faster than the overall population since 1970, according to the state Labor Department. In 1988 those over 65 accounted for 3.8 percent of Alaska's population, up from 2.3 percent in 1970. ``We are having a little in-migration,'' Sipe said. ``I don't think it's because of the benefits. I think it's because of family.'' Even without transplants, Alaska's older population is expected to continue growing in the 1990s. Alaskans ages 55-64, who soon will be signing up for longevity bonuses and beds in pioneers' homes, represent 5.4 percent of the population. That's still a small percentage, ``but they make up 15 to 20 percent of the voting block,'' making lawmakers reluctant to attack the programs publicly, said Rep. Terry Martin of Anchorage. ``I'm not concerned because I don't think anything's going to happen right away,'' said Mellie Terwilliger, 80, an Alaskan for 60 years who lives with her husband in Tok near their son and his family. She said senior citizens have considerable political clout in Juneau. ``We're very well-organized.'' Martin favors basing the bonus on need. A couple with a pair of pensions, social security income and investments do not need an extra $500 a month from the state, he said. But Sipe notes a 1984 study for the Older Alaskans Commission, which showed that half the longevity bonus recipients lived on $10,000 a year or less. The study said 17.6 percent had incomes above $20,000. State Sen. Jay Kerttula, a creator of the longevity bonus, said it was not based on need because that would have made it seem like welfare. Lawmakers ``understood from their lifetime of experiences on the frontier what allowed a frontiersman to accept some type of assistance with some dignity,'' Kerttula said. Basing the bonus on need would require more bureaucracy, and the increased costs would outweigh any savings, said Vera Gazaway, executive director of the non-profit Older Persons Action Group Inc. in Anchorage. Kerttula has proposed an annuity plan to replace state funding of the bonus, an idea that has not yet become law. State retirement homes also are becoming more costly. Pioneers' homes are for those over 65 who have been continuous residents of Alaska for at least 15 years. However, destitute Alaskans get priority and do not have to meet the age limit. One-sixth of those in the homes at the end of 1989 were considered destitute. The greatest demand is for beds in the nursing-care units, where the wait can run to five years. The rates, up to $800 a month for nursing care, compare with private nursing homes that charge more than $5,000 a month. The six homes are a major part of the elderly health-care system in Alaska. There are no profit-making nursing homes and only 12 private, non-profit facilities _ all but one with fewer than 100 beds. The pioneers' homes charge only those who can afford to pay, and because of the restrictive residency requirements the homes do not get federal Medicaid money. Bathony said that while costs have continued to rise, the Legislature has not increased the homes' budget since 1986. Alaska needs a system for home care as an alternative to nursing homes, Sipe said. Legislation is pending that would allow the state to use Medicaid money for home care. ``We're quite behind other states,'' she said. ``We're in the bottom third in terms of home-care options for seniors.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Feb. 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Benefits for Alaska Elderly Add Up to Thousands of Dollars
With BC-PRI--Alaska Elderly
DOC.TEXT: Annual benefits for an Alaskan over 65 total in the thousands of dollars. Here's a description: LONGEVITY BONUS: $250 a month to all Alaskans 65 and older who have lived in the state continuously for at least two years. No income limit. PIONEERS' HOMES: Six state-run retirement homes for those over 65 who have been continuous residents for at least 15 years. Exception to age requirement for the destitute. Rates from $525 a month for minimal services to $800 a month for nursing care. Compares to private nursing-home rates of more than $5,000 a month. PROPERTY TAXES: First $150,000 of assessed value of a home is exempt from tax for homeowners 65 and older. No income limit. Average benefit is $1,000 a year. Must have been a resident of the state since Jan. 1 of the given year. RENT REBATE: For renters over 65, the rebate is designed to provide the equivalent of the property-tax exemption. Based on rent paid, no income limit. Average 1989 benefit was $623. Must have been a resident of the state since Jan. 1. SALES TAXES: Requirements and benefits vary by city or borough. In Juneau, for example, those over 65 are exempt from the 4 percent sales tax and can ride city buses free. The city estimates the average tax savings at $400 a year. TUITION: Those 60 and older can take classes tuition-free at the University of Alaska on a space-available basis if they meet normal admission requirements. Tuition at the three largest campuses runs $546 a semester for a full undergraduate course load. HUNTING, FISHING & TRAPPING: The state offers an identification card for those 60 and older, which substitutes for the $32 annual hunting, fishing and trapping license. Must have been a resident at least a year to qualify. FERRY RIDES: The Alaska Marine Highway System offers free passage within the state for anyone over 65 from Oct. 1 to May 15. In summer, free passage is available on the three smaller ferries only as space is available. Does not include vehicle or cabin charges. Savings varies from $12 to $82 for a one-way trip in winter.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Feb. 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Flannery: At 88, Still Fighting
DOC.TEXT: It used to take the old IRA man an hour to cross the room at a NORAID fund-raiser, besieged as he was by people who wanted to shake his hand, kiss his cheek or snap his picture. This, they'd tell their children, is Michael Flannery: the teen-age soldier who fought the British in Ireland's war of independence; the young man who moved to America but never forgot Ireland; the old man who founded Irish Northern Aid to support the Irish Republican Army's battle against British rule in Northern Ireland. But when NORAID held its annual dinner last month, for the first time in 18 years Michael Flannery stayed home. At 88, most people are inclined to ease off, accepting easy acclaim and benign deference. Not Flannery. He has denounced the leaders of NORAID and of Sinn Fein, the IRA's political party, for placing too much faith in politics and not enough in military force. ``It grieved me to leave NORAID, because I was its founder,'' he says in his squeaky brogue. ``But it was the only thing my conscience would allow me to do.'' For three-quarters of a century, Flannery's conscience repeatedly has forced him to choose principle over expediency, and to fight other Irishmen over how to best fight the British. On a recent morning Flannery greeted a reporter at the door of his Queens home. His step, once brisk, now inclined toward a shuffle, and his back, once ramrod stiff, was slightly hunched. He sat on a piano bench in the living room, folded his long, thin hands on his lap and talked for two hours straight. He began not a month, a year, or a decade ago, but on Easter 1916, when Irish nationalists rose against British rule. He was a lanky 14-year-old from Tipperary who volunteered to run messages for the rebels. The Anglo-Irish conflict ended in 1921 with a treaty giving 26 of Ireland's 32 counties virtual independence as the predominantly Roman Catholic Irish Free State, based in Dublin. But the six mostly Protestant northeastern counties remained part of the United Kingdom, and civil war ensued in the south between those for and against the partition. Flannery joined the anti-treaty IRA faction led by Eamon de Valera, and was captured and imprisoned for two years. He saw several of his comrades executed in reprisal for IRA attacks, and he took part in a 39-day hunger strike. He left prison as bitter at Dublin as he was at London. De Valera, however, formed a new political party in 1926 and led his supporters into the Dublin parliament. Flannery, meanwhile, had moved to America; he watched in horror as de Valera rose to power and crushed the IRA, which still fought for a unified Irish republic. ``Within four years de Valera was arresting IRA men,'' Flannery said. ``Four years after that he was executing them.'' Flannery settled in the New York City borough of Queens with his wife, got a job with an insurance company and joined Irish athletic and cultural groups. And he raised money for the IRA. The American Irish lost interest in Ireland's intramural squabbles, but Flannery never gave up. He claimed to have visited every saloon in New York City, looking for donations even though he was a teetotaler _ a remnant of military discipline. When a rising tide of violence against Catholics in Northern Ireland revived the IRA in the late 1960s, Flannery was ready. Again he faced a choice: the ``official'' IRA, which decided to seek power politically or the ``provisional'' IRA, which took up arms in the North. Flannery threw in with the Provos. With a few other vets, he founded NORAID. Flannery insisted that the millions NORAID collected went to the families of dead or imprisoned IRA soldiers. But in 1981 he was arrested on his way out of church and accused of banking an operation to smuggle guns to the IRA. At the trial, Flannery delivered his own opening statement. ``We are indicted here for the love of freedom,'' he said, ``and the love of freedom alone.'' Even those opposed to the IRA, whose attacks often killed or maimed civilians, were moved by such a durable passion. Although Flannery and his co-defendants essentially admitted the accusations, they were found innocent, and the next year Flannery was elected grand marshal of the New York St. Patrick's Day parade. But America's guns, money and prayers did not resolve Northern Ireland's troubles, and in 1986 Sinn Fein declared itself willing to take seats in the Dublin parliament, a body from which militant nationalists had abstained since the island's partition. To Flannery, this was official recognition of the government that had imprisoned him, killed his comrades and sold out the North. The IRA sided with Sinn Fein, as did most of NORAID's younger members. Flannery did not press the issue; he continued to attend some NORAID functions, and NORAID continued to use his name. But last year a rift developed in NORAID, and Flannery joined dissidents in accusing the organization's leaders of steering it ``toward politics and away from its original humanitarian objectives.'' Shortly thereafter he stood before NORAID's executive committee in a wedding hall in Queens and accused Sinn Fein's leaders of being ``Free Staters'' whose devotion to politics would soommunist Party chief Milos Jakes. The country's first parliamentary elections in more than four decades are planned for June 8. Havel, 53, who has said he is more interested in being a writer than president, is popular among his countrymen and has not announced whether he will seek election in June. Havel's government has insisted the Soviet Union withdraw its 73,500 troops as quickly as possible and favors eventual dissolution of the Warsaw Pact. Some Czechoslovakian officials also have urged that NATO be phased out, something the Bush administration strongly opposes.

The fallout from the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. continued when three of the company's British units dismissed 210 employees as part of an ``orderly wind-down'' of operations. The workers joined 5,300 Drexel employees fired in the United States on Friday after the investment firm's parent filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection. Also Monday, Drexel's arm in Singapore said it had liquidated all its positions on the Singapore International Monetary Exchange and was scheduled to shut down by the end of this week.

The weather isn't the only thing behaving strangely this winter. The economy has been topsy-turvy as well. In just two months, December and January, many economists went from predicting an impending economic downturn to believing that the longest peacetime expansion in history has found another of its nine lives. The new general consensus of moderate economic growth this year is likely to be an important element in Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony today before Congress, when he reveals the Fed's policy targets for 1990. These targets will have a major influence on interest rates and economic growth.

Former Guinness PLC Chairman Ernest Saunders received $5.1 million in company funds in a secret Swiss bank account while he led Guinness' bid for Distillers Co., a prosecutor charged at the trial of Saunders and three others on charges stemming from the 1986 takeover. John Chadwick, a prosecutor from the Serious Fraud Office, told of the alleged payment as he concluded his opening statement Monday at the trial, which began last week. The four defendants face a total of 35 charges involving theft, false accounting and conspiracy in connection with Guinness' acquisition of Distillers, a Scottish manufacturer of whisky and gin.

AT&T demonstrated a digital telephone service to Japan and Great Britain based on an international standard, making it easier for companies to set up worldwide communications networks. The service shown Monday can be dialed up like a regular phone call once a special digital line is installed to the customer. It is expected to be available to many other nations by the end of the year, American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said. Unlike conventional analog phone lines, digital lines enable the transmission of computer data and video conferences. They also provide distortion-free phone calls and far faster fax transmissions overseas.

The United States is holding its own in the race against Japan to develop new superconductors, which could be in commercial use within five years, a panel of experts said. Next year, the United States will for the first time launch simple superconducting devices into space to determine how well the devices survive. Communications equipment using superconductors would be much lighter than conventional equipment and thus ideal for use in outer space, where the costs of launching climb enormously as weight increases, Edward Mead of Du Pont said Monday.

Appalachian coal miners voted on a contract with Pittston Coal Group that could end an acrimonious, 10-month strike that drew international support from labor organizations. United Mine Workers Vice President Cecil Roberts planned to announce the result of Monday's vote on Tuesday morning, UMW spokesman Gene Carroll said. UMW President Richard Trumka, AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland and U.S. Secretary of Labor Elizabeth Dole planned to make a simultaneous announcement at the AFL-CIO convention in Miami. Mrs. Dole appointed the super mediator, former Labor Secretary William Usery, who helped forge the tentative settlement announced Jan. 1.

The bailout of the nation's failed savings and loans will be a bonanza for lawyers, said Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman L. William Seidman. Seidman said Monday he expects to double the 40,000 lawsuits already under way against troubled thrifts and eventually to spend half a billion dollars for outside legal counsel. Speaking before the American Bankers Association's National Conference for Community Bankers, Seidman also criticized the credit union industry, saying it was expanding too quickly and overstating its financial strength.

Union leaders will not be intimidated by anti-abortion forces waging a letter-writing campaign aimed at keeping them neutral on the issue, AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland said. Kirkland spoke to reporters Monday after the 14.1-million member federation of unions opened its annual winter meeting. As expected, the Executive Council skipped voting on pro-choice resolutions and appointed a 14-member committee to determine whether the AFL-CIO should take a position on abortion, an issue the organization has sidestepped for more than a decade.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used f0303 of Feb. 16, with a Detroit dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Feb. 16 the percentage of the drop in profit-sharing for the Big Three autoworkers. The Big Three will spend 70.1 percent less on profit-sharing this year than last year, instead of 93.7 percent less originally reported. The AP also erroneously reported the total amount of profit-sharing this year. The total is $176 million, instead of $40 million.

DOC.HEAD: Former Guinness Chairman Got $5.1 Million in Swiss Account, Prosecutor Claims
DOC.TEXT: Former Guinness PLC Chairman Ernest Saunders received $5.1 million in company funds in a secret Swiss bank account while he led Guinness' bid for Distillers Co., a prosecutor charged at the trial of Saunders and three others on charges stemming from the 1986 takeover. John Chadwick, a prosecutor from the Serious Fraud Office, told of the alleged payment as he concluded his opening statement Monday at the trial, which began last week. The four defendants face a total of 35 charges involving theft, false accounting and conspiracy in connection with Guinness' acquisition of Distillers, a Scottish manufacturer of whisky and gin. The aim of the alleged conspiracy was to boost prices of Guinness' stock, making the company's $4.3 billion cash and stock bid more attractive than a rival bid from supermarket operator Argyll Group PLC. The funds deposited in Saunders' account came from an illegal payment from Guinness director Thomas Ward, Chadwick said. ``Money which Saunders claimed had been paid to Ward so that Ward could pay consultancy fees to other people in fact found its way into Saunders' own bank account in Switzerland,'' Chadwick said. British authorities are seeking Ward's extradition from the United States. Ward has denied any wrongdoing. Chadwick's opening statement was being made before the second jury impaneled to hear the case. The first jury was dismissed after three jurors withdrew for work and health reasons. Three other defendants are still awaiting trial in connection with what was then the largest takeover battle in British history. Guinness won the battle in April 1986. But in December of that year, the Department of Trade and Industry announced it was investigating the deal, and the allegations of financial wrongdoing emerged. Standing trial with 54-year-old Saunders are Gerald Ronson, 50, chairman of the diversified conglomerate Heron International PLC; former stockbroker Anthony Parnes, 44; and millionaire financier and arts patron Sir Jack Lyons, 74. In the second trial, not scheduled to begin before October, Saunders will be joined by Roger Seelig, 44, former Morgan Grenfell and Co. Ltd. corporate finance director; Lord Patrick Spens, 47, former director of corporate finance at the merchant bank Henry Ansbacher and Co. Ltd.; and David Mayhew, 48, who continues as senior corporate finance partner of the investment firm Cazenove and Co. The seven men have pleaded innocent to the charges and each is free on bail. Saunders faces two counts of conspiring to violate the Prevention of Fraud Act; two counts of authorizing or permitting Guinness to violate the Companies Act; eight counts of false accounting; two counts of theft and one count of destroying company documents. Ronson faces one count of conspiring to violate the Prevention of Fraud Act; one count of aiding and abetting Saunders to authorize or permit Guinness to violate the Companies Act; two counts of false accounting and one count of theft. Parnes faces five counts of false accounting and two counts of theft. Lyons faces one count of conspiring to violate the Prevention of Fraud Act; one count of conspiracy to violate the Companies Act; one count of aiding and abetting Saunders to authorize or permit Guinness to violate the Companies Act; four counts of false accounting and one count of theft.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Demonstrates Improved Digital Phone Service to Japan, Britain
DOC.TEXT: Companies with international operations may find it easier to set up a worldwide telephone and data-transmission network using a new digital phone service offered by AT&T. The phone company on Monday demonstrated potential uses for the service, which links the United States with Japan and Great Britain using an international transmission standard. A number of other nations are expected to be added to the network by the end of the year. The service can be dialed up like a regular phone call once a special digital line is installed to the customer, American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said. Unlike conventional analog phone lines, digital lines enable the transmission of computer data and video conferences. They also provide distortion-free phone calls and far faster fax transmissions overseas. AT&T began offering dial-up digital lines to other nations in 1988, but these lines are based on a North American standard, which transmits data at 56 kilobits per second. Most of the rest of the world uses digital lines that transmit data at 64 kilobits per second. A kilobit is 1,000 bits. A bit is the smallest piece of information used by a computer, and represents either the digit 1 or 0. The difference in standards has meant U.S. customers must use an adaptor to send computer-based information abroad, which creates the possiblity that errors could be introduced in the transmission, said AT&T spokesman Rick Wallerstein. With the new service, which was announced last month, a U.S. company could set up a phone and data-transmission network around the world based on the 64-kilobit standard. Before the dial-up digital services were available, the only way for a company to send computer data overseas was through a leased, private line. These ``dedicated'' lines are more expensive in general than the dial-up services, which are billed per minute of use like conventional phone lines. The new Switched Digital International service was approved Feb. 5 by the Federal Communications Commission. The service to Japan is provided in cooperation with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp. and Overseas Communications Japan, while the British service is a venture with British Telecom PLC. At a news conference Monday , AT&T demonstrated a video conference hookup with Tokyo using two of the new phone lines simultaneously. Because video transmissions contain a huge amount of data, their quality is improved by sending it over two lines at once. But the picture quality still is lower than what is provided by normal television broadcasts. The image is grainy and the motion is delayed, giving the impression that the video is being shown in slow motion. The equipment used for the video conference is made by PictureTel Corp. of Peabody, Mass., which has a marketing agreement with AT&T. AT&T also demonstrated a personal computer linkup through the phone lines. When changes were made on a computer screen in New York, they could be seen on a similar computer screen in Tokyo by watching the TV monitor used for the video conference. In addition, AT&T demonstrated a digital telephone, which provides far higher quality voice transmission than conventional phones, and an optical scanner that allows the user to scan documents or objects electronically, then send them over the phone lines abroad, where they appear on a computer screen. Nippon Telegraph and Telephone also demonstrated computer and video hookups over the new phone lines.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Bailout Chief Defends His Agency's Record Against Critics
DOC.TEXT: The head of the government's savings and loan bailout board defended his agency's track record against criticism that it has been slow to act. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corp. as well as the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., on Monday cited a barrage of statistics to demonstrate his agency's progress since its creation last year. The RTC has taken over more than 350 thrifts in 37 states and advanced $11.4 billion to institutions to stem runs on deposits or replace high-cost brokered deposits, Seidman told the American Bankers Association's National Conference for Community Bankers. In addition, the RTC has listed for sale about a tenth of the 300,000 properties it took over from the failed thrifts, Seidman said. Seidman said he has hired a staff of almost 1,900 people while in the process of merging his agency with the the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., a merger he described as ``a marriage that is about the equal of Trump versus Trump,'' referring to the marital troubles of develop Donald Trump and his wife, Ivana. He also said the agency has developed a strategic plan for how it will attack the S&L problem. ``Given the bureaucractic world we live in, that alone is earthshaking,'' he said. Seidman said the thrift bailout should be a boon to lawyers. The RTC is handling more than 40,000 lawsuits against failed thrifts, ``and that's just the beginning,'' he said. ``We expect 80,000 by the end of the year and over one-half billion dollars in outside legal fees'' on top of the expenses for about 1,000 government lawyers. ``We are well under way to creating a shortage of lawyers in this country,'' he quipped. Seidman spoke at the Phoenecian Resort, the palatial luxury complex built by Charles H. Keating Jr. Keating's thrift, Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif., and the resort were taken over by the government last year. Regulators say Lincoln could become the most costly thrift bailout ever. Seidman joked that he wanted to put a stop to some rumors that were circulating at the bankers convention. Among them, he said, was that the Phoenecian would be given away as a door prize. On another topic, Seidman criticized the credit union industry, saying it was expanding too quickly and overstating its financial strength. Credit unions, Seidman said, have been claiming that their deposit-insurance fund, run by the National Credit Union Administration, is stronger than that of other institutions because credit unions keep 1 percent of the funds on deposit with the NCUA. But the practice is deceptive because the credit unions also book the money as assets, Seidman said. Credit unions are growing extremely quickly and are increasing their investments in areas where they have little experience, he said. ``They've got a lot of the symptoms that the S&Ls had,'' he said. Many critics of the thrift industry attribute the bulk of its problems to rapid growth and bad investments in projects outside its traditional bread-and-butter areas, such as housing loans.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Lower at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stocks in London were lower at midday Tuesday, though well above their morning minimums as bargain hunters bought stock at technical support levels. At about noon, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 11.2 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,285.9. At its lowest, the index touched 2,277.2 points, the level at which traders said bargain hunters stepped in and bought selected stocks. Dealers said trading volume remained light, due in part to the troubles facing the world's bond markets. British bond prices were falling through midday Tuesday. Volume was a light 230.3 million shares compared with 156.4 million shares at the same time Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Wendy's Fourth-Quarter Earnings Drop
DOC.TEXT: Wendy's International Inc. reported a 16 percent drop in net income for the fourth quarter of 1989, but noted that earnings for the year increased 7 percent over 1988. The restaurant chain also reported Monday that systemwide sales topped $3 billion for the first time in company history. Wendy's, based in suburban Columbus, cited no specific reason for the drop in fourth-quarter earnings. President and Chief Executive Officer James W. Near said the company ended the year with 55 fewer restaurants, mostly because of sales to franchise owners. For the fourth quarter that ended Dec. 31, 1989, after-tax profit totaled $5.7 million, or 6 cents a share, on revenue of $261.1 million. That compared with earnings of $6.8 million, or 7 cents a share, on revenue of $258.7 million in the same 1988 period. Profits for all of 1989 rose to $30.4 million, or 32 cents a share, from $28.5 million, or 30 cents a share, in 1988. Revenue also were up, from $1.06 billion in 1988 to $1.07 billion. Wendy's said the results include a first-quarter accounting change for income taxes. The change improved net income by $5.2 million, or 5 cents a share. Systemwide sales, which include total sales from company and franchise restaurants, were $740 million for the quarter, up from $711 million during the comparable period in 1988. For the year, sales totaled $3.04 billion, compared with $2.9 billion the previous year. Near said customer transactions, which realized a 3 percent gain during the third quarter, grew another 4 percent in the fourth quarter. He said a new menu offering selected items at 99 cents each and an advertising campaign featuring Wendy's founder R. David Thomas were significant reasons for the jump in transactions. ``I'm satisfied with our progress ... but I know we must make more dramatic improvements to gain market share in the '90s,'' Near said. At year's end, there were 3,755 Wendy's Old Fashioned Hamburgers restaurants worldwide, including 1,118 operated by the company.

DOC.HEAD: Farley Faces Trouble Financing West Point Deal
DOC.TEXT: Chicago industrialist William F. Farley may be in financial trouble over his $58-a-share hostile takeover of Georgia-based West Point Pepperell Inc. last year. Farley faces a March deadline for his $1.03 billion ``bridge'' loan. But the investment banking firm he was using to issue junk bonds _ Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. _ is going out of business after its parent company filed for bankruptcy protection and Farley has been unable to sell any of West Point's major assets. ``He's getting squeezed more and more,'' said Edward F. Johnson, director of Johnson Redbook Service, a New York research firm. ``It's getting tougher. The textile business is slowing; plants he wanted to sell would (bring) less and he certainly wouldn't have paid as much for West Point this year as he did.'' Last April, Farley paid $1.6 billion for 95 percent of West Point's shares and assumed about $1 billion in debt for the well-respected Georgia textile and apparel firm. The purchase came after a bitter fight with former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Joseph L. Lanier Jr., whose family had run the company for years. However, Farley must sell about $350 million in assets to receive an extension of his bridge loan through June, and sales aren't going well. A jittery financial market has ``caused a lot of buyers to pull back out of the market,'' said Edgar Davis, executive vice president of West Point. ``Money that would normally be available to financial investors is out of their reach right now for a lot of reasons.'' Drexel's Chapter 11 filing also hurts, said Richard Byrne, a junk bond analyst with Merrill Lynch. ``West Point is an excellent company. Unfortunately it's highly leveraged,'' he said, adding that the company's paper in today's shaky junk bond market would be ``difficult to sell if not impossible.'' Last April, West Point issued $905 million in private placement of junk bonds. A week before Drexel filed for bankruptcy, two of the leading bond rating agencies lowered their ratings of Farley Inc., West Point-Pepperell and some subsidiaries. Last year, Farley announced it had reached an agreement to sell the hosiery, shirt and tailored apparel divisions of Cluett Peabody & Company Inc. to a Paris-based company for $600 million, lower than the $700 million Farley sought. The deal was to have closed last November. But reports in the trade press say the price has now dropped to $430 million and that one of the major banks backing the buyer, Bidermann Group, has backed out. A spokesman for Bidermann Industries USA Inc. declined to comment on whether price has been a factor. The deal is now expected to close next month. Farley has made some nuts-and-bolts changes at West Point. He hired Charles A. Lieppe, who had worked 21 years with Procter & Gamble Co., as president and chief operating officer. And Davis said Farley intends to concentrate on the company's strong core business of bed and bath products. The company has added 800 people at five plants making the products, and Davis said another 100 jobs may be added during the first six months of 1990. Farley also has invested between $80 million and $90 million in equipment and physical improvements to make the bed and bath plants more efficient.

DOC.HEAD: Hormel Considers Buying Frozen-Food Company
DOC.TEXT: After reporting an increase in first-quarter earnings, Hormel Chairman Richard Knowlton said the meatpacker is considering buying a company that would expand its frozen sandwich line. Knowlton told securities analysts Monday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that the Austin-based company aims to grow mainly through internal expansion and new products, but also is searching for acquisitions. Hormel is close to completing a deal for a company that would extend its frozen sandwich line, Knowlton told analysts at the Food, Beverage and Tobacco Conference in Fort Lauderdale. While he would not name the company, he said its annual sales were about $60 million. Knowlton also said Hormel will bolster its weak position in Europe by setting up a joint partnership with a European food company. But Knowlton told analysts that he expects one of his company's strongest areas of growth to be prepared foods that need no refrigeration and are designed to be prepared in microwave ovens. Hormel's Top Shelf line accounted for about $100 million in sales last year, and he expects that to double in the near future. Meanwhile, he expects Micro Cup Meals to exceed Top Shelf sales. And his company is test marketing a complementary line called Kid's Kitchen, which children can prepare for themselves. Hormel, meanwhile, announced record earnings for the first quarter ended Jan. 27. Net income of $14.4 million, or 19 cents per share, compared with net income of $13.7 million, or 18 cents per share, in the first quarter of fiscal 1989. Earnings per share were restated to account for a two-for-one stock split effective Jan. 31, the company said. Securities analysts had expected a decline in earnings because of restricted pork supplies and increased raw materials cost. Dollar sales for the first quarter also were at a record high $620.5 million, a 12.6 percent increase over sales of $551.2 million in the first quarter of last year.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese, U.S. Contractors Reach Basic Agreement on New Plane
DOC.TEXT: The main Japanese contractor said Tuesday it has reached agreement in principle with a U.S. aircraft maker on developing Japan's next jet fighter, a project that triggered charges of a U.S. technology giveaway. Junichiro Yamada, an official of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Co., said the formal agreement with General Dynamics Corp. of the United States on developing the FSX is to be signed by early next week. Then, he said, those two firms, together with Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., both of Japan, will set up a team to design the FSX, an advanced version of the U.S. F-16. Critics in the U.S. Congress have charged that the project will amount to a giveaway of U.S. technology in aeronautics, where the United States still enjoys a competitive edge. Proponents of the plan contend both sides will gain military and technological benefits. Defense Agency officials have said a total of 165 billion yen, or about $1.15 billion, will be needed over eight years to develop the plane, which is expected to go into production in 1997. Yamada said the team, consisting of 100 engineers, including 10 from General Dynamics, will begin design work at MHI's aerospace systems works in Nagoya, central Japan, in late March. He declined to discuss further details. On Nov. 29, 1988, the United States and Japan signed a memorandum of understanding on the FSX development. The Japanese Defense Agency appointed MHI as the prime contractor and General Dynamiscs, KHI and FHI as subcontractors. On Jan. 12, 1989, MHI and General Dynamics reached a licensing and technical assistance agreement covering the transfer of technical information on the U.S. F-16 to Japan. Last April, Congress passed legislation that sought, among other things, to prohibit transfer to Japan of critical U.S. jet engine technology. President Bush vetoed U.S. Congressional efforts to impose restrictions on the U.S.-Japan deal for joint development. Japan originally intended to develop the new fighter on its own. The United States wanted it to buy U.S. planes. The two sides then agreed on co-development.

DOC.HEAD: Heileman Halts Talks With Stroh
DOC.TEXT: Stroh Brewing Co. and G. Heileman Brewing Co. have cut off talks of a possible merger or sale of some Heileman brands, Heileman's president says. The trade newsletter Beer Marketer's Insights quoted Heileman President Murray Cutbush as telling wholesalers last week that discussions with Stroh had ended. Cindy Brown, Cutbush's secretary at Heileman's LaCrosse, Wis., offices, was out of the office and unavailable for comment early this morning. Cutbush said Stroh had approached Heileman ``regarding a possible merger'' after a deal for Stroh to sell to Adolph Coors Co. fell apart last year. Lacey Logan, a spokeswoman for Stroh, declined to comment. Stroh is the nation's third-largest brewer behind Anheuser-Busch Inc. and Miller Brewing Co. Coors and Heileman follow. Stroh executives were examining a three-way deal that would have included unidentified banks as partners, the newsletter said. The partnership would have enabled Stroh and Heileman to combine without putting up any cash. The banks would provide financing and reap part of the profits as owners. There was no indication why the talks broke off. Earlier this month, Heileman said its breweries in Frankenmuth and St. Paul, Minn., were for sale, along with the brands they produce. Heileman employs about 200 people at the Frankenmuth brewery, which it purchased from Carling National Co. in 1979. Stroh has been looking for potential partners since February 1989 amid financial struggles that have resulted in more than 300 layoffs and sales of some Stroh properties and divisions, including its ice-cream business.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Prepare for Possible Battle Over New Cigarette
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, `But a ...' to DELETE reference to when newspapers reported on marketing plan.
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) _ R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. might find itself embroiled in another battle over the test marketing of a cigarette, a leading women's advocate says. After a national firestorm of criticism a month ago, Reynolds shelved plans to market in Philadelphia a new menthol brand called Uptown, a cigarette the company said was targeted for black smokers. Now the company plans to test-market a cigarette called Dakota in Houston in April. According to news accounts, a marketing plan designed for the cigarette would gear a publicity campaign toward young women with a high school education or less. R.J. Reynolds, a division of RJR Nabisco Inc., says it has not seen the marketing plan. Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, said Monday from Washington in an interview with the Greensboro News & Record that she will encourage women's groups in Houston to organize and combat Dakota as black groups battled Uptown in Philadelphia. ``I personally, and I'm sure I speak for a huge majority of NOW members, cannot understand how any self-respecting company could seek to exploit so deliberately a group of young women who clearly, because they are not college-bound, probably never read any reports from the surgeon general on smoking,'' she said. ``They are deliberately leading them into a mode of life which will probably lead to their premature death.'' A marketing plan said to have been leaked to The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal and the magazine Ad Age, said that Dakota's chief goal is to capture the lucrative market among 18- to 24-year-old women with a high school education or less, the only group of Americans whose rate of smoking continues to increase. But a spokeswoman for R.J. Reynolds challenged the validity of the marketing plan. Maura Payne said R.J. Reynolds has not seen the plan, which was developed under contract by an outside firm, and does not know if it was fabricated or altered in any way. She said the cigarette is designed to compete against Marlboro. ``Anyone that is stealing documents and disseminating them is not above, in my mind, doing some altering of the documents as well to serve whatever agenda they seem to have,'' Ms. Payne said. She said R.J. Reynolds would stand by its new cigarette. ``We will bring it to market and we will let the smokers, the consumers, decide if it's a viable competitor for Marlboro or not,'' Ms. Payne said. Marlboro, made by rival Philip Morris, is the world's best-selling cigarette, outselling Reynolds' Winston brand by almost 2-1. Philip Morris is the world's top cigarette maker, and in recent years has increased its U.S. market share over No. 2 Reynolds. In Houston, anti-smoking groups might mount a fight against Dakota. ``I very strongly feel there will be an (opposition) effort,'' Eleanor Tinsley, a Houston City Council member, said Monday. ``This is a particularly vulnerable group of young women. To pick a group of young women who have not received a great deal of education and then give them cigarettes is, from my point of view, reprehensible.'' Three years ago, Ms. Tinsley pushed through an ordinance that gave Houston its first public smoking restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: Natwest's 1989 Profit Sinks 79 Percent
DOC.TEXT: National Westminster Bank PLC, one of Britain's big four commercial banks, said Tuesday its net profit sank 79 percent in 1989, largely due to a sharp increase in provisions for loan losses. Natwest said its net profit for the year came to 198 million pounds, the equivalent of $339 million, compared with 938 million pounds, or $1.6 billion, a year earlier. Earnings per share came to 15 pence, or 26 cents, compared with 62 pence, or $1.06. Natwest said it pre-tax profit slid 71 percent to 404 million pounds, or $687 million, from 1.407 billion pounds, or $2.41 billion. Total loan provisions for the year of 1.435 billion pounds, or $2.45 billion, which included charges for advances to lesser developed countries, were more than five times the charges Natwest took in 1988. Of its latest charges, 990 million pounds, or $1.69 billion, represented charges for loans to lesser developed countries, sharply higher than 49 million pounds, or $84 million, in such charges a year earlier. Natwest Chairman Lord Alexander said that as a result of the bank's provisioning for loans to lesser developed countries, which increased its coverage on problem sovereign loans to 75 percent from 36 percent in 1988, Natwest has put the debt problem ``firmly behind us.'' The bank also took an exceptional charge of 50 million pounds, or $86 million, in 1989 to cover legal fees and other potential costs associated with criminal charges stemming from its investment bank's handling of a stock sale for Blue Arrow PLC in 1987. County Natwest Investment Bank Ltd., the main underwriter of the issue, has been charged with failing to disclose a 9.5 percent stake it was left with in Blue Arrow after the share sale flopped. Alexander said of the provisions and exceptional charge, ``We believe all these actions are sensible and, on the basis of our fundamental strengths and trading record, are a platform for further progress.'' Natwest also took an extraordinary charge of 35 million pounds, or $60 million, largely to cover costs involved in its withdrawal as a primary dealer in the U.S. Treasury market. Total income, including interest income, commissions, and foreign exchange, came to 5.36 billion pounds, or $9.2 billion, up 15 percent from 4.66 billion pounds, $7.9 billion. Total assets at the end of the year were 116.2 billion pounds, or $199 billion, up from 98.6 billion pounds, or $169 billion. Natwest didn't break out fourth-quarter or half-year results. It isn't required to under British law.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler and Renault Plan New Vehicle
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. and the French automaker Renault will build a small sport-utility vehicle in Valladolid, Spain, the companies say. The year-old joint venture, ARCAD, will lease the plant from FASA Renault, a Spanish subsidiary of the automaker, the companies said Monday. Production of the vehicle code-named ``JJ'' will begin in the second half of 1992. The Spanish plant will employ about 350 people to assemble modules built outside the factory at supplier plants, which also will employ about 350 people. The vehicles will be marketed worldwide with the exception of North America. ARCAD also will make the vehicle for the North American market at a Chrysler plant yet to be chosen.

DOC.HEAD: Education Board Sues Over Channel One
DOC.TEXT: Some local school officials criticized the State Board of Education after it decided to sue over the use of a commercial television program and to expand its ban on the product. The board voted Monday to take the Thomasville City school system to court because of its refusal to abide by the state board's ban on the use of Channel One, a 12-minute commercial television program. The board also decided to sue the program's producer, Whittle Communications, of Knoxville, Tenn. The state board had voted to ban Channel One contracts signed after Feb. 1, but Monday declared that all contracts for the news show were void, even if they had been signed before the board outlawed it. State officials said about 90 local schools had agreed to show the program. Some local school officials criticized the moves, saying they infringed on the prerogatives of local boards. The Thomasville school board set up Monday's confrontation on Feb. 8 by signing a contract for the program, saying the state board had exceeded its authority by banning the show. ``The issue speaks very directly to local control vs. state control,'' Ronald B. Singletary, the Thomasville schools superintendent, told The News and Observer of Raleigh. ``It's going to be very difficult for us to motivate teachers and administrators to seriously look at options that are considered non-traditional with this kind of presumption that if it hasn't been used _ then don't use it,'' he said. Channel One offers a daily 12-minute news program, which includes two minutes of advertising. The contract with Whittle Communications requires schools to show the program to all students each day. In exchange, the schools are loaned $50,000 worth of video equipment for the length of the contract. The suit also charges that the Thomasville board exceeded its authority by signing the contract, allowed students to be exploited for commercial purposes, surrendered its control of classroom materials to Whittle and violated state laws that guarantee the privacy of students. The suit asks the court to bar Thomasville and any other local school system from contracting or implementing a contract with Whittle Communications. A statement from Whittle Communications said the company was studying the state board's action. Thomasville school officials did not return phone calls seeking reaction to the lawsuit. Whittle Communications announced in New York last Thursday it had signed up 2,510 school nationally for Channel One and had sold $200 million in advertising. The program is scheduled to debut March 5.

DOC.HEAD: Miners Vote to Accept Coal Contract, End 10-Month Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to recast, UPDATE with reax; pick up 5th graf, `It could ...' This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Appalachian coal miners' voted nearly 2-to-1 to ratify their contract with Pittston Coal Group, union officials announced today. The vote ends a bitter 10-month strike that served as a rallying point for the American labor movement. Pittston employees in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky voted 1,247 to 734 in favor of the pact. Sixty-three percent of the striking miners and laid-off workers endorsed the contract and 37 percent opposed it, according to figures provided by the United Mine Workers. The results were announced jointly in Virginia and in Bal Harbor, Fla., where the AFL-CIO is holding its annual winter meeting. UMW President Richard Trumka, AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland and U.S. Secretary of Labor Elizabeth Dole joined in the Florida announcement. Mrs. Dole appointed the super mediator, former Labor Secretary William Usery, who helped forge the tentative settlement announced Jan. 1. Trumka called miners in Castlewood, Va., at about 9:15 a.m. to tell them the strike was officially over. Kirkland and Mrs. Dole joined in the call. Kirkland called the vote ``a happy conclusion to a long and very gallant struggle.'' He told the miners: ``Your example and your steadfastness and your solidarity has been an inspiration to the entire trade union movement, not just here but throughout the world. It's given us all a lift and I want you to know we share your victory.'' Mrs. Dole said it was a joyous day for the nation because the ratification was ``an example of the success of the collective bargaining process.'' In Virginia, UMW Vice President Cecil Roberts told Pittston Coal Group President Michael Odom of the results. ``That's fantastic news,'' Odom said. ``I think the both of us can agree we've got a worthy contract for employees, the union and the company.'' It could be a week to 10 days before miners return to work since mines must be re-inspected and workers have to go through training courses, union officials said. Of the 1,310 miners voting in Virginia, 813, or 62 percent, endorsed the contract while 497 workers, or 38 percent, opposed it. Of 479 workers voting in West Virginia, 339, or 71 percent, favored the plan while 140, or 29 percent, were against it. The closest vote came in Kentucky, where 97 miners, or 50.5 percent, opposed the plan, while 95 workers, or 49.5 percent, supported it. Rufus Hall, 56, said miners were concerned about the scheduling flexibility in the new pact, but about nine out of 10 members of his Virginia local voted for it. ``It's a pretty good package except for the swing shift,'' he said. Under the tentative agreement, Pittston would continue to pay 100 percent of miners' health-care coverage, rather than forcing them to take on 20 percent of those costs. Pittston also would continue paying into an industry-wide pension fund from which it had withdrawn. The company won the right to operate shifts around the clock and to suspend 13 strikers accused of illegal strike activity and force them to go to arbitration if they want to keep their jobs. The strike drew widespread support from labor unions and religious leaders because of the use of peaceful civil disobedience _ primarily mass sit-down demonstrations to block coal trucks _ and because they believed Pittston was trying to break the union, a claim the company vigorously denied. Last October, a delegation of international labor leaders, including representatives of Poland's Solidarity trade union, attended a rally of Pittston strikers in Russell County. Soviet coal miners also toured the coalfields. Last summer, the walkout touched off wildcat sympathy strikes at other coal companies that had settled with the UMW. At their peak, those strikes affected tens of thousands of miners in much of the East and Midwest. The Pittston strike's peaceful image was marred by sporadic violence aimed at company property, supervisors and replacement workers. Russell County Circuit Judge Donald McGlothlin cited the violence when he refused last week to drop $64 million in fines against the union for illegal strike activities. Trumka said when the settlement was announced that the union would withhold a rank-and-file vote until all litigation related to the strike was dissolved. But he announced Thursday that the union was going ahead with the vote, and the miners received copies of the proposed contract Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Borrowing $6 Billion More Than Earlier Planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 4th graf, `The additional ...,' with source of funds. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government will borrow $6 billion more than previously announced during the January-March quarter to meet the requirements of the savings and loan bailout, the Treasury Department announced today. ``Treasury estimates that a total of $47.6 billion of market borrowing will be required for the January-March period, including the $34.4 billion that had been issued or announced through Friday, Feb. 16,'' it said. The Treasury originally announced on Jan. 31 it would need to borrow $41.6 billion. The additional funds will be obtained through regular auctions of weekly three- and six-month bills and 52-week bills, the Treasury said. Cash management bills also may be necessary to cover low points in the cash balance, it said. ``The revision takes into account the most up-to-date estimate of the Resolution Funding Corp.'s requirements to borrow from the Federal Financing Bank through March 31,'' it said. The bank is a conduit for funneling Treasury money to government agencies. The Resolution Funding Corp. was created in the thrift bailout law as the financing arm of the Resolution Trust Corp., which actually disposes of the failed savings and loan institutions. The bailout legislation provides $50 billion through next year to cover the losses in failed thrift institutions. But the trust corporation needs to borrow as much as an additional $100 billion. The borrowing, called ``working capital,'' would be repaid as the government sold loans, real estate and other assets inherited from failed thrifts.

DOC.BYLINE: No Court Action Against `Pass-Through Certificates' ^By RICHARD CARELLI
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to bar national banks from selling mortgages in the form of ``pass-through certificates'' _ a practice the securities industry says violates federal banking law. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that such sales are legal. Federal law allows national banks to sell the conventional real estate mortgages they hold, but generally prohibits banks from underwriting, buying and selling securities. Banks traditionally have sold longterm mortgages for other revenue sources, and an increasingly popular means of selling mortages is the use of pass-through certificates, which are securities. The buyer of such a certificate obtains an interest in a pool of the bank's conventional mortgages rather than a single mortgage. The California-based Security Pacific National Bank began selling mortgage pass-through certificates in 1987, with a $194 million public offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Securities Industry Association, a group of more than 500 organizations that account for over 90 percent of the nation's securities brokerage and investment banking business, asked federal regulators about the validity of pass-through certificates. The comptroller of the currency concluded that Security Pacific's pass-through certificate program was ``authorized under the national banking laws,'' which he said ``does not restrict the means by which national banks may sell or transfer interests in ... their mortgages.'' The comptroller's decision was in keeping with the recent trend toward deregulation of the banking industry, with the courts and federal regulators obliterating legal barriers between the banking industry and other forms of commerce. After the comptroller's decision on Security Pacific's sales of pass-through certificates, the Securities Industry Association sued in federal court. The suit sought to stop what the association asserted is the illegal sales of securities. U.S. District Judge Kevin Duffy of New York City ruled in 1988 that selling pass-through certificates amounted to underwriting securities in violation of a 1933 federal banking law, the Glass-Steagall Act. But the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last Sept. 8 reversed Duffy's ruling and agreed with the comptroller of the currency. The appeals court said such sales constitute ``the business of banking,'' and not the business of dealing in securities and stock. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for the Securities Industry Association said the effect of the 2nd Circuit court's ruling ``is to write Glass-Steagall right out of the statute books.'' In a ``friend-of-the-court'' brief supporting the appeal, lawyers for the Investment Company Institute said the appeals court ruling has allowed the underwriting of mortgage-backed securities directly by national banks. ``The decision simply demolishes the Glass-Steagall Act,'' they said. The Bush administration and lawyers for the Security Pacific National Bank urged the court to reject the appeal. The case is Securities Industry Association vs. Clarke, 89-748.
