DOC.HEAD: Report Places Smoking Cost at $52 Billion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 4 grafs with Sullivan testimony after 4th graf, `I'm especially ...'; adds byline. This also moved on general news wire.
DOC.TEXT: A new government report today estimated that smoking costs the nation more than $52 billion a year, largely for health care expenses. The report, by the Department of Health and Human Services, estimated smoking-related disease averages $1 billion per state but said some states pay a much higher price than others. California, the most populous state, has the highest costs, $5.8 billion. The economic cost is lowest in Alaska, where it is $82 million per year. ``I'm especially concerned that we make more progress in reaching young people, women, minorities and blue-collar workers with accurate and compelling information about smoking and its devastating impact on their health,'' HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan said in a statement accompanying the report. Presenting the report at a hearing by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, Sullivan called on tobacco companies to stop targeting women, minorities and young people. Sullivan, in written testimony, said that while Americans have a personal responsibility to protect their health tobacco companies and smoking advertisers must also be responsible. ``It is high time that we also stopped allowing smoking advertisers such a high hand,'' he said. ``A cigarette is the only legal product that, when used as intended, causes death. Advertisers who disproportionately target women, minorities or young Americans have gone too far. They must stop their irresponsibility.'' Sullivan also said advertising agency and the media should question their involvement with tobacco companies. He said he hoped to see them ``step forward to renounce tobacco ads and join in our anti-smoking efforts.'' Sullivan said the annual per-capita costs of smoking-related disease was $221 nationally. He said that ranges from a low of $56 a person in Utah to $284 in Rhode Island. The cost comes out of the pockets of smokers and nonsmokers alike, mostly in the forms of increased health care and insurance costs, Sullivan said. Sullivan recently condemned R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. for its plans to market a cigarette targeted at blacks. Reynolds subsequently dropped those plans, but it now intends to test-market a cigarette called Dakota that news accounts said under one proposal would be geared toward young women with a high school education or less. Sullivan has been concerned about minorities because they have higher rates of smoking than whites and they have a higher rate of smoking-related disease and death. Smoking causes about 390,000 deaths in the united States and about 29 percent of adults smoke, according to government statistics.

DOC.HEAD: Deere Reports Big Gain in First Quarter Earnings as Sales Soar
DOC.TEXT: Deere & Co. on Tuesday reported a 62 percent jump in quarterly earnings over the prior year, as sales in all categories of tractors, combines and farm implements soared. For the company's first quarter, earnings rose to $78.5 million, or $1.04 per share, on revenue of $1.64 billion. A year earlier Deere earned $48.4 million, or 65 cents per share, on revenue of $1.14 billion. The first-quarter report points to a possible third straight year of record earnings for the Moline-based Deere. ``We expect the overall mix of our sales and production to be more favorable in 1990 than in 1989,'' Deere & Co. Chairman Robert A. Hanson and President Hans W. Becherer said in a joint statement. Deere earned $380.2 million, or $5.06 a share, in the 1989 fiscal year, which ended Oct. 31. That was 20 percent more than the previous record set in 1988 when Deere earned $315.4 million, or $4.32 a share. Deere spokesman Robert Combs attributed the company's good fortune to the recovery in the agricultural economy. ``A significant factor is the continued rebound of the North American farm economy,'' Combs said. ``Farmers are coming off three years of strong income. They have reduced debt and are using an aging fleet of equipment. Now is the time for them to look at replacing their tractors and combines.'' Despite the huge profits and demand for Deere equipment, the company's employment levels have not changed dramatically. Its workforce has increased by just 600 employees in the last three months and now stands at 38,900.

The stock market dropped sharply today as traders grew increasingly concerned about the upward trend of interest rates worldwide. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 37.62 points at noon EST to 2,597.97. Losers outnumbered gainers by almost 6 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 217 up, 1,229 down and 391 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 77.04 million shares as of noon. Analysts said the tone for the session was set by rising interest rates in Japan and West Germany as U.S. traders returned after the long Presidents Day weekend. American interest rates also jumped today. Prices of long-term government bonds dropped as much at $14 for each $1,000 in face value, increasing their yields to the 8.64 percent-8.68 percent range. In addition to rising overseas rates, traders said the bond market was depressed by news that the Treasury raised its first-quarter borrowing needs by $6 billion. Upward pressure on worldwide interest rates has been widely cited as a primary force behind the stock market's poor performance so far this year. For one thing, that development is seen as deterring the Federal Reserve from stimulating the domestic economy to cushion the effects of a slowdown in business activity. Testifying before a congressional panel today, Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan said recent U.S. economic indicators are ``more encouraging than otherwise.'' However, he said, there are undercurrents in the economy such as lower corporate profits that continue to warrant caution. One stock trader said the market was more concerned about overseas interest rates than Greenspan's comments. ``The worry on Japan rates is really what is hurting us,'' said Daniel Williams, head position trader for Dillon, Read & Co. ``Most of the foreign (stock) markets were off, and we're just following suit.'' In addition, Williams said, computerized program selling kicked in at some Wall Street firms, further depressing share prices. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris dropped | to 37|, General Electric lost } to 61\, American Telephone & Telegraph dropped } to 39, IBM lost 1 to 102{, and Exxon was off } to 47\. Nordstrom was among the most active stocks among over-the-counter issues, down 2] at 27[, on top of a 3\-point slide Friday. The department store operator said its earnings for the fiscal year ended last month were likely to show a decline. In addition, a state agency in Washington that investigated Nordstrom's labor practices instructed it to pay unspecified amounts in back wages. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 2.53 to 181.22. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 3.39 at 355.38.

DOC.HEAD: Zenith Reveals Computer Sale Dispute; Posts Lower Earnings, Annual Loss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th and 5th graf, `In a statement ...' to UPDATE with details of dispute; picks up 6th graf, `Zenith reported...
DOC.TEXT: Zenith Electronics Corp. on Tuesday said the sale of its computer division to a French company is in dispute. The company also announced a 47 percent drop in fourth-quarter profit from its consumer electronics business and a $17 million loss for the full year. Zenith, the only major American manufacturer of color televisions, reported results only for its consumer electronics and components business. In a statement, the suburban Glenview-based company said results for its Zenith Data Systems computer business were not yet available because of a ``major dispute'' with the buyer, Groupe Bull of France, over the final sale price. Zenith said the sale, which was announced in October, was completed for $496.4 million in late December but that Groupe Bull has since requested a refund of $49 million, plus interest, apparently due to a disagreement over the value of the division's assets. Zenith reported net income from continuing operations of $4 million, or 15 cents per common share, for the three months ended Dec. 31 compared with $7.5 million, or 29 cents per share, for the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Fourth quarter revenue from continuing operations rose slightly, to $443 million from $440 million in 1988. For the full year, Zenith reported a net loss from continuing operations of $17 million, or 64 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $11 million, or 42 cents a share, in 1988. Annual revenue from continuing operations rose 11 percent to $1.5 billion from $1.4 billion in 1988. Zenith attributed the poor performance to higher material and labor costs, which the company said offset the positive effects of higher sales volume and efficiency improvements.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Fall Sharply Amid Interest Rate Concerns
DOC.TEXT: Prices declined broadly on Wall Street today as the outlook dimmed for an easing of interest rates anytime soon. Rising interest rates on West German and Japanese markets set a negative tone for stock trading and a surge in rates in the U.S. Treasury bond market only worsened matters. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue chip industrials was down 47.53 to 2,588.06 as of 12:30 p.m. EST. On the broader market, declining issues outnumbered advancers by a margin of about 6 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 217 stocks rising, 1,229 falling and 391 unchanged. NYSE volume came to 77.04 million shares at midday. Upward pressure on worldwide interest rates has been widely cited as a primary force behind the stock market's poor start in 1990. When interest rates rise overseas, U.S. rates must move upward to stay competitive. This trend has been seen as deterring the Federal Reserve from stimulating the domestic economy by lowering rates. And it appeared today the Fed sees little need to boost the economy. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan told Congress the economy has likely passed the danger point for an imminent recession and he predicted continued modest economic growth for the rest of 1990. Greenspan's comments contributed to a sharp drop on the Treasury bond market, where the government's bellwether 30-year bond tumbled 1\ point, or about $12.50 per $1,000 face value, by midday. Its yield, which goes up when its price falls, shot up to 8.63 percent from 8.46 percent late Friday. Wall Street often reacts negatively when Treasury bond rates advance.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Leaders Doubt Major Policy Change from Reagan Era
With PM-Coal Strike-Vote, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said today organized labor has an improved relationship with the Bush administration despite the president's refusal to let government intervene in the Eastern Airlines strike. ``I think it's clear that we have a positive relationship in that they believe the door is open, that I want a continuing dialogue, that the president does,'' Mrs. Dole said after meeting privately with AFL-CIO leaders. ``I understand that there are issues where we'll have to agree to disagree. Eastern is one of them. All right, so be it. We have to agree to disagree there,'' she said. Again defending President Bush's veto of legislation that would have created a panel to resolve the Eastern dispute, Mrs. Dole said there had been no favoritism toward management. Some union officials contend that Bush unfairly sided with Frank Lorenzo, head of Texas Air Corp., Eastern's parent company. Labor considers Lorenzo a union-buster who has refused to try to settle the strike through arbitration. ``I feel Mr. Lorenzo's labor policies leave a lot to be desired,'' Mrs. Dole said. The president was right to veto the legislation because transportation was not disrupted in any region of the country because of the strike, she said. ``Why are we arguing about it? I think it's clear,'' she said to reporters. Union officials say Bush's attitude toward organized labor appears to be a marked improvement from the Reagan era, but they doubt there's been a substantive shift in policy. The administration deserves credit for its involvement in the Pittston coal strike _ Mrs. Dole met with both sides and appointed a ``super mediator'' _ and for compromising on labor's long-sought hike in the minimum wage, union leaders said. But they also complain that Bush, while praising worker movements abroad such as Solidarity in Poland, has demonstrated ``union busting'' tendencies at home with the Eastern veto. ``Our president seems to be saying, `Workers' rights are fine in other parts of the world, but not in my backyard,''' said John Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union. The Executive Council of the 4.1 million-member AFL-CIO hopes to achieve improved relations with the Bush administration as its 33-member board meets today with Mrs. Dole. ``I give Bush and Liz Dole an A-plus on Pittston and a zero on Eastern,'' said Joyce Miller, vice president of the Amalgamated Colthing and Textile Workes Union. Many union officials considered Ronald Reagan, who fired striking air traffic controllers in 1981 and effectively killed that union, the worst president of the century for organized labor. ``President Bush and his `kinder, gentler' nation at least talks about issues that affect workers, like education, child care and health care. It took them long enough to come around on minimum wage, so we'll see on the others,'' Sweeney said. Susan Cowell, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, said Bush has been forced to improve the climate toward labor. ``Reagan created a revolution that was exposed as a fraud, and the public tide has turned against it. Bush is almost forced to be more moderate. That limits the degree to which he can hurt us,'' Cowell said. ``Bush is an odd character. He doesn't embrace an ideology the way Reagan does, but it's hard to see a policy difference,'' she said. Last year, Bush agreed to address the AFL-CIO's convention in Washington, marking the first time a president had addressed the federation since Jimmy Carter did in 1979. Reagan refused to speak in 1981 and was never invited again. At the time, AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland, who a month earlier had called Bush ``Reagan Lite,'' said the president's willingness to strike a compromise on minimum wage showed their had been some improvement over labor's strained relationship with Reagan. On Monday, Kirkland said union leaders would continue to lobby Congress for an override of Bush's veto of the Eastern Airlines legislation. As expected, the federation's Executive Council skipped a vote on pro-choice resolutions and instead appointed a 14-member committee of union leaders to determine whether a stand should be taken. Kirkland said the panel would not be swayed much by a national Right to Life Committee letter-writing campaign that urged union officials not to take a stand. ``I've been around a while, and I think I can tell grass roots from AstroTurf,'' Kirkland said, insinuating the letters were not from rank-and-file union members. The letters warned union leaders that rank-and-file members opposed to abortion would likely seek to have part of their union dues withheld if the AFL-CIO, which has sidestepped the issue for more than a decade, adopted a pro-choice position. ``I do not think the committee will be moved by threats or suggestions of reprisals. I think the committee will address the issues fairly and rationally and on the merits and will act accordingly,'' Kirkland said. National Right to Life Committee officials have said the AFL-CIO should sit the issue out because it does not impact collective bargaining or workplace conditions. Pro-choice union officials contend the issue impacts the economic well-being of working women. They note the AFL-CIO has traditionally taken a stand on a wide range of issues, including civil rights, gay rights and school busing. ``I would say that the committee probably breaks down almost 50-50,'' said Miller, a pro-choice member of the abortion panel. She predicted the AFL-CIO could adopt a pro-choice position as long as it included language acknowledging the moral and religious views of some union members. Kirkland declined to identify his personal position. The panel's chairman, William Wynn, president of the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union, is pro-choice but has said his personal feelings would not influence the committee's decision. Kirkland did not give the panel a deadline, but pro-choice officials want a decision by the council's May meeting. That would let labor leaders use the issue when making endorsements for the 1990 elections.

DOC.HEAD: AmBase Selling Insurance Companies
DOC.TEXT: AmBase Corp. said Tuesday it was putting its insurance operations up for sale, including its Home Insurance Co. subsidiary, to help boost its stock price and repay debt. Home Insurance, which was founded in 1853, is AmBase's largest insurance company with 2,000 agents and brokers nationwide and $2.3 billion in gross premiums written in 1989. Most of its premiums were in commercial and specialty lines. Its other insurance units are U.S. International Re, a reinsurance company with $207 million in gross premiums last year, and Commonwealth Insurance Co. of Canada, with $120 million in premiums. AmBase said it was selling its insurance operations because it believed its stock price was significantly undervalued. It said it hired First Boston Corp. to help seek bidders. ``Our recent share price does not fairly represent the inherent value of our company,'' said President Marshall Manley. ``We have very fine subsidiaries which are operating profitably.'' AmBase shares have been trading over the past year at between $7.37{ to $16.37{. By midday Tuesday, AmBase was up 62{ cents to $9 share on the New York Stock Exchange. AmBase said proceeds from the sales would be used to repay outstanding debt. AmBase, which also has interests in banking and investment services, had net income of $96 million, or $2.86 per share, in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic coal production totaled 20.8 million tons during the week ended Feb. 10, up 2.4 percent from the 20.3 million tons produced in the previous week, the U.S. Department of Energy reported Tuesday. The U.S. coal industry produced 18 million tons in the same week last year, according to the department's Energy Information Administration. Wyoming ranked first among the 27 coal-producing states with 3.53 million tons produced. Kentucky was second at 3.47 million tons and West Virginia was third at 3.1 million tons, the agency said. Domestic coal production so far this year is 119.8 million tons, 8.1 percent ahead of last year's production at this time. The week's production accounts for bituminous and lignite coal.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Close Sharply Lower
DOC.TEXT: Prices sharply lower on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday, pushed downward by weakness in the world's bond markets and a big decline on Wall Street. Some bargain buying at early afternoon lifted prices to their best levels of the day. However, the rally could not be sustained, dealers said, especially after the sharp drop in the initial hours of Wall Street trading. By the close of the European day, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 44.14 points at 2,591.44. Market watchers said volume remained light, which indicated a lack of outright selling and more of a drift lower. ``The market's decline is due to more selling than buying, but there hasn't been much of either,'' one dealer said. At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was down 20.1 points, or 0.9 percent, at 2,277.0, just slightly above its lowest point for the day of 2,276.4, and off from a midafternoon peak of 2,290.8. Volume amounted to a light 374.7 million shares, compared with 314.3 million shares Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Quaker Execs Hint They May Sell Fisher-Price
DOC.TEXT: The Quaker Oats Co. has no immediate plans to sell its Fisher-Price toy company, but has not ruled out a sale in the future, the Quaker chairman said. William Smithburg, speaking at a meeting in Fort Lauderdale, said Quaker is working aggressively to turn around the depressed profits of the toy unit by fiscal 1991. But he told a group of securities industry analysts here Monday the company only will be marginally profitable in the second half of fiscal 1990. Fisher-Price's market share in younger children's toys has dropped in the last year from 10 percent to the high 8 percent range, said Paul Price, Quaker's senior vice president of finance and new president of the division. Some analysts have predicted that the company could bring as much as $700 million to $800 million if the company were turned around. ``We will examine all, and I mean all, options regarding Fisher-Price,'' Smithburg said. That comment was a nod to analysts meeting here, many of whom have said that Quaker should get away from the volatile toy business. ``Quaker used to say `No, Fisher-Price is not for sale.' Now at least they say they are thinking about it,'' said John McMillan, an analyst for Prudential Bache Securities. As previously reported for the six months that ended Dec. 31, Fisher-Price reported operating income of $19 million, down 63 percent from the same time a year before. Quaker blames production delays and a poor mix of toys. But Smithburg said Fisher-Price is still the leader in the pre-school toy business and noted ``we are setting a pattern for a sizable turnaround in 1991 and into 1992.''

DOC.HEAD: Fed Chairman Says Economy May Be Past Danger Point
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf, On Wall, with 2 p.m. Dow figure
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said today the economy has likely passed the danger point for an imminent recession and he predicted continued, although modest, economic growth for the rest of this year. Greenspan said the central bank expects the economy to grow far more sluggishly this year than the Bush administration predicts. That scenario could dash the administration's hopes of making significant progress on reducing the federal budget deficit. Greenspan commented in an annual appearance before Congress to reveal the bank's all-important monetary and economic growth targets for the new year. The testimony bolstered the belief among many private economists that the Federal Reserve Board is not likely to move soon to push interest rates lower. Following Greenspan's testimony, prices tumbled in the stock and bond markets in midday trading that analysts said reflected investor worries about rising interest rates worldwide. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 stocks was down 42.57 points to 2,593.02 at 2 p.m. EST. In the credit markets, the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond was off by about $12.50 per $1,000 in face value, with its yield rising to 8.63 percent from 8.46 percent late Friday. Greenspan emphasized a belief that the economy appears to be rebounding from an extremely sluggish October-December period while at the same time inflationary pressures remain at unacceptable levels. The Fed chairman cited a string of recent economic reports showing a rebound in economic activity in January, ranging from rising auto sales to a big jump in housing construction. ``From these and similar data, one can infer the beginnings of a modest firming in economic activity,'' Greenspan told a House Banking subcommittee. ``While we cannot be certain that we are as yet out of the recessionary woods, such evidence warrants at least guarded optimism,'' he said. ``... Available indicators of near-term economic performance suggest that the weakest point may have passed.'' Greenspan's testimony served to reaffirm statements he made three weeks ago in another congressional appearance. The Fed's economic forecast showed that the central bank is looking for the economy, as measured by the gross national product, to grow at an anemic rate of between 1.75 percent and 2 percent this year. That is far below the administration's projection that the economy will grow by 2.6 percent this year, when measured from the fourth quarter of 1989. The administration is pinning its hopes of cutting the federal budget deficit in half on a belief that economic growth will rebound significantly in 1990 from the depressed level in the fourth quarter, when the GNP rose at an annual rate of just 0.5 percent, its poorest showing in 3{ years. But if as appears likely, the Fed pursues a tighter credit policy to dampen inflationary pressures, then interest rates will be higher than the administration is forecasting and growth will be slower _ two developments that will add billions of dollars to the budget deficit. The Fed's economic forecast for 1990 represented only a modest change from a preliminary estimate the central bank made last June when it forecast growth of 1.5 percent to 2 percent. However, the Fed substantially lowered its inflation estimate to 4 percent to 4.5 percent for consumer prices, down from a June forecast of 4.5 percent to 5 percent, signaling perhaps a renewed emphasis on getting prices lower. Greenspan said that while consumer prices for January, scheduled to be reported Wednesday, would show a sizable jump due to energy and food costs, a reversal of this temporary spurt ``is apparently under way.'' ``The ultimate objective of economic policy is to foster the maximum sustainable rate of economic growth,'' Greenspan said, adding that ``inflation insidiously undermines'' business and consumer confidence in the economy's future course. Greenspan's testimony tracked the expectations of many economists, who believe that the Fed is succeeding in attempts to engineer a ``soft landing'' for the economy in which growth slows enough to dampen inflation but not enough to end the 7-year-long economic recovery. But analysts said Greenspan's testimony sets the stage for a possible clash between the administration's optimistic economic goals and a Fed intent on keeping a damper on growth to make sure that inflation does not get out of hand. ``The public comments from the administration will be coming hot and heavy later on this year as Bush officials try to nudge the Fed into an easier stance,'' predicted David Jones, chief economist of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer. Economists said a spurt in prices at the beginning of the year, caused in large part by unusually cold weather which pushed up food costs, also was working against lower interest rates. ``The Fed does not want to be perceived as easing at a time when inflation is accelerating, even if those inflationary pressures were considered to be temporary,'' Jones said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Stock Investors Flood Frankfurt Market
DOC.TEXT: The symbolic collapse of the Berlin Wall opened a door of opportunity that attracted a big flow of Japanese investment to the West German stock exchange, helping not only to fuel a market boom but also raising speculation of a big slump once the money dries up. According to the Securities Dealers Association of Japan, Japanese investors increased the amount of their holdings of West German stocks to $944 million worth by the end of 1989, about 2{ times the amount of a year earlier. ``The amount of Japanese investments have been growing nowhere else but in West German stocks,'' said Kazumasa Funaoka, an association spokesman. Helping attract the investment is speculation that Eastern bloc liberalization and weakening East-West tensions will mean big moneymaking opportunities for West German companies in coming years. Relatively weak performances in other major stock markets also have made the Frankfurt exchange look attractive. The West German market's main indicator, the 100-issue FAZ index, has soared some 20 percent in the last three months. In contrast, the Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average rose 5 percent, and the New York's 30-issue Dow Jones Industrial Average rose only 1.5 percent. Five West German issues listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange _ Commerzbank AG, Bayer AG, Deutsche Bank AG, Dresdner Bank AG, and Volkswagen _ also have posted strong gains. Kenji Maeshiro, an analyst with Yamaichi Securities, Co., said the Japanese investment boom in West German market is based on expectations of stability in the West German economy and growth of the Frankfurt stock exchange. Japanese investors also are seeking a foothold ahead of the European Community's 1992 integration, as well as access to the newly opening Eastern bloc economies. Daiwa Securities, Co., is sending additional staffers from Tokyo to its Frankfurt subsidiary. Daiwa also has introduced a Europe-oriented fund for individual investors, its second since November, said Daiwa spokesman Yoshihiko Azuma. Giant Nomura Securities also recently introduced its first ``German Fund.'' Similar funds have been traded in the United States and Europe. Stock investors' increasing demand for the West German mark has strengthened the currency, analysts said. The mark, which is trading at around 80 yen or $1.67, has gained 20 percent against those two currencies since November. The investing power comes from Japan's abundant foreign exchange reserves, the rising value of the yen and substantial capital savings. Maeshiro said the Tokyo stock market's recent slowdown helped accelerate the German boom, as investors moved to an arena with greater returns. That in turn has made it more difficult to revive the Tokyo market, ``because market players are buying stocks in the West German market, not here,'' said one Nomura dealer, speaking on condition of anonymity. As stock prices continue rising more on speculation than on economic fundamentals, some analysts have been expressing concern that a massive inflow of Japanese money may overheat the West German market, which is only about one-tenth the size of the Tokyo market. Price increases under such conditions make the market vulnerable, Maeshiro said. ``The market's uptrend can be easily reversed once negative news comes out.'' But Finance Ministry spokesman Yoshikazu Sakai said Japanese investment would not be so influential as to damage the Frankfurt market. The market will correct itself as more investors worry about the speed of price increases and start cashing in their gains, Sakai said. ``We don't see Japanese investment there as a possible cause of economic problems in Japan and West Germany,'' he said. But Sakai said the boom could be temporary. ``Look at Spain funds and Southeast Asian funds, which investors used to be crazy about. These funds no longer attract them,'' he said. ``Who knows if West German funds are going to be like those?''

DOC.HEAD: Reform Leader of Czechoslovakia Visits the White House
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 16 grafs new with Bush, Havel remarks; picks up at pvs 8th graf, After his; subs pvs 13th graf, Havel arrived, to update
DOC.TEXT: President Bush welcomed Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel to the White House today, promising trade rewards for Prague's moves toward democracy and assuring him ``the United States will be part of your nation's rebirth.'' Bush cautioned, however, that troops of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ``will continue to play vital role in assuring stability and security in Europe,'' and that ``America will continue to play its part, including a strong military presence for our security and for Europe's.'' Some Czechoslovak leaders have called for eventual dissolution of NATO, along with the Warsaw Pact, the Soviet-led alliance to which Czechoslovakia belongs. However, a U.S. official who briefed reporters on the presidents' talks said Havel agreed that NATO troops were needed until European nations could provide their own security. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Havel believed that ``until new security structures emerge ... the requirement for NATO and the continued U.S. presence would endure.'' Havel, a former dissident playwright who spent five years in prison, was the first of Eastern Europe's new reform leaders to visit the White House. After their meeting, Bush hailed Havel as ``one of the heroes of the revolution of '89,'' a year that saw the old hardline communist government peacefully replaced by the reformers who put Havel into the presidency. ``Your life is a tribute to the difference one man can make,'' Bush told him in a departure speech. Bush announced his intention to waive the so-called Jackson-Vanik restrictions on trade relations with communist governments as U.S. and Czechoslovak representatives begin negotiations on a new trade agreement with a goal of giving Prague most-favored-nation status as a preferred trading partner. Granting Czechoslovakia such status _ extending to it the same low tariffs available to the nation's best trading partners _ is contingent on the Czechoslovak Parliament passing a law ending the former communist government's restrictive emigration policies. Congress then would would be asked to grant most-favored-nation status. Bush said he would also send Peace Corps volunteers to Czechoslovakia by the end of summer. Havel, in brief remarks, said his talks with Bush had been ``very important negotiations,'' and that he was happy to have ``the opportunity to be here to explain what happened in Czechoslovakia.'' Discussing his visit in a television interview before the White House meeting, Havel said: ``Above all, I want to inform the Americans about what happened in our country, what are the international consequences of it, what is our foreign policy, what it will be. And I want to lay foundations for a real, authentic friendship between our two nations.'' ``We are also interested in trade relations,'' he said on NBC's ``Today'' show. After his television appearance, Havel went to Georgetown University, where he spent nearly an hour answering questions from students through an interpreter. He drew laughter at one point when he said, ``There no longer are any dissidents (in Czechoslovakia). If there are, they are in government or other high positions.'' Havel also said that his government is ``facing a difficult task of changing'' the economy and has removed all controls on freedom of speech. And Havel said he has no fears about German reunification so long as the new country is a democracy. ``I wouldn't be afraid of a democratic country if it had 100 million people, but I would be afraid of a totalitarian country with a million people,'' he said. Havel's visit comes as relations are fast warming between Prague and Washington. ``Our relationship has been sort of frozen with the communist government,'' whose fall led to Havel's Dec. 29 installation as president, said a senior administration official who briefed White House reporters about the visit. ``And we're now able to warm it up, I think, rather naturally and quickly.'' Havel arrived in Washington on Monday evening after stops in Iceland and Canada in the week before his first trip to Moscow. Besides his private visit with Bush in the Oval Office, he met with top Bush advisers and was guest at a White House lunch. Havel is not expected to seek an economic handout from Washington, but rather focus on Czechoslovakia's role in the future of Europe and international financial institutions, said the administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Havel's country is on much firmer economic footing than its neighbors, Poland and Hungary. ``What they want is mainly language help,'' said Shirley Temple Black, the U.S. ambassador to Czechoslovakia, who accompanied Havel on the helicopter trip from Andrews Air Force Base to Washington. ``They want to know about managing ... They didn't come for the money,'' she said. After arriving, Havel spent about 15 minutes in a ``very cordial'' meeting at Blair House with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, said Havel's press secretary, Michael Zantovsky. ``We are not going to the United States to beg for big economic aid or loans or something similar,'' Havel told The New York Times in an interview before he left Prague. ``We are going to learn from a democratic system like the one we enjoyed for only so brief a period, only 20 years and lost. We can learn from American democracy. We can learn from a highly industrialized country, a highly developed education system and universities _ from many spheres that can serve as examples to us.'' On Wednesday, Havel speaks before a joint session of Congress before heading to New York for business, political and cultural meetings. In New York, he also will be feted by a rock concert in his honor before heading home Thursday night. Havel was elected by the Czechoslovak Parliament a few weeks after a peaceful revolution ousted the hardline government of Communist Party chief Milos Jakes. The country's first parliamentary elections in more than four decades are planned for June 8. Havel, 53, who has said he is more interested in being a writer than president, is popular among his countrymen and has not announced whether he will seek election in June. Havel's government has insisted the Soviet Union withdraw its 73,500 troops as quickly as possible and favors eventual dissolution of the Warsaw Pact. Some Czechoslovak officials also have urged that NATO be phased out, something the Bush administration strongly opposes.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures End Mostly Lower In Stock Market Reaction
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting pronounced weakness in the stock and bond markets. Prospects for beneficial precipitation in U.S. and South American crop regions also prompted selling but the main influence was ``this malaise in the financial markets,'' said Victor Lespinasse, a grain futures trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell more than 40 points before noon EST on the New York Stock Exchange amid dimming hopes for lower interest rates after Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan predicted the economy would grow much more slowly this year than the Bush administration has predicted. After the close, the Agriculture Department released weekly grain export inspections totals that were better than expected for wheat and soybeans and about as expected for corn. DOC.HEAD: Perrier Back on Sale in France March 1
DOC.TEXT: Source Perrier SA said Tuesday that new shipments of its Perrier brand sparkling water will arrive on French shelves March 1 bearing a special label showing they were bottled after last week's worldwide recall. In a telex to its domestic distributors, Source Perrier also said its representatives would visit distributors within the next week to collect bottles withdrawn from sale. Perrier representatives at the company's headquarters were unavailable to say when the popular water might return to the United States and other foreign markets. When the worldwide recall was announced Feb. 14, company executives said it may take 2{ months to withdraw 160 million bottles from sale in 120 countries and replace them with water untainted with the cancer-causing chemical benzene. Traces of benzene have been discovered in Perrier samples in several countries, including the United States, where 72 million bottles have been pulled off the shelves. Benzene entered Perrier's bottling line at Vergeze in southern France when workers failed to replace a filter that carries carbon dioxide gas from the underground spring to the plant, executives said. The benzene occurs naturally, they said. The recall operation is expected to cost the company about $200 million.

DOC.HEAD: Appliance Giant Says 1989 Profits Up 16.1 Percent
DOC.TEXT: New European business and better profit margins on North American sales boosted Whirlpool Corp.'s fourth-quarter earnings nearly 21 percent, the appliance manufacturer said Tuesday. Whirlpool said earned $49.4 million, or 71 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with a loss of $12 million, or 17 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988. The year-earlier period included a $45 million loss on the sale of Whirlpool's kitchen cabinet business. The company's 1989 fourth-quarter results include $9.2 million in writedowns connection with Whirlpool's plans to close its Mount Sterling, Ky., plant. Revenue totaled $1.57 billion, up from $1.02 billion in the fourth quarter of 1988, the company said. For the year, Whirlpool said it earned $187.2 million, or $2.70 a share, on revenue of $6.29 billion, up from $94.1 million, or $1.36 a share, on revenue of $4.42 billion, in in 1988. Whirlpool became the world's largest appliance concern with the January 1989 acquisition of a $470 million stake in the appliance division of Dutch electronics giant NV Philips. In line with the agreement, the company said 1989 results included all of the revenue of the joint venture, Whirlpool International BV, and 53 percent of its net earnings. Whirlpool International's performance and strong sales in North America helped boost earnings, the company said. However, these gains were offset by several factors, including higher interest expense and taxes, Whirlpool said. David R. Whitwam, Whirlpool chairman and chief executive officer, predicted flat sales to come and said wage cuts accepted by Whirlpool workers in Evansville, Ind., would help keep costs competitive. Whitwam predicted appliance sales would be down slightly in the first half of 1990, possibly rallying in the second half of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Pittston Miners Ratify Contract, `Rejuvenate' Labor Movement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 14th, ``I think...'' to UPDATE with comment from Pittston news conference.
DOC.TEXT: Appalachian miners ratified a contract with Pittston Coal Group after striking for nearly 11 months and were credited by labor leaders Tuesday with helping to rejuvenate the trade union movement. Striking and laid-off United Mine Workers from Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky voted 1,247 to 734 Monday to accept a contract nearly identical to a national UMW agreement that Pittston broke away from in May 1987. ``This is a victory for all workers,'' UMW Vice President Cecil Roberts told about 50 striking miners in announcing the results Tuesday at a union office here. The settlement ends a strike punctuated by violence, sit-down strikes and other tactics that resulted in millions of dollars in fines against the union. It could be a week to 10 days before the 1,700 active miners return to work, because mines must be re-inspected and workers must go through training courses, officials said. UMW members across the country had viewed Pittston as a maverick company attempting to break the union, a claim the company vigorously denied. The union also felt other companies would copy Pittston's tactics if it won concessions. The miners got job security and health and retirement provisions they sought but gave up the traditional five-day work week contained in the 1988 Bituminous Coal Operators Association contract signed by most other producers. That means Pittston won the right to operate around the clock, with voluntary labor on Sundays, a day the miners traditionally have not worked. ``Pittston set out to try to break our union and they didn't succeed,'' James Hall, a 57-year-old striking miner from St. Paul, said at a rally. ``It's a victory, no doubt about that.'' UMW President Richard Trumka, Treasurer John Banovic, AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland and Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole congratulated the miners in telephone calls from the AFL-CIO convention in Miami. ``You rejuvenated the labor movement throughout the world with this strike,'' Banovic said. Kirkland called the strike a ``gallant struggle that was an inspiration to the entire trade union movement.'' Dole, who intervened in the strike to appoint former labor secretary William Usery to mediate a settlement, called the pact an example of successful collective bargaining. ``It's a joyous day for everybody _ for the miners who are going back to work, for the families who will be getting a steady paycheck and certainly for the company, which will be going back to full production,'' Dole told the strikers. During his news conference, Roberts called Pittston President Michael Odom to tell him the contract was ratified. ``You have been a worthy adversary,'' he told Odom. ``We're hoping to work just as hard together now.'' ``I think the both of us can agree we've got a worthy contract for employees, the union and the company,'' Odom said. Odom said at an afternoon news conference that some miners will be back on their jobs as early as Thursday and most will be back to work next week. UMW members worked 14 months without a contract before the union struck on April 5, 1989. UMW officials persuaded members and leaders of other unions that the labor movement desperately needed a victory in the Pittston dispute, and hundreds of thousands of union members converged on the southwestern Virginia coalfields to show their support. To further show sympathy, nearly 46,000 UMW members from Appalachia and the Midwest went on short wildcat strikes last summer. ``We all learned some lessons from this strike; it's better to talk than to fight,'' Roberts said. ``I hope we can bring peace back to the coalfields of southwest Virginia. We're going to go about the business now of mining coal.'' Arthur Mabry, 60, of Lebanon, said he's glad to be going back to work. ``We're going to try to work the best we can with the company and hopefully overcome the hard feelings,'' he said. The UMW leadership will turn its attention to Circuit Judge Donald McGlothlin, who rejected a request by union and company attorneys to drop $64 million in strike-related fines against the UMW. The judge gave them until Thursday to try to change his mind.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Bill Rates Continue To Climb
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in Tuesday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $7.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.80 percent, up from 7.65 percent last week. Another $7.6 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.77 percent, also up from 7.65 percent last week. The rates were the highest since three-month bills sold for 7.83 percent on Feb. 5, and six-month bills averaged 7.92 percent on Oct. 2, 1989. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.07 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,802.80 and 8.20 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,607.20. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 8.05 percent last week, down from 8.13 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court To Consider Regulation of Self-Funded Health Care Plans
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Tuesday it will decide whether self-funded employee health care plans, which cover some 9.5 million Americans, are subject to state insurance laws and regulations. The justices said they will use the case of a seriously injured Pennsylvania teen-age girl to decide whether federal regulation of such plans pre-empts any state regulation. A decision is expected sometime in 1991. Self-funded plans are those in which all benefits are paid directly by an employer, and not purchased through an independent insurance company. The Illinois-based FMC Corp. has such a plan for its employees and their dependents, and that plan paid for a substantial part of the more than $178,000 in medical expenses incurred by Cynthia Ann Holliday since a January 1987 automobile accident in Indiana County, Pa. Miss Holliday, then 15, suffered permanent injuries when the car in which she was a passenger crashed. Her father, Gerald, is an FMC employee. Holliday sued the car's driver, Robert Lyons, in state court. Under a September 1987 settlement, Miss Holliday's recovery was limited to $49,875.50 plus interest. When FMC sought to recover some of its expenses by claiming the lawsuit settlement funds, Holliday successfully invoked a Pennsylvania law that prohibits such action. FMC then turned to a federal trial judge for help, contending that the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) was meant to be a sole means of regulating self-funded health plans and that it therefore pre-empts the prohibitive Pennsylvania law. The judge, upheld by the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last Sept. 11, ruled that state regulation of self-funded health care plans is not pre-empted by ERISA. FMC's appeal was supported by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the Self-Insurance Institute of America and numerous self-funded health and welfare plans. The case is FMC Corp. vs. Holliday, 89-1048.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mostly lower in moderate trading Tuesday but the British pound took center stage in foreign exchange, reaching a 10-month high against the U.S. currency here and abroad. Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $419.90 a troy ounce, $2.80 higher than Friday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $419.90 an ounce, up $2.65 from Friday. The U.S. financial markets were closed on Monday in observance of Presidents Day. Foreign exchange dealers said concerns about higher interest rates abroad, particularly in Britain, West Germany and Japan, were largely responsible for the dollar's drop. They said comments from Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan before Congress Tuesday, although bullish for the dollar, were shrugged off by traders. Greenspan expressed guarded optimism that the country can avoid a recession this year, thereby decreasing prospects for lower U.S. interest rates. Higher interest rates in Britain _ around 15 percent for bank lending _ helped support sterling. In London, one British pound cost $1.7040 late Tuesday, up from $1.7030. Sterling fetched $1.7115 in New York, up from $1.6972 Friday. The pound is now at its highest level since the end of April 1989 in both the London and the United States, traders said. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.66835 West German marks, down from 1.6758; 1.4785 Swiss francs, down from 1.4910; 5.6670 French francs, down from 5.6950; 1,237.50 Italian lire, down from 1,243.25; and 1.20075 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1998. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Monday: 1.6748 West German marks, down from 1.6765; 1.4865 Swiss francs, down from 1.4885; 5.6875 French francs, down from 5.6955; 1.8845 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8870; 1,243.00 Italian lire, unchanged; and 1.2014 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1993. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar firmed to 144.58 Japanese yen from Monday's 144.52. The dollar traded at 145.40 yen in London, and at 145.155 yen in New York, up from 144.13 Friday. Gold closed at $419.75 an ounce in London, up from $416.50 late Monday, and at $419.75 an ounce in Zurich, up from $416.60. European prices had peaked at $421.25 but fell back on profit-taking. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $419.85 an ounce, up from $417.65. Silver prices gained. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery closed at $5.332 a troy ounce, up from $5.328 Friday. Silver rose in London to $5.35 an ounce from $5.33.

DOC.HEAD: Honda Third-Quarter Earnings Slip 7.8 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Honda Motor Co. Ltd.'s earnings fell 7.8 percent in the third quarter due largely to foreign-exchange losses and higher interest costs, the company said Tuesday. For the three months ended Dec. 31, Honda's net income fell to 22.5 billion yen, or $156 million, from 24.4 billion yen in the year-ago period. Per-share income totaled 23.15 yen, or 16 cents, down from 24.78 yen. Revenue rose 8.5 percent to 942.8 billion yen, or $6.5 billion, from 868.7 billion yen. It was the highest net revenue ever recorded by Honda for a three-month period, the company said. Honda said third quarter earnings recovered from the first two quarters despite a general slowdown in the North American automobile market and capital outlays to expand manufacturing plants in the United States and in Japan. The company attributed the lower results to increased non-operating expenses, including foreign exchange losses and interest expenses. For the first nine months, net income totaled 55.2 billion yen, or 56.57 yen a share, down 24.4 percent from 72.97 billion yen, or 73.84 yen a share. Sales in the first nine months reached 2.8 trillion yen, or $19.1 billion, up 5.8 percent from 2.6 trillion yen in the same period a year ago. Honda said increased auto sales, cost cutting and a weaker yen contributed to increased net sales and operating income in the nine-month period.

DOC.HEAD: Deal Struck Between Eurotunnel, Banks to Free Up Capital
DOC.TEXT: Eurotunnel announced late Tuesday that a deal has been struck with the Anglo-French contracting consortium building the Channel Tunnel, defusing a financial crisis threatening to derail the project. The agreement allows the parent company to draw on new loans granted by creditor banks and comply with a court order to pay Trans-Manche Link (TML) some $114 million, the company said. The press statement announcing the deal said further details of the agreement would be made public Wednesday. Eurotunnel and the contractors began intense talks Monday around TML's refusal to sign a financing aggreement reached January with creditors that would have tided the project over until May. The scheme would have allowed Eurotunnel to draw upon $701 million from the $8.7 billion in new loans granted to the venture. TML was reported to be unhappy with management reshuffling last Thursday making Alastair Morton the project's chief executive, with contractors disliking his management style and criticism of cost overruns. Eurotunnel refused to confirm reports in the British press that the crisis had been resolved Monday with the appointment of John Neerhaut, vice president of the Bechtel group, to control day-to-day operations of the project. The tunnel, being built from both sides, is due to be opened in mid-1993 to rail traffic. About a third of the tunneling on the 34-mile project is complete.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: Reed & Co.

DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 38.74 points to 2,596.85. DOC.HEAD: Dow Drops 38.74 Points as Interest Rate Worries Rattle Market
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market dropped sharply Tuesday as an upward trend in worldwide interest rates troubled traders. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 38.74 points to close at 2,596.85. At one point during trading the widely watched barometer was down nearly 50 points. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 327 up, 1,257 down and 388 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 147.30 million shares, down from 166.84 million in Friday's session. The market was closed Monday for Presidents Day. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 174.97 million shares. Analysts said the tone for the session was set by rising interest rates in Japan and West Germany as U.S. traders returned after the three-day weekend. U.S. interest rates followed the trend, rising sharply. Prices of long-term government bonds plunged as much at $16 for each $1,000 in face value, increasing their yields to the 8.66 percent-8.70 percent range. Besides higher overseas rates, traders said the bond market was depressed by news that the Treasury raised its first-quarter borrowing needs by $6 billion. Upward pressure on worldwide interest rates has been widely cited as a primary force behind the stock market's poor performance so far this year. Higher rates make interest-bearing investments more attractive than stocks and deter the Federal Reserve from stimulating the domestic economy. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan told Congress Tuesday that recent U.S. economic indicators are ``more encouraging than otherwise.'' Analysts interpreted his remarks to mean the Fed would not push rates lower any time soon. One stock trader said the market was more concerned about interest rates abroad than Greenspan's comments. ``The worry on Japan rates is really what is hurting us,'' said Daniel Williams at Dillon, Read & Co. In addition, Williams said, computerized selling programs at some Wall Street firms further depressed prices. Phil Rettew, a senior market specialist with Merrill Lynch & Co., said the market has been poised for a selloff. ``I think that the worldwide decline in bond prices was just a little banana peel on the edge of the cliff,'' he said. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris dropped { to 37}, General Electric lost 1[ to 60~, American Telephone & Telegraph dropped } to 39, IBM lost | to 102~, and America Express lost } to 28\. Great Northern Nekoosa was the most active NYSE issue, jumping 1{ to 65] on news the company agreed to a buyout offer from Georgia-Pacific at $65.75 a share, up from Georgia-Pacific's original $63-a-share bid. Nordstrom, among the most active stocks in the over-the-counter market, was down 1} at 27}, compounding a 3\-point slide Friday. The department store operator said earnings for the fiscal year ended last month were likely to show a decline. In addition, a Washington state agency ordered Nordstrom to pay unspecified amounts in back wages. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market totaled $3,174.667 billion Tuesday, off $41.011 billion or 1.28 percent from Friday. The NYSE's composite index of all listed common stocks lost 2.38 to 181.37. Standard & Poor's industrial index lost 5.15 to close at 378.66, and S&P's 500-stock composite index lost 4.73 to close at 327.99. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market lost 5.18 to close at 423.83. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 3.89 to 354.88.

DOC.HEAD: Platinum Futures Surge Amid Physical Buying
DOC.TEXT: Platinum futures prices surged to new 2{-month highs Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting strong demand for the metal amid uncertainty about inflation, stock prices and South Africa. On other major commodity markets, copper futures rose; energy futures were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mostly lower. Platinum futures settled $8.40 to $9 higher with the contract for delivery in April up $9 at $534.40 a troy ounce, its highest daily finish since Nov. 27. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures finished $2.80 to $3.70 higher with February at $419.90 a troy ounce; silver ended 0.3 cent to 1.4 cents higher with March at $5.343 a troy ounce. Analysts linked the platinum rally to a spurt in purchases of physical platinum in the Far East and to renewed investment demand for the metal as a result of the stock market's steep drop on Tuesday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell nearly 39 points in reaction to rising interest rates in Japan and West Germany and to Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's prediction that the U.S. economy will grow much more slowly this year than the Bush administration had predicted. In testimony before a House Banking subcommittee, Greenspan also said inflation was in danger of accelerating. In the background are continuing fears of supply disruptions in South Africa, the world's leading platinum producer, stemming from the threat of anti-apartheid violence by followers of Nelson Mandela and the African National Congress. Platinum for April delivery has risen more than $20 an ounce since Mandela's release on Feb. 11. ``There are people in the world who, for one reason or another, fear supply disruptions in the future and keep buying platinum,'' said John Sak, first vice president in charge of precious metals futures with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Copper futures advanced for the fifth straight session on the Commodity Exchange amid continuing signs of dwindling supplies. The London Metal Exchange on Monday reported a 5,425-ton decline last week in its warehouse stocks of copper to 88,300 tons. On Tuesday, the Commodity Exchange said the level of copper stocks registered with that exchange fell 609 tons on Friday to 3,020 tons. Concerns about tightening supplies have helped boost the price for March delivery of copper by nearly 13 cents a pound in the past week. Copper futures finished 0.2 cents to 1.7 cents higher with March at $1.13 a pound. Most petroleum futures retreated on the New York Merc, partly in reaction to analysts' projections for increased crude-oil production by OPEC in the first half of 1990. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 11 cents to 23 cents lower with March at $22.19 a barrel; heating oil futures ended .10 cent to .25 cent lower with March at 57.38 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .18 cent lower to .21 cent higher with March at 60.20 cents a gallon. Near-month cattle futures fell steeply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in reaction to Friday's monthly USDA cattle-on-feed report, which showed a larger-than-expected number of cattle being fed for slaughter in the seven largest cattle-producing states. Pork futures rose, with pork bellies up sharply, on news that the Bush administration had granted most-favored-nation trade status to Czechoslovakia, which is likely to lead to new Czech purchases of U.S. pork. Live cattle futures settled .98 cent lower to .10 cent higher with February at 78.85 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent to .70 cent lower with March at 81.47 cents a pound; live hogs were .17 cent to .63 cent higher with February at 49.72 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .60 cent to 1.58 cent higher with February at 51.30 cents a pound. Wheat and soybean futures fell while corn futures rose fractionally on the Chicago Board of Trade, largely reflecting weakness in the stock and bond markets. Wheat futures settled 1} cents to 2\ cents lower with March at $3.82\ a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to } cent higher with March at $2.41{ a bushel; oats were 2{ cents to 4 cents lower with March at $1.34} a bushel; soybeans were 3{ cents to 6 cents lower with May at $5.78 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Looking Into Allegations By Former Sprint Employee
DOC.TEXT: US Sprint said Tuesday the FBI is investigating a former employee's allegations that the long-distance company obtained confidential information about competitors when it bid successfully for part of a $25 billion government contract. Sprint officials said the allegations first arose in August during an exit interview for a Sprint salesman in the Washington area, whose job was eliminated during a restructuring. Spokesman Syd Courson in Kansas City, where Sprint is based, said the company investigated the allegations and found no evidence of wrongdoing. Courson said the former employee made broad allegations that Sprint employees had obtained and used other long-distance companies' confidential information when preparing Sprint's bid for the FTS 2000 communications contract. Sprint, the nation's third-largest supplier of long-distance service, won 40 percent of the giant contract. Industry leader AT&T won the majority. ``We chalked it up to a disgruntled employee, a former employee,'' Courson said. Sprint's internal investigation was completed in October but resumed later in the year after allegations, assumed to be by the same person, that Sprint had tapped into the General Services Administration computer, Courson said. In October, a Sprint employee in the Washington area was contacted by the FBI, Courson said. Three other employees and an outside consultant who had worked for Sprint were contacted in late January about the allegations. ``We then contacted the FBI and told them of our findings, and offered them various documents,'' Courson said. ``We want to cooperate fully on this and get it behind us. That's essentially where it stands.'' Courson said the former employee who made the allegations had not worked directly on Sprint's bid for the FTS 2000 contract, described as the biggest non-military award ever handled by the federal government.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures End Mostly Lower
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices ended mostly lower in lackluster trading Tuesday, pressured by supply and demand concerns. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 23 cents to $22.19 a 42-gallon barrel. The contract, which expired at the close of trading, lost 42 cents in the previous session. The April contract ended 11 cents lower at $22.14 a barrel and May finished at $21.93, also down 11 cents. Analysts said the five-cent spread between the March and April closing prices did not bode well for future price expectations. ``It's not a bullish signal for the spread to be as weak as it is,'' said Tom Bentz, director of futures trading for United Energy Inc. Bentz said the small difference suggested weakness in demand. ``If demand were up March would have been a strong premium over April,'' he said. Among refined products, wholesale unleaded gasoline for March delivery rose 0.21 cent to 60.20 cents a gallon after losing 0.65 cent in the prior session. All other contracts finished lower. No. 2 heating oil for delivery in March slipped 0.10 cent to 57.38 cents a gallon, April declined 0.11 cent to 56.70 cents and May dropped 0.25 cent to 55.62 cents a gallon. Energy analysts said activity in the energy pits was relatively light with many traders in London for the International Petroleum Exchange convention. Cool weather in the Northeast gave heating oil futures a psychological boost midway through the session, but buying dried up amid expectations that demand has weakened while inventories have climbed. Analysts said March gasoline got a lift from a report about an explosion at an Amoco Oil Co. terminal in Whiting, Ind. A truck loading liquefied petroleum gas into a storage tank caught fire and exploded, killing two people and injuring three others, authorities said. The explosion was not expected to disrupt product shipments, traders said.

DOC.HEAD: Honeywell's 1989 Profit Totals $604 Million, Compared With 1988 Loss
DOC.TEXT: Honeywell Inc., which last year underwent a restructuring that included cutting jobs and retreating from its weapons business, on Tuesday reported 1989 earnings of $604 million, compared with a $435 million loss in 1988. Fourth-quarter earnings totaled $392 million, or $9.26 a share, compared with a loss of $483 million, or $11.35 a share, for the same 1988 period. Earnings per share for 1989 were $14.18, compared with a loss of $10.22 a share in 1988. The 1989 figures include an after-tax gain from the sale of assets _ primarily its sale of Yamatake-Honeywell shares _ of $313 million. Net income excluding asset sales totaled $291 million, the company said. Honeywell previously announced plans to divest its Defense and Marine Systems business. Income from this discontinued operation totaled $54 million in 1989, or $1.26 per share, the company said Tuesday. Income in 1989 from continuing operations totaled $550 million, or $12.92 a share. Sales from continuing operations in 1989 were $6.059 billion, up from $5.857 billion in 1988. Fourth-quarter sales from continuing operations were $1.610 billion, compared with $1.587 billion for the same 1988 period. Excluding sales from units divested in 1988 and 1989, sales grew nearly 7 percent in the quarter. ``In 1989, Honeywell delivered on the commitments we made to our shareholders,'' James J. Renier, chairman and chief executive officer, said Tuesday. ``We completed a year of markedly improved financial results and we took concrete actions to improve shareholder value. A new level of performance was established from which we intend to show continued improvement.'' The company last summer announced a restructuring that included cutting 4,000 jobs and selling a ``substantial portion'' of its 50 percent stake in Yamatake-Honeywell, a Japanese controls maker. Renier said then that Honeywell would focus on its main business of controls, which range from the familiar round home thermostats to automation equipment for paper mills and chemical plants.
