DOC.HEAD: Freeport-McMoran Gold Sold To Minorco
DOC.TEXT: Freeport-McMoran Gold Co., which operates two gold mining operations in Nevada, has agreed to be bought by Minorco SA for about $705 million, officials said Tuesday. Minorco, a European-based natural resources group with principal interests in mining and processing metals, will commence a tender offer of $17 per share for Freeport-McMoran Gold, which is 61 percent owned by Freeport-McMoran, Inc. of New Orleans. The deal was approved by the Freeport-McMoran Gold board, the companies said. Minorco failed last year in a $6.2 billion bid to take over Consolidated Gold Fields PLC. Gold Fields was later bought by Hanson PLC in a friendly $5.7 billion deal. ``The purchase of Freeport-McMoran Gold is a major step in Minorco's strategy of becoming an operator rather than a passive investor,'' said Hank Slack, an executive of Minorco. Investors greeted the deal enthusiastically. Freeport-Moran Gold stock rose $2.62{ to $16.62{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday. Freeport-McMoran Inc. said it agreed to tender its 61 percent interest into the offer or to sell those shares to Minorco separately if the tender offer is not completed. Freeport-McMoran Gold has joint venture interest in two Nevada gold mining operations. The company owns 70 percent of the Jerritt Canyon operation and 60 percent of the Big Springs operation, and operates both mines. Attributable gold production at the two sites in 1989 was 244,100 ounces of gold at a cash cost of $207 per ounce. For the year ending Dec. 31, 1989, Freeport-McMoran Gold revenue was $87.9 million and the company had total assets of $179.2 million. Freeport-McMoran Inc. said it would use the proceeds of the sale to help finance development of a sulfur discovery in the Gulf of Mexico and a copper-gold discovery in Indonesia, said company spokesman Craig E. Saporito. ``We announced our intention of selling some assets and reducing our debts by $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion and using the money to develop those discoveries. This made sense. It was not part of our core assets and not part of our long-range plans,'' Saporito said. As of Dec. 31, 1989, Freeport-McMoran Gold had proven and probable reserves of 2.22 million recoverable ounces of gold at its two mining operations, the majority of it at Jerritt Canyon.

DOC.HEAD: Cellular Telephone Giant Settles Lawsuit Against Radio Paging Firm
DOC.TEXT: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. and Graphic Scanning Corp. said Tuesday that they had agreed to form a joint venture to market cellular telephone services in the Milwaukee area and transfer other cellular properties, ending a legal dispute. Under the agreement, McCaw will manage the Milwaukee joint venture and own a 92 percent stake in it with Graphic owning 8 percent. McCaw also agreed to transfer to Graphic its rights to cellular telephone interests around Indianapolis, Ind. The settlement is subject to federal and state regulatory approval. McCaw, based in Kirkland, Wash., is the nation's largest cellular telephone company, with customers in 127 markets in 26 states. Graphic, based in Englewood, operates one of the country's largest radio paging businesses, is a major provider of cellular radio telephone services and serves telecommunications customers in the United States and the United Kingdom. McCaw had sued Graphic claiming the New Jersey company breached an oral agreement made several years ago in which it pledged to sell its share of the Milwaukee market for $40 per potential customer, or about $30 million, far below today's estimated market value of $175 million. Graphic denied agreeing to sell at that price. Under a settlement reached last week in U.S. District Court in Washington state, McCaw and Graphic agreed to create a regional joint venture by combining Graphic's interest in Milwaukee with McCaw's cellular interests in Wisconsin and Rockford, Ill. The new business would have a potential market of more than 1 million customers. ``Graphic took a haircut on the Milwaukee property but they lost less than they would have if they had gone to court,'' said Sal Muoio, an analyst with Gabelli & Co., a New York City brokerage firm that invests in Graphic. Late last year, McCaw agreed to buy a controlling interest in LIN Broadcasting Corp., a New York-based cellular telelphone and television station operator, for $3.38 billion. The deal is expected to close in late February.

DOC.HEAD: Limited Reports Increased Profits
DOC.TEXT: Limited Inc. said Tuesday its fourth-quarter profits increased by 27 percent from the same period a year ago while earnings for the year rose by 42 percent. Fourth-quarter profits totaled $153.1 million, or 85 cents per share, up from $120.1 million, or 67 cents per share, in the same period in 1988. The fourth quarter of 1989 was 14 weeks, one week longer than the same quarter last year. Sales were $1.58 billion, a 17 percent increase from $1.35 billion recorded for the year-ago period. For all of 1989, earnings totaled $346.9 million, or $1.92 per share, compared with $245.1 million, or $1.36 a share, in 1988. Sales totaled 4.64 billion, a 14 percent increase from $4.07 billion the previous year. The company cited no specific reason for the 1989 earnings, but Chairman Leslie H. Wexner attributed fourth-quarter results in part to growth among its Express, Victoria's Secret Stores and Victoria's Secret Catalogue divisions. He also cited the restructuring of the Brylane catalog division into three catalog businesses: Lane Bryant, Roaman's and Lerner. He also said the company's contract manufacturer expanded its operations to meet late-season demands. Limited Inc. operates 3,168 specialty apparel stores nationwide through the Limited, Express, Victoria's Secret, Henri Bendel, Lerner, Lane Bryant and Abercrombie & Fitch. It distributes apparel nationally through the catalogs.

DOC.HEAD: Maine Government May Pursue Suit Against Georgia-Pacific
With AM-Great Northern Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Maine's attorney general said he was prepared to pursue an antitrust suit if necessary against Georgia-Pacific Corp., although Gov. John R. McKernan and some mill workers were more optimistic about Tuesday's announcement that the company was buying Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. Attorney General James E. Tierney said the state should use the lawsuit to protect woodcutters and landowners who could be hurt financially by the $5 billion buyout. ``We have wood owners and woodcutters who for years have been able to sell to two companies and now they only have one,'' said Tierney, who hoped to negotiate with Georgia-Pacific for assurances. Environmentalists also had concerns that the deal would place more than 2.6 million acres _ about 12 percent of the land in Maine _ in the hands of a single, out-of-state corporation. Groups such as the Maine Audubon Society said they wanted to be sure Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific uses its new holdings for timber harvesting instead of development. Michael Kellett, Northeast regional director of the Wilderness Society, said the trend toward consolidation stifled diversity and created ``a more oligopolistic situation.'' ``But in this case, Great Northern already owned so much that I'm not sure it's going to make a huge situation,'' Kellett said. ``I do not feel any horrible sense of dread or crisis.'' Kellett said that in terms of land stewardship, there is no huge difference among the paper companies. Jerry Bley, resource specialist with the Natural Resources Council of Maine, said it remained to be seen whether Georgia-Pacific would abide by its assurances that it will maintain its mill operations use its land for timber operations, rather than sell parcels to developers to help pay debt incurred in the buyout. Great Northern is headquartered in Norwalk, Conn., but is incorporated in Maine. McKernan said he would reserve judgment on pursuing the antitrust suit. But he was optimistic about Georgia-Pacific's willingness to continue talks on woodland preservation and job security for Maine workers. ``We have been able to work with Georgia-Pacific, they made it clear they wanted to be good corporate citizens, they wanted to have the company flourish here in Maine,'' he said. Georgia-Pacific operates three mills in Woodland in eastern Maine and owns about 470,000 acres of forest land, according to the attorney general's office. Great Northern owns 2.1 million acres and three mills. Great Northern mill workers said they were relieved but apprehensive about Tuesday's announcement, which followed a bitter, four-month takeover battle. ``I'm kind of relieved to get it over with,'' said Fredericka Boynton, whose family has worked in the Millinocket mill for generations. ``I think it's going to be all right. You make the best of it.'' ``There's probably going to be a mixture of relief and apprehension,'' said Town Manager William Ayoob, ``relief that the corporate war is over, but apprehension that a new company is taking over.''

DOC.HEAD: Zenith in Dispute Over Computer Unit's Price; Earnings From TVs Slide
DOC.TEXT: Zenith Electronics Corp. on Tuesday revealed a disagreement with Groupe Bull over the final sale price of Zenith's computer business to the French concern. Both parties agreed the issue does not threaten to derail Bull's acquisition of Zenith Data Systems, which was effectively completed in December. But because the eventual outcome will affect Zenith's financial condition, the company reported fourth-quarter and annual results only for its consumer electronics business, which consists mainly of televisions and TV components. The results included a 47 percent drop in fourth-quarter profit and a $17 million loss for all of 1989, which the company said reflected higher material and labor costs despite higher sales volume and efficiency improvements. Zenith is disputing Bull's request for a $49 million refund on its Dec. 28 payment of $496.4 million for Zenith Data Systems, said Zenith spokesman John I. Taylor. Zenith had previously indicated that it expected a further payment, not a refund request, from Bull as the final adjustment to the purchase price ``Clearly, we have a difference of opinion of significant magnitude,'' Zenith Chairman Jerry K. Pearlman said in a statement. Zenith characterized the disagreement as a major dispute and said Bull may have violated the terms of their contract. A Bull spokesman denied the charge and downplayed the issue, pointing out that Zenith has 30 days to review the request and another 30 days in which to negotiate a resolution before an arbitrator steps in. ``We don't see it as major dispute at all,'' said spokesman Patrick Marx in a telephone interview from Bull's Paris headquarters. Zenith announced Oct. 2 an agreement to sell the computer unit to Bull for $91.9 million plus the adjusted net book value of the assets sold, for a total that Zenith initially estimated at $635 million and later lowered to an estimated $610 million. On Dec. 28, Bull paid Zenith $496.4 million in cash, an agreed-upon amount that Taylor said reflected 90 percent of the sum of the $91.9 million premium and the adjusted net book value of the computer unit's assets through Nov. 30. The payment effectively closed the sale of Zenith Data Systems, leaving only a final adjustment that would include the unit's asset value at the end of December. The sale agreement provided for Bull to submit the final adjustment, based on an audit of Zenith Data Systems commissioned by Bull. Electronics analysts said the dispute was a surprise and that a $49 million refund would hurt Zenith. ``If it works against them, it will affect their ability to bring down debt levels,'' said Laura Lederman, an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. Zenith had previously estimated a $22 million fourth-quarter operating profit from the computer unit but said Tuesday that because of substantial deterioration in the business during December, it expects the division to report a net loss. For its consumer electronics business, Zenith reported net income of $4 million, or 15 cents per common share, for the three months ending Dec. 31 compared with $7.5 million, or 29 cents per share, for the same period a year ago. Fourth-quarter revenue from consumer electronics rose slightly, to $443 million from $440 million in 1988. For the full year, Zenith reported a net loss from consumer electronics of of $17 million, or 64 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $11 million, or 42 cents a share, in 1988. Annual revenue from consumer electronics rose 11 percent to $1.5 billion from $1.4 billion in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Chief: CBS Merger Rumors `Ridiculous'
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney Co. Chairman Michael Eisner on Tuesday labeled reports of a possible merger with broadcasting giant CBS Inc. as rumors. But asked about the possibility of a merger by one of 9,000 Disney shareholders at Disney's annual meeting, Eisner added: ``That is not to say we wouldn't talk to them, haven't talked to them.'' The shareholder cited repeated reports in business and entertainment trade publications of a possible takeover of CBS by cash-rich Disney, which is rapidly expanding its entertainment, theme parks resorts and consumer products businesses. Disney earned $703 million in fiscal 1989, 35 percent more than in 1988. ``We don't comment on any rumors,'' Eisner said at the meeting, held at a convention center near Disneyland. Acknowledging the persistence of the reports, he added: ``If we did comment, we would have to comment every day on ridiculous rumors.'' Eisner and Disney President Frank Wells were brought in to run Disney at the end of 1984, and since then the company has boomed, with sharply higher revenues, expansions of moviemaking and theme parks and the decision last year to start a record label. The executives reviewed Disney's overlapping plans to exploit its trademark characters in theme parks, resorts, television, movies, recordings and magazines. They showed off Italian-language Disney comics and planned software to allow computer users to create their own Disney animation; displayed a prototype of a planned Mickey Mouse magazine in Russian and said Polish and Hungarian versions were being developed; and described the promotional blitz of products that will accompany Disney's ``Dick Tracy'' movie this summer. They also said Disney hopes to expand its stores from 41 now to perhaps 200, with outlets in Tokyo and Paris; reviewed previously announced plans to add new attractions to its theme parks and open all-new parks in California, Japan and Florida; and said they would court convention business with new hotels to help during slow periods. Epitomizing how Disney is expanding and blending its franchises was a tape of Miss Piggy _ Disney acquired rights to the Muppets last year _ singing ``Some Day My Prince Will Come'' from ``Cinderella'' in French for a Christmas special on European television. ``A great percentage of our growth potential lies outside our borders,'' Wells said. The wholesome image nurtured by founder Walt Disney was foremost in the minds of many shareholders, who peppered Eisner with questions about concerns over movies for mature audiences put out by Disney's Touchstone studio, soon to be joined by Hollywood Pictures, a third Disney studio. Asked about the use of four-letter words in those pictures, Eisner said, ``I'm no more pleased to see Bette Midler use an expletive than to see my 16-year-old use an expletive.'' But he said, ``Our movies tend to reflect society,'' adding that Disney can never hope to attract top filmmakers if ``we become censors.'' Another shareholder asked whether Disney was worried about losing the public's confidence by releasing ``crime terror and violence such as `Dick Tracy' and `Cocktail,''' which starred Tom Cruise. ``I believe there is a place for all kinds of movies if they are correctly labeled,'' Eisner said. He said he thought viewers would find ``Dick Tracy'' to be ``clearly a Disney film'' and less violent than it appeared in the trailer. Separately, Disney said Tuesday it was increasing the company's quarterly cash dividend from 12 cents per share to 14{ cents per share. The dividend is payable May 15 to shareholders of record on April 13.

DOC.HEAD: Guinness Case Link with Boesky, Witness claims
DOC.TEXT: Guinness PLC invested $100 million in convicted arbitrager Ivan Boesky's investment fund one month after he supported the brewing company's shares during its bid to take over a distillery, a witness said. Olivier Roux, Guinness' former finance director, testified Tuesday at the trial of former Guinness chairman Ernest Saunders and three other men accused of conspiring to boost the price of Guinness' stock to make its offer for Distillers Co. more attractive. The four face a total of 35 charges involving theft, false accounting and conspiracy in the course of Guinness' $4.3 billion acquisition of Distillers, a Scottish whisky and gin manufacturer. U.S. attorney Thomas Ward, a Guinness director, enlisted Boesky and millionaire investor Meshulam Riklis, husband of actress Pia Zadora, to support the bid in 1986, Roux said at Southwark Crown Court in London. Roux is a key witness who has been granted immunity in return for his testimony. He was asked by prosecutor John Chadwick: ``Were you aware Guinness made an investment of $100 million in the Boesky partnership?'' ``Yes,'' Roux replied. ``I was aware of the concept which came from Mr. Ward. I think he raised that at a meeting we had with Mr. Saunders in New York in mid-May 1986.'' Roux said the investment was approved by a Guinness board committee and later the whole board was told of the deal. Boesky was sentenced in December 1987 to three years in prison for filing false information with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the proposed acquisition of Fischbach Corp. Boesky, who was released to a halfway house last November to finish his term, earlier paid a civil penalty of $100 million to the SEC for trading on inside information. Ward, who has denied any wrongdoing and is fighting extradition proceedings in the United States, is named in two of the charges facing Saunders, 54; Heron Group chairman Gerald Ronson, 50; stockbroker Anthony Parnes, 44, and millionaire financier Sir Jack Lyons, 74. They have pleaded innocent. The prosecution alleges an illegal operation to spend the equivalent of $42.5 million boosting the price of Guinness stock to make its cash and share bid for Distilers more attractive in the face of a rival bid from supermarket operator Argyll Group PLC. The prosecution alleges Ward illegally received the equivalent of $8.8 million following the takeover and authorized an illicit payment of the equivalent of $510,000 to Lyons. Roux, the first witness at the trial, said Ward was ``intimately involved'' in the takeover battle against Argyll and kept the campaign going. He said Ward claimed the $8.8 million payment was to pay bills incurred in the United States, but he gave ``only vague'' descriptions of the work done, Roux said. Roux said Ward wanted the money put into an offshore bank account of a company named Marketing and Acquisitions Consultants to ``maintain confidentiality.'' The prosecution alleged Ward used the account to receive personal payments. Roux said he was concerned because all payments to directors had to be disclosed to the full board. But Saunders confirmed the payment and reassured him the money was not going to Ward personally. When the prosecutor concluded his opening statement on Monday, he claimed that Saunders received $5.1 million from the payment made to Ward and kept it in a secret Swiss bank account.

DOC.HEAD: Chevron Revamps Its U.S. Exploration and Production Operations
DOC.TEXT: Chevron Corp. said Tuesday it was cutting its U.S. oil exploration and production business because of diminishing oil reserves in the continental United States and public opposition to offshore drilling. Chevron U.S.A., the domestic oil and gas subsidiary of the nation's third-largest oil company, said it expects to eliminate 800 to 1,000 positions, or 10 to 12 percent of the organization, including middle and senior managers. Chevron, which will expand its international exploration and production, plans to accelerate sales of U.S. assets by unloading about 1,000 of its 1,700 domestic oil fields for some $700 million over the next two years. The company said it will sell the fields, which account for only 11 percent of current production, to small or regional operators for whom the fields might make a better fit, or negotiate trades with large companies. The changes are expected to result in a charge against 1990 first-quarter earnings of between $25 million and $30 million, the company said. Chevron, with $34.5 billion in assets, took a $1.2 billion charge against fourth-quarter 1989 earnings primarily because of an inactive oil field and environmental cleanup costs. The charge led to an $883 million loss for the quarter and depressed 1989 profits to $251 million from $1.77 billion in 1988. Chevron's problems left its stock undervalued, according to analysts, and vulnerable to a takeover or restructuring. That in turn spurred heavy trading in recent months while Chevron engaged in a legal battle to force Pennzoil Co. to sell its 8.8 percent share of Chevron stock. Chevron said it is worried that Pennzoil would try to use its position to force a restructuring detrimental to Chevron stockholders. Wall Street reacted with mild enthusiasm to Tuesday's announcement as Chevron's stock, down $1.12{ before the release hit the wire late in the trading day, rebounded slightly to close down 67{ cents at $69.25. ``I'm very encouraged,'' said Frederick Leuffer, an analyst with C.J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc. in New York. ``I think it represents a turn for the company. All the details are not out. This is only a relatively modest step in the right direction. We should find out more tomorrow.'' Chevron executives scheduled a meeting with analysts Wednesday in New York. The company said its restructuring is aimed mostly at cutting layers of management and lowering operating costs to make it more competitive and enhance profitability and shareholders' investments. Leuffer said Chevron, the nation's third largest oil company after Exxon Corp. and Mobil Oil Corp., is vastly undervalued. He placed its value at ``at least $116 a share,'' and said the stock could reach $90 a share. In 1988 and 1989, Chevron sold about $210 million worth of domestic assets. The company said it hoped that many staff cuts could be achieved voluntarily. The organizational changes include: _ Chevron U.S.A.'s three current exploration, land and production regions, based in San Ramon, Calif., Houston, and New Orleans, will be eliminated, including their management organization structure and positions. _ In place of the regional organization, the exploration and production functions will be divided into seven distinct business units, each directly responsible for its own financial performance, plus a centralized land department. All will report to a Chevron U.S.A. senior vice president in San Francisco. In production, five business units will be set up, headquartered in Bakersfield, Calif., Denver, Midland and Houston, Texas, and New Orleans. Current production activities now managed from Ventura, Calif., will be consolidated and report to the Bakersfield office.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Meets With Creditors on Reorganization Plan
DOC.NOTE: EDS: NEW grafs 3-4 to UPDATE with plans to continue talks Wednesday, Eastern unlikely to seek extension; SUBS 5th graf pvs to clarify that deadline is for filing plan on exclusive basis; picks up 6th graf pvs bg'ng, Lifland extended ...
DOC.TEXT: Officials of Eastern Airlines met Tuesday with major creditors in an effort to reach agreement on a new plan for its bankruptcy reorganization. Eastern's exclusive right to file such a plan was due to expire at midnight unless the federal bankruptcy court granted the airline another extension. Representatives of the airline and its creditors continued to meet late Tuesday and planned to extend the discussions into Wednesday, said Karen Ceremsak, a spokeswoman for Eastern at its headquarters in Miami. She declined to provide further details. Ms. Ceremsak said it appeared unlikely that Eastern would request an extension of Tuesday's end to its exclusive period, because creditors were negotiating with Eastern and unlikely to file their own reorganization plan. Creditors' attorneys and other representatives couldn't be reached for comment. Last Monday U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland granted Eastern's request for an eight-day extension, to Tuesday, of the deadline for filing its reorganization plan on an exclusive basis. During that time, other parties such as creditors cannot submit competing proposals. Lifland extended the deadline after several parties in the proceeding said progress had been made toward agreement on a plan. Eastern has been restructuring under bankruptcy court supervision since a bitter strike began last March 4. David I. Shapiro, the court-appointed examiner overseeing Eastern's Chapter 11 proceeding, supported Eastern's request last week for an extension and told Lifland that ``substantial progress'' is being made in negotiations between the airline and its creditors. The committee representing unsecured creditors also supported Eastern's petition. Even representatives of preferred shareholders, who recently advocated liquidation or outright sale of Eastern, supported the airline's request for more time. The preferred shareholders had criticized Eastern's latest reorganization proposal, which proposes to pay them no more than 10 cents on the dollar in the form of new stock. Eastern's latest plan also calls for paying unsecured creditors only 10 percent of their debts in cash when the airline emerges from bankruptcy protection, and 70 percent more over the following 10 years, without interest. In return for accepting partial repayment, Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp. would give the unsecured creditors 40 percent of Eastern's equity. Lawyers representing the Air Line Pilots Association and the Machinists union have opposed Eastern's requests for extensions of the deadline. Last week's extension was the fourth granted by Lifland since the bankruptcy proceeding began last March 9. The Eastern pilots and flight attendants abandoned their sympathy strikes just before Thanksgiving, but Eastern had rebuilt as a smaller carrier and hired mostly non-union workers to replace the strikers. The Machinists union remains on strike against the carrier.

DOC.HEAD: Kofler Sentenced in Prudential-Bache Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A man who was accused of embezzling more than $200,000 from house accounts at Prudential-Bache Securities has been sentenced to 24 months probation. Richard Kofler, who pleaded guilty June 29 to one count of felony mail fraud, also was ordered by U.S. District Judge John Keenan in Manhattan to pay $68,401.60 in restitution. Assistant U.S. Attorney Kerry Lawrence said that in addition to the restitution, Kofler had agreed with Prudential-Bache to pay back an additional amount to the firm. Kofler, 38, of Staten Island, admitted during his plea that he used his position as an operations manager to transfer shares from a Prudential-Bache mutual fund account to a fictitious account. Kofler said he wrote letters in the name of the fictitious account holder asking that the shares be redeemed and sent to one or more private post office boxes. Keenan told Kofler he was imposing the lenient sentence primarily at the request of the U.S. attorney's office, but he warned Kofler that any similar future conduct would result in a jail term. Lawrence said he did not know if Kofler still works in the securities industry, and declined to comment on why his office sought leniency.

DOC.HEAD: Cathay Pacific Exercises Option to Buy Four 747-400s
DOC.TEXT: Cathay Pacific Airways has exercised an option to purchase four Boeing 747-400s for about $550 million, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group confirmed. The order brings to 14 the number of long-range 747-400s the Hong Kong-based carrier has committed to buy. The airline also has ordered 15 other 747s of other series _ six 747-300s, eight 747-200 passenger jets and one -200 freighter. Cathay has taken delivery of three 747-400s from Boeing. It uses them to fly passengers nonstop between Hong Kong and European destinations. Turned-up wingtips, a 12-foot longer wingspan and the use of advanced composite materials help make Boeing's new 747-400 jetliner the longest-range passenger jet in the world. It can fly 8,400 statute miles nonstop fully loaded. Tuesday's order brings total Boeing 747-400 orders to 259. So far this year, Boeing has announced orders for 88 aircraft valued at about $7.28 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 1,812,000 net tons during the week ending Feb. 17, 1990, down 0.1 percent from the previous week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The week's production represented 80.9 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said Tuesday. American steelmakers produced 2,005,000 net tons in the same week last year, AISI said. Domestic steel production so far this year is 12,191,000 net tons, 9.6 percent below last year's pace, AISI said. Production by district for last week, (previous week in parentheses). North East Coast 236,000 tons (232,000 tons); Pittsburgh-Youngstown 277,000 tons (249,000 tons); Lake Erie 143,000 tons (139,000 tons); Detroit 150,000 tons (151,000 tons); Indiana-Chicago 454,000 tons (493,000 tons); Southern 252,000 tons (245,000 tons); Western 95,000 tons (93,000 tons).
